paragraph1: Verna's initial thoughts as she prepared for her Arctic getaway were remarkably innocent, centered on finding solitude and mental clarity rather than any malicious intent. The pristine, snow-covered landscape promised exactly what she craved: a complete escape from the chaos of city life and, most importantly, from men. She had grown weary of the familiar dance of flirtation and its accompanying complications, having already secured enough financial stability to feel protected. Her past pursuits had never been about extravagant wealth or excessive luxury; she had simply sought the security that money could provide, a buffer against life's uncertainties and potential threats. The Arctic's vast emptiness beckoned to her like a blank canvas, offering a chance for genuine introspection without the usual social obligations. As she contemplated the journey ahead, she reassured herself that her intentions were pure – she merely wanted peace, isolation, and time to reset her perspective.
paragraph2: At the outset Verna had not intended to kill anyone. What she had in mind was a vacation, pure and simple. Take a breather, do some inner accounting, shed worn skin. The Arctic suits herthere’s something inherently calming in the vast cool sweeps of ice and rock and sea and sky, undisturbed by cities and highways and trees and the other distractions that clutter up the landscape to the south.Among the clutter she includes other people, and by other people she means men. She’s had enough of men for a while. She’s made an inner memo to renounce flirtations and any consequences that might result from them. She doesn’t need the cash, not anymore. She’s not extravagant or greedy, she tells herselfall she ever wanted was to be protected by layer upon layer of kind, soft, insulating money, so that nobody and nothing could get close enough to harm her. Surely she has at last achieved this modest goal.

paragraph1: Afterward, at tea in Shiva’s flat, I talked to my elder sister Kamla. We talked about Shiva as a child; we remembered how, shortly after we had moved to our own house, he had once swallowed a plum and had begun seriously to choke. Fortunately, our house was next door to a doctor’s office, and he was in attendance that afternoon. He swiftly attended to the matter. It was a small crisis, but we could still, my sister and I, after all these years, celebrate the little boy’s escape from death, as though it were something final.I said to Kamla, expecting some solace from her, "And now we have nothing." She said, "And now we have nothing." My sorrow lasted for two years. For two years I mentally dated everything, even the purchase of a book, by its distance from Shiva's death.
paragraph2: Sitting in Shiva's flat with a cup of tea, Kamla and I found ourselves revisiting that terrifying day from his childhood. The image of my little brother choking on a plum remains etched in my memory - his face turning blue, his tiny hands flailing in panic. If it hadn't been for that doctor who lived next door, rushing in and performing the Heimlich maneuver, we might have lost him then. The irony of that memory hits me now, how we saved him that day only to lose him years later. "It's strange being here without him," Kamla whispered, her voice heavy with the same emptiness that's been my constant companion. These past two years since his passing have been measured not in months or seasons, but in the distance from that final day - every moment defined by his absence, every memory tinged with the realization that we can no longer create new ones together.

paragraph1: Consumed by political literature filled with tales of suffering and social inequality, he found himself sinking deeper into a state of despair and alienation. These heavy thoughts remained largely confined to conversations with Shama and his own internal dialogues. Seeking refuge from this overwhelming darkness, he turned to Charles Dickens's works, finding unexpected comfort in their pages. He began reimagining Dickens's vivid characters and Victorian landscapes as mirrors of his own world and its inhabitants. The satirical wit and biting humor characteristic of Dickens's storytelling gradually worked their magic, helping to dissolve his fears and temper his rage. This literary escape provided him with just enough fortitude to tackle even the most basic daily rituals, particularly the seemingly insurmountable task of getting dressed each morning, which had become a daily battle of self-assertion and personal validation.
paragraph2: He read political books. They gave him phrases which he could only speak to himself and use on Shama. They also revealed one region after another of misery and injustice and left him feeling more helpless and more isolated than ever. Then it was that he discovered the solace of Dickens. Without difficulty he transferred characters and settings to people and places he knew. In the grotesques of Dickens everything he feared and suffered from was ridiculed and diminished, so that his own anger, his own contempt became unnecessary, and he was given strength to bear the most difficult part of his daydressing in the morning, that daily affirmation of faith in oneself, which at times for him was almost like an act of sacrifice.

paragraph1: We are split people. For myself, half of me wishes to sit quietly with my legs crossed, letting the things that are beyond my control wash over me. But the other half wants to fight the holy war. Jihad! And certainly we could argue this out in the street, but I think, in the end, your past is not my past and your truth is not my truth and your solution — it is not my solution. So I do not know what it is you would like me to say. Truth and firmness is one suggestion, though there are many other people you can ask if that answer does not satisfy. Personally, my hope lies in the last days. The prophet Muhammad — peace be upon Him! — tells us that on the Day of Resurrection everyone will be struck unconscious. Deaf and dumb. No chit-chat. Tongueless. And what a bloody relief that will be. Now, if you will excuse me.
paragraph2: I find myself caught between two opposing forces within my soul: the tranquil acceptance of life's uncontrollable elements and the burning desire to wage a holy war against injustice. As I navigate through these conflicting emotions, I've come to understand that each person carries their own unique history, their personal version of truth, and their individual approaches to solving life's challenges. Sometimes, I'm unsure what others want to hear from me, whether they seek validation of their own beliefs or challenge my perspective. Perhaps the answer lies in standing firm with our truths, even though this stance might not satisfy everyone's expectations or desires. In moments of doubt, I find solace in the Prophet Muhammad's promise of the Day of Resurrection, when all voices will fall silent, and the weight of these earthly struggles will finally lift from our shoulders. The prospect of this ultimate peace brings me comfort as I grapple with these internal conflicts. If you'll excuse me now, I need some time to reflect on these matters.

paragraph1: Bobbi and I first met Melissa at a poetry night in town, where we were performing together. Melissa took our photograph outside, with Bobbi smoking and me self-consciously holding my left wrist in my right hand, as if I was afraid the wrist was going to get away from me. Melissa used a big professional camera and kept lots of different lenses in a special camera pouch. She chatted and smoked while taking the pictures. She talked about our performance and we talked about her work, which we’d come across on the Internet. Around midnight the bar closed. It was starting to rain then, and Melissa told us we were welcome to come back to her house for a drink. We all got into the back of a taxi together and started fixing up our seat belts. Bobbi sat in the middle, with her head turned to speak to Melissa, so I could see the back of her neck and her little spoon-like ear. Melissa gave the driver an address in Monkstown and I turned to look out the window. A voice came on the radio to say the wordseighties . . . pop . . . classics. Then a jingle played. I felt excited, ready for the challenge of visiting a stranger’s home, already preparing compliments and certain facial expressions to make myself seem charming.
paragraph2: Standing under the dim streetlight after our poetry performance, I watched as Melissa adjusted her camera settings, the professional equipment looking almost ceremonial in her practiced hands. She'd caught Bobbi and me just as we were leaving the venue, cigarette smoke curling around us while we discussed her photography, which we'd admired online before. Her movements were deliberate and artistic, matching the sophisticated demeanor I'd noticed during her earlier interactions inside. The conversation flowed easily between drags of shared cigarettes, and when the bar finally shut its doors at midnight, Melissa's invitation to continue our evening at her place felt both surprising and somehow inevitable. We piled into a taxi bound for Monkstown, the three of us settling into a comfortable silence punctuated by occasional laughter. During the ride, I found myself rehearsing witty remarks in my head, determined to present my most engaging self in this impromptu late-night gathering. There was something thrilling about following a near-stranger home, something that made me feel both reckless and alive. I kept stealing glances at Melissa's profile in the passing streetlights, wondering what her house would reveal about her, while Bobbi chatted animatedly from the backseat, seemingly unfazed by the spontaneity of our adventure.
text_input:
You are given two pararaphs of creative writing for a given writing instruction.
Your task is to determine which paragraph is overall better in terms of writing quality.

Paragraph 1:
Bobbi and I first met Melissa at a poetry night in town, where we were performing together. Melissa took our photograph outside, with Bobbi smoking and me self-consciously holding my left wrist in my right hand, as if I was afraid the wrist was going to get away from me. Melissa used a big professional camera and kept lots of different lenses in a special camera pouch. She chatted and smoked while taking the pictures. She talked about our performance and we talked about her work, which we’d come across on the Internet. Around midnight the bar closed. It was starting to rain then, and Melissa told us we were welcome to come back to her house for a drink. We all got into the back of a taxi together and started fixing up our seat belts. Bobbi sat in the middle, with her head turned to speak to Melissa, so I could see the back of her neck and her little spoon-like ear. Melissa gave the driver an address in Monkstown and I turned to look out the window. A voice came on the radio to say the wordseighties . . . pop . . . classics. Then a jingle played. I felt excited, ready for the challenge of visiting a stranger’s home, already preparing compliments and certain facial expressions to make myself seem charming.

Paragraph 2:
Standing under the dim streetlight after our poetry performance, I watched as Melissa adjusted her camera settings, the professional equipment looking almost ceremonial in her practiced hands. She'd caught Bobbi and me just as we were leaving the venue, cigarette smoke curling around us while we discussed her photography, which we'd admired online before. Her movements were deliberate and artistic, matching the sophisticated demeanor I'd noticed during her earlier interactions inside. The conversation flowed easily between drags of shared cigarettes, and when the bar finally shut its doors at midnight, Melissa's invitation to continue our evening at her place felt both surprising and somehow inevitable. We piled into a taxi bound for Monkstown, the three of us settling into a comfortable silence punctuated by occasional laughter. During the ride, I found myself rehearsing witty remarks in my head, determined to present my most engaging self in this impromptu late-night gathering. There was something thrilling about following a near-stranger home, something that made me feel both reckless and alive. I kept stealing glances at Melissa's profile in the passing streetlights, wondering what her house would reveal about her, while Bobbi chatted animatedly from the backseat, seemingly unfazed by the spontaneity of our adventure.

paragraph1: In 1967, in the papers and on All India Radio, they started hearing about a place called Naxalbari. It was one of a string of villages in the Darjeeling District, a narrow corridor at the northern tip of West Bengal. Tucked into the foothills of the Himalayas, nearly four hundred miles from Calcutta, closer to Tibet than to Tollygunge.Most of the villagers were tribal peasants who worked on tea plantations and large estates. For generations, they’d lived under a feudal system that hadn’t substantially changed. They were manipulated by wealthy landowners. They were pushed off fields they’d cultivated, denied revenue from crops they’d grown.That March, when a sharecropper in Naxalbari tried to plow land from which he’d been illegally evicted, his landlord sent thugs to beat him. The police had refused to intervene. After this, groups of sharecroppers began retaliating. They started burning deeds and records that had cheated them. Forcibly occupying land.It wasn’t the first instance of peasants in the Darjeeling District revolting. But this time their tactics were militant. Armed with primitive weapons, carrying red flags, shouting “Long Live Mao Tse-tung.”
paragraph2: The quiet village of Naxalbari in West Bengal's Darjeeling District became the epicenter of a brewing storm in 1967, as decades of exploitation finally reached a breaking point. The tribal peasants, who formed the backbone of the region's tea plantations and estates, had long endured the oppressive weight of a deeply entrenched feudal system. Working under the thumb of wealthy landowners, these laborers found themselves trapped in a cycle of manipulation and denied their fundamental rights. The spark that ignited the powder keg came when a sharecropper's attempt to reclaim his rightful land was met with brutal violence from thugs dispatched by his landlord. This incident proved to be the final straw, transforming docile workers into determined revolutionaries. The peasants, now emboldened by their collective anger, adopted militant tactics that included the dramatic burning of property deeds and forceful land occupations. Their struggle took on a distinct ideological character as they embraced Maoist principles, their resistance marked by the prominent display of red flags and revolutionary chants that echoed through the hills of Darjeeling, signaling the birth of a movement that would soon shake the foundations of Indian society.

paragraph1: As Junpei delves deeper into crafting his narrative about Kirie, he finds himself increasingly entangled in the mysterious interplay between her consciousness and the kidney-shaped stone that appears to guide her actions. What began as a simple premise evolves into something far more complex and ethereal, with the stone's nightly movements suggesting a deeper connection to Kirie's psychological state. The story seems to take on a life of its own, defying Junpei's initial intention of creating a straightforward psychological tale about a woman breaking free from her relationship with a married surgeon. Instead of following his planned trajectory where Kirie would develop animosity towards her lover, the narrative veers into more surreal territory, driven by forces that appear to emanate from within Kirie herself. Junpei observes, somewhat perplexed, as the character he created begins to shape her own destiny, transforming what should have been a realistic exploration of human relationships into something more mysterious and metaphysical.
paragraph2: The dark kidney-shaped stone now controls the greater part of her life.Surely the stone is not an object that has come to her from withoutJunpei becomes aware of this as his story progresses. The main point is something inside herself. Something inside herself is activating the kidney-shaped stone and urging her to take some kind of action. It keeps sending her signals for that purpose—signals in the form of the stone’s nightly movements.While he writes, Junpei thinks about Kirie. He senses that she (or something inside her) is propelling the story; it was never his intention to write something so divorced from reality. What Junpei had imagined vaguely beforehand was a more tranquil, psychological story line. In that story line, rocks did not take it upon themselves to move around.Junpei imagined that the doctor would cut her ties to the married surgeon. She might even come to hate him. This was probably what she had been seeking all along, unconsciously.

paragraph1: I sometimes see him in our neighborhood, and each time we meet, my mind wanders to what could have been. He now shares his life with Sarah, one of my friends, and they have two beautiful children together. Our encounters remain cordial, confined to lengthy chats on sun-dappled sidewalks or brief coffee meetings at the corner café. During these moments, he enthusiastically describes his latest ventures, his hands dancing through the air as he speaks, and occasionally, our shoulders brush or our knees touch under the table. These fleeting instances of closeness make me wonder about the parallel universe where we chose differently, where our paths merged instead of diverged, but I quickly push these thoughts aside and smile at his stories.
paragraph2: Now and then on the streets of my neighborhood I bump into a man I might have been involved with, maybe shared a life with. He always looks happy to see me. He lives with a friend of mine, and they have two children. Our relationship never goes beyond a longish chat on the sidewalk, a quick coffee together, perhaps a brief stroll in the same direction. He talks excitedly about his projects, he gesticulates, and at times as we’re walking our synchronized bodies, already quite close, discreetly overlap.

paragraph1: There’s a pair of pants I wore almost every day for the first five years I knew my husband. They were what I like to call sport pants, which differ from all-out sweatpants (or yoga pants, as fancy people now like to call them) in that they were made of a sturdy cotton twill rather than jersey material. Cut comfortably loose, the elastic waistband was the only place where the pants made any contact with my body. Anything could happen inside those pants without detection. I could be fat or less fat or kind of slender. They were extraordinarily utilitarian and patently unsexy. Nuns might opt to wear them. Or park rangers. Or seventy-year-old piano teachers. Or butch lesbians who captained coed Ultimate Frisbee teams. Or me. I wore them so often my husband took to referring to them as my uniform.
paragraph2: During the first five years of knowing my husband, I practically lived in these sport pants that became my signature look, much to his amusement. Made from durable cotton twill, these utterly practical pants were as far from fashionable as one could get, with their loose fit and forgiving elastic waistband that accommodated any fluctuations in my weight. They were the kind of pants you might expect to see on a nun doing gardening work or a park ranger during their off-duty hours - completely utilitarian and decidedly unglamorous. I loved how they adapted to my body and movements, making them perfect for everything from household chores to casual outings. My husband took to calling them my "uniform" because I wore them so religiously, and looking back, I can't blame him for the playful teasing. These pants represented a time when comfort trumped style in my wardrobe choices, and they became an endearing part of our early relationship memories.

paragraph1: I sit down on the chair slowly, looking at the tabletop. Things in silence. A half-full pitcher, the water in it standing motionless. When I want to drink I remove the glass cover, fill it, listening to and watching the water flow; the glass tinkles; the water runs; cool air rises; it's unique; it fascinates me. I'm fascinated, but I don't drink. Not yet. You have to be careful using up the things that make the time pass. I look at my hairbrush and see my hairs caught in it. I pick it up and begin to clean it out. The weak thin hairs of my ninety years. They're falling out one by one. Time, I whispered, what they call our years; we shed them that way, too. I stop and set the brush down. It lies there like an insect on its back, revolting me. If I leave everything this way and nobody touches it for a thousand years, that's how it will stay for a thousand years. Things on top of a table, a key or a water pitcher. How strange; everything in its place, without moving! Then my thoughts would freeze too, colorless and odorless and just sitting there, like a piece of ice.
paragraph2: As I settle into my familiar chair, my eyes fix upon the half-full water pitcher resting on the tabletop, its stillness mirroring the quiet of my thoughts. The simple act of pouring water has always fascinated me, though today I resist the urge to disturb its perfect tranquility, knowing that at ninety, every moment deserves to be savored like the last drop of precious wine. My gaze drifts to my old hairbrush, its bristles entangled with strands of my thinning silver hair, each fallen strand a testament to another year lived, another story told. It's peculiar how time marks its passage on our bodies, much like these lost hairs that accumulate day after day, silent witnesses to our gradual transformation. Setting down the brush, I'm struck by how objects, when left untouched, become frozen in time – the pitcher, the brush, even my scattered thoughts seem to crystallize into permanent fixtures, like ice in winter's grip. These mundane items on my table have become more than mere possessions; they are anchors in the flowing river of time, holding steady as the world continues its relentless march forward, while I sit here, contemplating the beauty in stillness.

paragraph1: Sitting behind the wheel, my thoughts drift between Joe and Paul, two men who represent entirely different chapters of my life. Joe's rebellious spirit awakens something primal in me, a magnetic pull toward chaos that I've long suppressed. Paul, my estranged husband, was my anchor through the darkest days after Mom died, his steady presence a comfort I took for granted until it wasn't there anymore. Now, as I navigate these familiar streets toward Joe's place, I can't help but question if I'm really choosing him or choosing to destroy the carefully constructed life I built with Paul. Joe's touch feels like a match to gasoline, igniting parts of me I thought had died long ago. Our connection, though seemingly casual, runs deeper than either of us admits. He doesn't just represent an escape; he mirrors the wild, untamed version of myself I've always been afraid to embrace. This drive feels symbolic—each mile taking me further from the safety of my past with Paul and closer to a dangerous freedom that both thrills and terrifies me. Perhaps what I'm really chasing isn't Joe at all, but rather the reckless, authentic self he gives me permission to be.
paragraph2: It wasn’t because I was in love with him. We’d only spoken a few times in the six months since he’d visited me in Minneapolis and gotten me pregnant. It had been Paul I’d grieved in the previous months, despite the fact that it was me who’d shattered our marriage to bits. Paul who occupied the center of my broken heart. Paul who’d been my lover and companion, my best friend and anchor in the years after my mother died, when my life had become unmoored. But I was compelled by Joe, powerfully drawn to his bad boy ways, sparked if not to life, then to flame. What I felt for him was weightless and by virtue of its weightlessness it seemed when I was with him that everything else in my life weighed less too. As if the sincere, earnest, sentimental life I’d made with Paul was nothing but a funny dream. I knew, as I drove to see Joe that day, that it wasn’t so much him that I longed to visit, but rather the version of myself that he brought out in me—the one who was outlandish and bold, the wild, self-destructive woman who would do anything.

paragraph1: The doors banged together, and the train started back.Then there was silence, the air like ice. Brittle-looking birch trees with black marks on their white bark, and some small, untidy evergreens, rolled up like sleepy bears. The frozen lake not level but mounded along the shore, as if the waves had turned to ice in the act of falling. And the building, with its deliberate rows of windows and its glassed-in porches at either end. Everything austere and northerly, black-and-white under the high dome of clouds. So still, so immense an enchantment.But the birch bark not white after all, as you got closer. Grayish yellow, grayish blue, gray.
paragraph2: The train's doors banged shut and lurched forward, giving way to an eerie silence as icy air pressed against the windows. Through the glass, brittle birch trees stood like sentinels, their bark marked with distinctive black stripes, while small evergreens huddled nearby like drowsy bears in winter slumber. A frozen lake stretched out, its shoreline decorated with wavy mounds caught in suspended animation beneath the austere northern sky. A solitary building punctuated the monochromatic landscape, its structured rows of windows and glass porches reflecting the diffused light from the clouded dome above. Upon closer inspection, the seemingly white birch bark revealed subtle variations of grayish yellow, blue, and pure gray, adding unexpected depth to the otherwise stark winter tableau.

paragraph1: Then Christmas Day will come. It will be a Monday, yet another Monday, pastel blue, and they will eat a turkey and some more root vegetables and a mince pie that Marcia will have finally got around to making, while Noriega sleeps unmothered in a room in a house ringed with soldiers, dreaming of how he got there or of how he will get out, or dreaming of killing he has done or would like to do, or dreaming of nothing, his round face pocked and bleak as an asteroid. The piece of the Berlin Wall that Marcia has given Eric in his stocking will get lost under the chesterfield. The cat will hide.Marcia will get a little drunk on the eggnog, and later, after the dishes are done, she will cry silently to herself, shut into the bathroom and hugging in her festive arms the grumbling cat, which she will have dragged out from under a bed for this purpose. She will cry because the children are no longer children, or because she herself is not a child anymore, or because there are children who have never been children, or because she can’t have a child anymore, ever again. Her body has gone past too quickly for her; she has not made herself ready.It’s all this talk of babies, at Christmas. It’s all this hope. She gets distracted by it, and has trouble paying attention to the real news.
paragraph2: On Christmas Day, Marcia will spend the morning in her warm kitchen, methodically preparing the traditional feast while the aroma of roasting turkey and root vegetables fills the house. As she works, Noriega will lie restless in his guarded room, his sleep punctuated by disturbing dreams that blur the lines between his past misdeeds and future possibilities. The day will unfold with small disappointments, like Eric's lost piece of the Berlin Wall that had appeared so promising in his Christmas stocking, now somewhere between the couch cushions or perhaps swept away with discarded wrapping paper. The eggnog, consumed steadily throughout the afternoon, will leave Marcia with a pleasant buzz that slowly transforms into a melancholic haze. She will find herself retreating to the bathroom, where she'll sit on the cool tile floor, cradling the cat she coaxed out from under the bed, her quiet tears falling into its fur. These moments alone will force her to confront the relentless march of time—children grown and gone, others never arriving, and the persistent feeling that life's changes have caught her unprepared despite the season's promises of renewal and hope. The television will murmur in the background with news she should care about but can't quite focus on, her mind too full of what was and what might have been.

You are given two pararaphs of creative writing for a given writing instruction.
Your task is to determine which paragraph is overall better in terms of writing quality.

Paragraph 1:
Then Christmas Day will come. It will be a Monday, yet another Monday, pastel blue, and they will eat a turkey and some more root vegetables and a mince pie that Marcia will have finally got around to making, while Noriega sleeps unmothered in a room in a house ringed with soldiers, dreaming of how he got there or of how he will get out, or dreaming of killing he has done or would like to do, or dreaming of nothing, his round face pocked and bleak as an asteroid. The piece of the Berlin Wall that Marcia has given Eric in his stocking will get lost under the chesterfield. The cat will hide.Marcia will get a little drunk on the eggnog, and later, after the dishes are done, she will cry silently to herself, shut into the bathroom and hugging in her festive arms the grumbling cat, which she will have dragged out from under a bed for this purpose. She will cry because the children are no longer children, or because she herself is not a child anymore, or because there are children who have never been children, or because she can’t have a child anymore, ever again. Her body has gone past too quickly for her; she has not made herself ready.It’s all this talk of babies, at Christmas. It’s all this hope. She gets distracted by it, and has trouble paying attention to the real news.

Paragraph 2:
On Christmas Day, Marcia will spend the morning in her warm kitchen, methodically preparing the traditional feast while the aroma of roasting turkey and root vegetables fills the house. As she works, Noriega will lie restless in his guarded room, his sleep punctuated by disturbing dreams that blur the lines between his past misdeeds and future possibilities. The day will unfold with small disappointments, like Eric's lost piece of the Berlin Wall that had appeared so promising in his Christmas stocking, now somewhere between the couch cushions or perhaps swept away with discarded wrapping paper. The eggnog, consumed steadily throughout the afternoon, will leave Marcia with a pleasant buzz that slowly transforms into a melancholic haze. She will find herself retreating to the bathroom, where she'll sit on the cool tile floor, cradling the cat she coaxed out from under the bed, her quiet tears falling into its fur. These moments alone will force her to confront the relentless march of time—children grown and gone, others never arriving, and the persistent feeling that life's changes have caught her unprepared despite the season's promises of renewal and hope. The television will murmur in the background with news she should care about but can't quite focus on, her mind too full of what was and what might have been.

paragraph1: If religion is the opium of the people, tradition is an even more sinister analgesic, simply because it rarely appears sinister. If religion is a tight band, a throbbing vein and a needle, tradition is a far homelier concoctionpoppy seeds ground into tea; a sweet cocoa drink laced with cocaine; the kind of thing your grandmother might have made. To Samad, as to the people of Thailand, tradition was culture, and culture led to roots, and these were good, these were untainted principles. That didn’t mean he could live by them, abide by them or grow in the manner they demanded, but roots were roots and roots were good. You would get nowhere telling him that weeds too have tubers, or that the first sign of loose teeth is something rotten, something degenerate, deep within the gums. Roots were what saved, the ropes one throws out to rescue drowning men, to Save Their Souls. And the further Samad himself floated out to sea, pulled down to the depths by a siren named Poppy Burt-Jones, the more determined he became to create for his boys roots on shore, deep roots that no storm or gale could displace.
paragraph2: Tradition weaves through life like an invisible thread, binding generations and shaping identities with its quiet yet unyielding presence. For Samad, this cultural tapestry represents both comfort and conflict, as he grapples with its demands while steadfastly believing in its fundamental importance. He sees tradition as the bedrock of cultural identity, the very essence that gives meaning to one's existence, even as he struggles to align his own actions with its principles. The metaphor of roots runs deep in his consciousness, extending beyond mere cultural connection to encompass the very essence of stability and salvation. Even in his moments of doubt, when he recognizes the decay within himself, Samad clings to the notion that even weeds possess roots – suggesting that even flawed foundations have value. This belief becomes particularly poignant as he feels the pull of Poppy Burt-Jones, threatening to uproot him from his cultural moorings. In response, his determination to secure strong roots for his sons intensifies, driven by an almost desperate need to ensure they have the cultural anchor he fears losing himself. This preoccupation with tradition and roots reveals both his deep-seated fears and his unwavering faith in the power of cultural heritage to provide stability and direction.

paragraph1: You've spent enough of your life already on all of that. Let's go away tomorrow, let's not waste a single day more, let's go before it's too late for us."Too late for what, exactly?" "Too late for... oh, I don't know. All I know is that I've wasted all these years looking for something, a sort of trophy I'd get only if I really, really did enough to deserve it. But I don't want it any more, I want something else now, something warm and sheltering, something I can turn to, regardless of what I do, regardless of who I become. Something that will just be there, always, like tomorrow's sky. That's what I want now, and I think it's what you should want too. But it will be too late soon. We'll become too set to change. If we don't take our chance now, another may never come for either of us."
paragraph2: Standing here with you now, I can't help but think about all the years we've let slip away, Sarah. Every morning, I wake up wondering if this is all there is – the same routine, the same faces, the same unfulfilled promises. I've spent a decade chasing promotions and accolades that feel hollow now. Remember when we used to talk about moving to that little coastal town, opening a bookstore, and living simply? That dream still haunts me. We're not getting any younger, and I'm terrified of waking up at sixty-five realizing we never took the chance. I need something real, something I can hold onto – not just numbers in a bank account or a fancy title on my business card. You've always been my anchor, and I know this is crazy, but I'm asking you to be brave with me. Let's leave this behind before we become too comfortable with our regrets. The house is already on the market, and I've got two plane tickets. What do you say?

paragraph1: Navigating the corridors of academic life, Connell finds himself increasingly aware of the performative nature of literary appreciation among his college peers. He observes with quiet skepticism how students, particularly one named Sadie, brandish their reading habits like badges of cultural sophistication, more concerned with the appearance of being well-read than genuinely engaging with the texts. The irony becomes especially apparent during a social gathering where Sadie bristles at the mention of politics, despite the inherently political nature of much of the literature she claims to revere. This reaction strengthens Connell's growing conviction that literature, in these circles, has been transformed into a tool for class distinction, allowing privileged readers to maintain a safe distance from the very real struggles they encounter in books. While he acknowledges the publishing industry's role in marketing books as status symbols, deliberately packaging and selling literature as cultural capital to those eager to display their refinement, Connell refuses to let this cynicism completely overshadow his relationship with writing. Instead, he discovers an authentic connection between the act of creating literature and life's simple pleasures, finding genuine fulfillment in the craft despite the pretensions that often surround it in academic environments.
paragraph2: He knows that a lot of the literary people in college see books primarily as a way of appearing cultured. When someone mentioned the austerity protests that night in the Stag’s Head, Sadie threw her hands up and saidNot politics, please! Connell's initial assessment of the reading was not disproven. It was culture as class performance, literature fetishised for its ability to take educated people on false emotional journeys, so that they might afterwards feel superior to the uneducated people whose emotional journeys they liked to read about. Even if the writer himself was a good person, and even if his book really was insightful, all books were ultimately marketed as status symbols, and all writers participated to some degree in this marketing. Presumably this was how the industry made money. Literature, in the way it appeared at these public readings, had no potential as a form of resistance to anything. Still, Connell went home that night and read over some notes he had been making for a new story, and he felt the old beat of pleasure inside his body, like watching a perfect goal, like the rustling movement of light through leaves, a phrase of music from the window of a passing car. Life offers up these moments of joy despite everything.

paragraph1: He read political books. They gave him phrases which he could only speak to himself and use on Shama. They also revealed one region after another of misery and injustice and left him feeling more helpless and more isolated than ever. Then it was that he discovered the solace of Dickens. Without difficulty he transferred characters and settings to people and places he knew. In the grotesques of Dickens everything he feared and suffered from was ridiculed and diminished, so that his own anger, his own contempt became unnecessary, and he was given strength to bear the most difficult part of his daydressing in the morning, that daily affirmation of faith in oneself, which at times for him was almost like an act of sacrifice.
paragraph2: Consumed by political literature filled with tales of suffering and social inequality, he found himself sinking deeper into a state of despair and alienation. These heavy thoughts remained largely confined to conversations with Shama and his own internal dialogues. Seeking refuge from this overwhelming darkness, he turned to Charles Dickens's works, finding unexpected comfort in their pages. He began reimagining Dickens's vivid characters and Victorian landscapes as mirrors of his own world and its inhabitants. The satirical wit and biting humor characteristic of Dickens's storytelling gradually worked their magic, helping to dissolve his fears and temper his rage. This literary escape provided him with just enough fortitude to tackle even the most basic daily rituals, particularly the seemingly insurmountable task of getting dressed each morning, which had become a daily battle of self-assertion and personal validation.

paragraph1: After my initial visit to the Passage Cardinet, I found myself taking penicillin, and from that moment on, fear became my constant companion. The memories of Madame P-R's apartment haunted me relentlessly, particularly the kitchen and bedroom scenes that played over and over in my mind like a twisted film reel. One day at the canteen, I attempted to explain my overwhelming anxiety to my colleagues, the girls, attributing it to the removal of a large beauty spot. Their reactions were a mix of confusion and mild amusement – they couldn't comprehend why such a minor procedure would trigger such intense fear. Though I deliberately downplayed the true depth of my terror, sharing even this small part of my experience provided a momentary sense of relief, like briefly surfacing for air while drowning. The intensity of my fear was such that I began seeing threats in the most ordinary places; even a stern-looking elderly woman in a commonplace setting would transform in my mind into someone potentially dangerous, someone who might wish me harm. This persistent state of anxiety colored every aspect of my daily life, turning routine encounters into potential threats.
paragraph2: After my first trip to the Passage Cardinet, I began taking penicillin and my life was suddenly ruled by fear. I kept imagining the kitchen and the bedroom in Madame P-R’s apartment, I couldn’t face what would come next. I told the girls at the canteen that I was afraid because I was having a large beauty spot removed from my back. They seemed surprised that such a harmless operation should make me so nervous. Admitting I was scared gave me a huge sense of relieffor a split-second, I could see myself in a pristine operating room, attended to by a surgeon in rubber gloves, instead of an ageing nurse in some dingy back kitchen.(To experience anew the emotions I felt back then is quite impossible. The closest I can get to the state of terror thrust upon me that week is to pick out any hostile, harsh-looking woman in her sixties waiting in line at the supermarket or the post office and to imagine that she is going to rummage around in my loins with some foreign object.)

paragraph1: Standing here behind what remains of the fallen kingdom, I find solace in the gentle stream that flows with pristine clarity. As I dip my feet into its icy-cold waters, I watch the fish swimming gracefully below, completely oblivious to the political turmoil that has transformed the land around them. These simple creatures continue their eternal routine, nibbling at the swaying weeds, utterly indifferent to concepts of power, governance, or the collapse of human institutions. The crumbling walls of the kingdom loom in my view, and atop the weathered tower, a two-colored flag still defiantly ripples in the breeze, a lasting reminder of what once was. Occasionally, travelers pass by, their eyes drawn to that persistent flag, and I hear them murmur about the kingdom's downfall, their words mixing with the stream's soothing whispers.
paragraph2: Just behind the kingdom that failed ran a nice little river. It was a clear, lovely stream, and many fish lived in it. Weeds grew there, too, and the fish ate the weeds. The fish didn’t care whether or not the kingdom had failed, of course. Whether it was a kingdom or a republic made no difference to them. They didn’t vote or pay taxes. Makes no difference to us, they figured.I washed my feet in the stream. A short soak in the icy-cold water turned them red. From the stream, you could see the walls and the tower of the castle in the kingdom that failed. The two-colored flag still flew from the tower, fluttering in the breeze. Everyone passing along the riverbanks would see the flag and say, “Hey, look at that. It’s the flag of the kingdom that failed.”

paragraph1: I can't seem to focus on these spreadsheets when all I can think about is the perfect stack of fluffy pancakes, drowning in maple syrup. Maybe I'm just living in the wrong timeline - I should be a successful stockbroker by now, forty years old, driving home in my luxury car on a drizzly Sunday morning, knowing a plate of homemade pancakes awaits me. Instead, I'm stuck here with my growling stomach and mounting deadlines. Denny's is just around the corner, and even though their pancakes are mediocre at best, they're still pancakes, right? The butter slowly melting, creating little pools of golden goodness... No, no, I need to snap out of this pancake-induced daydream. These reports won't review themselves, and my supervisor needs them by five. But still, those pancakes at Denny's might not be gourmet, but they'd definitely hit the spot right now. Focus, just focus - but why does every circular object on my desk remind me of pancakes?
paragraph2: I concentrated as fiercely as I could and tried to picture the sceneYou’re a forty-year-old stockbroker, it’s Sunday morning, it’s raining hard outside, and you’re on your way home to a stack of hot pancakes. The more I thought about it, the more it whetted my appetite. I’d had only one small apple since morning.Maybe I should zip over to Denny’s and dig into some pancakes, I thought. I’d passed a sign for Denny’s on the drive here. It was probably even close enough to walk. Not that Denny’s made great pancakes—the butter and the syrup weren’t up to my standards—but they would do. Truth be told, I’m a huge pancake fan. Saliva began to well up in my mouth. But I shook my head and tried to banish all pancake thoughts for the time being. I blew away all the clouds of illusion. Save the pancakes for later, I cautioned myself. You’ve still got work to do.

Paragraph 1:
I can't seem to focus on these spreadsheets when all I can think about is the perfect stack of fluffy pancakes, drowning in maple syrup. Maybe I'm just living in the wrong timeline - I should be a successful stockbroker by now, forty years old, driving home in my luxury car on a drizzly Sunday morning, knowing a plate of homemade pancakes awaits me. Instead, I'm stuck here with my growling stomach and mounting deadlines. Denny's is just around the corner, and even though their pancakes are mediocre at best, they're still pancakes, right? The butter slowly melting, creating little pools of golden goodness... No, no, I need to snap out of this pancake-induced daydream. These reports won't review themselves, and my supervisor needs them by five. But still, those pancakes at Denny's might not be gourmet, but they'd definitely hit the spot right now. Focus, just focus - but why does every circular object on my desk remind me of pancakes?

Paragraph 2:

I’d passed a sign for Denny’s on the drive here. It was probably even close enough to walk. Not that Denny’s made great pancakes—the butter and the syrup weren’t up to my standards—but they would do. Truth be told, I’m a huge pancake fan. Saliva began to well up in my mouth. But I shook my head and tried to banish all pancake thoughts for the time being. I blew away all the clouds of illusion. Save the pancakes for later, I cautioned myself. You’ve still got work to do.

paragraph1: Every time my phone buzzes, my heart leaps with a desperate hope that quickly dissolves into familiar disappointment when I see it's not Nick's name on the screen. Last week's call with Dad only intensified this ache - his well-meaning advice about moving on felt like salt in an open wound. I know Nick has moved on with Melissa; their social media posts paint a picture of the happiness I once thought would be mine. The rational part of my brain understands it's over, but my heart refuses to accept this new reality, leaving me in this perpetual state of longing and self-doubt. I spend countless hours analyzing my flaws, wondering if I wasn't good enough, pretty enough, or interesting enough to keep him. Days blur together as I compulsively check my phone, watching hours turn into days, and days into weeks, all while pretending to function normally. I've started applying for jobs and attending professional development seminars - desperate attempts to fill the void and create the illusion of progress. But even as I sit in these crowded rooms, taking notes and nodding along, my mind wanders back to Nick, and I find myself trapped in this endless cycle of waiting for a call that I know, deep down, will never come. The weight of this unrequited hope has become my constant companion, following me through every mundane moment of my days.
paragraph2: That evening I thought about my father’s phone call from the night before, and how I had wanted to tell Nick about it, and for a moment I really thoughtI will call Nick and he will come back. Things like this can be undone. But I knew that he would never come back again, not really. He wasn’t only mine any more, that part was over. Melissa knew things that I didn’t know. After everything that had happened between them they still desired one another. I thought about her email, and about how I was sick and probably infertile anyway, and how I could give Nick nothing that would mean anything to him. For the next few days I stared at my phone for hours on end and accomplished nothing. The time moved past visibly on the illuminated onscreen clock and yet I still felt as though I didn’t notice it passing. Nick didn’t call me that evening, or that night. He didn’t call me the next day, or the day after that. Nobody did. Gradually the waiting began to feel less like waiting and more like this was simply what life wasthe distracting tasks undertaken while the thing you are waiting for continues not to happen. I applied for jobs and turned up for seminars. Things went on.

paragraph1: But the airplane is a wonderful thing. You are still in one place when you arrive at the other. The airplane is faster than the heart. You arrive quickly and you leave quickly. You don't grieve too much. And there is something else about the airplane. You can go back many times to the same place. And something strange happens if you go back often enough. You stop grieving for the past. You see that the past is something in your mind alone, that it doesn't exist in real life. You trample on the past, you crush it. In the beginning it is like trampling on a garden. In the end you are just walking on ground. That is the way we have to learn to live now. The past is here." He touched his heart. "It isn't there." And he pointed at the dusty road.
paragraph2: The profound metaphorical significance of airplanes emerges as a powerful tool for navigating emotional landscapes and confronting past experiences. As metal vessels slice through clouds at remarkable speeds, they compress not only physical distance but also the psychological space between present reality and lingering memories. She observes how this swift traversal of space fundamentally alters one's relationship with past grievances, watching as he touches his heart before gesturing toward a dusty road below. The juxtaposition becomes clear - what exists in memory often bears little resemblance to current reality. Through repeated visits, these once-powerful emotional anchors gradually lose their hold, transforming from vivid, haunting presences into abstract concepts that exist solely within the mind's confines. The airplane serves as both literal vessel and symbolic gateway, enabling travelers to physically return to spaces where memories dwell, only to discover that time has rendered these emotional landmarks into something entirely different, something less commanding of their present selves.

paragraph1: Michael sat uneasily in his downtown apartment, acutely aware of the strange synchronicity unfolding around him. Through the walls, he could hear Marlon's television echoing the same broadcast playing on his own screen, creating an unsettling stereo effect that only heightened his sense of displacement. While Elizabeth and Marlon remained safely uptown, where he too should have been, circumstances involving an inoperable helipad near the Garden had forced him into this downtown location, despite the vehement protests of his family and friends. Their warnings about downtown's dangers now seemed eerily prophetic as he stood at his window, transfixed by the ominous sight before him. The southern sky had transformed into a canvas of destruction, with waves of ash advancing toward him like a slow-moving storm. The severity of the situation dawning on him, Michael realized that his West Coast connections had severely underestimated the magnitude of what was unfolding in downtown Manhattan. The doubled images on the televisions continued to play, providing a surreal backdrop to the real horror developing outside his window.
paragraph2: Michael could hear Marlon’s TV in the background. It was tuned to the same channel Michael was watching, but only Michael could see the images on the screen replicated simultaneously through his own window, a strange doubling sensation, like when you stand on a stage and look up at yourself on the Jumbotron. Elizabeth and Marlon were staying uptown; normally Michael, too, would be staying uptown—until five days ago he’d almost never set foot below Forty-second Street. Everyone—his brothers and sisters, all his West Coast friends—had warned him not to go downtown. It’s dangerous downtown, it’s always been that way, just stick with what you know, stay at the Carlyle. But because the helipad near the Garden had, for some reason, been out of commission it had been decided he should stay downtown, for reasons of proximity and to avoid traffic. Now Michael looked south and saw a sky darkened with ash. The ash seemed to be moving toward him. Downtown was really so much worse than anyone in L.A. could even begin to imagine.

paragraph1: Driving along the winding country roads with Mom that August afternoon, I couldn't help but feel nostalgic about the familiar landscapes I'd grown up with. The scattered farmhouses and rolling hills had been the backdrop of my childhood, though I didn't realize this would be one of my last times seeing them as a resident rather than a visitor. Fresh from my first year of college, I was savoring these moments of simple companionship with my mother, even if I didn't fully appreciate their significance at the time. When we spotted the yard sale signs outside Mrs. Henderson's solitary white house, Mom suggested we stop, and I agreed without hesitation. There was something poignant about the elderly woman sitting alone in her lawn chair, surrounded by pieces of her life she'd decided to part with. The late summer sun cast long shadows across her carefully arranged tables, where old china sets and weathered books told stories of decades past. Looking back now, that impromptu stop feels like a perfect snapshot of my last summer at home - unplanned, ordinary, yet somehow meaningful in ways I couldn't have understood then. Mom and I wandered between the tables, picking up trinkets and sharing quiet observations, while cicadas hummed in the background and time seemed to slow down just for us.
paragraph2: The summer I was 18 I was driving down a country road with my mother. This was in the rural county where I grew up and all of the roads were country, the houses spread out over miles, hardly any of them in sight of a neighbor. Driving meant going past an endless stream of trees and fields and wildflowers. On this particular afternoon, my mother and I came upon a yard sale at a big house where a very old woman lived alone, her husband dead, her kids grown and gone.“Let’s look and see what she has,” my mother said as we passed, so I turned the car around and pulled into the old woman’s driveway and the two of us got out.We were the only people there. Even the old woman whose sale it was didn’t come out of the house, only waving to us from a window. It was August, the last stretch of time that I would I live with my mother. I’d completed my first year of college by then and I’d returned home for the summer because I’d gotten a job in a nearby town. In a few weeks I’d go back to college and I’d never again live in the place I called home, though I didn’t know that then.

paragraph1: When I first took up English teaching after university, it seemed a good enough life—much like an extension of university. Language schools were mushrooming all over Europe, and if the teaching was tedious and the hours exploitative, at that age you don’t care too much. You spend a lot of time in bars, friends are easy to make, and there’s a feeling you’re part of a large network extending around the entire globe. You meet people fresh from their spells in Peru or Thailand, and this gets you thinking that if you wanted to, you could drift around the world indefinitely, using your contacts to get a job in any faraway corner you fancied. And always you’d be part of this cosy, extended family of itinerant teachers, swapping stories over drinks about former colleagues, psychotic school directors, eccentric British Council officers. In the late ’80s, there was talk of making a lot of money teaching in Japan, and I made serious plans to go, but it never worked out. I thought about Brazil too, even read a few books about the culture and sent off for application forms. But somehow I never got away that far. Southern Italy, Portugal for a short spell, back here to Spain. Then before you know it, you’re forty-seven years old, and the people you started out with have long ago been replaced by a generation who gossip about different things, take different drugs and listen to different music.
paragraph2: Teaching English became my default path after university, and looking back, it felt like a natural progression from campus life - just with more responsibility and longer hours. The classroom routine, though demanding, wasn't entirely unfamiliar, and the social atmosphere among teachers reminded me of my college days. I quickly found myself part of a vibrant community of fellow teachers, all of us young and eager to explore the world while making a living. We'd gather after classes, sharing stories of cultural mishaps and classroom triumphs, planning our next international moves over cheap wine in local bars. I had grand plans of teaching in Japan, dreaming of cherry blossoms and high-tech cities, and even entertained offers from language schools in Brazil, imagining myself on Copacabana Beach between classes. Those particular dreams never materialized, but I found myself instead in the sun-drenched towns of Southern Italy, the historic streets of Portugal, and the bustling cities of Spain. It wasn't until recently, sitting in a staff room in Barcelona, that I realized how much time had passed. The new teachers were discussing TikTok lessons and Instagram reels, while my stories of lugging around heavy textbooks and using overhead projectors seemed to belong to another era entirely. The young faces around me were a mirror reflecting my own journey from eager newcomer to seasoned professional, marking the subtle shift from being part of the new wave to becoming one of the experienced old guard.

paragraph1: In the quiet aftermath of a hurtful incident, Marianne finds herself sharing with Connell how his friend Eric had publicly mocked her physical appearance, specifically calling attention to her being flat-chested. Though Connell wasn't present during the incident, his response to hearing about it reveals the depth of his care for her. He wraps his arms around her protectively, his words carefully chosen to counter Eric's cruel remarks, emphasizing that her worth extends far beyond physical attributes. The tenderness of their embrace evolves into an intimate exchange, their voices dropping to whispers as they explore their feelings for one another and contemplate what lies ahead in their relationship. There's a profound vulnerability in their interaction, particularly as Marianne considers how rare and precious their connection is. The moment transcends the initial hurt that prompted their conversation, transforming into something more meaningful – a testament to their unique bond. Their physical closeness mirrors their emotional intimacy, creating a safe space where past hurts can be acknowledged and healed through understanding and acceptance. Marianne's recognition of the exceptional nature of their relationship underscores how their connection stands apart from ordinary interactions, suggesting that such depth of understanding and mutual care is a rare gift in life.
paragraph2: Your friend Eric called me flat-chested today in front of everyone.Connell paused. She felt his breathing. I didn’t hear that, he said. You were in the bathroom or somewhere. He said I looked like an ironing board.Fuck's sake, he's such a prick. Is that why you're in a bad mood? She shrugged. Connell put his arms around her belly. He's only trying to get on your nerves, he said. If he thought he had the slightest chance with you, he would be talking very differently. He just thinks you look down on him. She shrugged again, chewing on her lower lip.You have nothing to worry about with your appearance, Connell said.Hm.I don’t just like you for your brains, trust me.She laughed, feeling silly.He rubbed her ear with his nose and addedI would miss you if you didn’t want to see me anymore. Would you miss sleeping with me? she said. He touched his hand against her hipbone, rocking her back against his body, and said quietlyYeah, a lot. Can we go back to your house now? He nodded. For a few seconds they just stood there in stillness, his arms around her, his breath on her ear. Most people go through their whole lives, Marianne thought, without ever really feeling that close with anyone.

paragraph1: Standing at the desolate bus stop in the depths of night, I found myself drawn into conversation with Roger Button, whose presence seemed both peculiar and comforting. As uncertainty about the bus's arrival gnawed at my mind, Roger's unwavering confidence provided an unexpected anchor. His eyes sparkled with conviction as he painted a vivid picture of the inevitable bus journey, describing fellow passengers with their warm smiles and engaging personalities, as if he had already experienced this very moment countless times before. When Roger bid farewell and melted into the darkness, his footsteps fading like echoes against the pavement, I was left with an inexplicable sense of reassurance. Setting my bag down beside the lamppost's gentle glow, I strained my ears for any hint of an approaching engine, finding comfort in the stillness of the night air. Roger's enthusiastic description of the journey ahead had transformed my initial apprehension into a quiet anticipation, and I could almost envision the welcoming faces that awaited at my destination. The empty street no longer felt threatening but rather like a pause before the beginning of something meaningful, and I settled into this moment of peaceful expectation, trusting in Roger's promise that the bus would indeed come.
paragraph2: "It’s very late," I said. "Are you sure a bus will come?" "Oh, yes. Of course, you may have to wait. But eventually a bus will come." Then he touched me reassuringly on the shoulder. "I can see it might get a little lonely standing out here. But once the bus arrives your spirits will rise, believe me. Oh, yes. That bus is always a joy. It’ll be brightly lit up, and it’s always full of cheerful people, laughing and joking and pointing out the window. Once you board it, you’ll feel warm and comfortable, and the other passengers will chat with you, perhaps offer you things to eat or drink. There may even be singing—that depends on the driver. Some drivers encourage it, others don’t. Well, Fletcher, it was good to see you." We shook hands, then he turned and walked away. I watched him disappear into the darkness between two cottages.I walked up to the green and put my bag down at the foot of the lamppost. I listened for the sound of a vehicle in the distance, but the night was utterly still. Nevertheless, I had been cheered by Roger Button's description of the bus. Moreover, I thought of the reception awaiting me at my journey’s end—of the adoring faces of the young people—and felt the stirrings of optimism somewhere deep within me.

As uncertainty about the bus's arrival gnawed at my mind, Roger's unwavering confidence provided an unexpected anchor. His eyes sparkled with conviction as he painted a vivid picture of the inevitable bus journey, describing fellow passengers with their warm smiles and engaging personalities, as if he had already experienced this very moment countless times before. paragraph1: Standing there in the coffee shop, watching Mark's receding figure, I couldn't help but marvel at how twenty years had transformed my ex-girlfriend's brother into someone both familiar and foreign. Our conversation had meandered through the usual catching-up topics, but beneath the surface lay unspoken questions about paths not taken and lives that had diverged so completely. The steam from my cooling latte seemed to carry whispers of those deeper meanings we'd circled around but never quite grasped. As his silhouette disappeared into the bustling street, my mind drifted to another goodbye, one eternally frozen in time - that lovely young girl in the high school hallway back in 1964, clutching her "With the Beatles" album like a precious treasure. I can still see her walking away, her movements synchronized to some internal rhythm that I'll never know. Sometimes I wonder if she exists perpetually in that moment, forever sixteen, forever carrying that vinyl record, forever turning the corner at the end of that sunlit corridor. These two goodbyes, separated by decades yet somehow intertwined in my memory, remind me how we're all just passing figures in each other's stories, leaving impressions that linger long after we've walked away.
paragraph2: And so we said goodbye. I went to get my watch, which had been repaired, and my former girlfriend’s older brother slowly set off down the hill to Shibuya station. His tweed-jacketed figure was swallowed up in the afternoon crowd.I never saw him again. Chance had brought us together a second time. With nearly twenty years between encounters, in cities three hundred miles apart, we’d sat, a table between us, sipping coffee and talking over a few things. But these weren’t subjects you just chatted about over coffee. There was something more significant in our talk, something that seemed meaningful to us, in the act of living out our lives. Still, it was merely a hint, delivered by chance. There was nothing to link us together in a more systematic or organic way. (QuestionWhat elements in the lives of these two men were symbolically suggested by their two meetings and conversations?)I never saw that lovely young girl again, either, the one who was holding the LP “With the Beatles.” Sometimes I wonder—is she still hurrying down that dimly lit high-school hallway in 1964, the hem of her skirt fluttering as she goes? Sixteen even now, holding that wonderful album cover with the half-lit photo of John, Paul, George, and Ringo, clutching it tightly as though her life depended on it.

paragraph1: My middle sister Muneeza, now eleven, was entering her delinquent phase a little early. She was the true inheritor of my father’s black rage, and when she lost control it was terrible to behold. That summer she seemed to pick fights with my father on purpose; seemed prepared, at her young age, to test her strength against his. (I intervened in her rows with Abba only once, in the kitchen. She grabbed the kitchen scissors and flung them at me. They cut me on the thigh. After that I kept my distance.) As I witnessed their wars I felt myself coming unstuck from the idea of family itself. I looked at my screaming sister and thought how brilliantly selfdestructive she was, how triumphantly she was ruining her relations with the people she needed most. And I looked at my choleric, face-pulling father and thought about British citizenship. My existing Indian passport permitted me to travel only to a very few countries, which were carefully listed on the second right-hand page. But I might soon have a British passport and then, by hook or by crook, I would get away from him. I would not have this face-pulling in my life. At sixteen, you still think you can escape from your father. You aren’t listening to his voice speaking through your mouth, you don’t see how your gestures already mirror his; you don’t see him in the way you hold your body, in the way you sign your name. You don’t hear his whisper in your blood.
paragraph2: I watch helplessly as the discord between Muneeza and Father grows more intense with each passing day, their voices echoing through our home like thunderclaps in an endless storm. My middle sister, barely eleven, has already developed a fierceness that mirrors Father's volatile nature, making their confrontations increasingly dangerous. The day she hurled those kitchen scissors at me, leaving a jagged cut on my thigh, I realized I could no longer play mediator in their battles. The scar serves as a constant reminder of why I now retreat to my room when I hear their arguments begin, though the walls do little to muffle their shouting. Sometimes, I catch glimpses of myself in the mirror and search for signs of Father's temperament in my own features, desperately hoping I haven't inherited his quick-burning anger. My dreams of obtaining British citizenship have become an obsession, representing not just a document but an escape route from this suffocating atmosphere. I tell myself that once I'm far away, I can shed any trace of Father's influence like an old skin, starting fresh in a place where raised voices and flying scissors are not the language of family. Yet, even as I make these plans, a nagging doubt persists - can I truly outrun the parts of him that may already be woven into the fabric of who I am? For now, I remain caught between love and fear, watching my sister follow a path I desperately want to avoid.

paragraph1: For months, my body was investigated and photographed innumerable times from every angle and with every technique in existence. I realize now that I neither saw nor wanted to see anything of my inside, my skeleton, my organs. I had to wonder each time I was examined what more they would find.The catheter was removed in April. I wore it inside me for a year and a half. Over time, it became like a kind of jewel inlaid in my skin near the shoulder. I asked the doctor to give it to me, said I wanted to keep it. It was the first time he had received such a request, and he laughed“As a souvenir?” I also kept the wig. I saw it recently at the back of a drawer and I thought, I may never again have the chance to feel such strong emotion, and at the same time I thought, I’m mortal and I’m alive.I’ve spread out all the photos on the table in the living room. They look like the cards from a game of Clue, where all you can see of the house and the different rooms are the floors, the baseboards of the partitions, the bottoms of doors, the legs of furniture. No murder weapon, just the repeated signs of a struggle. Without thinking, I took a photo of the collection. Perhaps to give myself the illusion of capturing a whole. All of our story. But it’s not there. In a few years, these photos may hold no interest for either of us, except as testimonials to shoe fashion in the early two-thousands.
paragraph2: Throughout my prolonged medical journey, I found myself subjected to countless examinations, each one revealing more about my internal workings than I ever wished to know. The routine became almost mundane - doctors peering inside, making discoveries, and documenting everything with clinical precision. I distinctly remember the day my catheter was finally removed after a grueling year and a half. In what might seem peculiar to others, I asked to keep it as a memento, much to my doctor's amusement. The request wasn't entirely out of character for me; after all, I had already kept my wig from those difficult days. These objects serve as tangible reminders of the intense emotional landscape I traversed, each one marking a milestone in my confrontation with mortality. When I spread out the photographs from that period, it feels like playing an elaborate game of Clue, piecing together fragments of memories that sometimes feel like they belong to someone else. The images capture moments frozen in time - the sterile hospital rooms, the concerned faces of loved ones, the medical equipment that became so familiar. Looking at them now, I realize these snapshots will eventually become nothing more than curious artifacts, their emotional weight gradually diminishing until they're merely examples of outdated fashion and obsolete medical practices. Yet for now, each image and memento serves as a powerful reminder of my journey through illness and back to health, marking the delicate balance between being acutely aware of my mortality and celebrating my continued existence.

paragraph1: Sarah sat at her desk, methodically working through documents on the text-editing interface, her fingers dancing across the keyboard as she adjusted errant apostrophes and misplaced commas. The afternoon light filtered through the office windows, casting a soft glow on her screen as she navigated between tasks. Like clockwork, her hand would drift to her mouse every few minutes, automatically opening her social media feeds in a well-worn ritual. Her eyes scanned through the varied content - devastating news about an earthquake in Asia, followed by a friend's punny joke - yet her expression remained consistently neutral, absorbing everything with the same detached interest. Without any particular trigger, she would suddenly close the social media tabs, returning to her work with renewed focus. The quiet of her workday was occasionally interrupted by colleagues seeking her input on formatting questions or sharing the latest office memes, to which she would respond with brief, professional engagement before returning to her solitary tasks. The afternoon proceeded in this rhythm of focused work punctuated by these small digital and human interactions.
paragraph2: For the rest of the afternoon in the office, the woman worked on the same text-editing interface, moving apostrophes and deleting commas. After closing one file and before opening another, she routinely checked her social-media feeds. Her expression, her posture, did not vary depending on the information she encountered therea news report about a horrific natural disaster, a photograph of someone’s beloved pet, a female journalist speaking out about death threats, a recondite joke requiring familiarity with several other previous Internet jokes in order to be even vaguely comprehensible, a passionate condemnation of white supremacy, or a promoted tweet advertising a health supplement for expectant mothers. Nothing changed in her outward relationship to the world that would allow an observer to determine what she felt about what she saw. Then, after some length of time, with no apparent trigger, she closed the browser window and reopened the text editor. Occasionally one of her colleagues would interject with a work-related question and she would answer, or someone would share a funny anecdote with the office and they would all laugh, but mostly the work continued quietly.

paragraph1: Drapes. That would be her word for the blue curtains—drapes. And why not? He thought of the ginger cookies so perfectly round that she had to announce they were homemade, the ceramic coffee mugs on their ceramic tree, a plastic runner, he was sure, protecting the hall carpet. A high-gloss exactness and practicality that his mother had never achieved but would have admired—was that why he could feel this twinge of bizarre and unreliable affection? Or was it because he’d had two more drinks after the first?The walnut-stain tan—he believed now that it was a tan—of her face and neck would most likely continue into her cleavage, which would be deep, crêpey-skinned, odorous and hot. He had that to think of as he dialled the number that he had already written down. That and the practical sensuality of her cat’s tongue. Her gemstone eyes.
paragraph2: Sitting in her living space, he found himself studying every detail with an intensity that surprised him. The blue fabric hanging by the windows—drapes, he corrected himself, not curtains—matched perfectly with her ceramic mug collection, each piece methodically arranged on a wooden stand. Those ginger cookies she'd served him, impossibly round and uniform despite her insistence they were homemade, spoke volumes about her character. The entire space radiated a polished efficiency his mother had always strived for but never quite managed to achieve. Taking another sip from his glass, he wondered if the warmth in his chest was genuine attraction or just the whiskey talking. His gaze drifted to her sun-kissed skin, imagining how that golden tan might continue beneath her neckline, while appreciating the practical sensuality in her movements and the clean lines of her profile as he punched in the number she'd written down earlier.

paragraph1: The silence of snow, thought the man sitting just behind the bus driver. If this were the beginning of a poem, he would have called the thing he felt inside him the silence of snow.He'd boarded the bus from Erzurum to Kars with only seconds to spare. He'd just come into the station on a bus from Istanbul --- a snowy, stormy, two-day journey --- and was rushing up and down the dirty wet corridors with his bag in tow, looking for his connection, when someone told him the bus for Kars was leaving immediately.He'd managed to find it, an ancient Magirus, but the conductor had just shut the luggage compartment and, being "in a hurry," refused to open it again. That's why our traveler had taken his bag on board with him; the big dark-red Bally valise was now wedged between his legs. He was sitting next to the window and wearing a thick charcoal coat he'd bought at a Frankfurt Kaufhof five years earlier. We should note straightaway that this soft, downy beauty of a coat would cause him shame and disquiet during the days he was to spend in Kars, while also furnishing a sense of security.
paragraph2: Exhausted from his two-day journey from Istanbul to Erzurum, the man barely managed to catch the bus to Kars, his final destination. The heavy snowfall and winter's unforgiving grip had made his travel particularly challenging. In his rush to board, he found himself clutching his large dark-red Bally valise, as the impatient conductor had refused to open the luggage compartment beneath the bus. Finding a window seat, he settled in, wrapped in his thick charcoal coat purchased in Frankfurt, a garment that served as both protection against the bitter cold and a reminder of his life beyond Turkey's borders. The coat's Western origin stirred complex emotions within him - while it provided warmth and comfort, it also triggered an anticipatory sense of shame and unease about his impending time in Kars. As the bus began its journey through the snow-covered landscape, he found himself enveloped by what he perceived as the "silence of snow," a profound stillness that seemed to mirror his own internal state. The contrast between his Western attire and the traditional setting of his destination weighed heavily on his mind, foreshadowing the cultural tensions he would soon face in the provincial town of Kars.
