Finding a window seat, he settled in, wrapped in his thick charcoal coat purchased in Frankfurt, a garment that served as both protection against the bitter cold and a reminder of his life beyond Turkey's borders. The coat's Western origin stirred complex emotions within him - while it provided warmth and comfort, it also triggered an anticipatory sense of shame and unease about his impending time in Kars. As the bus began its journey through the snow-covered landscape, he found himself enveloped by what he perceived as the "silence of snow," a profound stillness that seemed to mirror his own internal state. The contrast between his Western attire and the traditional setting of his destination weighed heavily on his mind, foreshadowing the cultural tensions he would soon face in the provincial town of Kars.

paragraph1: Dancing with Emily beneath the starlit sky, I hold her close as Sarah Vaughan's enchanting rendition of "April in Paris" fills the air. The gentle sway of our bodies matches the rhythm perfectly, and I'm grateful for this extended version that stretches past eight minutes, postponing any awkward conversations about the diary incident. Her warmth against me feels both comforting and dangerous – a reminder of boundaries I shouldn't cross. When she mentions Charlie and their need to "sort things out," my heart sinks a little, though I try not to let it show. I've always been pretty useless at hiding my feelings, but tonight I'm doing my best to maintain composure. Emily's whispered assurance that I'm a good friend both soothes and stings; it's a reminder of my place in her life, firmly in the friendship zone. The stars above seem to mock my predicament, twinkling indifferently as we move across the outdoor dance floor. I can smell her perfume, feel the soft fabric of her dress beneath my fingers, and hear the subtle catch in her breath when certain memories surface between us. The promise of dinner afterward looms like a lifeline – at least then we'll have something else to focus on besides this delicate dance we're doing, both physically and emotionally.
paragraph2: We placed our wine glasses on the stone table and began to dance. We didn’t dance especially well—we kept bumping our knees—but I held Emily close to me, and my senses filled with the texture of her clothes, her hair, her skin. Holding her like this, it occurred to me again how much weight she'd put on. "You're right, Raymond," she said, quietly in my ear. "Charlie's all right. We should sort ourselves out." "Yes. You should." "You're a good friend, Raymond. What would we do without you?" "If I'm a good friend, I'm glad. Because I’m not much good at anything else. In fact, I’m pretty useless, really." I felt a sharp tug on my shoulder. "Don’t say that," she whispered. "Don't talk like that." Then a moment later, she said again"You’re such a good friend, Raymond." This was Sarah Vaughan's 1954 version of "April in Paris," with Clifford Brown on trumpet. So I knew it was a long track, at least eight minutes. I felt pleased about that, because I knew after the song ended, we wouldn’t dance any more, but go in and eat the casserole. And for all I knew, Emily would reconsider what I’d done to her diary, and decide this time it wasn’t such a trivial offence. What did I know? But for another few minutes at least, we were safe, and we kept dancing under the starlit sky.

paragraph1: Today, Taksim Square is Istanbul's chestnut tree. I've been living in Istanbul for sixty years, and I cannot imagine that there is a single inhabitant of this city who does not have at least one memory connected to Taksim Square. In the nineteen-thirties, the old artillery barracks, which the government now wants to convert into a shopping mall, contained a small football stadium that hosted official matches. The famous club Taksim Gazino, which was the center of Istanbul night life in the nineteen-forties and fifties, stood on a corner of Gezi Park. Later, buildings were demolished, trees were cut down, new trees were planted, and a row of shops and Istanbul's most famous art gallery were set up along one side of the park.In the nineteen-sixties, I used to dream of becoming a painter and displaying my work at this gallery. In the seventies, the square was home to enthusiastic celebrations of Labor Day, led by leftist trade unions and N.G.O.s; for a time, I took part in these gatherings.
paragraph2: Looking back on six decades of life in Istanbul, Taksim Square has been an ever-present witness to both my personal journey and the city's transformation. I vividly remember the old artillery barracks that found new life as a football stadium in the 1930s, where the roar of crowds would echo across the square on match days. The Taksim Gazino was the crown jewel of Istanbul's nightlife during the 1940s and 1950s, its music and laughter spilling onto the streets as the city's elite gathered there evening after evening. I watched as buildings were torn down and replaced by rows of trees, changing the square's character but adding welcome shade to its open spaces. The establishment of the art gallery particularly touched my heart, as I spent countless hours in the 1960s dreaming of seeing my own paintings hanging on its prestigious walls. When the 1970s arrived, the square took on a different energy as I joined the Labor Day marches alongside fellow activists, trade unionists, and NGO workers, our voices rising in unison for workers' rights. Each stone in Taksim Square holds a fragment of my memories, intertwined with the city's evolving story.

In the seventies, the square was home to enthusiastic celebrations of Labor Day, led by leftist trade unions and N.G.O.s; for a time, I took part in these gatherings.

paragraph1: My first encounter with an X-rated film on Canal Plus became a peculiar meditation on the nature of censorship and perception. Without a decoder, the television screen offered only scrambled images and garbled sounds, yet somehow this technical limitation created its own kind of voyeuristic intrigue. Through the electronic snow and distortion, I could make out the silhouette of a woman dressed in corset and stockings, accompanied by a male figure whose movements remained largely mysterious. The visual interference transformed what should have been explicit into something almost abstract – body parts appearing and disappearing like fragments of a dream, their actions impossible to anticipate or fully comprehend. As the scene progressed, the focus shifted deliberately to their most intimate parts, the camera exploring their coupling from various angles until reaching its inevitable conclusion with his release onto her stomach. This experience led me to contemplate how something once considered unviewable had become commonplace in our modern world. More than just a censored peep show, it sparked thoughts about the raw power of unfiltered human experience and how writing might capture that same visceral quality – that mixture of anticipation, wonder, and suspension of judgment that comes with witnessing such primal acts, even through a veil of electronic interference.
paragraph2: This summer, for the first time, I watched an X-rated film on Canal Plus. My television set doesn't have a decoder; the images on the screen were blurred, the words replaced by strange sound effects, hissing and babbling, a different sort of language, soft and continuous. One could make out the figure of a woman in a corset and stockings, and a man. The story was incomprehensible; it was impossible to predict any of their actions or movements. The man walked up to the woman. There was a close-up of the woman's genitals, clearly visible among the shimmerings of the screen, then of the man's penis, fully erect, sliding into the woman's vagina. For a long time this coming and going of the two sex organs was shown from several angles. The cock reappeared, in the man's hand, and the sperm spilled on to the woman's belly. No doubt one gets used to such a sight; the first time is shattering. Centuries and centuries, hundreds of generations have gone by, and it is only now that one can see this—a man's penis and a woman's vagina coming together, the sperm—something one could barely take in without dying has become as easy to watch as a handshake.It occurred to me that writing should also aim for that—the impression conveyed by sexual intercourse, a feeling of anxiety and stupefaction, a suspension of moral judgment.

paragraph1: East of the Tolly Club, after Deshapran Sashmal Road splits in two, there is a small mosque. A turn leads to a quiet enclave. A warren of narrow lanes and modest middle-class homes.Once, within this enclave, there were two ponds, oblong, side by side. Behind them was a lowland spanning a few acres.After the monsoon, the ponds would rise so that the embankment built between them could not be seen. The lowland also filled with rain, three or four feet deep, the water remaining for a portion of the year.The flooded plain was thick with water hyacinth. The floating weed grew aggressively. Its leaves caused the surface to appear solid—green in contrast to the blue of the sky.Simple huts stood here and there along the periphery. The poor waded in to forage for what was edible. In autumn, egrets arrived, their white feathers darkened by the city’s soot, waiting motionless for their prey.In the humid climate of Calcutta, evaporation was slow. But eventually the sun burned off most of the floodwater, exposing damp ground again.
paragraph2: East of the Tolly Club in Calcutta lies a tranquil, often overlooked area that begins beyond a modest mosque and two ponds, whose boundaries blur during the monsoon's relentless downpour. When the rains come, the lowland behind these ponds transforms into a waterlogged expanse, submerged under several feet of water that becomes carpeted with dense water hyacinth, creating an illusion of solid ground. The area's periphery is dotted with humble huts, where impoverished residents make their homes and wade into the waters to gather edible vegetation, their daily survival intertwined with the wetland's offerings. As autumn approaches, soot-stained egrets descend upon this urban wilderness, their once-pristine feathers bearing witness to the city's pollution as they hunt in the flooded terrain. The persistent humidity of Calcutta's climate ensures a gradual evaporation process, and as the waters slowly recede, they reveal the sodden earth beneath, marking the cyclical transformation of this forgotten corner of the city, where nature and human poverty coexist in a delicate balance.

paragraph1: The realization hits me hardest not when I look in the mirror, but when I scroll through social media and see familiar faces from my past transformed by time. These women I once knew, who shared my youth and vitality, are now posting pictures of their grandchildren and celebrating retirement parties. It's a peculiar kind of heartache, watching those who walked the same hallways as me morphing into their autumn years. I find myself particularly haunted by the memory of a girl from my high school days - we were in the same year, both seventeen and drunk on Beatles songs, though her name now escapes me like morning mist. She had this way of humming "Yesterday" during chemistry class, and I wonder if she still does that, perhaps now for her grandchildren. The transformation of my peers into grandmothers forces me to confront not just the passage of time, but the quiet death of youthful dreams we all carried. It's not my own aging that brings this melancholy; rather, it's witnessing the collective journey of my generation from wide-eyed teenagers to silver-haired elders, each face a mirror reflecting back the decades we've traveled.
paragraph2: What I find strange about growing old isn’t that I’ve got older. Not that the youthful me from the past has, without my realizing it, aged. What catches me off guard is, rather, how people from the same generation as me have become elderly, how all the pretty, vivacious girls I used to know are now old enough to have a couple of grandkids. It’s a little disconcerting—sad, even. Though I never feel sad at the fact that I have similarly aged.I think what makes me feel sad about the girls I knew growing old is that it forces me to admit, all over again, that my youthful dreams are gone forever. The death of a dream can be, in a way, sadder than that of a living being.There’s one girl—a woman who used to be a girl, I mean—whom I remember well. I don’t know her name, though. And, naturally, I don’t know where she is now or what she’s doing. What I do know about her is that she went to the same high school as I did, and was in the same year (since the badge on her shirt was the same color as mine), and that she really liked the Beatles.

paragraph1: Juliet stood at the threshold of change as the summer term at Torrance House School for Girls drew to a close in June 1965. Her temporary position, filling in for a teacher battling depression, was ending without the promise of permanence she had quietly hoped for. The weight of uncertainty pressed against her chest as she contemplated her next move, deciding to postpone her homeward journey in favor of visiting a friend up the coast. Her mind wandered to the recent evening spent with Juanita, her sole confidante among the teaching staff, at a screening of "Hiroshima, Mon Amour." The film's aftermath had led to startling confessions between the two women of similar age, with Juanita revealing her ongoing affair with a student's father. Juliet had found herself sharing her own parallel experience, though she had stepped back from pursuing it, mindful of the man's gravely ill wife. Juanita's subsequent wish for her lover's wife to be similarly indisposed had sent a chill through Juliet, particularly as Juanita admitted her fear of losing her position should the wife discover their entanglement.
paragraph2: Halfway through June of 1965, the term at Torrance House School for Girls is over. Juliet has not been offered a permanent job—the teacher she was replacing has recovered from a bout of depression—and she could now be on her way home. Instead, she is taking what she has described as a little detour. A little detour to see a friend who lives up the coast.About a month ago, she went with another teacher—Juanita, the only person on the staff who is near her age, and her only friend—to see a revival of a movie called “Hiroshima, Mon Amour.” Juanita confessed afterward that she herself, like the woman in the picture, was in love with a married man—the father of one of her students. Then Juliet said that she had found herself in somewhat the same situation but had not allowed things to go on because of the tragic plight of the man’s wife, who was a total invalid, more or less brain-dead. Juanita said she wished that her lover’s wife were brain-dead, but she was not—she was vigorous and powerful and could get Juanita fired.

paragraph1: I know deep in your heart, sweet pea, there's that burning desire to be seen, to be acknowledged for who you truly are. We all carry this weight, this yearning for validation, and yes, sometimes that thorny feeling when others shine brighter. I've felt it too - that twist in the gut when someone else's star rises. But don't let these emotions become your master. Channel them instead into your own growth, into the beautiful work of becoming. Your path is uniquely yours, and that's where your energy belongs.
paragraph2: We are all savages inside. We all want to be the chosen, the beloved, the esteemed. There isn’t a person reading this who hasn’t at one point or another had that why not me? voice pop into the interior mix when something good has happened to someone else. But that doesn’t mean you should allow it to rule your life, sweet pea. It means you have work to do.

paragraph1: Living in this corner of India, I find myself strangely removed from the political fervor that grips much of the nation. The independence movement, though forbidden in our maharaja's territory, echoes distantly like a song I can barely hear. My life's course has been meticulously charted - a BA degree, the promise of a scholarship, and an arranged marriage to the college principal's daughter - yet I feel no connection to any of it. The university halls, where I spend my days, seem like a foreign land where I wander aimlessly. I struggle to grasp the significance of Hardy's "The Mayor of Casterbridge," finding its Victorian drama utterly disconnected from my reality. The romantic verses of Shelley, Keats, and Wordsworth float past me like autumn leaves in the wind, their meaning always just beyond my reach. Our professor, with his monotonous dictation of endless notes, has become a symbol of everything that feels artificial in my education. His droning voice fills our classroom as we dutifully transcribe his words, but the knowledge remains superficial, never penetrating deeper than the ink on our pages. Sometimes I wonder if I'm merely playing a part in someone else's story, going through motions that hold no real meaning for me.

Paragraph 1:
Living in this corner of India, I find myself strangely removed from the political fervor that grips much of the nation. The independence movement, though forbidden in our maharaja's territory, echoes distantly like a song I can barely hear. My life's course has been meticulously charted - a BA degree, the promise of a scholarship, and an arranged marriage to the college principal's daughter - yet I feel no connection to any of it. His droning voice fills our classroom as we dutifully transcribe his words, but the knowledge remains superficial, never penetrating deeper than the ink on our pages. Sometimes I wonder if I'm merely playing a part in someone else's story, going through motions that hold no real meaning for me.

paragraph1: Time no longer flows as it once did through my university days, no longer marked by the comforting rhythm of lectures and coffee breaks at La Faluche. I still go through these motions, clutching my books and forcing down bland canteen meals, but everything has shifted since that moment I learned about it - that thing I refuse to name even in my private diary. I watch the other girls, with their empty bellies, laughing and planning their futures with such certainty, while my own has become a maze of undefined moments, each weighted with a decision I never wanted to make. My body moves through familiar spaces - lecture halls, cafeteria queues, library corners - but I feel like a ghost, separated from everyone by this secret that grows heavier each day. I carefully avoid certain words, certain thoughts, referring to it only in vague terms, as if language itself could keep this unwanted reality at bay.
paragraph2: Time ceased to be a series of meaningless days punctuated by university talks and lectures, afternoons spent in cafés and at the library, leading up to exams and the summer vacation, to the future. It became a shapeless entity growing inside me which had to be destroyed at all costs.I attended literature and sociology classes, I ate in the university canteen, I drank coffee twice a day at La Faluche, the students’ hangout. Yet I was living in a different world. There were the other girls, with their empty bellies, and there was me. To convey my predicament, I never resorted to descriptive terms or expressions such as "I’m expecting," "pregnant" or "pregnancy." They endorsed a future event that would never materialize. There was no point naming something that I was planning to get rid of. In my diary I would write, "it" or "that thing,"" only once “pregnant."

paragraph1: Studying the collection of photographs taken by Molly, Clive found himself drawn into an intimate revelation of Garmony's hidden world. Despite the photographer's masterful manipulation of light and shadow, certain masculine features remained unmistakable - the pronounced jaw and prominent Adam's apple stood as stubborn reminders of the subject's true identity. To an uninitiated viewer, these images might have appeared ridiculous or even comical, but Clive experienced something far more profound. The photographs exposed a deeply personal struggle, a private theater where Garmony enacted his feminine alter ego, worlds apart from his carefully constructed public image. There was something remarkably vulnerable in these captured moments, where a powerful man dared to explore his complex identity behind closed doors. This glimpse into Garmony's psychological landscape, his secret yearnings and internal conflicts, stirred an unexpected well of compassion within Clive. Through Molly's lens, the familiar political figure transformed into a more nuanced human being, one whose private battles and desires transcended the simplistic narratives of public life.
paragraph2: Molly's artful lighting could not dissolve the jawbones of a huge head or the swell of an Adam's apple. How he looked and how he felt he looked were probably very far apart. They should have been ridiculous, these photographs, they -were ridiculous, but Clive was somewhat awed. We knew so little about each other. We lay mostly submerged, like ice floes, with our visible social selves projecting only cool and white. Here was a rare sight below the waves, of a man's privacy and turmoil, of his dignity upended by the overpowering necessity of pure fantasy, pure thought, by the irreducible human element-mind. For the first time Clive considered what it might be like to feel kindly toward Garmony. It was Molly who had made it possible. In the third of the pictures he wore a boxy Chanel jacket and his gaze was turned downward; on some mental screen of selfhood he was a demure and feasible woman, but to an outsider what showed was evasion.

paragraph1: During the preliminary stages of netting her fourth husband, whom she’d flagged as a kink addict, Verna had gone even further. She’d told him she’d been named for "The Rite of Spring," a highly sexual ballet that ended with torture and human sacrifice. He’d laughed, but he’d also wriggleda sure sign of the hook going in.Now she says, "And you’re . . . Bob." It’s taken her years to perfect the small breathy intake, a certified knee-melter. "Yes," Bob says. "Bob Goreham," he adds, with a diffidence he surely intends to be charming. Verna smiles widely to disguise her shock. She finds herself flushing with a combination of rage and an almost reckless mirth. She looks him full in the faceyes, underneath the thinning hair and the wrinkles and the obviously whitened and possibly implanted teeth, it’s the same Bob—the Bob of fifty-odd years before. Mr. Heartthrob, Mr. Senior Football Star, Mr. Astounding Catch, from the rich, Cadillac-driving end of town where the mining-company big shots lived. Mr. Shit, with his looming bully’s posture and his lopsided joker’s smile.
paragraph2: Verna's calculated pursuit of her fourth husband unfolds with meticulous precision as she weaves an elaborate tale about her name's origins, connecting it to a sensual ballet performance she never witnessed. Her target, a man she believes harbors kinky inclinations, seems to be falling for her carefully crafted persona. During their interaction, she deploys her signature move—a deliberately breathy intake of air—while conversing with Bob, a technique she's perfected over years of seduction. Bob Goreham responds with an endearing shyness that almost makes her falter, especially when recognition dawns upon her. The man before her is none other than the former high school celebrity, the local golden boy who once commanded attention wherever he went. A complex mixture of rage and dark humor bubbles within her as memories of his past glory days surface, yet she maintains her facade with practiced ease, never letting her true emotions betray the carefully constructed image she's presenting. The irony of their current encounter adds an unexpected layer to her seduction strategy, one she hadn't anticipated but finds darkly amusing.

paragraph1: Striking a pose with her arm flexed and bandana tied just so, Prue did her best impression of "Rosie the Riveter," attempting to spark a shared memory of the 1940s with George, though that wasn't his real name. Her playful gesture hung in the air as George's mind wandered to darker corners of that decade, remembering not the celebrated workforce icon but the desperate child he had been, scrounging through streets and begging for scraps to survive. A particular memory surfaced of him defacing a film star's poster, his young hands tearing at the glossy paper with bitter satisfaction, though he kept this recollection locked away from Prue's eager eyes. Instead, he leaned back in his deck chair, the ice in his Scotch clinking softly as he took another slow drag from his cigarette. His response to her theatrical nostalgia was simply a smile, one that revealed his unusually long canines, while the gulf between her romanticized version of the war years and his harsh reality stretched wide and deep between them, unacknowledged in the warm afternoon air.
paragraph2: "It’s the forties look," she says to George, hand on her hip, doing a pirouette. "Rosie the Riveter. From the war. Remember her?" George, whose name is not really George, does not remember. He spent the forties rooting through garbage heaps and begging, and doing other things unsuitable for a child. He has a dim memory of some film star posed on a calendar tattering on a latrine wall. Maybe this is the one Prue means. He remembers for an instant his intense resentment of the bright, ignorant smile, the well-fed body. A couple of buddies had helped him take her apart with the rusty blade from a kitchen knife they’d found somewhere in the rubble. He does not consider telling any of this to Prue.George is sitting in a green-and-white striped canvas deck chair, reading the Financial Post and drinking Scotch. The ashtray beside him overflows with butts; many women have tried to cure him of smoking; many have failed. He looks up at Prue from behind his paper and smiles his foxy smile. This is a smile he does with the cigarette held right in the center of his mouthon either side of it his lips curl back, revealing teeth. He has long canines, miraculously still his.

paragraph1: "Our love remains steadfast, princess, even if the memories slip away like shadows at dusk," Axl whispered, reaching for her trembling hand. The princess turned to him, her eyes clouded with worry. "But Axl, how can we be certain? Our memories are like raindrops falling from leaves, disappearing one by one until nothing remains to remind us of what we once shared." Her voice quivered with uncertainty. Axl drew her closer, his heart heavy with his own unspoken doubts. "The strength of our bond transcends mere memories, my love. It's woven into the very fabric of our beings," he assured her, though privately questioning if love could truly survive without the foundation of shared experiences. The princess leaned into his embrace, seeking comfort in his warmth. "Perhaps you're right," she murmured, "yet I fear each forgotten moment creates a distance between us that even our hearts cannot bridge." Axl remained silent, knowing that his confident words masked his own deep-seated fears about their love's resilience in the face of such profound forgetting.
paragraph2: "What are you saying, princess? How can our love wither? Isn't it stronger now than when we were foolish young lovers?""But Axl, we can't even remember those days. Or any of the years between. We don't remember our fierce quarrels or the small moments we enjoyed and treasured. We don't remember our son or why he's away from us.""We can make all those memories come back, princess. Besides, the feeling in my heart for you will be there just the same, no matter what I remember or forget. Don't you feel the same, princess?""I do, Axl. But then again I wonder if what we feel in our hearts today isn't like these raindrops still falling on us from these soaked leaves above, even though the sky itself long stopped raining. I'm wondering if without our memories, there's nothing for it but our love to fade and die.""God wouldn't allow such a thing, princess." Axl said this quietly, almost under his breath, for he had himself felt an unnamed fear welling up within him.

paragraph1: I've wondered myself, boatman. And I think now it’s no single thing changed my heart, but it was gradually won back by the years shared between us. That may be all it was, boatman. A wound that healed slowly, but heal it did. There was a morning not long ago, the dawn brought with it the first signs of this spring, and I watched my wife still asleep though the sun already lit our chamber.And I knew the last of the darkness had left me. So we came on this journey, sir, and now my wife recalls our son crossing before us to this island, so his burial place must be within its woods or perhaps its gentle shores. Boatman, I’ve spoken honestly to you, and I hope it doesn’t cast your earlier judgement of us in doubt. For I suppose there’s some would hear my words and think our love flawed and broken. But God will know the slow tread of an old couple’s love for each other, and understand how black shadows make part of its whole.
paragraph2: I must tell you, dear boatman, how my heart found its way back through the gentle persistence of my wife's devotion over our years together. That dawn when I watched her sleeping form, bathed in the first light of morning, something profound shifted within me, marking the end of those dark years that had gripped my soul. The realization washed over me like a cleansing tide, and I knew then what we needed to do. Together, we made that sacred journey to the island where our son rests, a pilgrimage that both haunted and healed us. I share this with you now, hoping you won't think differently of me, though I know our love story might seem imperfect to those who judge from the outside. But God, in His infinite wisdom, understands the depth of our connection, how it weathered storms and emerged stronger, even if bearing scars. This love, though marked by loss and redemption, has become something more profound than I ever imagined possible in those earlier days of darkness.

paragraph1: Once she has parked outside the building, she saysYou can give me your number. But I don’t know if I’ll get in touch or not. O.K.? And, if you don’t hear from me, it won’t be because I haven’t thought about you. I will think about you. I just have to figure out what’s best. He says he understands, and he keys the number into her phone. The time on the dashboard is 8:56 a.m. He gets out of the car, and she watches him walk up to the main entrance of the building, carrying his black suitcase. One of the wheels on the case is hanging askew, broken—she can see that now. That’s probably why he carries it, instead of using the wheels.At the entrance, he turns back and looks at her over his shoulder. Then he’s gone, the door swinging shut behind him. The door of her own workplace, with its flat rectangular handle, with one glass panel broken at the bottom and patched with brown tape. She has been contained before, contained and directed, by the trappings of ordinary life. Now she no longer feels contained or directed by these forces; no longer directed by anything at all. Life has slipped free of its netting. She can do very strange things now; she can find herself a very strange person. Young men can invite her into holiday cottages for sexual reasons. It means nothing. That isn’t trueit means something, but the meaning is unfamiliar.
paragraph2: She parked the car outside the building, telling him he could give her his number though she wasn't sure if she'd use it, watching as he input the digits into her phone while the dashboard clock showed 8:56 a.m. in its green digital glow. He stepped out into the morning air, choosing to carry his suitcase with its broken wheel rather than drag it across the pavement, and turned back once to look at her before disappearing through the building's entrance. Sitting alone in the driver's seat, she found herself contemplating how her life had shifted, no longer feeling bound by the usual parameters that had once seemed to direct every decision, every moment. This new freedom felt both liberating and strange, like walking in a familiar room where all the furniture had been rearranged in the dark. She thought about how young men now invited her into their worlds, into their beds, casual propositions that should mean nothing yet somehow carried an weight she couldn't quite define. These invitations, including the phone number now stored in her device, existed in a space between meaningless and meaningful, much like the broken wheel on his suitcase – a small imperfection that somehow made the entire scene more real, more memorable. The morning light streamed through her windshield, and she sat there, aware that she was experiencing something that felt both insignificant and monumental at the same time.

And, if you don’t hear from me, it won’t be because I haven’t thought about you. I will think about you. I just have to figure out what’s best. He says he understands, and he keys the number into her phone. The time on the dashboard is 8:56 a.m. He gets out of the car, and she watches him walk up to the main entrance of the building, carrying his black suitcase. One of the wheels on the case is hanging askew, broken—she can see that now. That’s probably why he carries it, instead of using the wheels.At the entrance, he turns back and looks at her over his shoulder. Then he’s gone, the door swinging shut behind him. The door of her own workplace, with its flat rectangular handle, with one glass panel broken at the bottom and patched with brown tape. She has been contained before, contained and directed, by the trappings of ordinary life. Now she no longer feels contained or directed by these forces; no longer directed by anything at all. Life has slipped free of its netting. She can do very strange things now; she can find herself a very strange person. Young men can invite her into holiday cottages for sexual reasons. It means nothing. That isn’t trueit means something, but the meaning is unfamiliar.

Paragraph 2:
She parked the car outside the building, telling him he could give her his number though she wasn't sure if she'd use it, watching as he input the digits into her phone while the dashboard clock showed 8:56 a.m. in its green digital glow. He stepped out into the morning air, choosing to carry his suitcase with its broken wheel rather than drag it across the pavement, and turned back once to look at her before disappearing through the building's entrance. Sitting alone in the driver's seat, she found herself contemplating how her life had shifted, no longer feeling bound by the usual parameters that had once seemed to direct every decision, every moment. This new freedom felt both liberating and strange, like walking in a familiar room where all the furniture had been rearranged in the dark. She thought about how young men now invited her into their worlds, into their beds, casual propositions that should mean nothing yet somehow carried an weight she couldn't quite define. These invitations, including the phone number now stored in her device, existed in a space between meaningless and meaningful, much like the broken wheel on his suitcase – a small imperfection that somehow made the entire scene more real, more memorable. The morning light streamed through her windshield, and she sat there, aware that she was experiencing something that felt both insignificant and monumental at the same time.

paragraph1: On Christmas Day, Marcia will spend the morning in her warm kitchen, methodically preparing the traditional feast while the aroma of roasting turkey and root vegetables fills the house. As she works, Noriega will lie restless in his guarded room, his sleep punctuated by disturbing dreams that blur the lines between his past misdeeds and future possibilities. The day will unfold with small disappointments, like Eric's lost piece of the Berlin Wall that had appeared so promising in his Christmas stocking, now somewhere between the couch cushions or perhaps swept away with discarded wrapping paper. The eggnog, consumed steadily throughout the afternoon, will leave Marcia with a pleasant buzz that slowly transforms into a melancholic haze. She will find herself retreating to the bathroom, where she'll sit on the cool tile floor, cradling the cat she coaxed out from under the bed, her quiet tears falling into its fur. These moments alone will force her to confront the relentless march of time—children grown and gone, others never arriving, and the persistent feeling that life's changes have caught her unprepared despite the season's promises of renewal and hope. The television will murmur in the background with news she should care about but can't quite focus on, her mind too full of what was and what might have been.
paragraph2: Then Christmas Day will come. It will be a Monday, yet another Monday, pastel blue, and they will eat a turkey and some more root vegetables and a mince pie that Marcia will have finally got around to making, while Noriega sleeps unmothered in a room in a house ringed with soldiers, dreaming of how he got there or of how he will get out, or dreaming of killing he has done or would like to do, or dreaming of nothing, his round face pocked and bleak as an asteroid. The piece of the Berlin Wall that Marcia has given Eric in his stocking will get lost under the chesterfield. The cat will hide.Marcia will get a little drunk on the eggnog, and later, after the dishes are done, she will cry silently to herself, shut into the bathroom and hugging in her festive arms the grumbling cat, which she will have dragged out from under a bed for this purpose. She will cry because the children are no longer children, or because she herself is not a child anymore, or because there are children who have never been children, or because she can’t have a child anymore, ever again. Her body has gone past too quickly for her; she has not made herself ready.It’s all this talk of babies, at Christmas. It’s all this hope. She gets distracted by it, and has trouble paying attention to the real news.

paragraph1: Here we come to the heart of the matterI’ve never left Istanbul – never left the houses, streets and neighbourhoods of my childhood. Although I’ve lived in other districts from time to time, fifty years on I find myself back in the Pamuk Apartments, where my first photographs were taken and where my mother first held me in her arms to show me the world. I know this persistence owes something to my imaginary friend, and to the solace I took from the bond between us. But we live in an age defined by mass migration and creative immigrants, and so I am sometimes hard-pressed to explain why I’ve stayed not only in the same place, but the same building. My mother’s sorrowful voice comes back to me, ‘Why don’t you go outside for a while, why don’t you try a change of scene, do some travelling …?’Conrad, Nabokov, Naipaul – these are writers known for having managed to migrate between languages, cultures, countries, continents, even civilisations. Their imaginations were fed by exile, a nourishment drawn not through roots but through rootlessness; mine, however, requires that I stay in the same city, on the same street, in the same house, gazing at the same view. Istanbul’s fate is my fateI am attached to this city because it has made me who I am.
paragraph2: From my earliest memories, Istanbul has been more than just a city - it's been the cornerstone of my existence, with the Pamuk Apartments standing as the epicenter of my world. Though I've ventured into different districts throughout my life, some invisible thread always pulls me back to these familiar walls where I spent my childhood. Perhaps this magnetic attraction stems from the imaginary friend who once kept me company in these very rooms, creating a psychological anchor that I've never quite been able to break free from. When I consider the lives of literary giants like Conrad, Nabokov, and Naipaul, who found their creative voice through constant movement and displacement, I sometimes question my own sedentary nature. In this age where millions traverse borders and rebuild their lives in foreign lands, I find myself struggling to articulate why I remain so firmly rooted to this single building in this singular city. My mother's voice still echoes in my memories, urging me to explore the world beyond Istanbul's boundaries, yet here I remain. I've come to accept that my identity is inextricably woven into Istanbul's fabric - my fate dancing in perfect synchronicity with the city's own destiny, making it impossible to separate where Istanbul ends and I begin.

paragraph1: In the end it wasn’t much. A pranksterish half love that took on tragic undertones as he descended into the depths of heroin addiction and I came close to tumbling in after him. There was drama at my leaving, though it was more about my yearning for heroin than about my feelings for him. By autumn I was fifteen hundred miles away, having returned to the city where I actually lived, shaken and drained. By winter I’d come into the clear and continued on with my life, working at my job and filing for divorce, staying away from heroin and boys with blue hair.Time passed, and he became not himself in my memory but an emblem of my youthful folly, my experimental daring, my authentic scrabble to find a way in the world. I was nostalgic for him on occasion, though not even remotely heartbroken. I wished him well in my mind, though I doubted in a far-off way that “well” was how he was doing. He was not an actual, potentially suffering person, not a boy I’d once known who had his own hopes and dreams, but a symbol of my own period of liberation and self-destruction. He was part of a story I got to tell, but not the story itself.
paragraph2: Looking back on my relationship with him feels like excavating artifacts from another life, one where our pranksterish half-love spiraled into the dark undertow of his heroin addiction. I watched him sink deeper while barely managing to keep my own head above those murky waters, my growing appetite for the drug eventually exceeding any genuine feelings I had left for him. The irony wasn't lost on me - that I ultimately fled not because I stopped caring, but because the pull of heroin threatened to drag me under too. By the time I put enough miles and months between us, I had already begun reconstructing my life, filing divorce papers and steering clear of both needles and complicated men with haunted eyes. Now he exists more as a cautionary tale than a person, a symbol of youthful recklessness stripped of his own dreams and aspirations. Sometimes I catch myself wondering about him with a bittersweet nostalgia that lacks real heartache, hoping he found his way to safer shores while knowing better than to believe it. He was never meant to be the protagonist of my story, just a chapter in my own journey toward understanding who I needed to become - and who I needed to leave behind.

paragraph1: The Female Body has many uses. It’s been used as a door-knocker, a bottle-opener, as a clock with a ticking belly, as something to hold up lampshades, as a nutcracker, just squeeze the brass legs together.It sells cars, beer, shaving lotion, cigarettes, hard liquor; it sells diet plans and diamonds, and desire in tiny crystal bottles. Is this the face that launched a thousand products? You bet it is, but don’t get any funny big ideas, honey, that smile is a dime a dozen.It does not merely sell, it is sold. Money flows into this country or that country, flies in, practically crawls in, suitful after suitful, lured by all those hairless pre-teen legs. Listen, you want to reduce the national debt, don’t you? Aren’t you patriotic? That's the spirit. That’s my girl.She’s a natural resource, a renewable one luckily, because those things wear out so quickly. They don’t make ‘em like they used to. Shoddy goods.
paragraph2: The female body emerges as a versatile commodity in modern commerce, shapeshifting to suit various marketing needs while maintaining its core function as a seductive selling tool. Like a chameleon of capitalism, it drapes itself across luxury vehicles, beckons from beer advertisements, and promises transformation through cosmetic products, all while fueling a global economic engine that runs on desire and aspiration. This corporeal currency transcends borders and cultures, its value perpetually renewed yet paradoxically diminished through endless reproduction and exploitation. Society treats the female form as a renewable resource, harvesting its appeal with the same calculated efficiency as timber from a managed forest, though with far less concern for sustainability. In the grand marketplace of ideas and products, women's bodies become interchangeable units of commercial exchange, mass-produced like shoddy goods in a factory of flesh, their worth measured not in human terms but in profit margins and sales figures. The system perpetuates itself, turning the female form into both the product and the means of production, creating a cycle of commodification that seems to have no end.

paragraph1: In each apartment, there was also a locked glass cabinet displaying Chinese porcelains, teacups, silver sets, sugar bowls, snuffboxes, crystal glasses, rosewater pitchers, plates, and censers, which no one ever touched, although among them I sometimes found hiding places for miniature cars. There were unused desks inlaid with mother-of-pearl, turban shelves on which there were no turbans, and Japanese and Art Nouveau screens behind which nothing was hidden. There, in the library, gathering dust behind the glass, were my uncle’s medical booksin the twenty years since he’d immigrated to America, no one had touched them. To my childish mind, these rooms were furnished not for the living but for the dead.
paragraph2: Walking through these rooms feels like exploring an elaborate mausoleum, where every pristine object seems frozen in time, untouched by human hands. The locked glass cabinet stands as a silent sentinel, guarding its precious contents - delicate Chinese porcelains, fragile teacups, and gleaming silver sets that have never known the warmth of tea or the clinking of spoons. My eyes drift to the empty turban shelves and decorative screens, their intricate patterns collecting nothing but dust. Most haunting are my uncle's medical books, abandoned for two decades since he left for America, their pages yellowing and stiff from disuse. The furniture, though ornate and expensive, bears no indentation of bodies or signs of daily life. These rooms, with their perfectly preserved artifacts, seem more like shrines to absent lives than spaces meant for the living, and I can't help but feel like an intruder in this museum of suspended animation.

paragraph1: At first I was discouraged by the obvious limitations of our exchanges. These were emphasized by the fact that, although he spoke fairly good French, I could not express myself in his language. Later I realized that this situation spared me the illusion that we shared a perfect relationship, or even formed a whole. Because his French strayed slightly from standard use and because I occasionally had doubts about the meaning he gave to words, I was able to appreciate the approximate quality of our conversations. From the very beginning, and throughout the whole of our affair, I had the privilege of knowing what we all find out in the end the man we love is a complete stranger.
paragraph2: When he speaks French, his words flow with a certain grace, yet I find myself grappling with our linguistic divide, unable to reciprocate in his mother tongue. At first, this barrier frustrated me deeply, making me feel inadequate and disconnected. But gradually, I've come to embrace these imperfect exchanges between us. The halting conversations and occasional misunderstandings serve as constant reminders that what we have isn't some fairy-tale romance where two souls merge seamlessly into one. Instead, our language gap preserves the beautiful mystery between us, keeping alive the truth that no matter how close we become, he remains fundamentally unknowable. His foreignness, apparent in every accented word, has become precious to me – a testament to his distinct identity that I can love but never fully possess.

paragraph1: Standing under the dim streetlight after our poetry performance, I watched as Melissa adjusted her camera settings, the professional equipment looking almost ceremonial in her practiced hands. She'd caught Bobbi and me just as we were leaving the venue, cigarette smoke curling around us while we discussed her photography, which we'd admired online before. Her movements were deliberate and artistic, matching the sophisticated demeanor I'd noticed during her earlier interactions inside. The conversation flowed easily between drags of shared cigarettes, and when the bar finally shut its doors at midnight, Melissa's invitation to continue our evening at her place felt both surprising and somehow inevitable. We piled into a taxi bound for Monkstown, the three of us settling into a comfortable silence punctuated by occasional laughter. During the ride, I found myself rehearsing witty remarks in my head, determined to present my most engaging self in this impromptu late-night gathering. There was something thrilling about following a near-stranger home, something that made me feel both reckless and alive. I kept stealing glances at Melissa's profile in the passing streetlights, wondering what her house would reveal about her, while Bobbi chatted animatedly from the backseat, seemingly unfazed by the spontaneity of our adventure.
paragraph2: Bobbi and I first met Melissa at a poetry night in town, where we were performing together. Melissa took our photograph outside, with Bobbi smoking and me self-consciously holding my left wrist in my right hand, as if I was afraid the wrist was going to get away from me. Melissa used a big professional camera and kept lots of different lenses in a special camera pouch. She chatted and smoked while taking the pictures. She talked about our performance and we talked about her work, which we’d come across on the Internet. Around midnight the bar closed. It was starting to rain then, and Melissa told us we were welcome to come back to her house for a drink. We all got into the back of a taxi together and started fixing up our seat belts. Bobbi sat in the middle, with her head turned to speak to Melissa, so I could see the back of her neck and her little spoon-like ear. Melissa gave the driver an address in Monkstown and I turned to look out the window. A voice came on the radio to say the wordseighties . . . pop . . . classics. Then a jingle played. I felt excited, ready for the challenge of visiting a stranger’s home, already preparing compliments and certain facial expressions to make myself seem charming.

Melissa gave the driver an address in Monkstown and I turned to look out the window. A voice came on the radio to say the wordseighties . . . pop . . . classics. Then a jingle played. I felt excited, ready for the challenge of visiting a stranger’s home, already preparing compliments and certain facial expressions to make myself seem charming.

paragraph1: Contemplating eternal return has fundamentally altered my perception of reality, making me question how we judge moments when viewed through the lens of infinite repetition. I find myself unable to definitively condemn even the most troubling events, as their ephemeral nature seems to dissolve in the face of eternal recurrence. This complexity struck me most profoundly while browsing a book about Hitler recently. Despite the devastating loss of several family members in the Holocaust, I was unexpectedly moved by the portraits within its pages. The images triggered memories of my childhood, creating an unsettling juxtaposition between personal nostalgia and historical horror. The sepia-toned photographs, reminiscent of my own family albums, forced me to confront the uncomfortable intersection of individual memory and collective tragedy. This experience revealed how our personal histories can sometimes collide with broader historical narratives in ways that defy simple moral categorization.
paragraph2: Let us therefore agree that the idea of eternal return implies a perspective from which things appear other than as we know themthey appear without the mitigating circumstance of their transitory nature. This mitigating circumstance prevents us from coming to a verdict. For how can we condemn something that is ephemeral, in transit? In the sunset of dissolution, everything is illuminated by the aura of nostalgia, even the guillotine. Not long ago, I caught myself experiencing a most incredible sensation. Leafing through a book on Hitler, I was touched by some of his portraitsthey reminded me of my childhood. I grew up during the war; several members of my family perished in Hitler's concentration camps; but what were their deaths compared with the memories of a lost period in my life, a period that would never return?

paragraph1: On 16 Nov, 1989, I phoned the Soviet embassy in Paris and asked to speak to Mr S. The switchboard operator did not reply. After a long silence, a woman’s voice said‘You know, Mr S returned to Moscow yesterday.’ I immediately hung up. I felt as if I’d heard this sentence before, over the phone. The words were not the same but they had the same meaning, the same weight of horror, and were just as impossible to believe. Later, I remembered the announcement of my mother’s death, three and a half years earlier, how the nurse at the hospital had said‘Your mother passed away this morning after breakfast.’The Berlin Wall had fallen several days before. The Soviet regimes established in Europe were toppling one after the other. The man who had just returned to Moscow was a faithful servant of the USSR, a Russian diplomat posted in Paris.I had met him the previous year on a writers’ junket to Moscow, Tbilisi, and Leningrad, a voyage he had been assigned to accompany. We had spent the last night together, in Leningrad. After returning to France, we continued to see each other. The ritual was invariable. He would ring to ask if he could come around to see me in the afternoon or evening, or, more rarely, a day or two later. He would arrive and stay just a few hours, which we spent making love. Then he left, and I would live in wait for his next call.
paragraph2: On that fateful November morning in 1989, I dialed the familiar number of the Soviet embassy in Paris, my fingers trembling slightly as I waited for a response. When the woman's voice informed me that Mr. S had departed for Moscow just the day before, an overwhelming wave of dread washed over me, eerily reminiscent of that devastating call about my mother's death three and a half years ago. The timing seemed cruelly significant, coinciding with the momentous fall of the Berlin Wall and the gradual unraveling of Soviet power across Europe. My mind wandered back to our first meeting during my writers' tour of Moscow, Tbilisi, and Leningrad the previous year, where Mr. S, a Russian diplomat, had entered my life with the force of an unexpected storm. Our subsequent encounters in France had fallen into a pattern of brief, intense meetings, dominated by physical intimacy and unspoken understanding. These rendezvous, though fleeting, had become the axis around which my entire existence revolved. I found myself living from one call to the next, my days measured not by hours but by the intervals between his contacts. The news of his sudden return to Moscow felt like more than just a departure; it was as if the ground beneath my feet had shifted, mirroring the seismic political changes sweeping across Eastern Europe. His absence left a void that seemed to echo the broader upheaval of that transformative period, making my personal loss feel inexplicably connected to the historic collapse of an entire political system.

paragraph1: I squeezed her hand and said nothing. I knew little about Keats or his poetry, but I thought it possible that in his hopeless situation he would not have wanted to write precisely because he loved her so much. Lately I'd had the idea that Clarissa's interest in these hypothetical letters had something to do with our own situation, and with her conviction that love that did not find its expression in a letter was not perfect. In the months after we'd met, and before we'd bought the apartment, she had written me some beauties, passionately abstract in the ways our love was different from and superior to any that had ever existed. Perhaps that's the essence of a love letter, to celebrate the unique. I had tried to match her, but all that sincerity would permit me were the facts, and they seemed miraculous enough to mea beautiful woman loved and wanted to be loved by a large, clumsy, balding fellow who could hardly believe his luck.
paragraph2: Contemplating Keats's poetry and his personal life, I've often wondered if the intensity of his emotions prevented him from writing love letters, as if the depth of feeling was too overwhelming to capture in mere correspondence. This thought strikes a particular chord when I think about Clarissa's fascination with imagined letters between Keats and his love, perhaps seeing parallels with our own story. In those early, heady days of our relationship, Clarissa would send me these incredibly passionate letters, each one a celebration of what we had found together, expressing something uniquely ours. I tried my best to respond in kind, but my attempts always felt constrained by my own earnestness. All I could really convey was my genuine amazement that someone like Clarissa - so beautiful, so complete - could love someone like me. Looking back, I wonder if my simple, heartfelt responses were more authentic than any elaborate declarations I might have attempted, much like how Keats's silence might have spoken volumes about the depth of his own feelings.

paragraph1: As a simple man, I've always preferred to experience life directly, watching and absorbing rather than theorizing about it. This approach has given me the peculiar sensation of having lived multiple lives, each distinct yet somehow interconnected. I often find myself at the fountain, observing the dancers with their fluid movements, but I feel separated from them by an invisible barrier, like a sheet of glass that keeps me perpetually on the outside looking in. Years ago, someone painted "Soul Brother" outside my house during a time of unrest, and that gesture still haunts me, making me question my true connection to others and my place in the community. There was a time when I felt seamlessly woven into the fabric of everyday life, but everything changed the day I caught my reflection in the mirror and realized I needed to break free. This newfound freedom, while liberating, has made me hyperaware of my physical existence and the mundane yet essential tasks required to maintain it until my final day comes.
paragraph2: I am a simple man who decided to act and see for himself, and it is as though I have had several lives. I do not wish to add to these. Some afternoons I walk to the circle with the fountain. I see the dancers but they are separated from me as by glass. Once, when there were rumours of new burnings, someone scrawled in white paint on the pavement outside my houseSoul Brother. I understand the words; but I feel, brother to what or to whom? I was once part of the flow, never thinking of myself as a presence. Then I looked in the mirror and decided to be free. All that my freedom has brought me is the knowledge that I have a face and have a body, that I must feed this body and clothe this body for a certain number of years. Then it will be over.

paragraph1: She prints on the card, “Gerald, Sorry I couldn’t be with you. This is all the rage. Love, K.”When evening has fallen and the party must be in full swing, she calls a delivery taxi. Cheryl will not distrust anything that arrives in such an expensive bag. She will open it in public, in front of everyone. There will be distress, there will be questions. Secrets will be unearthed. There will be pain. After that, everything will go way too far.She is not well; her heart is pounding, space is wavering once more. But outside the window it’s snowing—the soft, damp, windless flakes of her childhood. She puts on her coat and goes out, foolishly. She intends to walk just to the corner, but when she reaches the corner she goes on. The snow melts against her face like small fingers touching. She has done an outrageous thing, but she doesn’t feel guilty. She feels light and peaceful and filled with charity, and temporarily without a name.
paragraph2: Seated at her desk, she carefully penned the deceptive note to Gerald, her elegant handwriting masking the calculated nature of her plan. The message expressed regret for missing the gathering while hinting at a fashionable gift to come, though she knew the delivery would be anything but pleasant. Her stomach churned with physical discomfort, yet her mind felt remarkably clear as she imagined Cheryl's inevitable public unveiling of the package and the subsequent unraveling of carefully guarded secrets. The prospect of the ensuing chaos brought her an unexpected sense of serenity rather than guilt. Stepping outside into the gently falling snow, she embraced the anonymity of the white landscape, each snowflake stirring memories of more innocent childhood days. The familiar crunch beneath her feet and the crisp winter air seemed to validate her actions, as if nature itself understood the necessity of her orchestrated disruption. In this moment of calculated revenge, she found herself paradoxically at peace, knowing that while others would soon face their truths, she had already found her liberation.

paragraph1: Standing here in these winding streets, I can hardly believe how different everything feels from my memories of this place. Years ago, I would traverse the English countryside with boundless energy and certainty, each journey filling me with excitement and purpose. This village, in particular, was once like a second home - a place where I had left an indelible mark on the community and knew every corner intimately. Now, as I shuffle through these narrow lanes between ancient stone cottages, nothing seems familiar. The weak lamplight casts confusing shadows, and the paths that should lead to the village square seem to mock my failing sense of direction. I pause repeatedly, trying to orient myself using landmarks that have either vanished or transformed beyond recognition. The weight of time presses heavily on my shoulders as I realize how much both this place and I have changed. My once-confident steps have become hesitant, and the darkness between the buildings feels more oppressive than ever. Exhausted and fighting a growing sense of defeat, I've decided to approach one of these cottages and knock, hoping to find a familiar face - someone who might remember the person I used to be in this village that now feels like a stranger's home.
paragraph2: There was a time when I could travel England for weeks on end and remain at my sharpest—when, if anything, the travelling gave me an edge. But now that I am older I become disoriented more easily. So it was that on arriving at the village just after dark I failed to find my bearings at all. I could hardly believe I was in the same village in which not so long ago I had lived and come to exercise such influence.There was nothing I recognized, and I found myself walking forever around twisting, badly lit streets hemmed in on both sides by the little stone cottages characteristic of the area. The streets often became so narrow I could make no progress without my bag or my elbow scraping one rough wall or another. I persevered nevertheless, stumbling around in the darkness in the hope of coming upon the village square—where I could at least orient myself—or else of encountering one of the villagers. When after a while I had done neither, a weariness came over me, and I decided my best course was just to choose a cottage at random, knock on the door, and hope it would be opened by someone who remembered me.

paragraph1: Suddenly, it was all before him, the prospect of freedom, of working whenever he wanted, of inviting home some of the women he had seen on the Falmer campus, lolling on the steps outside the library, of returning to his unexamined self and being guiltlessly shot of Maisie. All this caused a tear of gratitude to roll down his cheek. He also felt fierce impatience for her to be gone. It crossed his mind to offer to drive her to the station now, but there were no trains from Lewes at 3 A.M., and she had not packed. Hearing his sob, she reached for the bedside light and, leaning over to look into his face, saw the dampness around his eyes. Firmly and deliberately she whispered, “I will not be blackmailed, Michael. I will not, repeat not, be emotionally manipulated by you into staying.”Was ever a marriage dissolved so painlessly? Within a week she had left for the hill farm in Powys. In the course of a year they exchanged a couple of postcards. Then one came from an ashram in India, where she remained for three years and from where she sent one day her cheery acceptance of a divorce, all papers duly signed. He did not see her until his twenty-sixth birthday, at which she appeared with a shaved head and a jewel in her nose. Many years later, he spoke at her funeral. Perhaps it was the ease of their parting in the old rectory that made him so incautious about marrying again, and again
paragraph2: Michael lay in the darkness, his mind swirling with conflicting emotions as he contemplated the imminent end of his marriage to Maisie. The promise of freedom tantalized him, painting vivid pictures of an unrestrained future where he could bring home other women and shed the weight of marital obligations that had become increasingly suffocating. A solitary tear of gratitude rolled down his cheek as he imagined this liberation, though his anticipation was tinged with an urgent desire for Maisie's departure. She, however, proved more perceptive than he anticipated, abruptly illuminating the room and declaring her refusal to be emotionally manipulated into remaining. The dissolution of their union proceeded with remarkable speed, as Maisie relocated to a hill farm in Powys within the week, eventually finding her way to an ashram in India. Their communication dwindled to a sparse exchange of postcards over the years, with the final correspondence bringing news of Maisie's willingness to divorce. Their paths wouldn't cross again until Michael's twenty-sixth birthday, when she appeared before him as someone fundamentally changed from the woman he had known. The surprising ease with which their marriage had unraveled seemed to set a precedent in Michael's life, as he found himself moving through subsequent marriages with a similar detachment, collecting wives and divorces with an almost casual regularity that echoed the pattern established in that first, fateful separation.

paragraph1: Growing up in our modest neighborhood, I've always been acutely aware of the stark divide between our lives and those of the professionals who seem to inhabit a different world entirely. While I've accepted my place in the working class, I've channeled all my hopes and dreams into my younger brother's future. He has the spark, the potential to cross that invisible line and become something more than what our circumstances dictated. Unlike our father, who has made peace with his inability to read and write, often turning it into a self-deprecating joke while relying on my uncle, a law clerk in the city, to handle his paperwork, I refuse to accept such limitations for my brother. I see how the other half lives - their manicured lawns, private schools, and summer vacations - and I'm determined that my brother will one day walk among them as an equal. Every extra shift I work, every sacrifice I make, is an investment in his escape from our working-class reality into the professional world I can only observe from afar.
paragraph2: Ordinary for me, but for my brother it wasn’t going to be like that. He was going to break away; he was going to be a professional man; I was going to see to that. For the rich and the professional the world is not ordinary. I know, I see them. Where you build a hut, they build a mansion; where you have mud and a pará-grass field, they have a garden; when you kill time on a Sunday, they have parties. We all come out of the same pot, but some people move ahead and some people get left behind. Some people get left behind so far they don’t know and they stop caring .Like my father. He couldn’t read and write and he didn’t care. He even joke about his illiteracy, slapping his fat arms and laughing. He say he is happy to leave that side of life to his younger brother, who is a law clerk in the city.

paragraph1: For the next three years, Eileen and Aidan lived in a one-bedroom apartment in the south city center, illegally downloading foreign films, arguing about how to split the rent, taking turns cooking and washing up. Lola and Matthew got engaged. Alice won a lucrative literary award, moved to New York, and started sending Eileen e-mails at strange hours of the day and night. In December, Simon called Eileen and told her that Alice was back in Dublin and had been admitted to a psychiatric hospital. Eileen was sitting on the sofa, her phone held to her ear, while Aidan was at the sink, rinsing a plate under the tap. After she and Simon had finished speaking, she sat there on the phone, saying nothing, and he said nothing. They were both silent. Right, he said eventually. I’ll let you go. A few weeks later, Eileen and Aidan broke up. He told her there was a lot going on and they both needed space. He went to live with his parents, and she moved into a two-bedroom apartment with a married couple. Lola and Matthew decided to have a small wedding in the summer. Simon went on answering his correspondence promptly, taking Eileen out for lunch now and then, and keeping his personal life to himself. It was April, and several of Eileen’s friends had recently left or were in the process of leaving Dublin. She attended the leaving parties, wearing her dark-green dress with the buttons, or her yellow dress with the matching belt. In living rooms with low ceilings and paper lampshades, people talked to her about the property market. My sister’s getting married in June, she would tell them. That’s exciting, they would reply. You must be so happy for her. Yeah, it’s funny, Eileen would say. I’m not.
paragraph2: Eileen and Aidan settled into a rhythm in their small apartment, their days filled with shared movie nights and quiet negotiations over dishes and laundry. Their domestic routine unfolded against a backdrop of significant changes in their social circle, most notably Lola, Eileen's sister, announcing her engagement to Matthew with characteristic enthusiasm. The news coincided with Alice's literary success and subsequent move to New York, a departure that left a noticeable void in their friend group. When Alice's mental health deteriorated, leading to her hospitalization back in Dublin, the news reached Eileen through an uncomfortable conversation with Simon. The exchange, laden with unspoken tensions, took place while Aidan lingered in the background, creating a triangle of awkward silence. Their own relationship began to unravel slowly, like a loosened thread, until Aidan finally packed his belongings and returned to his parents' house. Eileen found herself relocating to a new living arrangement with another couple, her life once again in transition. She moved through various social gatherings with a peculiar detachment, listening to friends discuss their plans to leave Dublin while mechanically participating in conversations about Lola's wedding preparations. The city seemed to be slowly emptying of familiar faces, each departure marking another shift in the landscape of her life. Throughout these changes, Eileen maintained a careful distance from her own emotions, observing the reshaping of her world with the same detached interest one might give to watching clouds change shape across a winter sky.

paragraph1: One Kashmiri morning in the early spring of 1915, my grandfather Aadam Aziz hit his nose against a frost-hardened tussock of earth while attempting to pray. Three drops of blood plopped out of his left nostril, hardened instantly in the brittle air and lay before his eyes on the prayer-mat, transformed into rubies. Lurching back until he knelt with his head once more upright, he found that the tears which had sprung into his eyes had solidified, too; and at that moment, as he brushed diamonds contemptuously from his lashes, he resolved never again to kiss earth for any god or man. This decision, however, made a hole in him, a vacancy in a vital inner chamber, leaving him vulnerable to women and history. Unaware of this at first, despite his recently completed medical training, he stood up, rolled the prayer-mat into a thick cheroot, and holding it under his right arm surveyed the valley through clear, diamond-free eyes.The world was new again. After a winter's gestation in its eggshell of ice, the valley had beaked its way out into the open, moist and yellow. The new grass bided its time underground; the mountains were retreating to their hill-stations for the warm season. (In the winter, when the valley shrank under the ice, the mountains closed in and snarled like angry jaws around the city on the lake.)
paragraph2: That fateful morning in Kashmir's early spring of 1915 forever altered my grandfather Aadam Aziz's relationship with faith and destiny. As he bent down to pray, his nose struck the frost-hardened earth with unexpected force, creating a collision that would reshape his spiritual journey. I can still picture the scene: drops of his blood falling like precious rubies onto the prayer mat, while his tears, transformed by the crystalline morning light, resembled scattered diamonds on the frozen ground. In that moment of pain and clarity, my grandfather made an unshakeable vow - never again would he bow before any god or mortal. This decisive rejection of submission, however, left a peculiar emptiness within him, a void that would later make him unusually susceptible to the influence of women and the sweeping tides of history. Standing there, unaware of his newfound vulnerability, he gazed across the valley as winter's icy grip gradually loosened its hold. The landscape before him was transforming, mirroring his internal metamorphosis, as the first signs of spring began to emerge from beneath the thawing snow. Nature's renewal seemed to echo his personal awakening, though he couldn't have known then how this morning's events would ripple through generations to come.

paragraph1: Quichotte's life had become a testament to modern-day isolation, with his social circle having dwindled to near nonexistence over the years. His remaining connections consisted primarily of a handful of commercial travelers and an assortment of virtual acquaintances on Facebook, ranging from lonely hearts seeking companionship to those who regularly shared provocative content. When he enthusiastically announced his latest scheme involving Miss Salma R. on his social media feed, his online "friends" responded with overwhelming disapproval. Their digital protests manifested through a barrage of frown emojis, disapproving Bitmojis, and satirical GIFs featuring Salma R. herself, all collectively suggesting they viewed his plan as nothing short of madness. These virtual companions, though distant and largely anonymous, made their concerns clear about what they perceived as his potentially dangerous and misguided intentions. However, Quichotte remained steadfast in his resolve, brushing aside their digital warnings with the same determination that had characterized his increasingly isolated existence, choosing to pursue his seemingly delusional plan regardless of the unanimous opposition he faced online.
paragraph2: The truth was that Quichotte had almost no friends anymore—no social group, no cohort, no posse, no real pals—having long ago abandoned the social whirl. On his Facebook page, he had “friended” or “been friended by” a small and dwindling group of commercial travellers like himself, as well as by an assortment of lonely hearts, braggarts, exhibitionists, and salacious ladies behaving as erotically as the social medium’s somewhat puritanical rules allowed. Every single one of these quote-unquote “friends” saw his plan, when he had enthusiastically posted it, for what it was—a harebrained scheme, verging on lunacy—and attempted to dissuade him, for his own good, from stalking or harassing Miss Salma R. In response to his post there were frown emojis and Bitmojis wagging fingers at him reprovingly, and there were GIFs of Salma R. herself, crossing her eyes, sticking out her tongue, and rotating a finger by her right temple, all of which added up to the universally recognized set of gestures meaning “cray cray.” However, Quichotte would not be deterred.

paragraph1: Every night, I settle into bed with my book, finding solace in the gentle hum of cars passing beneath my apartment window. The steady stream of traffic has become an essential lullaby, accompanying my nightly reading ritual until my eyes grow heavy. But sometimes, I wake in those peculiar hours when the world seems to hold its breath - the witching hours when even the most restless drivers have found their way home. In these moments of absolute quiet, sleep becomes elusive, and my mind wanders down darker paths. The silence feels oppressive, almost tangible, and I lie awake counting the minutes until dawn. My thoughts spiral into uncomfortable territories, pondering life's uncertainties and anxieties that seem magnified in the stillness. It's only when the first rays of sunlight peek through my curtains, accompanied by the familiar sound of morning commuters, that I feel the weight of the night lifting from my chest.
paragraph2: This evening as I read in bed I hear the roar of cars that speed down the road below my apartment. And the fact of their passing makes me aware of my own stillness. I can only fall asleep when I hear them. And when I wake up in the middle of the night, always at the same time, it’s the absolute silence that interrupts my sleep. That’s the hour when there’s not a single car on the road, when no one needs to get anywhere. My sleep grows lighter and lighter and then it abandons me entirely. I wait until someone, anyone, drives by. The thoughts that come to roost in my head in those moments are always the gloomiest, also the most precise. That silence, combined with the black sky, takes hold of me until the first light returns and dispels those thoughts, until I hear the presence of lives passing along the road below me.
