paragraph1: That fateful storm raged through both our houses that night, but the real tempest was yet to come when we discovered what that wretched villain had done. I still remember the shock waves through our literary circles when it emerged he'd stolen entire passages for "The Tumult," shamelessly lifting concepts and words from my old friend's work. The scandal was devastating, forcing publishers to withdraw and destroy every copy of that plagiarized book, but what emerged from those ashes was truly remarkable. My friend, who had always been a quiet hero in our circle, had endured years of setbacks and hardship, watching silently as his work was stolen. Yet fate has a way of setting things right - his genuine brilliance could no longer be contained or denied. I watched with a mixture of joy and vindication as his original works were finally recognized, becoming modern classics that sparked a fierce bidding war for rights. The awards and commercial success that followed were merely confirmation of what we'd always known about his talent. Looking back now, I can't help but reflect on how the plagiarist's self-destructive behavior ultimately served to illuminate the true genius among us, though the scars of that betrayal never fully healed.
paragraph2: Much of the rest you will know. It was the perfect story. A wild storm surged through my house and Jocelyn’s. All the correct ingredients. A wretched villain, a quiet hero. A national treasure knocked flying from his pedestal, dishonest fingers deep in the till, an old friend down on his luck, betrayed, whole passages lifted, whole conception stolen, characters, too, no plausible explanation from the guilty man, whose friends now understood his reluctance to publish, tens of thousands of copies of “The Tumult” removed from the shops and pulped. And the old friend? Nobly refused to condemn, unavailable for interviews—and, of course, a genius revealed, best book in years, a modern classic, a mild man loved by his students and colleagues, dumped by his publisher, books out of print. Then a scramble to procure the rights, all the rights, to the backlist as well as “Dance,” agents and auctions involved, film rights and movie people involved. Then the prizes—Booker, Whitbread, Medici, Critics Circle, in one long noisy banquet. Copies of the Gorgeous edition selling for five thousand pounds on AbeBooks. Then, as the dust settled, and with my book still “flying” off the shelves, thoughtful articles on the nature of literary kleptomania, the strange compulsion to be caught, and acts of artistic self-destruction in late middle age.

paragraph1: A person is nothing but his image. Philosophers can tell us that it doesn't matter what the world thinks of us, that nothing matters but what we really are. But philosophers don't understand anything. As long as we live with other people, we are only what other people consider us to be. Thinking about how others see us and trying to make our image as attractive as possible is considered a kind of dissembling or cheating. But does there exist another kind of direct contact between my self and their selves except through the mediation of the eyes? Can we possibly imagine love without anxiously following our image in the mind of the beloved? When we are no longer interested in how we are seen by the person we love, it means we no longer love.
paragraph2: I've always wrestled with the philosophical claim that our true identity exists independently of how others see us, finding it increasingly difficult to separate my sense of self from the reflections in others' eyes. When I interact with people, I wonder if there's ever a pure, unfiltered connection between us, or if everything is inevitably mediated through the images we project and perceive. Even in my most intimate relationships, I find myself carefully maintaining certain impressions, not out of deception but because I believe caring about how we're seen is fundamental to love itself. How can someone claim to love another while being completely indifferent to how that person perceives them? My identity feels like a complex interplay between my internal world and the countless ways I'm reflected in others' consciousness, making it impossible to determine where the 'real me' truly resides.

paragraph1: When that first pregnancy was well advanced, around Christmas time, Avie had received a brief letter from Grace."I hear you are married and expecting. You may not have heard I have dropped out of college, due to some troubles I have had with my health and my nerves. I often think of our talks and particularly the dream you told me about. It still scares the daylights out of me. Love, Grace."Avie remembered then the conversation with Marsha. The colitis. The tone of Grace’s letter seemed off kilter, with some pleading note in it that made her put off answering. She herself was feeling quite happy at the time, full of practical concerns, light-years away from whatever stuff they had talked about in college. She didn’t know if she could ever find her way back there or find a way to talk to Grace as she was now. And later, of course, she got too busy.She asks Royce if he heard anything from Grace, ever."No. No. Why should I?" "I just thought." "No.""I thought you might have looked her up later on."Not a good idea."She has disappointed him. Prying. Trying to get at some spot of live regret right under the ribs. A woman.
paragraph2: Avie sat with Grace's letter in her hands, her own pregnancy making the words feel heavier than they should. The correspondence detailed Grace's withdrawal from college and her subsequent battles with health issues and frayed nerves, intertwining with a haunting dream Avie had once shared. The memory of past conversations with Marsha surfaced, particularly one about colitis, adding another layer of complexity to Grace's desperate tone. Something about the pleading nature of the letter made Avie hesitate, and she found herself postponing her response indefinitely. During this period, Avie was wrapped up in the cocoon of her new life, feeling increasingly disconnected from the deep, philosophical discussions she once shared with Grace during their college days. The busyness of life provided a convenient excuse to maintain this distance, and the connection continued to fade. When she finally broached the subject with Royce, seeking any information about Grace's whereabouts or well-being, his response was dismissive and tinged with disappointment. He interpreted her questioning as unnecessary dwelling on past regrets, creating a subtle tension between them that mirrored the unresolved nature of her relationship with Grace.

paragraph1: The summer I was 18 I was driving down a country road with my mother. This was in the rural county where I grew up and all of the roads were country, the houses spread out over miles, hardly any of them in sight of a neighbor. Driving meant going past an endless stream of trees and fields and wildflowers. On this particular afternoon, my mother and I came upon a yard sale at a big house where a very old woman lived alone, her husband dead, her kids grown and gone.“Let’s look and see what she has,” my mother said as we passed, so I turned the car around and pulled into the old woman’s driveway and the two of us got out.We were the only people there. Even the old woman whose sale it was didn’t come out of the house, only waving to us from a window. It was August, the last stretch of time that I would I live with my mother. I’d completed my first year of college by then and I’d returned home for the summer because I’d gotten a job in a nearby town. In a few weeks I’d go back to college and I’d never again live in the place I called home, though I didn’t know that then.
paragraph2: Driving along the winding country roads with Mom that August afternoon, I couldn't help but feel nostalgic about the familiar landscapes I'd grown up with. The scattered farmhouses and rolling hills had been the backdrop of my childhood, though I didn't realize this would be one of my last times seeing them as a resident rather than a visitor. Fresh from my first year of college, I was savoring these moments of simple companionship with my mother, even if I didn't fully appreciate their significance at the time. When we spotted the yard sale signs outside Mrs. Henderson's solitary white house, Mom suggested we stop, and I agreed without hesitation. There was something poignant about the elderly woman sitting alone in her lawn chair, surrounded by pieces of her life she'd decided to part with. The late summer sun cast long shadows across her carefully arranged tables, where old china sets and weathered books told stories of decades past. Looking back now, that impromptu stop feels like a perfect snapshot of my last summer at home - unplanned, ordinary, yet somehow meaningful in ways I couldn't have understood then. Mom and I wandered between the tables, picking up trinkets and sharing quiet observations, while cicadas hummed in the background and time seemed to slow down just for us.

paragraph1: She sat there, contemplating Dr. Byford's clinical explanation of her condition—a psychological disconnect between her authentic feelings and outward actions that had roots in her girlhood trauma. The diagnosis made sense, yet it opened up deeper questions about whether today's young women faced the same internal battles she had endured. Through social media posts and casual conversations with her nieces, she observed the familiar patterns: girls still struggling to reconcile their true selves with society's expectations, still trapped in the age-old paradigm of being desired rather than expressing desire. Despite Howard's optimistic views about evolving gender roles, she saw little fundamental change. The evidence was everywhere—in the epidemic of eating disorders, the hidden scars of self-harm, and the small daily deceptions women employed to navigate their world. The faces might be different, but the underlying struggle remained eerily similar to her own past.
paragraph2: She was a woman still controlled by the traumas of her girlhood. It made more sense to put her three-year-old self in the dock. As Dr Byford explained, she was really the victim of a vicious, peculiarly female psycological disordershe felt one thing and did another. She was a stranger to herself.And were they still like that, she wondered - these new girls, this new generation? Did they still feel one thing and do another? Did they still only want to be wanted? Were they still objects of desire instead of - as Howard might put it - desiring subjects? No, she could see no serious change. Still starving themselves, still reading women's magazines that explicitly hate women, still cutting themselves with little knives in places they think can't be seen, still faking their orgasms with men they dislike, still lying to everybody about everything.

paragraph1: Throughout their friendship, Claire had satirized his scrupulous intellectualism, just as he had teased her about her artistic ideals. It was her old joke that Howard was only human in a theoretical sense. This was the general feeling in Wellington toohis students found it near impossible to imagine that Howard should have a wife, a family, that he went to the bathroom, that he felt love. Claire was not as naive as the students; she knew he did love, and intensely, but she also saw that it was not articulated in him in the normal way. Something about his academic life had changed love for him, changed its nature. Of course, without Kiki, he couldn’t function – anyone who knew him knew that much. But it was the kind of marriage you couldn’t get a handle on. He was bookish, she was not; he was theoretical, she political. She called a rose a rose. He called it an accumulation of cultural and biological constructions circulating around the mutually attracting binary poles of nature/artifice. Claire had always been curious how a marriage like that worked.”
paragraph2: Claire often found herself puzzled by Howard's peculiar way of navigating the world, frequently teasing him about being human only in theory—a sentiment that resonated deeply with his bewildered students who couldn't quite reconcile their professor's abstract intellectualism with the notion that he, too, experienced mundane human moments like grocery shopping or feeling heartbreak. While others might see Howard as an impenetrable fortress of academic discourse, Claire possessed a unique insight into his capacity for love, even if it manifested through the lens of theoretical frameworks and scholarly references. The dynamic between Howard and his wife Kiki particularly fascinated Claire, as their partnership seemed to defy conventional logic: Howard, eternally lost in the realm of ideas and abstractions, had somehow found his anchor in Kiki, whose political consciousness and practical groundedness appeared at odds with his theoretical meanderings. Yet Claire recognized that this unlikely union was far from arbitrary; Kiki's presence in Howard's life served as an essential tether to reality, making their marriage, however puzzling to outsiders, an indispensable foundation for Howard's functioning in the real world, beyond the safety of his beloved books and theories.

Yet Claire recognized that this unlikely union was far from arbitrary; Kiki's presence in Howard's life served as an essential tether to reality, making their marriage, however puzzling to outsiders, an indispensable foundation for Howard's functioning in the real world, beyond the safety of his beloved books and theories.

paragraph1: My mother keeps stealing glances at me during our drive to the station, her unease palpable in the confined space of the car. I can tell she wants to say something meaningful but doesn't quite know how to bridge the gap that's formed between us. When she asks me to take my feet off the dashboard, I comply without protest, watching her hands grip the steering wheel a little tighter. Her questions about money and what the doctor said feel like attempts to normalize the situation, to find solid ground in this shifting landscape of our relationship. I give her short answers, all while wrestling with the crushing realization that my identity as a "normal person" has somehow slipped away. The truth hits me hard: my suffering isn't special or unique, and it won't magically transform me into someone else, whether I choose to voice it or keep it buried inside. As we pull up to the station, I mutter a quick thank you and step out of the car, leaving behind both my mother and the weight of her concerned glances.
paragraph2: On the way to the station that evening my mother kept glancing at me, as if something about my behaviour was off-putting, and she wanted to reprimand me for it but couldn’t decide what it was. Eventually she told me to take my feet off the dashboard, which I did. You must be relieved, she said. Yeah, delighted. How are you managing for money? Oh, I said. I’m okay. She glanced in the rear-view mirror. The doctor didn’t say anything else, did he? she said. No, that was it. I looked out the window at the station. I had the sense that something in my life had ended, my image of myself as a whole or normal person maybe. I realised my life would be full of mundane physical suffering, and that there was nothing special about it. Suffering wouldn’t make me special, and pretending not to suffer wouldn’t make me special. Talking about it, or even writing about it, would not transform the suffering into something useful. Nothing would. I thanked my mother for the lift to the station and got out of the car.

paragraph1: There Verna spent the days peeling potatoes and scrubbing floors and scouring toilets along with her fellow-delinquents. They wore gray maternity dresses and gray wool stockings and clunky brown shoes, all paid for by generous donations, they were informed. In addition to their scouring and peeling chores, they were treated to bouts of prayer and self-righteous hectoring. What had happened to them was justly deserved, the speeches went, because of their depraved behavior, but it was never too late to redeem themselves through hard work and self-restraint. They were cautioned against alcohol, tobacco, and gum chewing, and were told that they should consider it a miracle of God if any decent man ever wanted to marry them.Verna’s labor was long and difficult. The baby was taken away from her immediately so that she would not get attached to it. There was an infection, with complications and scarring, but it was all for the best, she overheard one brisk nurse telling another, because those sorts of girls made unfit mothers anyway. Once she could walk, Verna was given five dollars and a bus ticket and instructed to return to the guardianship of her mother, because she was still a minor.
paragraph2: Verna shuffles through her daily routine alongside other fallen girls, their collective punishment manifesting in endless cycles of potato peeling, floor scrubbing, and toilet scouring. Their identical gray maternity dresses, donated wool stockings, and heavy brown shoes strip away any remnants of individuality, marking them as society's cautionary tales. Daily prayer sessions and stern lectures hammer home their moral failings, with authority figures constantly reminding them that their predicament stems from their own misdeeds, offering salvation only through backbreaking work and rigid self-control. The girls endure repeated warnings against various vices - alcohol, tobacco, and even the seemingly innocent act of chewing gum - while being reminded that finding a future husband would be nothing short of divine intervention. After enduring an agonizing labor, Verna faces the cruel reality of immediate separation from her baby, a policy designed to prevent maternal bonding. Her postpartum illness becomes merely another opportunity for nurses to dismiss her as an unfit mother, their harsh words reaching her fever-addled consciousness. Finally, with minimal resources and a bus ticket in hand, she's sent back to her mother's care, her youth paradoxically both her burden and her only remaining protection.

paragraph1: On this spring afternoon in Istanbul, my partner and I find ourselves intertwined on a musty mattress, our bodies moving in perfect synchronicity as the warmth from the bustling streets seeps through the walls of our cool sanctuary. The contrast between the heat outside and the refreshing atmosphere in our room only heightens our sensations, while a gentle breeze drifts through the window, kissing our skin with its delicate chill. Our rhythm momentarily falters when we hear the unmistakable sounds of young boys playing football in the garden below, their innocent game punctuated by not-so-innocent swearing that floats up to our window. We catch each other's eyes and share a knowing smile, amused by how our own indecencies mirror theirs in an oddly innocent way. But this moment of shared humor dissolves quickly as our passion reignites, and we lose ourselves once again in our intimate dance, forgetting both the children's playful profanities and my partner's earring that has somehow slipped away in our fervor.
paragraph2: Outside the sky was shimmering as it does only in Istanbul in the spring. In the streets people still in their winter clothes were perspiring, but inside shops and buildings, and under the linden and chestnut trees, it was still cool. We felt the same coolness rising from the musty mattress on which we were making love, the way children play, happily forgetting everything else. A breeze wafted in through the balcony window, tinged with the sea and linden leaves; it lifted the tulle curtains, and they billowed down again in slow motion, chilling our naked bodies. From the bed of the back bedroom of the second- floor apartment, we could see a group of boys playing football in the garden below, swearing furiously in the May heat, and as it dawned on us that we were enacting, word for word, exactly those indecencies, we stopped making love to look into each other’s eyes and smile. But so great was our elation that the joke life had sent us from the back garden was forgotten as quickly as the earring.

paragraph1: I watched her diminish in the doorway, her yellow dress a bright spot against the darkening threshold, her smile fixed and brave. The guilt gnawed at me as the distance grew between us, and I felt like a coward for leaving this way. My mind drifted to those evenings when I would return from the cinema, mentally rehearsing answers to her inevitable questions, preparing myself for her searching gaze. Now, as the train pulled away, I could picture her alone in the house, methodically removing traces of my existence – perhaps folding away clothes I'd left behind or rearranging furniture to fill the spaces I once occupied. Through the window, I observed the Sernam buildings sliding past, then the railway workers' houses growing smaller and smaller, each vanishing sight a reminder of what I was leaving behind, of what I was choosing to forget.
paragraph2: After kissing me at the door, she tried to keep talking. Last image of herin the doorway, rounded arms framing her heavy silhouette in a yellow dress—her prettiest one, tight around the chest and the belly—a wide, fixed smile. This time, once again, I felt that I was leaving badly, in a cowardly way.I took the shortest route to the train, the one that goes past the Shell station. There, in the old days, I’d stop to prepare myself for her interrogating look when I returned from the cinema, bracing myself, wiping off what was left of my lipstick. What will people think of you?On the train, I couldn’t help imagining her, washing the dishes in a solitary silence, all sign of my presence soon erased. I watched C. disappear—the Sernam buildings, the railway workers’ housing beside the tracks.

paragraph1: I am amazed sometimes to think how old I am. I can remember when the streets of the town I lived in were sprinkled with water to lay the dust in summer, and when girls wore waist cinchers and crinolines that could stand up by themselves, and when there was nothing much to be done about things like polio and leukemia. Some people who got polio got better, crippled or not, but people with leukemia went to bed, and, after some weeks’ or months’ decline in a tragic atmosphere, they died.It was because of such a case that I got my first job, in the summer holidays, when I was thirteen.Old Mrs. Crozier lived on the other side of town. Her stepson, Bruce, who was usually called Young Mr. Crozier, had come safely home from the war, where he had been a fighter pilot, had gone to college and studied history, and got married, and now he had leukemia. He and his wife were staying with Old Mrs. Crozier.
paragraph2: At my age, memories flood back like waves, taking me to a time when life moved at a different pace. I vividly remember those summer days when water trucks would dampen the dusty streets, and women would gracefully walk by in their waist cinchers and crinolines, their silhouettes a stark contrast to today's casual fashions. Back then, we lived under the shadow of different fears – polio was every mother's nightmare, and leukemia was practically a death sentence. It was actually leukemia that led to my first job when I was thirteen, a position that came about in the most unfortunate circumstances. Young Mr. Crozier, who had survived the war as a fighter pilot and later became a history scholar, was battling the disease. The irony wasn't lost on any of us – he had dodged bullets in the sky only to face this invisible enemy at home. He and his wife had moved in with Old Mrs. Crozier, his stepmother, as the illness took its toll, transforming their lives and, indirectly, leading to my early entry into the workforce.

Her stepson, Bruce, who was usually called Young Mr. Crozier, had come safely home from the war, where he had been a fighter pilot, had gone to college and studied history, and got married, and now he had leukemia. He and his wife were staying with Old Mrs. Crozier.

Paragraph 2:

paragraph1: My father vanished into thin air in 1959, leaving behind a seven-year-old me and countless unanswered questions. Years later, we discovered he had been living in a modest hotel in Montparnasse, Paris, where he would spend hours at a local café, occasionally catching glimpses of Jean-Paul Sartre. His peculiar existence was initially sustained by my grandmother's generous financial support, drawn from the substantial railroad fortune my grandfather had amassed during his lifetime. The arrangement continued undisturbed until twenty-five years after my grandfather's passing, when the family wealth began to show signs of depletion. My grandmother, faced with dwindling resources, made the difficult decision to cut off my father's funding. This abrupt end to his comfortable exile transformed him into yet another struggling Turkish intellectual in Paris, joining the ranks of many others who had sought refuge in the city of lights, only to find themselves grappling with financial hardship while clinging to their intellectual pursuits.
paragraph2: In 1959, when I was seven years old, my father went missing under mysterious circumstances; several weeks later, we received word that he was in Paris, living in a cheap hotel in Montparnasse. He was filling up the notebooks that he would later give to me, and from time to time, from the Café Dome, he’d spot Jean-Paul Sartre passing in the street. At first, my grandmother sent him money from Istanbul. My grandfather had made a fortune in railroads. Under my grandmother’s tearful gaze, my father and my uncles hadn’t yet managed to squander their entire inheritance—not all of the apartments had been sold. But, twenty-five years after her husband’s death, my grandmother decided that the money was running out and she stopped subsidizing her bohemian son in Paris.This was how my father joined the long line of penniless and miserable Turkish intellectuals who had been walking the streets of Paris for a century already.

The arrangement continued undisturbed until twenty-five years after my grandfather's passing, when the family wealth began to show signs of depletion. My grandmother, faced with dwindling resources, made the difficult decision to cut off my father's funding. This abrupt end to his comfortable exile transformed him into yet another struggling Turkish intellectual in Paris, joining the ranks of many others who had sought refuge in the city of lights, only to find themselves grappling with financial hardship while clinging to their intellectual pursuits.

Paragraph 2:
In 1959, when I was seven years old, my father went missing under mysterious circumstances; several weeks later, we received word that he was in Paris, living in a cheap hotel in Montparnasse. He was filling up the notebooks that he would later give to me, and from time to time, from the Café Dome, he’d spot Jean-Paul Sartre passing in the street. At first, my grandmother sent him money from Istanbul. My grandfather had made a fortune in railroads. Under my grandmother’s tearful gaze, my father and my uncles hadn’t yet managed to squander their entire inheritance—not all of the apartments had been sold. But, twenty-five years after her husband’s death, my grandmother decided that the money was running out and she stopped subsidizing her bohemian son in Paris.This was how my father joined the long line of penniless and miserable Turkish intellectuals who had been walking the streets of Paris for a century already.

paragraph1: It was 1960. I was twenty. It was suggested that it was time I learned to drive. Driving skills were not considered as essential then as they are now—people, especially young people, didn’t automatically have cars. Still, knowing how to drive could be useful. My father would teach me, said he.Easier said than done. After I’d mistaken the gas pedal for the brake and almost rammed his car into a stone wall, this driving plan was quietly dropped. No tears shed by meI had other things on my mind, such as existentialism, moon goddesses, and the writing of tortured poetry.My next attempt was in 1964. This time, the heroic would-be driving teacher was a very nice boyfriend. His father was a used-car dealer known as Frank the Pirate, so this boyfriend had a Frank the Pirate special to drive. (The car later exploded.)After three sessions—enjoyed by me with merry glee, endured by the nice boyfriend with white knuckles and clenched teeth—he gave up. “I can’t teach you,” he said. “You have no fears.”This was news to me. I thought I had lots of fears—thunderstorms, forest fires, bears—but these were not the right kind of fears for driving. I was not afraid of other drivers, of the edges of roads, or of huge chunks of steel whizzing toward me at insane speeds.
paragraph2: Learning to drive in the 1960s proved to be quite an adventure, marked by two memorable but unsuccessful attempts that revealed my unconventional approach to operating a vehicle. My father's initial effort to teach me at age twenty came to an abrupt halt after a near-accident that left us both rattled, though I remained largely unfazed. Truth be told, I was more captivated by contemplating life's deeper meanings and composing poetry than mastering the intricacies of driving, making my father's decision to abandon the lessons rather inconsequential to me. A second attempt emerged in 1964 when my boyfriend, whose father was the enigmatic Frank the Pirate, volunteered to guide me through the process. However, my fearless attitude behind the wheel, which I saw as natural and liberating, proved to be a source of constant anxiety for him. While most driving instructors worry about their students being too timid, my boyfriend found himself in the unusual position of dealing with someone who showed absolutely no hesitation or concern on the road. Eventually, he came to the realization that my fearlessness, though admirable in other contexts, was potentially hazardous when combined with a two-ton vehicle, leading him to join my father in the ranks of those who had given up on teaching me to drive.

paragraph1: That night of January 20-21 still haunts me, though I no longer mark it as an anniversary in the traditional sense. What was once a source of deep anguish has gradually transformed into something more profound - a crucial stepping stone toward understanding what it means to bring new life into this world. The physical and emotional toll of that experience opened my eyes to the sacrifices of parenthood, something I had always viewed with hesitation and uncertainty. For years, I carried the weight of my inaction during those dark hours, letting guilt gnaw at my conscience until I finally found solace in putting words to paper. Through writing, I've discovered my calling: to transmute these raw, visceral experiences into something universal, something that bridges the gap between my private suffering and our shared human condition. Perhaps this is why I was meant to endure that ordeal - to serve as a translator of sorts, converting intimate bodily and psychological experiences into language that resonates with others who've walked similar paths, helping them feel less alone in their own journeys of loss and transformation.
paragraph2: For many years I celebrated the night of January 20-21 as an anniversary.Now I know that this ordeal and this sacrifice were necessary for me to want to have children. To accept the turmoil of reproduction inside my body and, in turn, to let the coming generations pass through me.I have finished putting into words what I consider to be an extreme human experience, hearing on life and death, time, law, ethics and taboo ‒ an experience that sweeps through the body.I have rid myself of the only feeling of guilt in connection with this eventthe fact that it had happened to me and I had done nothing about it. A sort of discarded present. Among all the social and psychological reasons that may account for my past, of one I am certainthese things happened to me so that I might recount them. Maybe the true purpose of my life is for my body, my sensations and my thoughts to become writing, in other words, something intelligible and universal, causing my existence to merge into the lives and heads of other people.
text_input:
You are given two pararaphs of creative writing for a given writing instruction.
Your task is to determine which paragraph is overall better in terms of writing quality.

Paragraph 1:
That night of January 20-21 still haunts me, though I no longer mark it as an anniversary in the traditional sense. What was once a source of deep anguish has gradually transformed into something more profound - a crucial stepping stone toward understanding what it means to bring new life into this world. The physical and emotional toll of that experience opened my eyes to the sacrifices of parenthood, something I had always viewed with hesitation and uncertainty. For years, I carried the weight of my inaction during those dark hours, letting guilt gnaw at my conscience until I finally found solace in putting words to paper. Through writing, I've discovered my calling: to transmute these raw, visceral experiences into something universal, something that bridges the gap between my private suffering and our shared human condition. Perhaps this is why I was meant to endure that ordeal - to serve as a translator of sorts, converting intimate bodily and psychological experiences into language that resonates with others who've walked similar paths, helping them feel less alone in their own journeys of loss and transformation.

Paragraph 2:
For many years I celebrated the night of January 20-21 as an anniversary.Now I know that this ordeal and this sacrifice were necessary for me to want to have children. To accept the turmoil of reproduction inside my body and, in turn, to let the coming generations pass through me.I have finished putting into words what I consider to be an extreme human experience, hearing on life and death, time, law, ethics and taboo ‒ an experience that sweeps through the body.I have rid myself of the only feeling of guilt in connection with this eventthe fact that it had happened to me and I had done nothing about it. A sort of discarded present. Among all the social and psychological reasons that may account for my past, of one I am certainthese things happened to me so that I might recount them. Maybe the true purpose of my life is for my body, my sensations and my thoughts to become writing, in other words, something intelligible and universal, causing my existence to merge into the lives and heads of other people.

paragraph1: I stood before the dilapidated building, its peeling paint and rusty fixtures a stark contrast to the elegant piano recital I'd expected to attend. Pressing the intercom button repeatedly, I was met with nothing but hollow silence, each unanswered buzz echoing my growing disappointment. The gray sky loomed overhead as I waited, hoping someone else would arrive or show some sign that I wasn't the only one expecting an event today. The stillness was unsettling, broken only by the occasional distant car horn and rustling leaves. After what felt like an eternity of shifting from foot to foot and checking my phone for any missed notifications, I finally accepted the reality that nothing was happening here today. Clutching my bouquet of red flowers, I reluctantly turned away and began walking toward the bus stop, already dreading my mother's inevitable questions about where I'd been and why I was returning with the flowers I'd so carefully selected. At the station, I briefly considered throwing them away, watching other commuters hurry past, but the thought of wasting money on flowers that cost nearly half my weekly allowance stopped me. Instead, I held them closer, their vibrant petals a splash of color against the dreary afternoon.
paragraph2: Paint had peeled off it in spots, and it was starting to rust. I couldn’t think of anything else to do, so I pressed the intercom button one more time, holding it down longer, but the result was the same as before—deep silence.With no idea what to do, I leaned back against the gate and stood there for some ten minutes. I had a faint hope that someone else might show up before long. But no one came. There was no sign of any movement, either inside the gate or outside. There was no wind. No birds chirping, no dogs barking. As before, an unbroken blanket of gray cloud lay above.I finally gave up—what else could I do?—and with heavy steps started back down the street toward the bus stop, totally in the dark about what was going on. The only clear thing about the whole situation was that there wasn’t going to be a piano recital or any other event held here today. All I could do was head home, bouquet of red flowers in hand. My mother would doubtless ask, “What’re the flowers for?,” and I would have to give some plausible answer. I wanted to toss them in the trash bin at the station, but they were—for me, at least—kind of expensive to just throw away.

paragraph1: He woke to discover that he had undergone a metamorphosis and become Gregor Samsa.He lay flat on his back on the bed, looking at the ceiling. It took time for his eyes to adjust to the lack of light. The ceiling seemed to be a common, everyday ceiling of the sort one might find anywhere. Once, it had been painted white, or possibly a pale cream. Years of dust and dirt, however, had given it the color of spoiled milk. It had no ornament, no defining characteristic. No argument, no message. It fulfilled its structural role but aspired to nothing further.There was a tall window on one side of the room, to his left, but its curtain had been removed and thick boards nailed across the frame. An inch or so of space had been left between the horizontal boards, whether on purpose or not wasn’t clear; rays of morning sun shone through, casting a row of bright parallel lines on the floor. Why was the window barricaded in such a rough fashion? Was a major storm or tornado in the offing? Or was it to keep someone from getting in? Or to prevent someone (him, perhaps?) from leaving?
paragraph2: Gregor Samsa lay motionless on his back, his transformed body pressed against the mattress as he fixed his gaze upon the ceiling above. The surface that stretched over him was utterly unremarkable, bearing a sickly hue reminiscent of spoiled milk, its pallid appearance the result of years of accumulated grime and neglect. Through the window positioned on the left wall of his chamber, thin strips of morning light managed to penetrate the thick wooden boards that had been firmly nailed across the frame. These rays created an odd pattern of illumination that danced across the dingy ceiling, drawing Gregor's attention to the mysterious circumstances of his confinement. The presence of these boards raised unsettling questions in his mind - were they installed as a precaution against an impending storm, a barrier to ward off potential intruders, or perhaps, more disturbingly, a means to ensure he remained trapped within? The uncertainty of his situation weighed heavily upon him as he continued to contemplate the dreary expanse above, unable to move from his position or make sense of his extraordinary transformation.

paragraph1: There was a time when I could travel England for weeks on end and remain at my sharpest—when, if anything, the travelling gave me an edge. But now that I am older I become disoriented more easily. So it was that on arriving at the village just after dark I failed to find my bearings at all. I could hardly believe I was in the same village in which not so long ago I had lived and come to exercise such influence.There was nothing I recognized, and I found myself walking forever around twisting, badly lit streets hemmed in on both sides by the little stone cottages characteristic of the area. The streets often became so narrow I could make no progress without my bag or my elbow scraping one rough wall or another. I persevered nevertheless, stumbling around in the darkness in the hope of coming upon the village square—where I could at least orient myself—or else of encountering one of the villagers. When after a while I had done neither, a weariness came over me, and I decided my best course was just to choose a cottage at random, knock on the door, and hope it would be opened by someone who remembered me.
paragraph2: Standing here in these winding streets, I can hardly believe how different everything feels from my memories of this place. Years ago, I would traverse the English countryside with boundless energy and certainty, each journey filling me with excitement and purpose. This village, in particular, was once like a second home - a place where I had left an indelible mark on the community and knew every corner intimately. Now, as I shuffle through these narrow lanes between ancient stone cottages, nothing seems familiar. The weak lamplight casts confusing shadows, and the paths that should lead to the village square seem to mock my failing sense of direction. I pause repeatedly, trying to orient myself using landmarks that have either vanished or transformed beyond recognition. The weight of time presses heavily on my shoulders as I realize how much both this place and I have changed. My once-confident steps have become hesitant, and the darkness between the buildings feels more oppressive than ever. Exhausted and fighting a growing sense of defeat, I've decided to approach one of these cottages and knock, hoping to find a familiar face - someone who might remember the person I used to be in this village that now feels like a stranger's home.

When after a while I had done neither, a weariness came over me, and I decided my best course was just to choose a cottage at random, knock on the door, and hope it would be opened by someone who remembered me.

Paragraph 2:

paragraph1: This is why men are so sad, why they feel so cut off, why they think of themselves as orphans cast adrift, footloose and stringless in the deep void.“What void?” she asks.“What are you talking about? The void of the Universe,” he says.And she says “Oh,” and looks out the window and tries to get a handle on it, but it’s no use, there’s too much going on, too many rustlings in the leaves, too many voices, so she says, "Would you like a cheese sandwich, a piece of cake, a cup of tea?"And he grinds his teeth because she doesn’t understand, and wanders off, not just alone but Alone, lost in the dark, lost in the skull, searching for the other half, the twin who could complete him.Then it comes to himhe’s lost the Female Body! Look, it shines in the gloom, far ahead, a vision of wholeness, ripeness, like a giant melon, like an apple, like a metaphor for breast in a bad sex novel; it shines like a balloon, like a foggy noon, a watery moon, shimmering in its egg of light.Catch it. Put it in a pumpkin, in a high tower, in a compound, in a chamber, in a house, in a room. Quick, stick a leash on it, a lock, a chain, some pain, settle it down, so it can never get away from you again.
paragraph2: Standing beneath the dim light of his apartment, Marcus poured out his existential anguish to Sarah, describing how he felt like a lone particle floating in the cosmic emptiness, disconnected from any meaningful anchor in life. His words hung heavy in the air as Sarah shifted uncomfortably, struggling to find an appropriate response to his metaphysical musings. When she finally broke the silence by offering him coffee and cookies, Marcus felt a sharp pang of disappointment, sensing the vast chasm between his internal world and her practical approach to his distress. He turned away from her, his shoulders slumping as he retreated further into the labyrinth of his thoughts, where he grappled with an overwhelming sense of incompleteness that seemed to define his existence. In his mind, the image of the Female Body emerged as a powerful symbol of wholeness and vitality, something he yearned to possess and contain, like a precious artifact in a museum case or a rare butterfly pinned behind glass. The more Sarah attempted to ground their interaction in everyday reality, the more Marcus felt himself drifting away, caught between his desperate need for connection and his inability to bridge the gap between his abstract longings and the concrete world around him.

paragraph1: Jerome sat between Zora and Levi at the table, their quiet meal becoming a moment of profound connection that transcended the need for words. As he glanced at his sister's familiar profile and caught his brother's characteristic gesture of pushing food around the plate, memories flooded back with startling clarity. He could still picture the three of them as children, giggling beneath their makeshift fortress of dining chairs and their mother's best sheets, creating a world that belonged to them alone. The way Zora's laugh still carried the same musical quality it had back then, how Levi's eyes crinkled at the corners just like their father's - these details were woven into the fabric of Jerome's own identity. He saw pieces of himself reflected in their mannerisms, heard echoes of his own voice in their speech patterns, and felt the unshakeable certainty that his understanding of love had been shaped by these two people who were more than siblings; they were extensions of his own being, co-authors of his life's most meaningful chapters.
paragraph2: People talk about the happy quiet that can exist between two loves, but this, too, was great; sitting between his sister and his brother, saying nothing, eating. Before the world existed, before it was populated, and before there were wars and jobs and colleges and movies and clothes and opinions and foreign travel -- before all of these things there had been only one person, Zora, and only one placea tent in the living room made from chairs and bed-sheets. After a few years, Levi arrived; space was made for him; it was as if he had always been. Looking at them both now, Jerome found himself in their finger joints and neat conch ears, in their long legs and wild curls. He heard himself in their partial lisps caused by puffy tongues vibrating against slightly noticeable buckteeth. He did not consider if or how or why he loved them. They were just lovethey were the first evidence he ever had of love, and they would be the last confirmation of love when everything else fell away.

paragraph1: After years of transient living and shared spaces, he found himself deeply attached to his mortgaged house, a connection that grew stronger during his period of illness and desperation. The mere thought of ownership, despite the financial obligations, provided him with an unprecedented sense of comfort and security. His mind often wandered to the stark contrast between his current situation and his past experiences, particularly the crowded living arrangements with Mrs. Tulsi's family. The memories of constantly shifting between different residences as a child, followed by the years spent in various properties owned by his wife Shama's family, including Hanuman House in Arwacas and the dwellings in Shorthills and Port of Spain, had left him yearning for a place to truly call his own. Now, as he surveyed his property, a profound sense of achievement washed over him. The knowledge that this space belonged to him, that he had a personal stake in this piece of land, filled him with wonder and satisfaction. Even in his weakened state, the private sanctuary of his home offered him a refuge he had never known before, a tangible manifestation of his journey from dependence to autonomy, from being a perpetual guest to becoming a rightful owner.
paragraph2: He thought of the house as his own, though for years it had been irretrievably mortgaged. And during these months of illness and despair he was struck again and again by the wonder of being in his own house, the audacity of itto walk in through his own front gate, to bar entry to whoever he wished, to close his doors and windows every night, to hear no noises except those of his family, to wander freely from room to room and about his yard, instead of being condemned, as before, to retire the moment he got home to the crowded room in one or the other of Mrs Tulsi’s houses, crowded with Shama’s sisters, their husbands, their children. As a boy he had moved from one house of strangers to another; and since his marriage he felt he had lived nowhere but in the house of the Tulsis, at Hanuman House in Arwacas, in the decaying wooden house at Shorthills, in the clumsy concrete house in Port of Spain. And now at the end he found himself in his own house, on his own half-lot of land, his own portion of the earth. That he should have been responsible for this seemed to him, in these last months, stupendous.

paragraph1: Looking back on those complicated days with Sylvia and Roxanne, I still feel uneasy about how they circled around Mr. Crozier like competing planets around an aging sun. Their rivalry made me deeply uncomfortable, especially considering Mr. Crozier's advanced age and vulnerability. I never wanted to dwell on the intimate aspects of his final decisions, though Sylvia ultimately claimed her victory by whisking him away to that lakeside cottage where he spent his last breaths. Our families were all grappling with their own storms during those years - my mother's deteriorating health cast a long shadow over our household, while the Hoys faced their own private battles. I remember how Dorothy Crozier showed remarkable resilience after her stroke, transforming into something of a neighborhood legend with her generous Halloween candy distributions. Now, as I feel time's steady march in my own bones and witness the subtle shifts in my reflection, those memories take on new meaning. The complexities of aging, desire, and family loyalty seem less black and white than they did back then, though the discomfort of those particular events still lingers in my mind.
paragraph2: The clouds were high and white, glaring. They looked nothing like rain clouds, and there was a breeze only because we were in a moving car with the windows rolled down.I understood pretty well the winning and losing that had taken place between Sylvia and Roxanne, but it was strange to think of the almost obliterated prize, Mr. Crozier—and to think that he could have had the will to make a decision, even to deprive himself, so late in his life. The carnality at death’s door—or the true love, for that matter—was something I wanted to shake off back then, just as I would shake caterpillars off my sleeve.Sylvia took Mr. Crozier away to a rented cottage on the lake, where he died sometime before the leaves were off.The Hoy family moved on, as mechanics’ families often did.My mother struggled with a crippling disease, which put an end to all her money-making dreams.Dorothy Crozier had a stroke, but recovered, and famously bought Halloween candy for the children whose older brothers and sisters she had ordered from her door.I grew up, and old

Your task is to determine which paragraph is overall better in terms of writing quality.

Paragraph 1:
Looking back on those complicated days with Sylvia and Roxanne, I still feel uneasy about how they circled around Mr. Crozier like competing planets around an aging sun. Their rivalry made me deeply uncomfortable, especially considering Mr. Crozier's advanced age and vulnerability. I never wanted to dwell on the intimate aspects of his final decisions, though Sylvia ultimately claimed her victory by whisking him away to that lakeside cottage where he spent his last breaths. Our families were all grappling with their own storms during those years - my mother's deteriorating health cast a long shadow over our household, while the Hoys faced their own private battles. I remember how Dorothy Crozier showed remarkable resilience after her stroke, transforming into something of a neighborhood legend with her generous Halloween candy distributions. Now, as I feel time's steady march in my own bones and witness the subtle shifts in my reflection, those memories take on new meaning. The complexities of aging, desire, and family loyalty seem less black and white than they did back then, though the discomfort of those particular events still lingers in my mind.

paragraph1: On the way to the station that evening my mother kept glancing at me, as if something about my behaviour was off-putting, and she wanted to reprimand me for it but couldn’t decide what it was. Eventually she told me to take my feet off the dashboard, which I did. You must be relieved, she said. Yeah, delighted. How are you managing for money? Oh, I said. I’m okay. She glanced in the rear-view mirror. The doctor didn’t say anything else, did he? she said. No, that was it. I looked out the window at the station. I had the sense that something in my life had ended, my image of myself as a whole or normal person maybe. I realised my life would be full of mundane physical suffering, and that there was nothing special about it. Suffering wouldn’t make me special, and pretending not to suffer wouldn’t make me special. Talking about it, or even writing about it, would not transform the suffering into something useful. Nothing would. I thanked my mother for the lift to the station and got out of the car.
paragraph2: My mother keeps stealing glances at me during our drive to the station, her unease palpable in the confined space of the car. I can tell she wants to say something meaningful but doesn't quite know how to bridge the gap that's formed between us. When she asks me to take my feet off the dashboard, I comply without protest, watching her hands grip the steering wheel a little tighter. Her questions about money and what the doctor said feel like attempts to normalize the situation, to find solid ground in this shifting landscape of our relationship. I give her short answers, all while wrestling with the crushing realization that my identity as a "normal person" has somehow slipped away. The truth hits me hard: my suffering isn't special or unique, and it won't magically transform me into someone else, whether I choose to voice it or keep it buried inside. As we pull up to the station, I mutter a quick thank you and step out of the car, leaving behind both my mother and the weight of her concerned glances.

paragraph1: Then one day in April someone rang my buzzer. I thought it was him. Instead it was another woman who knew my boyfriend just as well as I did, who saw him on the days I didn’t. I’d shared the same man with this woman for nearly five years. She lived in another neighborhood, and she’d come to know about me thanks to a book I’d lent him, the same book that he in turn, idiotically, had lent to her. Unbelievable. Inside that book there was a piece of paper, the receipt from a doctor’s visit, with my name and address. At which point all the little things that puzzled her about their relationship made sense. She realized that she was only one of his lovers, and that we were an unwitting threesome.
paragraph2: Opening my door that April evening, I expected to see Marcus's familiar face, but instead found myself staring at a woman who seemed oddly composed despite the circumstances. As she introduced herself as Sarah, my heart sank when I realized we shared more than just pleasantries – we shared the same boyfriend for nearly five years. The truth unraveled through a simple book receipt, of all things. I had lent Marcus my copy of "The Great Gatsby," which he then passed to her, unknowingly leaving behind the bookstore receipt with my name and address tucked between its pages. Her discovery explained the mysterious phone calls that ended abruptly, the unexplained absences, and the vague references to family commitments that now seemed painfully obvious. Standing there in my doorway, we were two women connected by betrayal, our separate lives suddenly and irrevocably intertwined through one man's deception.

paragraph1: None of you will go to America, none of you will be film stars. And none of you will be working in supermarkets as I heard some of you planning the other day. Your lives are set out for you. You’ll become adults, then before you ‘re old, before you ‘re even middle-aged, you’ll start to donate your vital organs. That’s what each of you was created to do. You’re not like the actors you watch on your videos, you’re not even like me. You were brought into this world for a purpose, and your futures, all of them, have been decided. So you’re not to talk that way any more. You’ll be leaving Hailsham before long, and it’s not so far off, the day you’ll be preparing for your first donations. You need to remember that. If you ‘re to have decent lives, you have to know who you are and what lies ahead of you, every one of you.”Then she went silent, but my impression was that she was continuing to say things inside her head, because for sometime her gaze kept roving over us, going from face to face just as if she were still speaking to us. We were all pretty relieved when she turned to look out over the playing field again.“It’s not so bad now,” she said, even though the rain was as steady as ever. “Let’s just go out there. Then maybe the sun will come out too.”
paragraph2: Standing before the silent classroom, she drew a deep breath before shattering their innocent dreams, my impression was that she had rehearsed this moment countless times. Her words fell heavy like the rain outside, explaining with calculated precision how their aspirations of becoming film stars, relocating to America, or even working mundane jobs in supermarkets were nothing but hollow fantasies. The truth she unveiled was far more clinical: they were created for organ donation, their bodies destined to sustain others' lives. As she spoke, the students' faces reflected the weight of their predetermined fate, their earlier chatter about favorite actors and dream careers now seeming painfully naive. She made it crystal clear that they were fundamentally different from the celebrities they admired on screen, different even from herself - their lives mapped out long before they could comprehend the concept of choice or free will. The room grew thick with unspoken questions and suppressed emotions, yet she maintained her composure, her eyes occasionally drifting to the rain-soaked playing field beyond the windows. In an unexpected turn, perhaps sensing the suffocating atmosphere of despair, she suggested they head outside, her voice carrying a hint of hope that the sun might break through the clouds, offering a momentary respite from the crushing reality she had just revealed.

paragraph1: Florence's complex relationship with intimacy manifests as a profound internal struggle, where her deep love for Edward collides with an overwhelming sense of revulsion towards sexual acts. This visceral aversion creates a peculiar paradox in her aspirations for the future, as she warmly embraces the idea of motherhood and finds genuine joy in the presence of children, yet wishes desperately to bypass the physical requirements of conception. Her mind often wanders to impossible scenarios where pregnancy might occur through magical means, allowing her to achieve her maternal desires without confronting her sexual fears. The depth of her squeamishness suggests something far more significant than mere physical discomfort; it points to a fundamental disconnect that threatens her emotional equilibrium and overall well-being. Florence experiences this aversion as a total bodily rejection, feeling that sexual intimacy would somehow unravel her carefully maintained composure and sense of self. The prospect of physical relations with Edward looms over her not as a natural expression of love but as a dreaded obligation, a necessary evil she must somehow endure to access other forms of happiness, including the domestic life she envisions. This internal conflict creates a constant tension between her desires for connection and her instinctive recoil from physical intimacy.
paragraph2: In optimistic moments, she tried to convince herself that she suffered from no more than a heightened form of squeamishness that was bound to pass. Certainly, the thought of Edward’s testicles, pendulous below his “engorged penis”—another horrifying term—had the potency to make her upper lip curl, and the idea of herself being touched “down there” by someone else, even someone she loved, was as repulsive as, say, a surgical procedure on her eye. But her squeamishness did not extend to babies. She liked them; she had looked after her cousin’s little boys on occasion and enjoyed herself. She thought that she would love being pregnant by Edward, and in the abstract, at least, she had no fears about childbirth. If only she could, like the mother of Jesus, arrive at that swollen state by magic.Florence suspected that there was something profoundly wrong with her, that she had always been different, and that at last she was about to be exposed. Her problem, she thought, was greater, deeper, than straightforward physical disgusther whole being was in revolt against the prospect of entanglement and flesh; her composure and essential happiness were about to be violated. She simply did not want to be “entered” or “penetrated.” Sex with Edward could not be the summation of her joy but the price she must pay for it.

paragraph1: But today for the first time she was certain that even in Paul’s presence she would find the courage to say what she wanted, what she really wanted, in the depth of her soul; she was certain that she would find this courage even at the price of ruining everything between them. Next to her, she heard the sound of loud breathing. Paul had really fallen asleep. As if she were putting the same reel of film back in the projector, she ran through the whole scene once againshe is speaking to the visitor, Paul is watching them with astonishment, and the guest is saying, “In your next life, do you want to stay together or never meet again?" (It is strangeeven though he has all the necessary information about them, terrestrial psychology is incomprehensible to him, the concept of love unfamiliar, so he cannot guess what a difficult situation he would create by his sincere, practical, and well-intended question.)Agnes gathers all her inner strength and answers in a firm voice, “We prefer never to meet again.”These words are like the click of a door shutting on the illusion of love.
paragraph2: Agnes lay motionless beside Paul's sleeping form, her mind wrestling with thoughts that had long haunted their relationship. The gentle rhythm of his breathing contrasted sharply with the turbulent dialogue unfolding in her imagination, where a mysterious visitor, detached from human sentiment, posed an impossible choice. This ethereal figure, naive to the complexities of human emotions, asked whether she would choose to reunite with Paul in another life or forever remain strangers. The question, though hypothetical, crystallized years of unspoken doubts and suppressed desires. Agnes mentally rehearsed her response, each imagined word building her courage like a slowly fortifying wall. In the darkness of their shared bedroom, she finally embraced the truth she had been avoiding: she would choose never to meet him again. This realization, though painful, felt like removing a mask she had worn for too long. The imagined conversation became a private ceremony of liberation, allowing Agnes to acknowledge that their love, beautiful as it once seemed, was an illusion she could no longer sustain.

paragraph1: When he speaks French, his words flow with a certain grace, yet I find myself grappling with our linguistic divide, unable to reciprocate in his mother tongue. At first, this barrier frustrated me deeply, making me feel inadequate and disconnected. But gradually, I've come to embrace these imperfect exchanges between us. The halting conversations and occasional misunderstandings serve as constant reminders that what we have isn't some fairy-tale romance where two souls merge seamlessly into one. Instead, our language gap preserves the beautiful mystery between us, keeping alive the truth that no matter how close we become, he remains fundamentally unknowable. His foreignness, apparent in every accented word, has become precious to me – a testament to his distinct identity that I can love but never fully possess.
paragraph2: At first I was discouraged by the obvious limitations of our exchanges. These were emphasized by the fact that, although he spoke fairly good French, I could not express myself in his language. Later I realized that this situation spared me the illusion that we shared a perfect relationship, or even formed a whole. Because his French strayed slightly from standard use and because I occasionally had doubts about the meaning he gave to words, I was able to appreciate the approximate quality of our conversations. From the very beginning, and throughout the whole of our affair, I had the privilege of knowing what we all find out in the end the man we love is a complete stranger.

paragraph1: Sometimes I wonder if my life would be more meaningful without the conventional markers of success—no children running through hallways, no books bearing my name on dusty shelves. Perhaps there's beauty in leaving no trace, in simply existing without the pressure to create lasting impacts. I've spent years agonizing over climate change, political upheavals, and societal collapse, but lately, I'm drawn to a simpler vision. I dream of a modest house nestled among trees, its walls lined with well-worn books, sharing quiet evenings with someone who understands my soul. Taking care of my aging parents feels more important than any career achievement, though Simon doesn't quite grasp why I'd choose such a path. The two-bedroom layout we discuss feels like a compromise, a physical manifestation of our differing views on what makes a life worth living. My childhood fantasies of a peaceful existence seem simultaneously within reach and impossibly distant. While others chase promotions and plan exotic vacations, I find myself longing for the kind of contentment that comes from staying still, from building a life that values presence over legacy.
paragraph2: If, as I think is quite possible now, I never have any children and never write any books, I suppose I will leave nothing on this earth to be remembered by. And maybe that’s better. It makes me feel that rather than worrying and theorising about the state of the world, which helps no one, I should put my energy into living and being happy. When I try to picture for myself what a happy life might look like, the picture hasn’t changed very much since I was a child – a house with flowers and trees around it, and a river nearby, and a room full of books, and someone there to love me, that’s all. Just to make a home there, and to care for my parents when they grow older. Never to move, never to board a plane again, just to live quietly and then be buried in the earth. What else is life for? But even that seems so beyond me that it’s like a dream, completely unrelated to anything in reality. And yes, when it comes to myself and Simon, two bedrooms please.

paragraph1: It was a poorly built house in a way, since wind blew in through cracks and gaps all over the place. Pleasant enough in the summer, but, come winter, it was hell. With no money to buy a space heater, my wife and I and the cat would crawl under the futons once the sun set, literally clinging to each other to keep warm. Many a time we’d wake up to find the water in the kitchen faucet frozen solid.Once winter passed, the spring would come. And spring was a lovely season. She and I and the cat would breathe a sigh of relief. In April, the railroads went on strike for a few days, and we were ecstatic. Not a single train came rumbling by all day. We carried the cat down to the railroad tracks and sat there sunning ourselves. It was so quiet it was as if we were sitting at the bottom of a lake. We were young, just married, and the sunshine was free!Even now, when I hear the word “poor,” I remember that thin, triangular sliver of land. And I wonder, Who could be living there now?
paragraph2: Those first years of marriage in that rickety house still flood my mind with bittersweet memories. My wife and I, along with our faithful cat, struggled through each winter in that poorly insulated dwelling, where our financial constraints meant no space heater to ward off the biting cold. We'd create our own warmth by huddling together under layers of futons, our cat nestled between us, while the kitchen faucet regularly froze solid, a testament to our spartan living conditions. But spring, oh spring was our salvation, bringing with it a warmth that melted away our winter hardships. I particularly remember that April during the railroad strike, when the usual clamor of trains fell silent. We seized that rare moment of tranquility to bask in the sunshine on the empty tracks, our cat contentedly purring beside us, young love making everything seem somehow perfect despite our circumstances. Even now, years later, whenever I hear the word "poor," my thoughts drift back to that humble abode, and I find myself wondering about its current inhabitants, hoping they too find moments of joy amidst the challenges, just as we did in our youth.

paragraph1: Maybe we're just born to love and worry about the people we know, and to go on loving and worrying even when there are more important things we should be doing. And if that means the human species is going to die out, isn't it in a way a nice reason to die out, the nicest reason you can imagine? Because when we should have been reorganising the distribution of the world's resources and transitioning collectively to a sustainable economic model, we were worrying about sex and friendship instead. Because we loved each other too much and found each other too interesting. And I love that about humanity, and in fact it's the very reason I root for us to survive - because we are so stupid about each other.
paragraph2: I've often pondered why we humans seem hardwired to prioritize our immediate relationships over the pressing global challenges that threaten our collective future. We spend countless hours worrying about friendships, pursuing romantic connections, and nurturing family bonds, while issues like economic inequality and environmental sustainability remain largely unaddressed. It's both fascinating and maddening how our hearts gravitate toward individual connections rather than tackling the complex problems of resource distribution that could benefit millions. Yet, there's something profoundly touching about this seemingly irrational aspect of our nature. The way we cherish personal bonds, invest deeply in love affairs, and maintain lifelong friendships might appear foolish when compared to larger societal needs, but it's precisely this capacity for intimate connection that makes me believe in humanity's worth and hope for its continued existence. Perhaps our predisposition to love and care for those closest to us, despite its apparent shortsightedness, is our most redeeming quality.

paragraph1: Connell has been casually seeing a friend of theirs called Teresa. Marianne has no real problem with Teresa, but finds herself frequently prompting Connell to say bad things about her for no reason, which he always refuses to do. He wears nice clothes, volunteered Joanna. Not really, said Peggy. I mean, he has a look, but it’s just tracksuits most of the time. I doubt he even owns a suit. Joanna sought Marianne’s eye contact again, and this time Marianne returned it. Peggy, watching, took a performatively large mouthful of Cointreau and wiped her lips with the hand she was using to hold the bottle. What? she said. Well, isn’t he from a fairly working-class background? said Joanna. That's so oversensitive, Peggy said. I can't criticise someone's dress sense because of their socio-economic status? Come on. No, that’s not what she meant, said Marianne. Because you know, we’re all actually very nice to him, said Peggy. Marianne found she couldn’t look at either of her friends then. Who's 'we'? she wanted to say. Instead she took the bottle of Cointreau from Peggy's hand and swallowed two mouthfuls, lukewarm and repulsively sweet.
paragraph2: Marianne found herself caught in a delicate conversation with Joanna and Peggy about Connell and his new romantic interest, Teresa. Despite having no particular animosity toward Teresa, Marianne had developed a peculiar habit of attempting to draw criticism about her from Connell, though he consistently refused to participate in such discussions. The conversation took an unexpected turn when Joanna commented positively on Connell's fashion choices, only to be swiftly contradicted by Peggy, who dismissively pointed out his preference for tracksuits. A knowing look passed between Marianne and Joanna, but Peggy, misreading the exchange, immediately became defensive and brought up Connell's socioeconomic status. The sudden shift in atmosphere created a palpable tension that made Marianne distinctly uncomfortable. Rather than contribute further to the increasingly awkward discussion, she opted to take a contemplative sip from Peggy's Cointreau, silently reflecting on the complex web of social dynamics and unspoken feelings that seemed to surround any conversation involving Connell. The interaction highlighted the subtle undercurrents of class consciousness and personal histories that colored their friendship group's dynamics.

paragraph1: The day before Nell and Lizzie are due to leave for the city, Nell comes across a note written by Tig, long ago, when the two of them installed mosquito nets over the beds as a communal service. The mosquitoes can be thick as fur on the outsides of the screens, especially in June; they can squeeze through the tiniest cracks. Once inside, they whine. Even if you’ve got repellent on, they can ruin your night."Large mosquito nettingAt the end of the bug season the large netting should be packed in this bag. The wooden frame, once collapsed, is inserted in the inner compartment of the green bag—Thanks."What green bag? she wonders. Probably it got mildew and someone discarded it. In any case, no one had ever followed these instructions of Tig’s; the mosquito netting is merely left in place and tied into a bundle when not in use.She smooths out the piece of paper carefully and stores it away in her bag. It’s a message, left by Tig for her to find. Magical thinking, she knows that perfectly well, but she indulges in it, anyway, because it’s comforting. She’ll take this piece of paper back to the city, but what will she do with it there? What does one ever do with these cryptic messages from the dead?
paragraph2: Nell's fingers trembled slightly as she held the weathered piece of paper, her eyes scanning Tig's familiar handwriting about the mosquito netting they had once installed together in their community service days. The detailed instructions, written with Tig's characteristic thoroughness, specified that the netting should be carefully packed away in a green bag when the bug season ended. A wry smile crossed Nell's face as she recalled how those well-intentioned instructions had likely been ignored, with the netting probably ending up hastily bundled and tied instead of being properly stored as Tig had meticulously planned. The green bag itself had presumably been discarded long ago, just another forgotten detail in the passage of time. With gentle movements, she tucked the note into her bag, treating it as if it were a precious artifact - which, in many ways, it was. This unexpected discovery felt like a message from beyond, a ghostly hello from Tig that bridged the gap between past and present. As she prepared to return to the city, Nell contemplated how the deceased often leave behind such cryptic breadcrumbs - scattered notes, forgotten instructions, and casual reminders that suddenly transform into profound connections to those we've lost. The note would travel with her, a tangible piece of Tig's essence preserved in simple words about mosquito netting.

paragraph1: Throughout this year, swimming became my sanctuary in diverse waters across Europe, each dip carrying its own story and significance. In Portugal, Mary, Sarah, and I found healing in the Atlantic waves as we recovered from COVID, our bodies gradually regaining strength in the salty embrace. Later, I alternated between solitary swims and shared moments with Brian, finding both solitude and connection in the water. The Mediterranean beckoned in Greece, where Rachel, Zayd, and our four children created lasting memories, their laughter echoing across the crystal-clear bays. The writing workshop participants joined me there too, turning our aquatic adventures into inspiration for stories yet untold. In Oslo, the bracing Nordic waters provided a different kind of awakening as Roda and Tor's children showed us their favorite swimming spots, their fearless plunges inspiring our own courage. Each immersion felt like a rebirth, a metaphorical letting go of worries and inhibitions. As I dove beneath the surface in these various locations, I discovered that swimming wasn't just about physical movement—it was about awakening to new experiences and embracing the freedom that comes with surrendering to the water's embrace.
paragraph2: In Portugal, I swam with Mary and Sarah while the three of us were recovering from the COVID we gave each other. In Greece, I swam alone and with my husband Brian and with our friends Rachel and Zayd and with all four of our collective kids and off the side of a boat with a good number of the sixty people who were taking our writing workshop. In Norway, I swam with my family and our friends Roda and Tor and their kids in the middle of Oslo.I floated. I paddled and kicked. I waded and wavered and eventually dove in. And I remembered how I used to love to do those things. I realized that I still do.It made me think about what mustering up the energy to dive in gives us, in a larger sense—both in the water and out of it. It rattles the bones. It makes us shiver and squeal. It wakes us up and gives us the chance to feel the kind of liberation one feels when you plunge ahead and dive in, which is another way of saying let go.
