paragraph1: "Those people seem so pleased to see each other," Manager said. And I realized she'd been watching them as closely as I had."Yes, they seem so happy," I said. "But it's strange because they also seem upset." "Oh, Klara," Manager said quietly. "You never miss a thing, do you?" Then Manager was silent for a long time, holding her sign in her hand and staring across the street, even after the pair had gone out of sight. Finally she said"Perhaps they hadn't met for a long time. A long, long time. Perhaps when they last held each other like that, they were still young." "Do you mean, Manager, that they lost each other?" She was quiet for another moment. "Yes," she said, eventually. "That must be it. They lost each other. And perhaps just now, just by chance, they found each other again." Manager's voice wasn't like her usual one, and though her eyes were on the outside, I thought she was now looking at nothing in particular. I even started to wonder what passers-by would think to see Manager herself in the window with us for so long.
paragraph2: From my position by the store window, I watched intently as the two figures outside displayed what seemed to be conflicting emotions, their faces caught between joy and distress at their encounter. Manager stood beside me, her usual businesslike demeanor softening as she observed my careful attention to the scene unfolding before us. "You notice everything, don't you, Klara?" she remarked, her voice carrying a hint of admiration. The pair outside continued their awkward dance of emotions, their body language speaking volumes about their complicated history. After they departed, Manager's gaze lingered on the now-empty sidewalk, and she mused that they must have been separated for years before this chance meeting. Her voice took on an unusually contemplative tone, quite different from her typical practical manner, and I noticed how her eyes seemed to look beyond the street, perhaps into her own past. The moment revealed not just the complexity of human reunions but also how such encounters could stir deep memories in unexpected observers, making me wonder about Manager's own story of lost connections.

paragraph1: It goes without saying that one of the men is tall, rather handsome—in a vulgar way—a little dim and vicious, while the other man is shorter, weasel-faced, and sly. This short, sly man leaned on the Coca-Cola hoarding that marked the entrance to the village and raised a hand in friendly greeting, while his companion took the small stick that he had, up to that point, been chewing, threw it on the ground, and smiled. They could just as well have been leaning on a lamppost and chewing gum, and the smell of borscht could have been in the air, but in our village we do not make borscht—we eat couscous and tilefish and that was the smell in the air, tilefish, which even to this day we can hardly bear to smell because it reminds us of the day the two men arrived in the village.
paragraph2: The two men materialized at the edge of the village, their presence marked by the pungent aroma of tilefish wafting through the humid air. The taller of the pair cut an imposing figure with his rough-hewn good looks and brutish demeanor, his dim eyes betraying a capacity for thoughtless violence. His shorter companion, whose features bore an unmistakable resemblance to a weasel, possessed a calculating air that seemed to assess every detail of their surroundings. While the village's daily fare of couscous and tilefish set it apart from regions where borscht might fill local bowls, today these familiar scents mingled with an undercurrent of approaching trouble. The shorter man casually propped himself against a weather-worn Coca-Cola billboard, offering a deceptively friendly wave to no one in particular, as his companion spat out the remnants of a gnawed stick, his lips curling into an unsettling smile that promised nothing good.

paragraph1: Learning to drive in the 1960s proved to be quite an adventure, marked by two memorable but unsuccessful attempts that revealed my unconventional approach to operating a vehicle. My father's initial effort to teach me at age twenty came to an abrupt halt after a near-accident that left us both rattled, though I remained largely unfazed. Truth be told, I was more captivated by contemplating life's deeper meanings and composing poetry than mastering the intricacies of driving, making my father's decision to abandon the lessons rather inconsequential to me. A second attempt emerged in 1964 when my boyfriend, whose father was the enigmatic Frank the Pirate, volunteered to guide me through the process. However, my fearless attitude behind the wheel, which I saw as natural and liberating, proved to be a source of constant anxiety for him. While most driving instructors worry about their students being too timid, my boyfriend found himself in the unusual position of dealing with someone who showed absolutely no hesitation or concern on the road. Eventually, he came to the realization that my fearlessness, though admirable in other contexts, was potentially hazardous when combined with a two-ton vehicle, leading him to join my father in the ranks of those who had given up on teaching me to drive.
paragraph2: It was 1960. I was twenty. It was suggested that it was time I learned to drive. Driving skills were not considered as essential then as they are now—people, especially young people, didn’t automatically have cars. Still, knowing how to drive could be useful. My father would teach me, said he.Easier said than done. After I’d mistaken the gas pedal for the brake and almost rammed his car into a stone wall, this driving plan was quietly dropped. No tears shed by meI had other things on my mind, such as existentialism, moon goddesses, and the writing of tortured poetry.My next attempt was in 1964. This time, the heroic would-be driving teacher was a very nice boyfriend. His father was a used-car dealer known as Frank the Pirate, so this boyfriend had a Frank the Pirate special to drive. (The car later exploded.)After three sessions—enjoyed by me with merry glee, endured by the nice boyfriend with white knuckles and clenched teeth—he gave up. “I can’t teach you,” he said. “You have no fears.”This was news to me. I thought I had lots of fears—thunderstorms, forest fires, bears—but these were not the right kind of fears for driving. I was not afraid of other drivers, of the edges of roads, or of huge chunks of steel whizzing toward me at insane speeds.

paragraph1: Archie possessed a remarkable talent for shedding his past and family connections as effortlessly as one might discard an old costume. Standing at this pivotal moment, he found himself contemplating his next move while his identity seemed to shift and reshape itself like clay in his hands. The metaphorical fork in the road before him demanded a choice, and as he caught a glimpse of his plain, forgettable features in a nearby window, he made his decision with surprising casualness. Queens Park lay ahead on the unfamiliar path he selected, its unknown territory both daunting and oddly appealing. Like a determined Monopoly player advancing across the board, Archie steeled himself against the urge to look backward, choosing instead to press forward into his self-imposed exile, leaving behind all that was familiar in pursuit of reinvention.
paragraph2: Generally, women can’t do this, but men retain the ancient ability to leave a family and a past. They just unhook themselves, like removing a fake beard, and skulk discreetly back into society, changed men. Unrecognizable. In this manner, a new Archie is about to emerge. We have caught him on the hop. For he is in a past-tense, future-perfect kind of mood. He is in a maybe this, maybe that kind of mood. Approaching a forked road, he slows down, checks his undistinguished face in the wing-mirror, and quite indiscriminately chooses a route he’s never taken before, a residential street leading to a place called Queens Park. Go straight pastGo!, Archie-boy, he tells himself; collect two hundred and don’t for gawd’s sake look back.

paragraph1: I did not attend my father’s wedding. I did not even know there had been a wedding until my father called early one Sunday during my final year at Swarthmore. I was roused from sleep by a pounding on my door, followed by the voice of one of my hallmates saying my last name. I knew before answering that it was my father; there was no one else who would have called me before nine. My father had always been an early riser, believing that the hours between five and seven were the most profitable part of the day. He would use that time to read the newspaper and then go for a walk, along Marine Drive when we lived in Bombay and on the quiet roads of our town on the North Shore of Massachusetts, where we moved when I was sixteen, after my mother got sick. As much as he used to encourage my mother and me to join him, I knew he preferred being alone. Things were different now, of course; those solitary hours he’d once savored had become a prison for him, a commonplace. I knew that he no longer bothered to go for walks and that since my mother’s death he hardly slept at all. I had not spoken to my father in several weeks. He had been in Calcutta, visiting my grandparents, all four of whom were still alive, and when I picked up the phone, left for me hanging upside down by its cord, I expected him to say only that he had returned safely, not that I now had a stepmother and two stepsisters.
paragraph2: I missed my father's wedding entirely, learning about it only through an unexpected phone call that jolted me awake one early Sunday morning during my last year at Swarthmore College. When my hallmate knocked on my door to tell me about the call, I knew instinctively it was my father - he had always been an early riser, cherishing those quiet morning hours for his walks and reading sessions. But lately, those solitary activities had lost their appeal for him, especially after my mother's illness and eventual passing. The once-peaceful mornings now seemed to taunt him as he battled persistent insomnia, leaving him a changed man from the father I once knew. We hadn't spoken for several weeks while he was visiting family in Calcutta, which wasn't unusual for us, but nothing could have prepared me for the news he delivered that morning. His voice, carrying across thousands of miles, seemed both familiar and strange as he matter-of-factly informed me that I now had a stepmother and two stepsisters. The words hung in the air between us, transforming my world in an instant, and I found myself struggling to process this sudden, dramatic shift in our family dynamic. The fact that he had gotten married without even telling me beforehand felt like a betrayal, yet another reminder of how much our relationship had changed since my mother's death. Standing there in my dorm room, still in my pajamas, I realized that my family structure had been completely reorganized without my knowledge or participation.

paragraph1: It was the month of June, the morning sun was emerging from the clouds, and Alain was walking slowly down a Paris street. He observed the young girlsevery one of them showed her naked navel between trousers belted very low and a T-shirt cut very short. He was captivated, captivated and even disturbedit was as if their seductive power resided no longer in their thighs, their buttocks, or their breasts but in that small round hole at the center of the body.This provoked him to reflectif a man (or an era) sees the thighs as the center of female seductive power, how does one describe and define the particularity of that erotic orientation? He improvised an answerthe length of the thighs is the metaphoric image of the long, fascinating road (which is why the thighs must be long) that leads to erotic achievement. Indeed, Alain said to himself, even in mid-coitus the length of the thighs endows woman with the romantic magic of the inaccessible.If a man (or an era) sees the buttocks as the center of female seductive power, how does one describe and define the particularity of that erotic orientation? He improvised an answerbrutality, high spirits, the shortest road to the goal, a goal that is all the more exciting for being double.If a man (or an era) sees the breasts as the center of female seductive power, how does one describe and define the particularity of that erotic orientation? He improvised an answersanctification of woman, the Virgin Mary suckling Jesus, the male sex on its knees before the noble mission of the female sex.But how does one define the eroticism of a man (or an era) that sees female seductive power as centered in the middle of the body, in the navel?
paragraph2: Walking through Paris on a sun-drenched June morning, Alain found himself increasingly preoccupied with the prevalent fashion trend among young women—their exposed navels catching his attention at every corner and boulevard. The phenomenon stirred within him a deeper contemplation about how different cultures and epochs had varying perceptions of female allure's focal point. His mind wandered through the landscape of human desire, considering how throughout history, different parts of the female form had commanded attention and sparked fascination. The thighs, he mused, represented a tantalizing journey, like a winding road that promised adventure and discovery in its lengthy course. The buttocks, with their bold prominence, seemed to him emblematic of vitality and forthright confidence, a celebration of life's more direct and unabashed pleasures. Breasts, in their eternal significance, carried the weight of both sanctity and nurture, embodying femininity's most noble and life-giving aspects. Yet here, in modern Paris, the navel emerged as a new center of seductive gravity, and Alain found himself pondering its unique implications. This small circular indent, this remnant of our very beginning, now commanded attention in a way that seemed both novel and somehow profound. The sight of these exposed midriffs throughout the city streets forced him to reconsider his understanding of attraction and its evolution, as he observed how this simple fashion choice had transformed a formerly hidden part of anatomy into a powerful symbol of contemporary sensuality.

paragraph1: The dark kidney-shaped stone now controls the greater part of her life.Surely the stone is not an object that has come to her from withoutJunpei becomes aware of this as his story progresses. The main point is something inside herself. Something inside herself is activating the kidney-shaped stone and urging her to take some kind of action. It keeps sending her signals for that purpose—signals in the form of the stone’s nightly movements.While he writes, Junpei thinks about Kirie. He senses that she (or something inside her) is propelling the story; it was never his intention to write something so divorced from reality. What Junpei had imagined vaguely beforehand was a more tranquil, psychological story line. In that story line, rocks did not take it upon themselves to move around.Junpei imagined that the doctor would cut her ties to the married surgeon. She might even come to hate him. This was probably what she had been seeking all along, unconsciously.
paragraph2: As Junpei delves deeper into crafting his narrative about Kirie, he finds himself increasingly entangled in the mysterious interplay between her consciousness and the kidney-shaped stone that appears to guide her actions. What began as a simple premise evolves into something far more complex and ethereal, with the stone's nightly movements suggesting a deeper connection to Kirie's psychological state. The story seems to take on a life of its own, defying Junpei's initial intention of creating a straightforward psychological tale about a woman breaking free from her relationship with a married surgeon. Instead of following his planned trajectory where Kirie would develop animosity towards her lover, the narrative veers into more surreal territory, driven by forces that appear to emanate from within Kirie herself. Junpei observes, somewhat perplexed, as the character he created begins to shape her own destiny, transforming what should have been a realistic exploration of human relationships into something more mysterious and metaphysical.

The story seems to take on a life of its own, defying Junpei's initial intention of creating a straightforward psychological tale about a woman breaking free from her relationship with a married surgeon. Instead of following his planned trajectory where Kirie would develop animosity towards her lover, the narrative veers into more surreal territory, driven by forces that appear to emanate from within Kirie herself. Junpei observes, somewhat perplexed, as the character he created begins to shape her own destiny, transforming what should have been a realistic exploration of human relationships into something more mysterious and metaphysical.

paragraph1: The truth was that Quichotte had almost no friends anymore—no social group, no cohort, no posse, no real pals—having long ago abandoned the social whirl. On his Facebook page, he had “friended” or “been friended by” a small and dwindling group of commercial travellers like himself, as well as by an assortment of lonely hearts, braggarts, exhibitionists, and salacious ladies behaving as erotically as the social medium’s somewhat puritanical rules allowed. Every single one of these quote-unquote “friends” saw his plan, when he had enthusiastically posted it, for what it was—a harebrained scheme, verging on lunacy—and attempted to dissuade him, for his own good, from stalking or harassing Miss Salma R. In response to his post there were frown emojis and Bitmojis wagging fingers at him reprovingly, and there were GIFs of Salma R. herself, crossing her eyes, sticking out her tongue, and rotating a finger by her right temple, all of which added up to the universally recognized set of gestures meaning “cray cray.” However, Quichotte would not be deterred.
paragraph2: Quichotte's life had become a testament to modern-day isolation, with his social circle having dwindled to near nonexistence over the years. His remaining connections consisted primarily of a handful of commercial travelers and an assortment of virtual acquaintances on Facebook, ranging from lonely hearts seeking companionship to those who regularly shared provocative content. When he enthusiastically announced his latest scheme involving Miss Salma R. on his social media feed, his online "friends" responded with overwhelming disapproval. Their digital protests manifested through a barrage of frown emojis, disapproving Bitmojis, and satirical GIFs featuring Salma R. herself, all collectively suggesting they viewed his plan as nothing short of madness. These virtual companions, though distant and largely anonymous, made their concerns clear about what they perceived as his potentially dangerous and misguided intentions. However, Quichotte remained steadfast in his resolve, brushing aside their digital warnings with the same determination that had characterized his increasingly isolated existence, choosing to pursue his seemingly delusional plan regardless of the unanimous opposition he faced online.

paragraph1: Robbie Turner, only son of a humble cleaning lady and of no known father, Robbie who had been subsidized by Briony’s father through school and university, had wanted to be a landscape gardener, and now wanted to take up medicine, had the boldness of ambition to ask for Cecilia’s hand. It made perfect sense. Such leaps across boundaries were the stuff of daily romance. What was less comprehensible, however, was how Robbie imperiously raised his hand now, as though issuing a command which Cecilia dared not disobey. It was extraordinary that she was unable to resist him. At his insistence she was removing her clothes, and at such speed. She was out of her blouse, now she had let her skirt drop to the ground and was stepping out of it, while he looked on impatiently, hands on hips. What strange power did he have over her? Blackmail? Threats? Briony raised two hands to her face and stepped back a little way from the window. She should shut her eyes, she thought, and spare herself the sight of her sister’s shame. But that was impossible, because there were further surprises. Cecilia, mercifully still in her underwear, was climbing into the pond, was standing waist deep in the water, was pinching her nose—and then she was gone. There was only Robbie, and the clothes on the gravel, and beyond, the silent park and the distant, blue hills. The sequence was illogical—the drowning scene, followed by a rescue, should have preceded the marriage proposal. Such was Briony’s last thought before she accepted that she did not understand, and that she must simply watch.
paragraph2: Robbie Turner's position in the social hierarchy was marked by his modest origins as the son of a cleaning lady, yet his trajectory had been altered by the generosity of Briony's father, who funded his education and nurtured his ambitions. With determination and intellectual promise, Robbie pursued dual aspirations: first to become a landscape gardener, and subsequently, to enter the medical profession, all while harboring deeper feelings for Cecilia. The complexity of their relationship manifested in a peculiar scene by the pond, where Robbie's apparent authority over Cecilia emerged in an unexpected display of power dynamics. Cecilia's willing compliance with his command to undress and enter the water revealed a layer of their relationship that transcended social boundaries and conventional expectations. This moment, witnessed by young Briony, created a profound disturbance in her understanding of narrative structure and romantic relationships. The scene's defiance of traditional storytelling logic particularly troubled Briony, who struggled to reconcile the apparent reversal of social roles and the inexplicable urgency of Cecilia's actions. The interaction challenged her preconceptions about class, authority, and romantic behavior, forcing her to confront the limitations of her own narrative framework and her understanding of adult relationships, while simultaneously highlighting the complex web of emotions and power dynamics at play between Robbie and Cecilia.

paragraph1: As graduation approaches, my father's call brings news of yet another change in our already transformed family life - they're moving from our old house to a more connected suburb of Boston, a decision clearly influenced by Chitra's preferences. The new location, he explains enthusiastically, offers everything she needs: an Indian grocery store within walking distance and a community of Bengali families, a stark contrast to the isolated existence my mother had chosen for us years ago. I listen politely, though my mind is already set on my post-graduation plans to explore South America, a journey that will take me even further from this evolving family dynamic. During the graduation ceremony, I spot them in the crowd - my father, Chitra, and my stepsisters Rupa and Piu - all maintaining appropriate expressions of pride and support. Yet I can't help but feel the weight of unspoken history between us, particularly with Rupa and Piu. When we gather for family photos, our smiles feel rehearsed, our poses calculated, each of us carefully maintaining the facade of familial harmony while avoiding any genuine connection. The distance between us, born from events we never discuss, seems to stretch wider than ever, even as we stand shoulder to shoulder. After the ceremony, my father speaks optimistically about new beginnings, expressing gratitude for Chitra's role in convincing him to finally leave behind the house filled with memories of my mother. His words carry both hope and an implicit acknowledgment of the past we're all trying to move beyond, though in markedly different directions.
paragraph2: A few weeks before my college graduation, my father called to say that he was selling our house, that he and Chitra and the girls were moving to a more traditional one in a less isolated suburb of Boston. There were other Bengalis nearby and an Indian grocery in the town, things that were more important to Chitra than the proximity of the ocean and modernist architecture had been for my mother. I would not be following my father to that new house; I had made plans to travel in South America after graduating. The events over Christmas had never been discussed, never acknowledged. Along with my father, Chitra and Rupa and Piu watched my commencement sitting on folding chairs on the grass, clapping when it was my turn to walk to the dais, posing beside me for photographs in my cap and gown. The girls were polite to me, respectful of the fact that it was my day, but it was as if we’d never met. I knew that they had never revealed anything to Chitra or to my father about the things I had said and done that night, that it would remain between the three of us, that in their silence they continued both to protect and to punish me. The memory of that night was now the only tie between us, eclipsing everything else. In their utterly polite way, they made that clear. They spoke only to each other, and though their accents had turned American, my stepsisters, the closest thing I would ever have to siblings, seemed more impenetrable to me now than they had when they arrived. “Everyone closer,” my father directed from behind his new camera, and Rupa and Piu held their shoulders tensely as I draped an arm around each. “We are both moving forward, Kaushik,” my father told me after the ceremony. “New roads to explore.” And, without our having to say it, I knew we were both thankful to Chitra for chafing under whatever lingered of my mother’s spirit in the place she had last called home and for forcing us to shut its doors.

paragraph1: At my age, memories flood back like waves, taking me to a time when life moved at a different pace. I vividly remember those summer days when water trucks would dampen the dusty streets, and women would gracefully walk by in their waist cinchers and crinolines, their silhouettes a stark contrast to today's casual fashions. Back then, we lived under the shadow of different fears – polio was every mother's nightmare, and leukemia was practically a death sentence. It was actually leukemia that led to my first job when I was thirteen, a position that came about in the most unfortunate circumstances. Young Mr. Crozier, who had survived the war as a fighter pilot and later became a history scholar, was battling the disease. The irony wasn't lost on any of us – he had dodged bullets in the sky only to face this invisible enemy at home. He and his wife had moved in with Old Mrs. Crozier, his stepmother, as the illness took its toll, transforming their lives and, indirectly, leading to my early entry into the workforce.
paragraph2: I am amazed sometimes to think how old I am. I can remember when the streets of the town I lived in were sprinkled with water to lay the dust in summer, and when girls wore waist cinchers and crinolines that could stand up by themselves, and when there was nothing much to be done about things like polio and leukemia. Some people who got polio got better, crippled or not, but people with leukemia went to bed, and, after some weeks’ or months’ decline in a tragic atmosphere, they died.It was because of such a case that I got my first job, in the summer holidays, when I was thirteen.Old Mrs. Crozier lived on the other side of town. Her stepson, Bruce, who was usually called Young Mr. Crozier, had come safely home from the war, where he had been a fighter pilot, had gone to college and studied history, and got married, and now he had leukemia. He and his wife were staying with Old Mrs. Crozier.

Young Mr. Crozier, who had survived the war as a fighter pilot and later became a history scholar, was battling the disease. The irony wasn't lost on any of us – he had dodged bullets in the sky only to face this invisible enemy at home. paragraph1: During those empty, sleepless nights, I thought a lot about The Knife as an idea. A knife was a tool, and acquired meaning from the use we made of it. Language, too, was a knife. I could cut open the world and reveal its meaning, its inner workings, its secrets, its truths. It could cut through from one reality to another. It could call bullshit, open people's eyes, create beauty. Language was my knife. If I had unexpectedly been caught in an unwanted knife fight, maybe this was the knife I could use to fight back.
paragraph2: During those restless nights when sleep eludes me, I find myself contemplating the dual nature of the knife, both as a tangible object and as a metaphor for language itself. Like a blade that cuts through material, words slice through layers of deception to expose hidden truths. I've come to understand that language, much like a knife, derives its significance not from mere existence but from purposeful wielding. It serves as my trusted implement, capable of traversing between different planes of reality and extracting deeper meanings from beneath surface appearances. When confronted with hostility or falsehood, I grasp language as my weapon of choice, ready to defend and counter with precision and eloquence.

paragraph1: Ibn Rushd's passing in Marrakesh marked the beginning of a complex and somewhat ironic legacy that would stretch far beyond the Islamic world he knew. The philosopher, who had dedicated his life to reconciling Aristotelian thought with Islamic doctrine, could not have foreseen how his careful commentaries would reshape intellectual discourse in medieval Europe. His death came at a time when his works were already falling into obscurity in his homeland, yet they were simultaneously beginning a remarkable journey across cultural boundaries. The Latin translations of his commentaries on Aristotle would go on to profoundly influence Christian scholasticism and European secular thought, despite his own deeply religious convictions. This twist of fate saw his ideas taking root in contexts that might have troubled the devout Muslim scholar, as they became instrumental in developing secular philosophical traditions. Meanwhile, in the Islamic world, the theological views of his intellectual rival, Ghazali, gained ascendancy, effectively overshadowing Ibn Rushd's rationalist approach to religious understanding. The triumph of Ghazali's ideas in Islamic thought created a striking contrast: while Ibn Rushd's influence waned in his own cultural sphere, his intellectual legacy flourished in distant lands among scholars who approached his work with different cultural and religious perspectives, ultimately shaping Western philosophical discourse for centuries to come.
paragraph2: History is unkind to those it abandons and can be equally unkind to those who make it. Ibn Rushd died (of old age, or so we believe) while travelling in Marrakesh barely a year after his rehabilitation, and never saw his fame grow, never saw it spread beyond the borders of his own world and into the infidel world beyond, where his commentaries on Aristotle became the foundations of his mighty forebear’s popularity, the cornerstones of the infidels’ godless philosophy, saecularis, which meant the kind of idea that came only once in a saeculum, an age of the world, or maybe an idea for the ages, and which was the very image and echo of the ideas he had spoken only in dreams. Perhaps, as a godly man, Ibn Rushd would not have been delighted by the place history gave him, for it is a strange fate for a believer to become the inspiration of ideas that have no need of belief, and a stranger fate still for a man’s philosophy to be victorious beyond the frontiers of his own world but vanquished within those borders, because in the world he knew it was the children of his dead adversary, Ghazali, who multiplied and inherited the kingdom, while his own bastard brood spread out, leaving his forbidden name behind them, to populate the earth.

paragraph1: Remember the first time we kissed? he said. At the party. And I said I didn’t think the utility room was a good place to be kissing and we left. You know I went up to my room and waited for you, right? I mean for hours. And at first I really thought you would come. It was probably the most wretched I ever felt in my life, this kind of ecstatic wretchedness that in a way I was practically enjoying. Because even if you did come upstairs, what then? The house was full of people, it’s not like anything was going to happen. But every time I thought of going back down again I would imagine hearing you on the stairs, and I couldn’t leave, I mean I physically couldn’t. Anyway, how I felt then, knowing that you were close by and feeling completely paralysed by it, this phone call is very similar. If I told you where my car is right now, I don’t think I’d be able to leave, I think I would have to stay here just in case you
paragraph2: I still remember that night at the party when we kissed in the utility room, though I couldn't shake the feeling that it wasn't the right place for such an intimate moment. After leaving that cramped space, I retreated to my room, where minutes stretched into hours as I waited, desperately hoping to hear your footsteps approaching my door. The anticipation held me hostage, creating an invisible barrier that kept me from leaving, even as hope gradually gave way to disappointment. I sat there, frozen in place, my ears straining to catch any sound that might signal your arrival, while my mind cycled through endless possibilities of what could have been. It's strange how that same paralyzing sensation has returned now, years later, triggered by your phone call. Remember the first time we kissed? he said. At the party. And I said I didn’t think the utility room was a good place to be kissing and we left. You know I went up to my room and waited for you, right? I mean for hours. And at first I really thought you would come. It was probably the most wretched I ever felt in my life, this kind of ecstatic wretchedness that in a way I was practically enjoying. Because even if you did come upstairs, what then? The house was full of people, it’s not like anything was going to happen. But every time I thought of going back down again I would imagine hearing you on the stairs, and I couldn’t leave, I mean I physically couldn’t. Anyway, how I felt then, knowing that you were close by and feeling completely paralysed by it, this phone call is very similar. If I told you where my car is right now, I don’t think I’d be able to leave, I think I would have to stay here just in case you

paragraph1: I've always found it fascinating how we humans, despite facing existential threats like climate change and resource depletion, remain fundamentally preoccupied with matters of the heart. We obsess over relationships, chase love, and prioritize personal connections while larger, potentially species-ending problems loom on the horizon. Sometimes I wonder if this very trait - our inability to look beyond immediate emotional needs - might be what ultimately leads to our downfall. Yet paradoxically, I find this aspect of humanity deeply endearing. There's something beautiful about our species being so invested in love and connection that we might accidentally stumble toward extinction while pursuing it. Perhaps it's this same capacity for emotional attachment and caring that gives me hope. Even as I acknowledge our collective foolishness, I believe our inherent drive to connect and support one another might just be what saves us in the end.
paragraph2: Maybe we're just born to love and worry about the people we know, and to go on loving and worrying even when there are more important things we should be doing. And if that means the human species is going to die out, isn't it in a way a nice reason to die out, the nicest reason you can imagine? Because when we should have been reorganising the distribution of the world's resources and transitioning collectively to a sustainable economic model, we were worrying about sex and friendship instead. Because we loved each other too much and found each other too interesting. And I love that about humanity, and in fact it's the very reason I root for us to survive - because we are so stupid about each other.

paragraph1: From the training session (it took place at one of the castles of central Bohemia) she sent me a letter that was one hundred percent Marketa, chock-full of earnest enthusiasm for everything around her. It was all so wonderfulthe early-morning calisthenics, the talks, the discussions, even the songs they sang; she praised the "healthy atmosphere" that reigned there and diligently added a few words to the effect that the revolution in the West would not be long in coming. Actually I quite agreed with what she said; I even believed in the imminence of a revolution in Western Europe; there was only one thing I could not accepther happy, buoyant mood in the face of my desire. So I bought a postcard and (to hurt, shock, and confuse her) wroteOptimism is the opium of the people! A healthy atmosphere stinks of stupidity! Long live Trotsky! Ludvik
paragraph2: Upon receiving Marketa's letter from her training session at the castle in central Bohemia, I found myself grappling with conflicting emotions. Her words brimmed with an almost infectious enthusiasm as she detailed their daily activities, group discussions, and communal songs, all wrapped in what she called a "healthy atmosphere." While she painted a picture of camaraderie and revolutionary potential in the West, her unbridled optimism struck a discordant chord within me. Though I shared her belief in an impending revolution, her cheerful disposition felt somehow inappropriate, even offensive to my current state of mind. The stark contrast between her buoyant spirit and my own darker outlook compelled me to respond with deliberate provocation. I penned a postcard, my words carefully chosen to disturb her contentment: "Optimism is the opium of the people! A healthy atmosphere stinks of stupidity! Long live Trotsky!" I signed it simply as Ludvik, knowing my message would pierce her bubble of revolutionary idealism.

paragraph1: Aidan closes the door and puts his bag down at his feet. O.K., he says. The car smells of alcohol. Aidan still feels that he doesn’t really know who this woman is, this woman lying on the back seat. She’s coming up fairly often in his life at this point, but who is she? At first he thought she was Declan’s girlfriend, or at least a candidate for that role, but then in the hotel the other night she seemed different—glamorous in a way, with all those men looking at her—and of course Declan wasn’t there, and she even invited Aidan for a drink afterward. He could ask his brother, How do you know this girl? I mean, are you riding her, or what? But Declan’s sensibilities would be offended by that kind of thing.How would you get home if you didn’t have a lift? Pauline says.Walk, Aidan says.How long would it take?
paragraph2: Aidan gently shut the car door and set his bag on the ground, his mind wandering to the mysterious woman who kept appearing in his life like a recurring dream. He had initially dismissed her as Declan's girlfriend, but their recent encounter at the hotel had challenged that assumption. She had seemed different then - more sophisticated, self-assured, deliberately catching his eye across the lobby before suggesting they share a drink. The memory of her transformation from Declan's supposed partner to this intriguing stranger left him both curious and confused. He contemplated asking Declan directly about their connection, but the thought of his brother's likely hostile response to such questioning made him reconsider. The whole situation felt like a puzzle with missing pieces, and Aidan couldn't shake the feeling that there was more to her story than met the eye. His thoughts were interrupted by Pauline's practical question about his journey home, to which he casually mentioned walking, prompting her predictable concern about the distance.

paragraph1: Standing before the silent classroom, she drew a deep breath before shattering their innocent dreams, my impression was that she had rehearsed this moment countless times. Her words fell heavy like the rain outside, explaining with calculated precision how their aspirations of becoming film stars, relocating to America, or even working mundane jobs in supermarkets were nothing but hollow fantasies. The truth she unveiled was far more clinical: they were created for organ donation, their bodies destined to sustain others' lives. As she spoke, the students' faces reflected the weight of their predetermined fate, their earlier chatter about favorite actors and dream careers now seeming painfully naive. She made it crystal clear that they were fundamentally different from the celebrities they admired on screen, different even from herself - their lives mapped out long before they could comprehend the concept of choice or free will. The room grew thick with unspoken questions and suppressed emotions, yet she maintained her composure, her eyes occasionally drifting to the rain-soaked playing field beyond the windows. In an unexpected turn, perhaps sensing the suffocating atmosphere of despair, she suggested they head outside, her voice carrying a hint of hope that the sun might break through the clouds, offering a momentary respite from the crushing reality she had just revealed.
paragraph2: None of you will go to America, none of you will be film stars. And none of you will be working in supermarkets as I heard some of you planning the other day. Your lives are set out for you. You’ll become adults, then before you ‘re old, before you ‘re even middle-aged, you’ll start to donate your vital organs. That’s what each of you was created to do. You’re not like the actors you watch on your videos, you’re not even like me. You were brought into this world for a purpose, and your futures, all of them, have been decided. So you’re not to talk that way any more. You’ll be leaving Hailsham before long, and it’s not so far off, the day you’ll be preparing for your first donations. You need to remember that. If you ‘re to have decent lives, you have to know who you are and what lies ahead of you, every one of you.”Then she went silent, but my impression was that she was continuing to say things inside her head, because for sometime her gaze kept roving over us, going from face to face just as if she were still speaking to us. We were all pretty relieved when she turned to look out over the playing field again.“It’s not so bad now,” she said, even though the rain was as steady as ever. “Let’s just go out there. Then maybe the sun will come out too.”

paragraph1: The Minister found himself swept along by a cluster of attendants, their hands steering him toward the waiting aircraft with such insistence that his feet barely seemed to touch the ground. Words, which had been his constant companions throughout his career, suddenly felt hollow and meaningless as the gravity of action alone dominated this crucial moment. As they approached the plane's stairway, nature itself seemed to mirror his internal turbulence when a gray cloud drifted across the moon's face, unleashing a sudden, violent downpour. The heavy raindrops drummed against his shoulders and head, creating a deafening curtain that muffled the urgent instructions being called out around him. Just as abruptly as it had begun, the deluge ceased, and the moon emerged once more, casting its pale light over the glistening tarmac. The Minister clutched his suit bag tighter to his chest, a reflexive gesture of self-preservation, as he regained his composure and continued to move forward, still guided by his entourage's determined hands.
paragraph2: "This way, Minister. This way.” So many people seemed to be touching the Minister, guiding him, advising him, that he felt as if he were not so much walking as being carried. He stopped trying to speak. What point was there in words? Actions, only actions. A few feet from the stairs to the plane, he became aware of a sudden change in the lightan impudent gray cloud between the Minister of the Interior and that fat beautiful moon. Large warm raindrops big as acorns fell on his nose, on his single shoe, on his lapel, on the world. Rain fell off the curve of the plane in torrential sheets, rain rioted on the cheap tin roof of the airport, soaking the Minister to the skin, making it even harder to hear instructions, and then, just as abruptly, stopped. The cloud moved on, the moon returned. The Minister held his elbow together. He pressed his suit bag to his chest. "This way, Minister, this way.” The Minister shut his mouth and followed.

paragraph1: Contemplating Keats's poetry and his personal life, I've often wondered if the intensity of his emotions prevented him from writing love letters, as if the depth of feeling was too overwhelming to capture in mere correspondence. This thought strikes a particular chord when I think about Clarissa's fascination with imagined letters between Keats and his love, perhaps seeing parallels with our own story. In those early, heady days of our relationship, Clarissa would send me these incredibly passionate letters, each one a celebration of what we had found together, expressing something uniquely ours. I tried my best to respond in kind, but my attempts always felt constrained by my own earnestness. All I could really convey was my genuine amazement that someone like Clarissa - so beautiful, so complete - could love someone like me. Looking back, I wonder if my simple, heartfelt responses were more authentic than any elaborate declarations I might have attempted, much like how Keats's silence might have spoken volumes about the depth of his own feelings.
paragraph2: I squeezed her hand and said nothing. I knew little about Keats or his poetry, but I thought it possible that in his hopeless situation he would not have wanted to write precisely because he loved her so much. Lately I'd had the idea that Clarissa's interest in these hypothetical letters had something to do with our own situation, and with her conviction that love that did not find its expression in a letter was not perfect. In the months after we'd met, and before we'd bought the apartment, she had written me some beauties, passionately abstract in the ways our love was different from and superior to any that had ever existed. Perhaps that's the essence of a love letter, to celebrate the unique. I had tried to match her, but all that sincerity would permit me were the facts, and they seemed miraculous enough to mea beautiful woman loved and wanted to be loved by a large, clumsy, balding fellow who could hardly believe his luck.

paragraph1: It's a funny thing about the modern world. You hear girls in the toilets of clubs saying, "Yeah, he fucked off and left me. He didn't love me. He just couldn't deal with love. He was too fucked up to know how to love me." Now, how did that happen? What was it about this unlovable century that convinced us we were, despite everything, eminently lovable as a people, as a species? What made us think that anyone who fails to love us is damaged, lacking, malfunctioning in some way? And particularly if they replace us with a god, or a weeping madonna, or the face of Christ in a ciabatta roll---then we call them crazy. Deluded. Regressive. We are so convinced of the goodness of ourselves, and the goodness of our love, we cannot bear to believe that there might be something more worthy of love than us, more worthy of worship. Greeting cards routinely tell us everybody deserves love. No. Everybody deserves clean water. Not everybody deserves love all the time.
paragraph2: Standing in the dimly lit club bathroom, I watch women console each other over their latest heartbreaks, their mascara-stained faces reflecting in the spotty mirrors as they declare their exes "couldn't love properly." These moments have become almost ritualistic in their frequency, yet they spark something deeper in my mind about how we view love in our society. We've somehow collectively decided that we're all inherently deserving of romantic love, as if it's a birthright rather than something that grows through mutual effort and understanding. It's fascinating how we judge those who choose different paths – the monks, the nuns, the spiritually devoted who find fulfillment beyond romantic partnerships. We label them as damaged or incomplete, while simultaneously claiming that love should be unconditional and freely given. The irony doesn't escape me that we're more adamant about our right to be loved than our right to clean water or shelter. Perhaps we've confused what we want with what we truly deserve, creating a society that demands emotional fulfillment while neglecting basic human needs.
text_input:

Your task is to determine which paragraph is overall better in terms of writing quality.

Paragraph 1:
It's a funny thing about the modern world. You hear girls in the toilets of clubs saying, "Yeah, he fucked off and left me. He didn't love me. He just couldn't deal with love. He was too fucked up to know how to love me." Now, how did that happen? What was it about this unlovable century that convinced us we were, despite everything, eminently lovable as a people, as a species? What made us think that anyone who fails to love us is damaged, lacking, malfunctioning in some way? And particularly if they replace us with a god, or a weeping madonna, or the face of Christ in a ciabatta roll---then we call them crazy. Deluded. Regressive. We are so convinced of the goodness of ourselves, and the goodness of our love, we cannot bear to believe that there might be something more worthy of love than us, more worthy of worship. Greeting cards routinely tell us everybody deserves love. No. Everybody deserves clean water. Not everybody deserves love all the time.

Paragraph 2:
Standing in the dimly lit club bathroom, I watch women console each other over their latest heartbreaks, their mascara-stained faces reflecting in the spotty mirrors as they declare their exes "couldn't love properly." These moments have become almost ritualistic in their frequency, yet they spark something deeper in my mind about how we view love in our society. We've somehow collectively decided that we're all inherently deserving of romantic love, as if it's a birthright rather than something that grows through mutual effort and understanding. It's fascinating how we judge those who choose different paths – the monks, the nuns, the spiritually devoted who find fulfillment beyond romantic partnerships. We label them as damaged or incomplete, while simultaneously claiming that love should be unconditional and freely given. The irony doesn't escape me that we're more adamant about our right to be loved than our right to clean water or shelter. Perhaps we've confused what we want with what we truly deserve, creating a society that demands emotional fulfillment while neglecting basic human needs.

paragraph1: Fiona lived in her parents’ house, in the town where she and Grant went to university. It was a big, bay-windowed house that seemed to Grant both luxurious and disorderly, with rugs crooked on the floors and cup rings bitten into the table varnish. Her mother was Icelandic—a powerful woman with a froth of white hair and indignant far-left politics. The father was an important cardiologist, revered around the hospital but happily subservient at home, where he would listen to his wife’s strange tirades with an absentminded smile. Fiona had her own little car and a pile of cashmere sweaters, but she wasn’t in a sorority, and her mother’s political activity was probably the reason. Not that she cared. Sororities were a joke to her, and so was politics—though she liked to play “The Four Insurgent Generals” on the phonograph, and sometimes also the “Internationale,” very loud, if there was a guest she thought she could make nervous. A curly-haired gloomy-looking foreigner was courting her—she said he was a Visigoth—and so were two or three quite respectable and uneasy young interns. She made fun of them all and of Grant as well. She would drolly repeat some of his small-town phrases. He thought maybe she was joking when she proposed to him, on a cold bright day on the beach at Port Stanley. Sand was stinging their faces and the waves delivered crashing loads of gravel at their feet.
paragraph2: Growing up in her parents' house, Fiona navigated a unique domestic landscape shaped by the contrasting personalities of her mother and father. Her Icelandic mother, instantly recognizable by her striking white hair, wielded considerable influence with her strong political convictions, while her father, despite his prestigious position as a cardiologist, maintained a notably passive presence within the household. Fiona's lifestyle reflected a blend of comfort and independence, evidenced by her ownership of a small car and collection of cashmere sweaters, yet she deliberately distanced herself from conventional social structures like sororities, likely influenced by her mother's political mindset. Her approach to both politics and romantic pursuits was characterized by a sharp sense of irony, as she playfully mocked her various suitors, including a melancholic foreign admirer and several young medical interns. This tendency toward gentle mockery extended to her relationship with Grant, whom she would tease by mimicking his rural manner of speaking. The pattern of Fiona's characteristic irreverence made it all the more unexpected when she chose a particularly inhospitable day at the beach, marked by biting cold and gusty winds, to propose marriage to Grant, transforming what might have been another occasion for playful banter into a pivotal moment in their relationship.

paragraph1: I recall the early weeks of my emigration. As Stalinism had already been unanimously condemned, people readily understood the tragedy the Russian occupation meant for my country, and they saw me as wrapped in an aura of respectable sadness. I remember sitting at a bar with a Parisian intellectual who had given me much support and help. It was our first meeting in Paris, and I could see grand words hovering in the air above uspersecution, gulag, freedom, banishment from the homeland, courage, resistance, totalitarianism, police terror. Eager to drive off the kitsch of those solemn spectres, I started describing how the fact of being followed, of having police microphones in our apartments, had taught us the delectable art of the hoax. A friend and I had switched apartments, and names as well; he, a big womanizer who was regally indifferent to the microphones, had pulled off some of his finest exploits in my studio. Given that the trickiest moment in any amorous adventure is the breakup, my emigration worked out perfectly for himone fine day the girls and the ladies arrived to find the apartment locked and my name gone from the door, while I was sending off little farewell cards from Paris, with my own signature, to seven women I had never seen
paragraph2: I still vividly remember those first weeks after fleeing Russian occupation, when the world seemed to view us emigrants through a lens of what I'd call "respectable sadness." It was during that period when Stalinism was being universally condemned, and this timing worked in our favor, drawing natural sympathy from those we encountered. One evening particularly stands out in my memory: I was sitting with this Parisian intellectual who spoke in profound terms about persecution and freedom, his words hanging heavy in the air like smoke from his expensive cigarettes. The gravity of the situation almost overwhelmed me, until my mind wandered back to the clever scheme my friend and I had devised before my departure. We had switched apartments and identities to confuse the police surveillance, a plan that worked better than we'd imagined. While I prepared for my escape, my friend took full advantage of his borrowed identity, pursuing romantic adventures with remarkable enthusiasm. The absurdity of our situation reached its peak when I found myself sending farewell cards to women I'd never met, while he continued living under my name, enjoying the fruits of our identity swap. Looking back, I can't help but smile at how we managed to inject a bit of mischief into such serious circumstances.

paragraph1: As it happened, she was right about the homesickness. After her return to Bombay, she never had a day’s heart trouble again; and, as the letter from her niece Stella confirmed, at ninety-one she was still going strong. Soon after she left, my father told us he had decided to "shift location" to Pakistan. As usual, there were no discussions, no explanations, just the simple fiat. He gave up the lease on the flat in Waverley House at the end of the summer holidays, and they all went off to Karachi, while I went back to school. I became a British citizen that year. I was one of the lucky ones, I guess, because in spite of that chess game I had the Dodo on my side. And the passport did, in many ways, set me free. It allowed me to come and go, to make choices that were not the ones my father would have wished. But I, too, have ropes around my neck, I have them to this day, pulling me this way and that, East and West, the nooses tightening, commanding, choose, choose. I buck, I snort, I whinny, I rear, I kick. Ropes, I do not choose between you.Lassoes, lariats, I choose neither of you, and both. Do you hear? I refuse to
paragraph2: I remember when she finally returned to Bombay, finding relief from her heart troubles at the remarkable age of ninety-one. Stella, her niece, wrote to inform us of her improved condition, bringing a momentary sense of peace to our scattered family narrative. The memory intertwines with my own story of displacement, when my father's unilateral decision to relocate to Pakistan left me stranded in a peculiar limbo. While my family packed up our lives from Waverley House that summer, I remained behind at school, eventually claiming British citizenship – a turn of events that would have surely dismayed my father. This passport, this small booklet of freedom, became both my liberation and my burden. It granted me the very independence my father had sought to prevent, yet it also intensified the internal tug-of-war I constantly experience. I feel myself pulled by invisible ropes in multiple directions, never fully committing to one path or another. These conflicting forces – East and West, tradition and modernity, family loyalty and personal freedom – continue to shape my identity, leaving me suspended between worlds, much like a puppet caught in opposing strings, neither fully here nor there.

paragraph1: He thought of the house as his own, though for years it had been irretrievably mortgaged. And during these months of illness and despair he was struck again and again by the wonder of being in his own house, the audacity of itto walk in through his own front gate, to bar entry to whoever he wished, to close his doors and windows every night, to hear no noises except those of his family, to wander freely from room to room and about his yard, instead of being condemned, as before, to retire the moment he got home to the crowded room in one or the other of Mrs Tulsi’s houses, crowded with Shama’s sisters, their husbands, their children. As a boy he had moved from one house of strangers to another; and since his marriage he felt he had lived nowhere but in the house of the Tulsis, at Hanuman House in Arwacas, in the decaying wooden house at Shorthills, in the clumsy concrete house in Port of Spain. And now at the end he found himself in his own house, on his own half-lot of land, his own portion of the earth. That he should have been responsible for this seemed to him, in these last months, stupendous.
paragraph2: After years of transient living and shared spaces, he found himself deeply attached to his mortgaged house, a connection that grew stronger during his period of illness and desperation. The mere thought of ownership, despite the financial obligations, provided him with an unprecedented sense of comfort and security. His mind often wandered to the stark contrast between his current situation and his past experiences, particularly the crowded living arrangements with Mrs. Tulsi's family. The memories of constantly shifting between different residences as a child, followed by the years spent in various properties owned by his wife Shama's family, including Hanuman House in Arwacas and the dwellings in Shorthills and Port of Spain, had left him yearning for a place to truly call his own. Now, as he surveyed his property, a profound sense of achievement washed over him. The knowledge that this space belonged to him, that he had a personal stake in this piece of land, filled him with wonder and satisfaction. Even in his weakened state, the private sanctuary of his home offered him a refuge he had never known before, a tangible manifestation of his journey from dependence to autonomy, from being a perpetual guest to becoming a rightful owner.

paragraph1: So the girl decided to set out alone on a face-seeking journey. For the time being, she found a face that would fit her, and pasted it on where her own face should be. Without a face of some kind, people she met along the way would find her strange.The girl walked all over the world. Climbed high mountains, crossed deep rivers, walked across vast deserts, managed to make her way through savage jungles. She was sure that if she came across her face she’d recognize it right away. Since this is a very important part of my existence, she told herself. As she travelled, she met many people, and had all kinds of odd experiences. She was nearly trampled by a herd of elephants, was attacked by a huge black spider, was almost kicked by wild horses.A long time passed as she walked everywhere, examining countless faces as she went, yet she never found her own face. What she saw were always the faces of others. She didn’t know what to do. And before she knew it she was no longer a girl but an adult woman. Would she never be able to find her own face again? She fell into despair.
paragraph2: The girl set out alone on her desperate search for her own face, temporarily wearing a borrowed one to blend in with those she met along her winding path. Through treacherous mountains that scraped the sky and across rushing rivers that threatened to sweep her away, she pressed forward with unwavering determination. The borrowed face felt foreign against her skin as she traversed scorching deserts and dense jungles, narrowly escaping death when a herd of elephants almost crushed her beneath their massive feet. A giant spider's venomous attack and the powerful kicks of wild horses tested her resolve, yet she persisted in her quest for identity. "Where could my true face be hiding?" she wondered repeatedly, her internal dialogue punctuating the endless search. As seasons changed and years passed, the girl's body transformed into that of a woman, but her reflection remained a stranger's. She examined countless faces in villages and cities, in mirrors and still waters, hoping to recognize herself in someone else's features. Yet with each passing day, her heart grew heavier with the realization that her own face remained elusive, lost somewhere in the vast expanse of existence, perhaps never to be found.

paragraph1: Teaching English became my default path after university, and looking back, it felt like a natural progression from campus life - just with more responsibility and longer hours. The classroom routine, though demanding, wasn't entirely unfamiliar, and the social atmosphere among teachers reminded me of my college days. I quickly found myself part of a vibrant community of fellow teachers, all of us young and eager to explore the world while making a living. We'd gather after classes, sharing stories of cultural mishaps and classroom triumphs, planning our next international moves over cheap wine in local bars. I had grand plans of teaching in Japan, dreaming of cherry blossoms and high-tech cities, and even entertained offers from language schools in Brazil, imagining myself on Copacabana Beach between classes. Those particular dreams never materialized, but I found myself instead in the sun-drenched towns of Southern Italy, the historic streets of Portugal, and the bustling cities of Spain. It wasn't until recently, sitting in a staff room in Barcelona, that I realized how much time had passed. The new teachers were discussing TikTok lessons and Instagram reels, while my stories of lugging around heavy textbooks and using overhead projectors seemed to belong to another era entirely. The young faces around me were a mirror reflecting my own journey from eager newcomer to seasoned professional, marking the subtle shift from being part of the new wave to becoming one of the experienced old guard.
paragraph2: When I first took up English teaching after university, it seemed a good enough life—much like an extension of university. Language schools were mushrooming all over Europe, and if the teaching was tedious and the hours exploitative, at that age you don’t care too much. You spend a lot of time in bars, friends are easy to make, and there’s a feeling you’re part of a large network extending around the entire globe. You meet people fresh from their spells in Peru or Thailand, and this gets you thinking that if you wanted to, you could drift around the world indefinitely, using your contacts to get a job in any faraway corner you fancied. And always you’d be part of this cosy, extended family of itinerant teachers, swapping stories over drinks about former colleagues, psychotic school directors, eccentric British Council officers. In the late ’80s, there was talk of making a lot of money teaching in Japan, and I made serious plans to go, but it never worked out. I thought about Brazil too, even read a few books about the culture and sent off for application forms. But somehow I never got away that far. Southern Italy, Portugal for a short spell, back here to Spain. Then before you know it, you’re forty-seven years old, and the people you started out with have long ago been replaced by a generation who gossip about different things, take different drugs and listen to different music.

When I first took up English teaching after university, it seemed a good enough life—much like an extension of university. Language schools were mushrooming all over Europe, and if the teaching was tedious and the hours exploitative, at that age you don’t care too much. You spend a lot of time in bars, friends are easy to make, and there’s a feeling you’re part of a large network extending around the entire globe. You meet people fresh from their spells in Peru or Thailand, and this gets you thinking that if you wanted to, you could drift around the world indefinitely, using your contacts to get a job in any faraway corner you fancied. And always you’d be part of this cosy, extended family of itinerant teachers, swapping stories over drinks about former colleagues, psychotic school directors, eccentric British Council officers. In the late ’80s, there was talk of making a lot of money teaching in Japan, and I made serious plans to go, but it never worked out. I thought about Brazil too, even read a few books about the culture and sent off for application forms. But somehow I never got away that far. Southern Italy, Portugal for a short spell, back here to Spain. Then before you know it, you’re forty-seven years old, and the people you started out with have long ago been replaced by a generation who gossip about different things, take different drugs and listen to different music.

paragraph1: I had wanted to be a writer. But after the events I am about to describe, I studied engineering geology and became a building contractor. Even so, readers shouldn’t conclude from my telling the story now that it is over, that I’ve put it all behind me. The more I remember, the deeper I fall into it. Perhaps you, too, will follow, lured by the enigma of fathers and sons.In 1984, we lived in a small apartment deep in Beşiktaş, near the nineteenth-century Ottoman Ihlamur Palace. My father had a little pharmacy called Hayat, meaning “Life.” Once a week, it stayed open all night, and my father took the late shift. On those evenings, I’d bring him his dinner. I liked to spend time there, breathing in the medicinal smells while my father, a tall, slim, handsome figure, had his meal by the cash register. Almost thirty years have passed, but even at fortyfive I still love the smell of those old pharmacies lined with wooden drawers and cupboards.
paragraph2: Growing up in Beşiktaş near the majestic Ihlamur Palace in 1984, I spent countless hours at my father's pharmacy, Hayat, where the distinct medicinal scents became an integral part of my childhood memories. Those late evenings watching him work diligently, mixing medications and attending to patients, left an indelible mark on my young mind. Though I had always dreamed of becoming a writer, life's unexpected turns steered me toward engineering geology and eventually into the building contractor business. The familiar aroma of that pharmacy still follows me today at forty-five, offering a peculiar comfort when memories resurface. My relationship with my father, complex and multifaceted, continues to influence my life choices and emotional landscape. Sometimes, walking past old pharmacies in Istanbul, I catch a whiff of that distinctive smell, and suddenly, I'm transported back to those evenings at Hayat, where my father's dedication to his profession unknowingly shaped the man I would become, even if my path diverged from my original literary aspirations.

paragraph1: Opening my door that April evening, I expected to see Marcus's familiar face, but instead found myself staring at a woman who seemed oddly composed despite the circumstances. As she introduced herself as Sarah, my heart sank when I realized we shared more than just pleasantries – we shared the same boyfriend for nearly five years. The truth unraveled through a simple book receipt, of all things. I had lent Marcus my copy of "The Great Gatsby," which he then passed to her, unknowingly leaving behind the bookstore receipt with my name and address tucked between its pages. Her discovery explained the mysterious phone calls that ended abruptly, the unexplained absences, and the vague references to family commitments that now seemed painfully obvious. Standing there in my doorway, we were two women connected by betrayal, our separate lives suddenly and irrevocably intertwined through one man's deception.
paragraph2: Then one day in April someone rang my buzzer. I thought it was him. Instead it was another woman who knew my boyfriend just as well as I did, who saw him on the days I didn’t. I’d shared the same man with this woman for nearly five years. She lived in another neighborhood, and she’d come to know about me thanks to a book I’d lent him, the same book that he in turn, idiotically, had lent to her. Unbelievable. Inside that book there was a piece of paper, the receipt from a doctor’s visit, with my name and address. At which point all the little things that puzzled her about their relationship made sense. She realized that she was only one of his lovers, and that we were an unwitting threesome.

paragraph1: My father was forty-five or forty-six when he had a heart attack. This trouble with his heart was surprising, since for all the years we had known him as children his trouble was his stomach and his indigestion, requiring bottles and bottles of a particular brand of medicinal stomach powder, which he never had the foresight to buy when he was all right, preferring instead during a crisis to send his children on the long walk to the local pharmacy for the powder.A couple of years after this heart trouble, my father was put on half pay by the Trinidad Guardian, the newspaper for which he worked. I was in school in England when this happened, and I worried about the effect of this half pay on my family; things had been bad enough on my father’s full pay. But my father, now near the end of things, was possessed by a strange lightness of spirit. It was as though the heart illness, officially recognized by doctors and the newspaper, gave full expression and an extra validity to the unhappiness he had felt for years, with the Guardian, with my mother’s family, with his poverty, with prejudice and the British Empire and the unhappy state of India, and with many other things; and it was no longer necessary now for him to go over any of the points.
paragraph2: My father's heart attack came as a shock to us all, striking him in his mid-forties with no warning beyond his chronic gastric issues that had him regularly visiting the pharmacy for stomach powder. The sudden cardiac event seemed to mock those years of digestive complaints, presenting itself as a far more serious threat to his well-being. When the Trinidad Guardian newspaper put him on half pay two years after his heart attack, I was studying in England, and the news filled me with dread. We had barely managed with his full salary, and I couldn't help but worry about how my family would cope with this reduced income. Yet, strangely enough, father's reaction was entirely unexpected. The heart condition, now officially diagnosed, seemed to lift a weight from his shoulders. It was as if this medical verdict had somehow validated all his life's frustrations – his dissatisfaction with his job, his complicated family dynamics, the social inequities he had long railed against, and his deep-seated resentment toward the British Empire. The diagnosis became a sort of permission slip, freeing him from the obligation to constantly justify his grievances. These concerns that had once consumed him now seemed to drift away, replaced by an almost serene acceptance of his circumstances. The heart attack, paradoxically, had given him a peculiar kind of peace.

paragraph1: The quiet village of Naxalbari in West Bengal's Darjeeling District became the epicenter of a brewing storm in 1967, as decades of exploitation finally reached a breaking point. The tribal peasants, who formed the backbone of the region's tea plantations and estates, had long endured the oppressive weight of a deeply entrenched feudal system. Working under the thumb of wealthy landowners, these laborers found themselves trapped in a cycle of manipulation and denied their fundamental rights. The spark that ignited the powder keg came when a sharecropper's attempt to reclaim his rightful land was met with brutal violence from thugs dispatched by his landlord. This incident proved to be the final straw, transforming docile workers into determined revolutionaries. The peasants, now emboldened by their collective anger, adopted militant tactics that included the dramatic burning of property deeds and forceful land occupations. Their struggle took on a distinct ideological character as they embraced Maoist principles, their resistance marked by the prominent display of red flags and revolutionary chants that echoed through the hills of Darjeeling, signaling the birth of a movement that would soon shake the foundations of Indian society.
paragraph2: In 1967, in the papers and on All India Radio, they started hearing about a place called Naxalbari. It was one of a string of villages in the Darjeeling District, a narrow corridor at the northern tip of West Bengal. Tucked into the foothills of the Himalayas, nearly four hundred miles from Calcutta, closer to Tibet than to Tollygunge.Most of the villagers were tribal peasants who worked on tea plantations and large estates. For generations, they’d lived under a feudal system that hadn’t substantially changed. They were manipulated by wealthy landowners. They were pushed off fields they’d cultivated, denied revenue from crops they’d grown.That March, when a sharecropper in Naxalbari tried to plow land from which he’d been illegally evicted, his landlord sent thugs to beat him. The police had refused to intervene. After this, groups of sharecroppers began retaliating. They started burning deeds and records that had cheated them. Forcibly occupying land.It wasn’t the first instance of peasants in the Darjeeling District revolting. But this time their tactics were militant. Armed with primitive weapons, carrying red flags, shouting “Long Live Mao Tse-tung.”

paragraph1: During initial consultations, prospective patients frequently find themselves drawn to studying Dr. Henry Perowne's hands, searching for the telltale markers of surgical excellence - steadiness, sensitivity, and unblemished skin. These scrutinizing moments often become decisive turning points, with some patients revealing their discomfort through nervous glances, trembling voices, and excessively courteous goodbyes before ultimately seeking treatment elsewhere. Others, whether swayed by Perowne's professional reputation or simply indifferent to such details, choose to proceed with their treatment despite any reservations about his hands. A notable subset of patients, particularly those already grappling with cognitive challenges, may not even register such physical details during their visits. Yet, Perowne maintains a composed indifference to this selective patient attrition, secure in the knowledge that the constant flow of neurological cases will inevitably bring new patients to fill any vacancies in his practice, maintaining a steady stream of those seeking his expertise.
paragraph2: Most people at their first consultation take a furtive look at the surgeon’s hands in the hope of reassurance. Prospective patients look for delicacy, sensitivity, steadiness, perhaps unblemished pallor. On this basis, Henry Perowne loses a number of cases each year. Generally, he knows it’s about to happen before the patient doesthe downward glance repeated, the prepared questions beginning to falter, the overemphatic thanks during the retreat to the door. Other patients don’t like what they see but are ignorant of their right to go elsewhere; some note the hands but are placated by the reputation, or don’t give a damn; and there are still others who notice nothing, or feel nothing, or are unable to communicate owing to the cognitive impairment that has brought them in the first place.Perowne himself is not concerned. Let the defectors go along the corridor or across town. Others will take their place. The sea of neural misery is wide and deep.
