paragraph1: Bilquis stood naked beneath the golden light, her eyebrowless face a testament to her raw vulnerability. The reflection in the mirror revealed a stranger, someone untethered from her former self, as if the firewind that had swept through her life had carried away more than just her physical appearance. Like countless migrants before her, she had crossed invisible borders only to find herself increasingly unrecognizable, her identity eroding with each step away from home. Her youth, once vibrant and assured, now seemed like a distant dream, scattered like ashes in the wake of explosive change. The weight of her father's suicide had already begun unraveling the fabric of her past, even before she'd left her city behind. Now, stripped bare of both clothing and context, she existed in a suspended state of disconnection, her history becoming as faint as a watermark on aged paper, leaving her exposed and adrift in the harsh glare of her new reality.
paragraph2: O Bilquis. Naked and eyebrowless beneath the golden knight, wrapped in the delirium of the firewind, she saw her youth flying past her, borne away on the wings of the explosion which were still beating in her ears. All migrants leave their pasts behind, although some try to pack it into bundles and boxes but on the journey something seeps out of the treasured mementoes and old photographs, until even their owners fail to recognize them, because it is the fate of migrants to be stripped of history, to stand naked amidst the scorn of strangers upon whom they see the rich clothing, the brocades of continuity and the eyebrows of belonging at any rate, my point is that Bilquis's past left her even before she left that city; she stood in a gully, denuded by the suicide of her father, and watched it go

paragraph1: Tradition weaves through life like an invisible thread, binding generations and shaping identities with its quiet yet unyielding presence. For Samad, this cultural tapestry represents both comfort and conflict, as he grapples with its demands while steadfastly believing in its fundamental importance. He sees tradition as the bedrock of cultural identity, the very essence that gives meaning to one's existence, even as he struggles to align his own actions with its principles. The metaphor of roots runs deep in his consciousness, extending beyond mere cultural connection to encompass the very essence of stability and salvation. Even in his moments of doubt, when he recognizes the decay within himself, Samad clings to the notion that even weeds possess roots – suggesting that even flawed foundations have value. This belief becomes particularly poignant as he feels the pull of Poppy Burt-Jones, threatening to uproot him from his cultural moorings. In response, his determination to secure strong roots for his sons intensifies, driven by an almost desperate need to ensure they have the cultural anchor he fears losing himself. This preoccupation with tradition and roots reveals both his deep-seated fears and his unwavering faith in the power of cultural heritage to provide stability and direction.
paragraph2: If religion is the opium of the people, tradition is an even more sinister analgesic, simply because it rarely appears sinister. If religion is a tight band, a throbbing vein and a needle, tradition is a far homelier concoctionpoppy seeds ground into tea; a sweet cocoa drink laced with cocaine; the kind of thing your grandmother might have made. To Samad, as to the people of Thailand, tradition was culture, and culture led to roots, and these were good, these were untainted principles. That didn’t mean he could live by them, abide by them or grow in the manner they demanded, but roots were roots and roots were good. You would get nowhere telling him that weeds too have tubers, or that the first sign of loose teeth is something rotten, something degenerate, deep within the gums. Roots were what saved, the ropes one throws out to rescue drowning men, to Save Their Souls. And the further Samad himself floated out to sea, pulled down to the depths by a siren named Poppy Burt-Jones, the more determined he became to create for his boys roots on shore, deep roots that no storm or gale could displace.

paragraph1: I'd spent the Spring in London, and all in all, even if I hadn't achieved everything I'd set out to, it had been an exciting interlude. But with the weeks slipping by and summer getting closer, the old restlessness had started to return. For one thing, I was getting vaguely paranoid about running into any more of my former university friends. Wandering around Camden Town, or going through CDs I couldn’t afford in West End megastores, I’d already had too many of them come up to me, asking how I was getting on since leaving the course to "seek fame and fortune." It’s not that I was embarrassed to tell them what I’d been up to. It was just that—with a very few exceptions—none of them was capable of grasping what was or wasn't, for me at this particular point, a "successful" few months. As I’ve said, I hadn’t achieved every goal I’d set my sights on, but then thosem goals had always been more like long-term targets. And all those auditions, even the really dreary ones, had been an invaluable experience. In almost every case,
paragraph2: My spring in London brought a whirlwind of emotions that I'm still processing as the weather warms and summer creeps in. While the city's energy fueled my creative pursuits and provided countless opportunities, I can't shake the feeling that I fell short of some key objectives I'd set for myself. The thought of bumping into old university mates around town fills me with a peculiar unease, not because I'm ashamed of where I am, but because explaining my journey feels like translating a poem into a language that doesn't quite capture its essence. They'll ask about my quest for "fame and fortune" since graduation, expecting clear markers of success - roles landed, agents signed, names in playbills. But how do I convey that success, for me, lies in the countless auditions I've attended, each one a masterclass in resilience and growth? These experiences, though not resulting in immediate triumphs, have shaped my artistic journey in ways my former classmates, now pursuing more conventional paths, might struggle to understand. The spring has taught me that progress isn't always visible to others, but its impact resonates deeply within.

paragraph1: P's birthday celebration at the start of the New Year has become my favorite winter gathering, offering a refreshing break from the usual tedious family holidays. As I arrive at his house, I can already sense the vibrant energy that awaits inside. The kitchen bustles with activity as the wives efficiently coordinate the meal preparation, their laughter and chatter adding to the festive atmosphere. I eagerly accept a glass of prosecco before lunch, savoring the moment as I sample various appetizers laid out on the counter. Eventually, I find myself drifting to the patio where the other adults have congregated, some smoking, all of us relaxing as we watch the children engaged in their seemingly endless soccer match in the yard below.
paragraph2: Unlike the slog of other winter holidays spent with family, always arduous, P’s birthday, at the beginning of the New Year, was an unpredictable gathering, languorous and light. I looked forward to the commotion of the crowded house, the pots of water on the verge of boiling, the smartly dressed wives always ready to lend a hand in the kitchen. I waited for the first few glasses of prosecco before lunch to go to my head, sampled the various appetizers. Then I liked to join the other adults out on the patio for a little fresh air, to smoke a cigarette and comment on the soccer game the kids played without interruption in the yard.

Paragraph 2:

paragraph1: Every October morning in 1963, I found myself wandering through Rouen's department stores, uncomfortably warm in my winter coat, killing time until college classes would begin again. The ritual of checking for my period had become an obsession, each night ending with the same stark entry in my diary: "NOTHING." The waiting consumed me, transforming ordinary days into a blur of anxiety and hope. I tried to distract myself with a novel I'd started the previous year, but the words seemed hollow now, unable to capture my attention as they once had. One afternoon, seeking escape, I watched an Italian film called *Il Posto*, but instead of providing relief, it only crystallized the terrifying possibility that my period might never return. Despite my growing unease, I joined other girls for a showing of Sartre's *Huis Clos*, though my mind remained fixated on my absent period throughout the performance. The play's character Estelle and a peculiar boy with red eyes left an impression, yet even these theatrical elements seemed to merge with my personal crisis. In my diary that night, alongside notes about the performance, I couldn't help but reflect on how my current reality had become as stark and confining as the play's setting. The streets of Rouen, the familiar corridors of the dormitory, and even my own room had become spaces of anxious contemplation, each day marking another moment of uncertainty in this unwanted waiting game.
paragraph2: In October 1963, in the city of Rouen, I waited for my period for over a week. It was a warm, sunny month. I felt heavy and stuffy in my winter coat, especially in the department stores where I had taken to browsing and buying stockings, waiting for college to resume. When I got back to my room in the girls’ dorm in the Rue d’Herbouville, I would still hope to see a stain appear on my panties. I began writing in my diary every evening—the word NOTHING in big, underlined capital letters. I would wake up in the middle of the night and instinctively know that "nothing" had happened. The year before, around the same time, I had started work on a novel; now this seemed faraway, something that was not to be pursued. One afternoon I went to see Il Posto, an Italian film in black and white. It was the slow, sad story of a young man working as an office clerk—his very first job. The cinema was almost empty. As I watched the frail figure of the boy in his cheap raincoat, the humiliations he suffered during his pathetic existence, somehow I knew the bleeding would not come back. One evening I was talked into going to the theater by some of the girls who had gotten a spare ticket. They were putting on Huis Clos by Jean-Paul Sartre and I had never been to see a contemporary production. The theater was packed. I stared at the brightly lit stage at the back, obsessed with the fact that I no longer had my period. All I can remember about the play is the character called Estelle, a blonde girl in a blue dress, and the Boy dressed as a manservant, with red, lidless eyes. In my diary I wrote"Fantastic. If only I didn’t have this REALITY inside me.

paragraph1: I can’t complain. Unlike me, P, to whom I owe these pages, didn’t make it out of the story. She’ll never visit her children in other countries, or cry about distances or the passing of days, that merciless, automatic plot device which propels us forward and brings us to our knees. Her parties, however, have stayed with me, and the thought of them still quickens the heartthe secluded house packed with people, the sunlit lawn, those hours of sublime detachment. A setting I cherished, a promising start I tried to finish, to put into words, in which I’d been, briefly, a wayward husband, an inspired author, a happy man.
paragraph2: I survived while P did not, and that stark reality haunts me when I think about all the things they'll never experience - the chance to reunite with far-flung relatives, watch the seasons change, or see time unfold in its relentless march forward. Yet P's parties remain crystallized in my mind, each one a perfect snapshot of those magical afternoons at their secluded residence. I can still picture the sunlight dancing across the immaculate lawn, feel the hours melting away in pure delight as we gathered there. Those celebrations were more than mere social events; they were catalysts for creativity, transforming me into both a wandering spouse and an impassioned writer, finding inspiration in every moment we shared in that enchanted space.

paragraph1: Mother died on Monday 7 April in the old people’s home attached to the hospital at Pontoise, where I had installed her two years previously. The nurse said over the phone“Your mother passed away this morning, after breakfast.” It was around ten o’clock.For the first time the door of her room was closed. The body had already been washed and a strip of gauze had been wrapped around her head and under her chin, pushing all the skin up around her eyes and mouth. A sheet covered her body up to her shoulders, hiding her hands. She looked like a small mummy. The cot sides had been taken down and left on either side of the bed. I wanted to slip her into the white nightdress with a crochet border that she had once bought for her own funeral. The nurse told me one of the staff would see to this and would also take the crucifix my mother kept in her bedside drawer and place it on her chest. The two screws that pinned the copper arms on to the cross were missing. The nurse wasn’t sure they could be replaced. It didn’t matter, I wanted her to have her crucix all the same. On the trolley stood the bunch of forsythia I had brought the day before. The nurse suggested I go straight to the administration office while they drew up an inventory of my mother’s personal belongings. She had very few things of her own left – a suit, a pair of blue summer shoes, an electric shaver.
paragraph2: Standing in the sterile hospital room, I struggled to process the nurse's earlier phone call informing me of my mother's passing shortly after breakfast at the Pontoise care facility. The timing seemed almost mundane, yet it marked the end of a life that had meant everything to me. Now, as I gazed at her still form, the white gauze carefully wrapped around her head and the crisp sheet pulled up to her shoulders, I felt an overwhelming need to ensure everything was perfect for her final journey. The nightdress she had specifically chosen for this moment waited to be placed on her, a final act of dignity and respect for her wishes. I remembered the crucifix in her bedside drawer, knowing it needed some attention before it could rest properly on her chest, as she would have wanted. The nurse's gentle suggestion to visit the administration office for the inventory of her belongings served as a harsh reminder of how few material possessions she had accumulated in her final days. Each item would need to be carefully documented, though their practical value was minimal compared to the weight of memories they carried. The institutional efficiency of death's aftermath felt at odds with the profound personal loss I was experiencing, as I stood there, trying to fulfill my final duties as a child to their parent.

paragraph1: You've always known that love can't be forced or manipulated, that it must flow naturally between two hearts like a river finding its path. When you try to control love, to bend it to your will, it slips through your fingers like morning mist, leaving only emptiness behind. You understand this truth deeply now, though it took years of painful lessons to learn it. That day on the bus remains etched in your memory - your arms marked with tracks, your soul heavy with shame, convinced you were beyond redemption. The little girl didn't see what you saw in yourself; she only noticed another human being and offered her purple balloon with pure, uncomplicated kindness. You turned away, believing yourself unworthy of such a simple, beautiful gift, but you were wrong. That moment could have been your bridge back to hope, a reminder that beauty still existed in your world, even when you couldn't see it yourself.
paragraph2: You cannot convince people to love you. This is an absolute rule. No one will ever give you love because you want him or her to give it. Real love moves freely in both directions. Don’t waste your time on anything else.Most things will be okay eventually, but not everything will be. Sometimes you’ll put up a good fight and lose. Sometimes you’ll hold on really hard and realize there is no choice but to let go. Acceptance is a small, quiet room.One hot afternoon during the era in which you’ve gotten yourself ridiculously tangled up with heroin you will be riding the bus and thinking what a worthless piece of crap you are when a little girl will get on the bus holding the strings of two purple balloons. She’ll offer you one of the balloons, but you won’t take it because you believe you no longer have a right to such tiny beautiful things. You’re wrong. You do.

paragraph1: I've always wrestled with the philosophical claim that our true identity exists independently of how others see us, finding it increasingly difficult to separate my sense of self from the reflections in others' eyes. When I interact with people, I wonder if there's ever a pure, unfiltered connection between us, or if everything is inevitably mediated through the images we project and perceive. Even in my most intimate relationships, I find myself carefully maintaining certain impressions, not out of deception but because I believe caring about how we're seen is fundamental to love itself. How can someone claim to love another while being completely indifferent to how that person perceives them? My identity feels like a complex interplay between my internal world and the countless ways I'm reflected in others' consciousness, making it impossible to determine where the 'real me' truly resides.
paragraph2: A person is nothing but his image. Philosophers can tell us that it doesn't matter what the world thinks of us, that nothing matters but what we really are. But philosophers don't understand anything. As long as we live with other people, we are only what other people consider us to be. Thinking about how others see us and trying to make our image as attractive as possible is considered a kind of dissembling or cheating. But does there exist another kind of direct contact between my self and their selves except through the mediation of the eyes? Can we possibly imagine love without anxiously following our image in the mind of the beloved? When we are no longer interested in how we are seen by the person we love, it means we no longer love.
text_input:
You are given two pararaphs of creative writing for a given writing instruction.
Your task is to determine which paragraph is overall better in terms of writing quality.

Paragraph 1:
I've always wrestled with the philosophical claim that our true identity exists independently of how others see us, finding it increasingly difficult to separate my sense of self from the reflections in others' eyes. When I interact with people, I wonder if there's ever a pure, unfiltered connection between us, or if everything is inevitably mediated through the images we project and perceive. Even in my most intimate relationships, I find myself carefully maintaining certain impressions, not out of deception but because I believe caring about how we're seen is fundamental to love itself. How can someone claim to love another while being completely indifferent to how that person perceives them? My identity feels like a complex interplay between my internal world and the countless ways I'm reflected in others' consciousness, making it impossible to determine where the 'real me' truly resides.

Paragraph 2:
A person is nothing but his image. Philosophers can tell us that it doesn't matter what the world thinks of us, that nothing matters but what we really are. But philosophers don't understand anything. As long as we live with other people, we are only what other people consider us to be. Thinking about how others see us and trying to make our image as attractive as possible is considered a kind of dissembling or cheating. But does there exist another kind of direct contact between my self and their selves except through the mediation of the eyes? Can we possibly imagine love without anxiously following our image in the mind of the beloved? When we are no longer interested in how we are seen by the person we love, it means we no longer love.

paragraph1: Standing in the kitchen, I watched as she methodically opened the fridge door, pointing out the items they wouldn't be taking back to the city. Her hands lingered on each shelf, and I could sense her reluctance to leave this countryside retreat that had become more than just a temporary home. "When things get overwhelming in the city," she confided, "I'll probably close my eyes and think about this place." As their car disappeared down the gravel driveway, I began the familiar routine of preparing the house for its next occupants. While cleaning, I discovered traces of their stay scattered throughout - seashells carefully arranged on windowsills, family photographs forgotten in drawers, and shopping lists written in her distinctive handwriting. These small remnants told the story of their time here, and I found myself carefully collecting them, knowing they might want these memories back someday. The house felt different now, quieter perhaps, waiting patiently for new voices to fill its rooms and new stories to unfold within its walls.
paragraph2: Before heading out, the mother shows me the stuff in the fridge that they don’t want to take back to the city. She tells me that she’s grown quite fond of this house, that she already misses it. Maybe, when she’s feeling stressed, or overwhelmed by work, she’ll think of this placethe clean air, the hills, the clouds blazing at sunset.I wish the family safe travels and say goodbye. I stand there waiting until the car’s out of sight. Then I start to prepare the house for the new family that’s supposed to get here tomorrow. I make the beds. I tidy the room the girls turned upside down. I sweep the flies they swatted.They’ve forgotten, or left on purpose, a few things they don’t need, things I hold on to. Pictures the girls drew, shells they picked up at the beach, the last drops of a perfumed shower gel. Shopping lists in the faint, small script that the mother used, on other sheets of paper, to write all about us.

paragraph1: My mother had always taken pride in maintaining our home's modernist aesthetic, carefully selecting each piece of furniture to complement the architecture. The black leather sectional, chrome floor lamp, and glass-topped cocktail table were her signature touches, along with the white fiberglass dining table and its matching chairs that usually stood bare and pristine. Today, however, something was different. The sleek dining table, which she had always kept uncovered to showcase its contemporary design, was draped with an Indian print cloth that seemed oddly out of place among the modern furnishings. Gone were the artfully arranged fresh fruits and flowers she typically displayed; instead, I found a humble plate accompanied by a saltshaker and pickle jars. As I approached the table where my place was set, I could see the translucent luchis waiting on my plate, surrounded by several bowls of aromatic dal and vegetables, creating a scene that felt both foreign and comforting in our modernist space.
paragraph2: My mother had insisted on furnishing the house with pieces true to its modernist architecturea black leather sectional configured in a U, a chrome floor lamp arcing overhead, a glass-topped kidney-shaped cocktail table, and a dining table made of white fibreglass surrounded by matching chairs. She had never allowed a cloth to cover the table, but one was there now, something with an Indian print that could just as easily have been a bedspread and didn’t fully reach either end. In the center, instead of the generous cluster of fresh fruit or flowers my mother would have arranged, there was a stainless-steel plate holding an ordinary saltshaker and two jars of pickles, hot mango and sweet lime, their lids missing, their labels stained, spoons stuck into their oils. A single place had been set for me at one end, with translucent luchis piled on a plate, and several smaller bowls containing dal and vegetables arrayed in a semicircle.

paragraph1: There are beings who are overwhelmed by the reality of others, their way of speaking, of crossing their legs, of lighting a cigarette. They become mired in the presence of others. One day, or rather one night, they are swept away inside the desire and the will of a single Other. Everything they believed about themselves vanishes. They dissolve and watch a reflection of themselves act, obey, swept into a course of events unknown. They trail behind the will of the Other, which is always one step ahead. They never catch up.There is no submission, no consent, only the stupefaction of the real. All one can do is repeat “This can’t be happening to me” or “It is me this is happening to,” but in the event, “me” is no longer, has already changed. All that remains is the Other, master of the situation, of every gesture and the moment to follow, which only he foresees.
paragraph2: They watch themselves dissolve into mere shadows of their former selves, their autonomy slipping away like water through cupped hands. The overwhelming presence of the Other looms large, dictating their every move, thought, and desire until they can no longer distinguish their own will from this dominating force. "This can't be happening to me," they whisper in moments of clarity, but these brief glimpses of self-awareness only serve to highlight how far they've drifted from their original identity. Their lives unfold before them like a theater production where they've been relegated to spectators, watching their own bodies move through carefully orchestrated scenes directed by an unseen hand. The transformation is subtle yet absolute, leaving them trapped in a perpetual state of passive observation as their authentic selves fade into distant memory. Each day brings a further erosion of their independent will, replaced by an existence that merely echoes the desires and demands of the Other, who maintains an unwavering grip on their consciousness.

paragraph1: We aren’t supposed to want our mothers that way, with the pining intensity of sexual love, but I did, and if I couldn’t have her, I couldn’t have anything. Most of all I couldn’t have pleasure, not even for a moment. I was bereft, in agony, destroyed over her death. To experience sexual joy, it seemed, would have been to negate that reality. And more, it would have been to betray my mother, to be disloyal to the person she had been to memy hero, a single mother after she bravely left an unhealthy relationship with my father when I was five. She remarried when I was eleven. My stepfather had loved her and been a good husband to her for ten years, but shortly after she died, he’d fallen in love with someone else. His new girlfriend and her two daughters moved into my mother’s house, took her photos off the walls, erased her. I needed my stepfather to be the kind of man who would suffer for my mother, unable to go on, who would carry a torch. And if he wouldn’t do it, I would.
paragraph2: The raw ache of my mother's absence consumes me daily, manifesting in a confusing blend of devotion and desire that leaves me questioning the boundaries of filial love. This overwhelming attachment to her memory has become an almost physical longing, reminiscent of passionate love, though I recognize the inappropriateness of such feelings. My mother stands as a beacon of courage in my mind, her decision to leave my father when I was young marking her as my personal hero. The decade she spent with my stepfather seemed to validate her brave choice, offering her the happiness she deserved. Yet, his swift emotional pivot after her death has shattered my world anew. Watching him allow his new girlfriend and her children to systematically erase my mother's presence from their once-shared home feels like a betrayal of the highest order. Every removed photograph and replaced piece of furniture cuts like a fresh wound. While he moves forward, seemingly unburdened by her memory, I find myself becoming an ardent guardian of her legacy, refusing to let time or others diminish the profound impact she had on my life.

paragraph1: Gazing out from his West London window, Clive had long held romantic notions about civilization's essence, imagining it as an intricate tapestry of artistic expression, architectural brilliance, and refined living. Yet, as his eyes swept across the urban landscape before him, these idealistic visions crumbled against the harsh reality of his surroundings. The monotonous rows of identical houses stretched endlessly, their uniformity broken only by the occasional satellite dish or neglected garden. Mass-produced vehicles crawled through congested streets like mechanical ants, while discarded packaging and yesterday's newspapers tumbled across pavements in the morning breeze. This sprawling chaos, he realized, bore little resemblance to the cultural sophistication he had envisioned. Instead, it reminded him of the disheveled aftermath of a grand party, where all traces of elegance had vanished with the dawn. As he contemplated this disparity, Clive found himself questioning whether the great artists and visionaries of the past would recognize any remnants of their creative spirit in this contemporary urban jungle.
paragraph2: In his corner of West London, and in his self-preoccupied daily round, it was easy for Clive to think of civilization as the sum of all the arts, along with design, cuisine, good wine, and the like. But now it appeared that this was what it really was-square miles of meagre modern houses whose principal purpose was the support of TV aerials and dishes; factories producing worthless junk to be advertised on the televisions and, in dismal lots, lorries queuing to distribute it; and everywhere else, roads and the tyranny of traffic. It looked like a raucous dinner party the morning after. No one would have wished it this way, but no one had been asked. Nobody planned it, nobody wanted it, but most people had to live in it. To watch it mile after mile, who would have guessed that kindness or the imagination, that Purcell or Britten, Shakespeare or Milton, had ever existed?

paragraph1: Driven by an increasingly fragile mind, an aging Indian man traverses the vast American landscape while harboring an all-consuming obsession with the charismatic television personality, Miss Salma R. As his rational judgment wanes, he transforms his simple infatuation into what he perceives as profound love, drawing parallels between his situation and the romantic tales of classical literature. Inspired by the operatic rendition of Don Quichotte, he adopts this noble moniker for himself, fashioning his identity after the legendary knight-errant. With unwavering determination, he embarks on a quixotic quest to transcend the boundary between viewer and star, convinced that his gallant actions and magnetic personality will ultimately lead him into Miss Salma R.'s glittering world of fame and eventually capture her affections.
paragraph2: There once lived, at a series of temporary addresses across the United States of America, a travelling man of Indian origin, advancing years, and retreating mental powers, who had developed an unwholesome, because entirely one-sided, passion for a certain television personality, the beautiful, witty, and adored talk-show host Miss Salma R., whom he had never metan infatuation that he characterized, quite inaccurately, as love. In the name of this so-called love, he christened himself Quichotte, for the opera “Don Quichotte,” and resolved to be his “beloved” ’s knight-errant, to pursue her zealously right through the television screen into whatever exalted high-definition reality she and her kind inhabited, and, by deeds as well as by grace, to win her heart.

paragraph1: Now and then on the streets of my neighborhood I bump into a man I might have been involved with, maybe shared a life with. He always looks happy to see me. He lives with a friend of mine, and they have two children. Our relationship never goes beyond a longish chat on the sidewalk, a quick coffee together, perhaps a brief stroll in the same direction. He talks excitedly about his projects, he gesticulates, and at times as we’re walking our synchronized bodies, already quite close, discreetly overlap.
paragraph2: I sometimes see him in our neighborhood, and each time we meet, my mind wanders to what could have been. He now shares his life with Sarah, one of my friends, and they have two beautiful children together. Our encounters remain cordial, confined to lengthy chats on sun-dappled sidewalks or brief coffee meetings at the corner café. During these moments, he enthusiastically describes his latest ventures, his hands dancing through the air as he speaks, and occasionally, our shoulders brush or our knees touch under the table. These fleeting instances of closeness make me wonder about the parallel universe where we chose differently, where our paths merged instead of diverged, but I quickly push these thoughts aside and smile at his stories.

paragraph1: The useless days will add up to something. The shitty waitressing jobs. The hours writing in your journal. The long meandering walks. The hours reading poetry and story collections and novels and dead people’s diaries and wondering about sex and God and whether you should shave under your arms or not. These things are your becoming.One Christmas at the very beginning of your twenties when your mother gives you a warm coat that she saved for months to buy, don’t look at her skeptically after she tells you she thought the coat was perfect for you. Don’t hold it up and say it’s longer than you like your coats to be and too puffy and possibly even too warm. Your mother will be dead by spring. That coat will be the last gift she gave you. You will regret the small thing you didn’t say for the rest of your life.
paragraph2: In those early years of your life, you never realized how the simple acts were shaping you, molding you into who you'd become. The late-night waitressing shifts taught you patience, while your private journaling sessions helped you understand your deepest thoughts. Those long walks through the city streets, seemingly aimless at the time, were actually teaching you to observe and reflect. Even the hours spent reading dog-eared paperbacks in your tiny apartment were quietly expanding your world. Then came that Christmas in your early twenties, when your mother presented you with that practical, warm coat. You remember wanting something trendier, more fashionable, and the slight disappointment that crossed your face. If only you had known that by spring, she would be gone, and that coat would become the last gift she'd ever give you. Now, years later, you understand how those small moments, those simple gifts, carried so much more weight than you ever gave them credit for.

paragraph1: Real change happens on the level of the gesture. It’s one person doing one thing differently than he or she did before. It’s the man who opts not to invite his abusive mother to his wedding; the woman who decides to spend her Saturday mornings in a drawing class instead of scrubbing the toilets at home; the writer who won’t allow himself to be devoured by his envy; the parent who takes a deep breath instead of throwing a plate. It’s you and me standing naked before our lovers, even if it makes us feel kind of squirmy in a bad way when we do. The work is there. It’s our task. Doing it will give us strength and clarity. It will bring us closer to who we hope to be.
paragraph2: Across countless lives, individuals make deliberate choices that reshape their personal narratives through seemingly small but powerful gestures. A man finally breaks free from generational trauma by excluding his emotionally abusive mother from his wedding celebration, while a woman reclaims her creative spirit by choosing art classes over the endless cycle of household duties. In another corner of life, a writer consciously subdues his jealousy when encountering colleagues' success, transforming bitter emotions into quiet determination. A parent, caught in a moment of frustration, pauses to breathe deeply instead of lashing out, creating a new pattern of response. Paragraph 1:
Real change happens on the level of the gesture. It’s one person doing one thing differently than he or she did before. It’s the man who opts not to invite his abusive mother to his wedding; the woman who decides to spend her Saturday mornings in a drawing class instead of scrubbing the toilets at home; the writer who won’t allow himself to be devoured by his envy; the parent who takes a deep breath instead of throwing a plate. It’s you and me standing naked before our lovers, even if it makes us feel kind of squirmy in a bad way when we do. The work is there. It’s our task. Doing it will give us strength and clarity. It will bring us closer to who we hope to be.

Paragraph 2:
Across countless lives, individuals make deliberate choices that reshape their personal narratives through seemingly small but powerful gestures. paragraph1: But the plan had to change. She was not well. At first, they thought it was nerves. The upheaval. The foolish fuss.Then the pains came. Pain whenever she took a deep breath. Pain under the breastbone and in her left shoulder. She ignored it. She joked about God punishing her for her amorous adventure and said that he, God, was wasting his time when she didn’t even believe in him.She had something called pericarditis. It was serious and she had ignored it to her peril. It was something she would not be cured of but could manage, with difficulty. She could never teach again. paragraph2: She first noticed the pain during a particularly stressful week at school, brushing it off as mere exhaustion or perhaps anxiety taking its physical toll. Teaching had always demanded everything from her, and she was accustomed to pushing through discomfort for her students' sake. But this pain was different, more persistent, creeping through her chest like an unwelcome visitor that refused to leave. When the diagnosis of pericarditis finally came, it hit her with the force of an avalanche, sweeping away the carefully constructed plans she'd made for her career. The doctors' warnings about infection risks in the classroom environment left no room for negotiation – her teaching days were over. Ray, ever her steadfast supporter, didn't hesitate to reshape their lives around this new reality. His decision to join the police force in Maverley, a quiet town she'd barely heard of before, became their lifeline. Watching him adapt so readily to small-town police work while she adjusted to her new limitations filled her with equal measures of gratitude and guilt.

paragraph1: I sat beside him day after day, watching his frail form surrounded by the steady beeping of machines and tangled tubes, sharing fragments of our past at Hailsham that he desperately wanted to claim as his own. Each time I spoke of the pavilion where Tommy and Ruth would meet, or the way Miss Lucy would furrow her brow during art class, his eyes would light up with an almost childlike curiosity. He'd ask me to describe the same scenes repeatedly – the football matches on the south field, the secret corners where we'd trade our artworks, the way the morning mist would settle over the grounds during winter. Sometimes he'd interrupt with such specific questions about the guardians or the dormitory arrangements that it felt like he was trying to memorize every detail, attempting to weave these borrowed memories into the fabric of his own fading existence. As he lay there, getting closer to completing, I began to understand why these stories meant so much to him – they were more than just tales of a place he'd never been; they were lifelines to a past he wished he'd had. Watching him cling to these memories, making them his own in his final days, made me realize how fortunate I'd been to have actually lived those moments with Tommy and Ruth at Hailsham, and how those experiences, which I'd sometimes taken for granted, had shaped the very essence of who I am.
paragraph2: So over the next five or six days, I told him whatever he wanted to know, and he'd lie there, all hooked up, a gentle smile breaking through. He'd ask me about the big things and the little things. About our guardians, about how we each had our own collection chests under our beds, the football, the rounders, the little path that took you all round the outside of the main house, round all its nooks and crannies, the duck pond, the food, the view from the Art Room over the fields on a foggy morning. Sometimes he'd make me say things over and over; things I'd told him only the day before, he'd ask about like I'd never told him. "Did you have a sports pavilion?" "Which guardian was your special favourite?" At first I thought this was just the drugs, but then I realised his mind was clear enough. What he wanted was not just to hear about Hailsham, but to remember Hailsham, just like it had been his own childhood. He knew he was close to completing and so that's what he was doinggetting me to describe things to him, so they'd really sink in, so that maybe during those sleepless nights, with the drugs and the pain and the exhaustion, the line would blur between what were my memories and what were his. That was when I first understood, really understood, just how lucky we'd been—Tommy, Ruth, me, all the rest of us.

paragraph1: “Sometimes I have this dream,” the young man in the wheelchair said. His voice had a strange echo to it, as if it were rising up from the bottom of a cavernous hole. “There’s a sharp knife stabbed into the soft part of my head, where the memories are. It’s stuck deep down inside. It doesn’t hurt or weigh me down—it’s just stuck there. And I’m standing off to one side, looking at this like it’s happening to someone else. I want someone to pull the knife out, but no one knows that it’s stuck inside my head. I think about yanking it out myself, but I can’t reach my hands inside my head. It’s the strangest thing. I can stab myself, but I can’t reach the knife to pull it out. And then everything starts to disappear. I start to fade away, too. And only the knife is left. Only the knife is always there—to the very end. Like the bone of some prehistoric animal on the beach. That’s the kind of dream I have,” he said.
paragraph2: Night after night, the young man in the wheelchair finds himself revisiting the same peculiar dream, where a sharp knife protrudes from the precise location in his head where his memories are stored. The blade's presence, though striking and invasive, creates no physical discomfort or distress; rather, he experiences the scene with a detached curiosity, as if watching it happen to someone else entirely. His eyes search desperately for a helping hand, someone who might notice and extract the deeply embedded knife, but to his frustration, he remains invisible to passersby, the knife's existence acknowledged only by him. In moments of desperation, he attempts to reach for it himself, his fingers stretching and grasping, but the knife remains stubbornly beyond his reach, like an itch that cannot be scratched. As the dream progresses, the world around him gradually dissolves into nothingness, leaving only the solitary knife suspended in space, resembling an ancient bone washed up on a distant shore, weathered by time and elements.

paragraph1: During my university years in the late seventies, musical preferences seemed far more polarized than they are today, something I've noticed while observing my nephew's diverse playlist. While he effortlessly transitions from melancholic Argentinian tangos to Edith Piaf's passionate French ballads and obscure indie tracks, our musical landscape was starkly divided. Most of my peers aligned themselves with either the progressive rock enthusiasts, who spent hours dissecting complex compositions, or the classical music devotees, who rarely ventured beyond their beloved orchestral pieces. I found my musical sanctuary with Emily, a kindred spirit who shared my deep appreciation for the Great American Songbook. Together, we would spend countless afternoons hunting through record stores, building our collections of vocal standards. We both gravitated toward the smoky vocals of Sarah Vaughan, the understated elegance of Chet Baker, and the sultry interpretations of Julie London and Peggy Lee. Interestingly, neither of us particularly connected with the more popular interpretations by Frank Sinatra or Ella Fitzgerald, preferring instead the less mainstream artists who brought their own unique color to these timeless compositions.
paragraph2: Today, a young person's likely to listen to any sort of music. My nephew, who starts university this autumn, is going through his Argentinian tango phase. He also likes Edith Piaf as well as any number of the latest indie bands. But in our day tastes weren't nearly so diverse. My fellow students fell into two broad campsthe hippie types with their long hair and flowing garments who liked “progressive rock,” and the neat, tweedy ones who considered anything other than classical music a horrible din. Occasionally you’d bump into someone who professed to be into jazz, but this would always turn out to be of the so-called crossover kind—endless improvisations with no respect for the beautifully crafted songs used as their starting points. So it was a relief to discover someone else, and a girl at that, who appreciated the Great American Songbook. Like me, Emily collected LPs with sensitive, straightforward vocal interpretations of the standards—you could often find such records going cheap in junk shops, discarded by our parents’ generation. She favoured Sarah Vaughan and Chet Baker. I preferred Julie London and Peggy Lee. Neither of us was big on Sinatra or Ella Fitzgerald

paragraph1: She gets up and quickly dresses and walks through every room in the house, introducing the walls and the furniture to this new idea. A cavity everywhere, most notably in her chest. She makes coffee and doesn’t drink it. She ends up in her bedroom once more, and finds that the introduction to the current reality has to be done all over again.But then there is a surprise. She is capable, still, of shaping up another possibility.If he doesn’t know that Sadie is dead he will just expect things to go on as usual. And how would he know, unless he is told? And who would he be told by, unless by Corrie herself?She could say something that would destroy them, but she does not have to.What a time it has taken her, to figure this out.And after all, if what they had—what they have—demands payment, she is the one who can afford to pay.When she goes down to the kitchen again she goes gingerly, making everything fit into its proper place.
paragraph2: Corrie moves through her morning routine with mechanical precision, her body following familiar patterns while an inexplicable void grows in her chest. She dresses methodically, each gesture deliberate, as if trying to anchor herself to normalcy. The coffee she prepares sits untouched, its aroma filling the kitchen but failing to provide its usual comfort. Throughout the morning, she repeatedly attempts to acclimate herself to her new reality, silently mouthing words that might make Sadie's death more tangible, more real. The weight of this unshared knowledge hangs heavy, particularly when she considers him—the one person who remains blissfully unaware. A peculiar power settles over her as she realizes she alone controls this information, this devastating truth that could shatter their carefully maintained equilibrium. The recognition of her role as keeper of this secret brings both burden and clarity, as she acknowledges her willingness to shoulder whatever consequences their shared past might bring. Moving cautiously through her house, Corrie's steps betray her attempt to maintain order in a world suddenly thrown into chaos.

paragraph1: I've often pondered why we humans seem hardwired to prioritize our immediate relationships over the pressing global challenges that threaten our collective future. We spend countless hours worrying about friendships, pursuing romantic connections, and nurturing family bonds, while issues like economic inequality and environmental sustainability remain largely unaddressed. It's both fascinating and maddening how our hearts gravitate toward individual connections rather than tackling the complex problems of resource distribution that could benefit millions. Yet, there's something profoundly touching about this seemingly irrational aspect of our nature. The way we cherish personal bonds, invest deeply in love affairs, and maintain lifelong friendships might appear foolish when compared to larger societal needs, but it's precisely this capacity for intimate connection that makes me believe in humanity's worth and hope for its continued existence. Perhaps our predisposition to love and care for those closest to us, despite its apparent shortsightedness, is our most redeeming quality.
paragraph2: Maybe we're just born to love and worry about the people we know, and to go on loving and worrying even when there are more important things we should be doing. And if that means the human species is going to die out, isn't it in a way a nice reason to die out, the nicest reason you can imagine? Because when we should have been reorganising the distribution of the world's resources and transitioning collectively to a sustainable economic model, we were worrying about sex and friendship instead. Because we loved each other too much and found each other too interesting. And I love that about humanity, and in fact it's the very reason I root for us to survive - because we are so stupid about each other.

paragraph1: And so we said goodbye. I went to get my watch, which had been repaired, and my former girlfriend’s older brother slowly set off down the hill to Shibuya station. His tweed-jacketed figure was swallowed up in the afternoon crowd.I never saw him again. Chance had brought us together a second time. With nearly twenty years between encounters, in cities three hundred miles apart, we’d sat, a table between us, sipping coffee and talking over a few things. But these weren’t subjects you just chatted about over coffee. There was something more significant in our talk, something that seemed meaningful to us, in the act of living out our lives. Still, it was merely a hint, delivered by chance. There was nothing to link us together in a more systematic or organic way. (QuestionWhat elements in the lives of these two men were symbolically suggested by their two meetings and conversations?)I never saw that lovely young girl again, either, the one who was holding the LP “With the Beatles.” Sometimes I wonder—is she still hurrying down that dimly lit high-school hallway in 1964, the hem of her skirt fluttering as she goes? Sixteen even now, holding that wonderful album cover with the half-lit photo of John, Paul, George, and Ringo, clutching it tightly as though her life depended on it.
paragraph2: Standing there in the coffee shop, watching Mark's receding figure, I couldn't help but marvel at how twenty years had transformed my ex-girlfriend's brother into someone both familiar and foreign. Our conversation had meandered through the usual catching-up topics, but beneath the surface lay unspoken questions about paths not taken and lives that had diverged so completely. The steam from my cooling latte seemed to carry whispers of those deeper meanings we'd circled around but never quite grasped. As his silhouette disappeared into the bustling street, my mind drifted to another goodbye, one eternally frozen in time - that lovely young girl in the high school hallway back in 1964, clutching her "With the Beatles" album like a precious treasure. I can still see her walking away, her movements synchronized to some internal rhythm that I'll never know. Sometimes I wonder if she exists perpetually in that moment, forever sixteen, forever carrying that vinyl record, forever turning the corner at the end of that sunlit corridor. These two goodbyes, separated by decades yet somehow intertwined in my memory, remind me how we're all just passing figures in each other's stories, leaving impressions that linger long after we've walked away.

Sixteen even now, holding that wonderful album cover with the half-lit photo of John, Paul, George, and Ringo, clutching it tightly as though her life depended on it.

Paragraph 2:
Standing there in the coffee shop, watching Mark's receding figure, I couldn't help but marvel at how twenty years had transformed my ex-girlfriend's brother into someone both familiar and foreign. Our conversation had meandered through the usual catching-up topics, but beneath the surface lay unspoken questions about paths not taken and lives that had diverged so completely. The steam from my cooling latte seemed to carry whispers of those deeper meanings we'd circled around but never quite grasped. As his silhouette disappeared into the bustling street, my mind drifted to another goodbye, one eternally frozen in time - that lovely young girl in the high school hallway back in 1964, clutching her "With the Beatles" album like a precious treasure. I can still see her walking away, her movements synchronized to some internal rhythm that I'll never know. Sometimes I wonder if she exists perpetually in that moment, forever sixteen, forever carrying that vinyl record, forever turning the corner at the end of that sunlit corridor. These two goodbyes, separated by decades yet somehow intertwined in my memory, remind me how we're all just passing figures in each other's stories, leaving impressions that linger long after we've walked away.

paragraph1: Each time they had sex, she told Habara a strange and gripping story afterward. Like Queen Scheherazade in “A Thousand and One Nights.” Though, of course, Habara, unlike the king, had no plan to chop off her head the next morning. (She never stayed with him till morning, anyway.) She told Habara the stories because she wanted to, because, he guessed, she enjoyed curling up in bed and talking to a man during those languid, intimate moments after making love. And also, probably, because she wished to comfort Habara, who had to spend every day cooped up indoors.Because of this, Habara had dubbed the woman Scheherazade. He never used the name to her face, but it was how he referred to her in the small diary he kept. “Scheherazade came today,” he’d note in ballpoint pen. Then he’d record the gist of that day’s story in simple, cryptic terms that were sure to baffle anyone who might read the diary later.
paragraph2: Every afternoon, Habara awaited the arrival of the woman he privately called Scheherazade, their encounters following an unchanging pattern that had become as natural as breathing. Their physical intimacy, though passionate, served as merely a prelude to what Habara truly anticipated: the stories she would share while lying beside him in the aftermath. Like her namesake from "A Thousand and One Nights," she wove tales that transported him beyond the confines of his indoor existence, each narrative a window to the world he couldn't access. Yet unlike the legendary queen, she departed before darkness fully descended, leaving Habara to preserve fragments of her stories in his diary with cryptic notations. Her true identity remained carefully guarded in his mind, the nickname "Scheherazade" serving as both a shield and a tribute to their unique arrangement. Through her stories, she offered him not just entertainment but a lifeline to human connection, transforming his isolation into something more bearable with each visit.

paragraph1: From my position by the store window, I watched intently as the two figures outside displayed what seemed to be conflicting emotions, their faces caught between joy and distress at their encounter. Manager stood beside me, her usual businesslike demeanor softening as she observed my careful attention to the scene unfolding before us. "You notice everything, don't you, Klara?" she remarked, her voice carrying a hint of admiration. The pair outside continued their awkward dance of emotions, their body language speaking volumes about their complicated history. After they departed, Manager's gaze lingered on the now-empty sidewalk, and she mused that they must have been separated for years before this chance meeting. Her voice took on an unusually contemplative tone, quite different from her typical practical manner, and I noticed how her eyes seemed to look beyond the street, perhaps into her own past. The moment revealed not just the complexity of human reunions but also how such encounters could stir deep memories in unexpected observers, making me wonder about Manager's own story of lost connections.
paragraph2: "Those people seem so pleased to see each other," Manager said. And I realized she'd been watching them as closely as I had."Yes, they seem so happy," I said. "But it's strange because they also seem upset." "Oh, Klara," Manager said quietly. "You never miss a thing, do you?" Then Manager was silent for a long time, holding her sign in her hand and staring across the street, even after the pair had gone out of sight. Finally she said"Perhaps they hadn't met for a long time. A long, long time. Perhaps when they last held each other like that, they were still young." "Do you mean, Manager, that they lost each other?" She was quiet for another moment. "Yes," she said, eventually. "That must be it. They lost each other. And perhaps just now, just by chance, they found each other again." Manager's voice wasn't like her usual one, and though her eyes were on the outside, I thought she was now looking at nothing in particular. I even started to wonder what passers-by would think to see Manager herself in the window with us for so long.

paragraph1: I’d say that the quantity of boredom, if boredom is measurable, is much greater today than it once was. Because the old occupations, at least most of them, were unthinkable without a passionate involvementthe peasants in love with their land; my grandfather, the magician of beautiful tables; the shoemakers who knew every villager’s feet by heart; the woodsmen; the gardeners; probably even the soldiers killed with passion back then. The meaning of life wasn’t an issue, it was there with them, quite naturally in their workshops, in their fields. Each occupation had created its own mentality, its own way of being. A doctor would think differently from a peasant, a soldier would behave differently from a teacher. Today we’re all alike, all of us bound together by our shared apathy toward our work. That very apathy has become a passion. The one great collective passion of our time.
paragraph2: I often ponder how boredom seems to have tightened its grip on our modern world, a stark contrast to times past when people found genuine fulfillment in their daily labors. In my mind's eye, I see peasants working the soil with unwavering dedication, their lives intertwined with the rhythms of the earth. I think of my grandfather, whose skilled hands crafted exquisite tables with a passion that transformed mere wood into art. The shoemakers, woodsmen, gardeners, and soldiers of yesteryear each possessed a unique mindset, their identities deeply rooted in their crafts. Their work wasn't just a means of survival; it was a calling that gave their existence profound meaning. Today, however, I witness a peculiar phenomenon – a widespread detachment from our work, a collective ennui that, paradoxically, has become our only shared passion. This universal disengagement seems to be the defining characteristic of our era, binding us together in our mutual disconnection.

paragraph1: I am a simple man who decided to act and see for himself, and it is as though I have had several lives. I do not wish to add to these. Some afternoons I walk to the circle with the fountain. I see the dancers but they are separated from me as by glass. Once, when there were rumours of new burnings, someone scrawled in white paint on the pavement outside my houseSoul Brother. I understand the words; but I feel, brother to what or to whom? I was once part of the flow, never thinking of myself as a presence. Then I looked in the mirror and decided to be free. All that my freedom has brought me is the knowledge that I have a face and have a body, that I must feed this body and clothe this body for a certain number of years. Then it will be over.
paragraph2: As a simple man, I've always preferred to experience life directly, watching and absorbing rather than theorizing about it. This approach has given me the peculiar sensation of having lived multiple lives, each distinct yet somehow interconnected. I often find myself at the fountain, observing the dancers with their fluid movements, but I feel separated from them by an invisible barrier, like a sheet of glass that keeps me perpetually on the outside looking in. Years ago, someone painted "Soul Brother" outside my house during a time of unrest, and that gesture still haunts me, making me question my true connection to others and my place in the community. There was a time when I felt seamlessly woven into the fabric of everyday life, but everything changed the day I caught my reflection in the mirror and realized I needed to break free. This newfound freedom, while liberating, has made me hyperaware of my physical existence and the mundane yet essential tasks required to maintain it until my final day comes.

paragraph1: Ka firmly believed that men could be divided into two distinct categories when it came to matters of the heart. The first type required intimate knowledge of a woman's daily routines, personal anecdotes, and quirks before love could blossom in their hearts. In contrast, the second type, to which Ka himself belonged, experienced love's overwhelming force with minimal understanding of the woman in question. These men fell deeply and irrevocably in love based on mere glimpses or brief encounters, their hearts captured by an essence rather than detailed familiarity. This mysterious and somewhat irrational approach to love defined Ka's own romantic experiences throughout his life.
paragraph2: There are two kind of men,' said Ka, in a didatic voice. 'The first kind does not fall in love until he's seen how the girls eats a sandwich, how she combs her hair, what sort of nonsense she cares about, why she's angry at her father, and what sort of stories people tell about her. The second type of man -- and I am in this category -- can fall in love with a woman only if he knows next to nothing about her.

paragraph1: Standing here with you now, I can't help but think about all the years we've let slip away, Sarah. Every morning, I wake up wondering if this is all there is – the same routine, the same faces, the same unfulfilled promises. I've spent a decade chasing promotions and accolades that feel hollow now. Remember when we used to talk about moving to that little coastal town, opening a bookstore, and living simply? That dream still haunts me. We're not getting any younger, and I'm terrified of waking up at sixty-five realizing we never took the chance. I need something real, something I can hold onto – not just numbers in a bank account or a fancy title on my business card. You've always been my anchor, and I know this is crazy, but I'm asking you to be brave with me. Let's leave this behind before we become too comfortable with our regrets. The house is already on the market, and I've got two plane tickets. What do you say?
paragraph2: You've spent enough of your life already on all of that. Let's go away tomorrow, let's not waste a single day more, let's go before it's too late for us."Too late for what, exactly?" "Too late for... oh, I don't know. All I know is that I've wasted all these years looking for something, a sort of trophy I'd get only if I really, really did enough to deserve it. But I don't want it any more, I want something else now, something warm and sheltering, something I can turn to, regardless of what I do, regardless of who I become. Something that will just be there, always, like tomorrow's sky. That's what I want now, and I think it's what you should want too. But it will be too late soon. We'll become too set to change. If we don't take our chance now, another may never come for either of us."

paragraph1: Marketa was in a bad mood, and since it never rains but it pours, the phone began to ring. Karel picked up thereceiver. His voice was hesitant, his responses suspiciously laconic and suggestive. Marketa had the feeling he was choosing his words very carefully, trying to hide the real sense of what he was saying. She was certain he was making a date with another woman. "Who was that?"" she asked. Karel said it was a woman colleague who lived in the neighboring town and was supposed to come and have a meeting with him that week. From then on Marketa did not say a word. Was she really that jealous? Once upon a time she had been. Yes, when they had first fallen in love. But that was years ago. Now what she felt as jealousy was really only habit.To put it another way, every love relationship is based on unwritten conventions rashly agreed upon by the lovers during the first weeks of their love. On the one hand, they are living a sort of dream; on the other, without realizing it, they are drawing up the fine print of their contracts like the most hard-nosed of lawyers. O lovers! Be wary during those perilous first days! If you serve the other party breakfast in bed, you will be obliged to continue same in perpetuity or face charges of animosity and treason!
paragraph2: Marketa's irritation deepened as the shrill ring of the telephone pierced the already tense atmosphere. She watched Karel answer it, her suspicion mounting as his voice took on that careful, measured tone she had come to dread. His responses were frustratingly brief, each word seemingly calculated, feeding her growing certainty that a woman was on the other end of the line. When he finally hung up, his explanation about a female colleague from the neighboring town planning a meeting did little to quell her unease. Marketa maintained her silence, internally grappling with the familiar pangs of jealousy that coursed through her. As she sat there, scrutinizing her own emotions, she realized how her jealousy had evolved over the years, morphing from raw, genuine feeling into something more mechanical, almost ritualistic. It was as if she was merely going through the motions of suspicion, playing a part she had written for herself long ago. This realization led her to contemplate the broader nature of romantic relationships, how they begin like dreams where lovers unwittingly establish unspoken rules and expectations. These early moments, seemingly insignificant at the time, lay the foundation for future patterns and obligations, silently binding couples to behaviors and reactions they never consciously chose. It served as a cautionary tale for new lovers, warning them to be mindful of the subtle contracts they write in those first enchanted days together.

paragraph1: The last time I saw my mother at her home, it was July, a Sunday. I travelled there by train. At Motteville, we sat in the station for a long time. It was hot. It was quiet, both in the compartment and outside. I looked out the open window; the platform was empty. On the other side of the S.N.C.F. railroad barriers, the tall grass almost touched the lowest branches of the apple trees. It was then that I could really feel that I was approaching C. and that I was going to see my mother. The train continued on to C. at a reduced speed.Leaving the station, I thought I recognized various faces, without being able to put a name to any of them. Perhaps I had never known the names. It was less hot, thanks to the wind. It’s always windy in C. Everyone, including my mother, believes that it’s colder in C. than in other places, even those just five kilometres away.I didn’t take the taxi that was parked in front of the railway hotel, as I would have anywhere else. As soon as I’m in C., I go back to my old waysa taxi is for communions, weddings, and burials. There’s no reason to spend money like that. I headed up Rue Carnot, to the town center. At the first pâtisserie, I bought cakes, éclairs, and apple tarts—the kind she used to tell me to bring home after midday Mass. I bought some flowers, too, gladioli, which last a long time. Until I got to the housing complex where she lives, I didn’t think anything besides, I’m going to see her again and She’s waiting for me.
paragraph2: As I journeyed by train toward my mother's home that sweltering Sunday in July, the brief pause at Motteville station allowed me to absorb the drowsy atmosphere of the summer afternoon. The stillness was palpable, broken only by the distant hum of insects and the occasional metallic creak of the train's cooling engine. I could sense C. drawing nearer with each passing moment, that familiar yet somehow foreign destination where my mother awaited. Upon arrival, I found myself in the peculiar position of failing to recognize faces that should have been familiar, their features somehow altered by time or perhaps my own shifting memories. The climate in C. had always been notably cooler and more wind-swept than surrounding areas, a fact my mother never failed to mention and one that all local residents seemed to accept as gospel truth. Rather than hailing a taxi, I embraced the local custom of walking into the town center, my footsteps echoing against the cobblestones as I made my way to purchase the customary offerings - delicate pastries from the corner bakery and a carefully selected bouquet of flowers. These simple rituals stirred memories of countless previous visits, each one marked by the same anticipatory flutter in my chest as I approached my mother's door. The weight of the pastry box in one hand and the fresh flowers in the other served as tangible anchors to this moment, bridging the gap between past visits and the present, all while my thoughts raced ahead to the imminent reunion with my mother.

The last time I saw my mother at her home, it was July, a Sunday. I travelled there by train. At Motteville, we sat in the station for a long time. It was hot. It was quiet, both in the compartment and outside. I looked out the open window; the platform was empty. On the other side of the S.N.C.F. railroad barriers, the tall grass almost touched the lowest branches of the apple trees. It was then that I could really feel that I was approaching C. and that I was going to see my mother. The train continued on to C. at a reduced speed.Leaving the station, I thought I recognized various faces, without being able to put a name to any of them. Perhaps I had never known the names. It was less hot, thanks to the wind. It’s always windy in C. Everyone, including my mother, believes that it’s colder in C. than in other places, even those just five kilometres away.I didn’t take the taxi that was parked in front of the railway hotel, as I would have anywhere else. As soon as I’m in C., I go back to my old waysa taxi is for communions, weddings, and burials. There’s no reason to spend money like that. I headed up Rue Carnot, to the town center. At the first pâtisserie, I bought cakes, éclairs, and apple tarts—the kind she used to tell me to bring home after midday Mass. I bought some flowers, too, gladioli, which last a long time. Until I got to the housing complex where she lives, I didn’t think anything besides, I’m going to see her again and She’s waiting for me.

Paragraph 2:
As I journeyed by train toward my mother's home that sweltering Sunday in July, the brief pause at Motteville station allowed me to absorb the drowsy atmosphere of the summer afternoon. The stillness was palpable, broken only by the distant hum of insects and the occasional metallic creak of the train's cooling engine. I could sense C. drawing nearer with each passing moment, that familiar yet somehow foreign destination where my mother awaited. Upon arrival, I found myself in the peculiar position of failing to recognize faces that should have been familiar, their features somehow altered by time or perhaps my own shifting memories. The climate in C. had always been notably cooler and more wind-swept than surrounding areas, a fact my mother never failed to mention and one that all local residents seemed to accept as gospel truth. Rather than hailing a taxi, I embraced the local custom of walking into the town center, my footsteps echoing against the cobblestones as I made my way to purchase the customary offerings - delicate pastries from the corner bakery and a carefully selected bouquet of flowers. These simple rituals stirred memories of countless previous visits, each one marked by the same anticipatory flutter in my chest as I approached my mother's door. The weight of the pastry box in one hand and the fresh flowers in the other served as tangible anchors to this moment, bridging the gap between past visits and the present, all while my thoughts raced ahead to the imminent reunion with my mother.

paragraph1: Zora declined the lunch invitation, explaining that she had limited herself to just one meal per day, her voice tinged with resignation. When Kiki suggested an alternative activity, Zora halfheartedly proposed shopping, though her demeanor suggested deep dissatisfaction with her wardrobe and, more importantly, herself. As Kiki attempted to offer reassurance about Zora's appearance, the younger woman responded by tugging anxiously at her clothes, her gestures revealing a profound self-loathing that words couldn't mask. This interaction stirred something deep within Kiki, bringing to the surface her long-held anxieties about raising daughters in a world that seemed determined to undermine their self-worth. Despite her conscious efforts to shield them from harmful influences by carefully monitoring their media exposure and creating a nurturing environment, Kiki felt an overwhelming sense of helplessness in the face of society's relentless assault on women's body image. The pervasive negativity seemed to seep through every crack, making her protective measures feel futile against the tide of cultural pressures.
paragraph2: "Well, I won’t be here for lunch. I can only really eat one meal a day at this point. I’m going shopping – you should come," offered Zora, without enthusiasm. "We haven’t done that in for ever. I need some new shit to wear. I  hate everything I own." "You look fine." "Right. I look fine. Except I don't," said Zora, tugging sadly at her man's nightshirt. This was why Kiki had dreaded having girlsshe knew she wouldn't be able to protect them from self-disgust. To that end she had tried banning television in the early years, and never had a lipstick or a woman's magazine crossed the threshold of the Belsey home to Kiki's knowledge, but these and other precautionary measures had made no difference. It was in the air, or so it seemed to Kiki, this hatred of women and their bodies-- it seeped in with every draught in the house; people brought it home on their shoes, they breathed it in off their newspapers. There was no way to control it.

paragraph1: Portia waded into the lake, feeling the familiar embrace of water that had known her at six, at nine, at twelve, at fifteen—each version of herself preserved somehow in these unchanged waters. The white stump still protruded from the shoreline, the ancient rocks still dotted the water's edge, everything exactly as it had always been, offering a peculiar comfort in its steadfast presence. The lake's surface remained peaceful, mirroring the sky with perfect stillness, as if time itself had forgotten to move forward in this secluded corner of the world. Then the dinner bell rang, Pamela's practiced rhythm cutting through the tranquil air, and though it was merely a call to evening meals as always, something in its tone today spoke of warning, of approaching calamity. Portia stood frozen between two impulses: to flee deeper into the lake's timeless shelter or to turn back toward whatever awaited her at the house. As she hesitated, the landscape around her seemed to shift and transform in her mind's eye—trees slowly sinking beneath rising waters, the beloved white stump disappearing under relentless waves, rocks vanishing one by one into the depths. She saw herself running through this drowning world, trying desperately to alert others to the impending catastrophe, but in this waking nightmare, she was both mute and invisible, forced to watch as everything familiar slipped away beneath the surface, leaving her alone with the terrible knowledge of what was to come.
paragraph2: She wades into the lake, slipping into the water as if between the layers of a mirrorthe glass layer, the silver layer. She meets the doubles of her own legs, her own arms, going down. She floats with only her head above water. She is herself at fifteen, herself at twelve, herself at nine, at six. On the shore, attached to their familiar reflections, are the same rock, the same white stump that have always been there. The cold hush of the lake is like a long breathing out of relief. It’s safe to be this age, to know that the stump is her stump, the rock is hers, that nothing will ever change.There’s a bell, ringing faintly from the distant house. The dinner bell. It’s Pamela’s turn to cook. What will they have? A strange concoction. Pamela has her own ideas about food.The bell rings again, and Portia knows that something bad is about to happen. She could avoid it; she could swim out further, let go, and sink.She looks at the shore, at the waterline, where the lake ends. It’s no longer horizontalit seems to be on a slant, as if there had been a slippage in the bedrock; as if the trees, the granite outcrops, Wacousta Lodge, the peninsula, the whole mainland were sliding gradually down, submerging. She thinks of a boat—a huge boat, a passenger liner—tilting, descending, with the lights still on, the music still playing, the people talking on and on, still not aware of the disaster that has already overcome them. She sees herself running naked through the ballroom—an absurd, disturbing figure with dripping hair and flailing arms, screaming at them, “Don’t you see? It’s coming apart, everything’s coming apart, you’re sinking. You’re finished, you’re over, you’re dead!”She would be invisible, of course. No one would hear her. And nothing has happened, really, that hasn’t happened before.
