paragraph1: For many years I celebrated the night of January 20-21 as an anniversary.Now I know that this ordeal and this sacrifice were necessary for me to want to have children. To accept the turmoil of reproduction inside my body and, in turn, to let the coming generations pass through me.I have finished putting into words what I consider to be an extreme human experience, hearing on life and death, time, law, ethics and taboo ‒ an experience that sweeps through the body.I have rid myself of the only feeling of guilt in connection with this eventthe fact that it had happened to me and I had done nothing about it. A sort of discarded present. Among all the social and psychological reasons that may account for my past, of one I am certainthese things happened to me so that I might recount them. Maybe the true purpose of my life is for my body, my sensations and my thoughts to become writing, in other words, something intelligible and universal, causing my existence to merge into the lives and heads of other people.
paragraph2: That night of January 20-21 still haunts me, though I no longer mark it as an anniversary in the traditional sense. What was once a source of deep anguish has gradually transformed into something more profound - a crucial stepping stone toward understanding what it means to bring new life into this world. The physical and emotional toll of that experience opened my eyes to the sacrifices of parenthood, something I had always viewed with hesitation and uncertainty. For years, I carried the weight of my inaction during those dark hours, letting guilt gnaw at my conscience until I finally found solace in putting words to paper. Through writing, I've discovered my calling: to transmute these raw, visceral experiences into something universal, something that bridges the gap between my private suffering and our shared human condition. Perhaps this is why I was meant to endure that ordeal - to serve as a translator of sorts, converting intimate bodily and psychological experiences into language that resonates with others who've walked similar paths, helping them feel less alone in their own journeys of loss and transformation.

Paragraph 1:

To accept the turmoil of reproduction inside my body and, in turn, to let the coming generations pass through me.I have finished putting into words what I consider to be an extreme human experience, hearing on life and death, time, law, ethics and taboo ‒ an experience that sweeps through the body.I have rid myself of the only feeling of guilt in connection with this eventthe fact that it had happened to me and I had done nothing about it. A sort of discarded present. Among all the social and psychological reasons that may account for my past, of one I am certainthese things happened to me so that I might recount them. Maybe the true purpose of my life is for my body, my sensations and my thoughts to become writing, in other words, something intelligible and universal, causing my existence to merge into the lives and heads of other people.

Paragraph 2:
That night of January 20-21 still haunts me, though I no longer mark it as an anniversary in the traditional sense. What was once a source of deep anguish has gradually transformed into something more profound - a crucial stepping stone toward understanding what it means to bring new life into this world. The physical and emotional toll of that experience opened my eyes to the sacrifices of parenthood, something I had always viewed with hesitation and uncertainty. For years, I carried the weight of my inaction during those dark hours, letting guilt gnaw at my conscience until I finally found solace in putting words to paper. Through writing, I've discovered my calling: to transmute these raw, visceral experiences into something universal, something that bridges the gap between my private suffering and our shared human condition. Perhaps this is why I was meant to endure that ordeal - to serve as a translator of sorts, converting intimate bodily and psychological experiences into language that resonates with others who've walked similar paths, helping them feel less alone in their own journeys of loss and transformation.

paragraph1: I often find myself pondering the circumstances of my birth, contemplating the intricate web of factors that determined my entry into this world. The city I was born in, now aging and impoverished, stands as a testament to a once-great empire, its glory now buried beneath layers of historical debris and decline. Sometimes, in moments of deep reflection, I wonder if I deserved a different beginning, perhaps in a more prosperous place or during a more favorable time. Yet, I must acknowledge my relative good fortune – being born into an affluent family provided me with privileges and opportunities that many of my contemporaries lacked, especially during those challenging years when our city struggled to maintain its dignity amidst economic hardship. These thoughts about my origins feel as fundamental and unchangeable as my physical features or my gender, woven into the very fabric of my identity. Like the ancient philosophers who pondered the role of fate in human existence, I've come to view my birth circumstances as part of a larger design, neither entirely random nor completely predetermined, but existing in that mysterious space where destiny and chance intersect. This contemplation of my origins has become a recurring theme in my self-reflection, leading me to better understand not just where I came from, but who I am and how these initial conditions shaped my life's trajectory.
paragraph2: At least once in a lifetime, self-reflection leads us to examine the circumstances of our birth. Why were we born in this particular corner of the world, on this particular date? These families into which we were born, these countries and cities to which the lottery of life has assigned us – they expect love from us, and in the end, we do love them, from the bottom of our hearts – but did we perhaps deserve better? I sometimes think myself unlucky to have been born in an ageing and impoverished city buried under the ashes of a ruined empire. But a voice inside me always insists this was really a piece of luck. If it were a matter of wealth, then I could certainly count myself fortunate to have been born into an affluent family at a time when the city was at its lowest ebb (though some have ably argued the contrary). Mostly I am disinclined to complainI’ve accepted the city into which I was born in the same way I’ve accepted my body (much as I would have preferred to be more handsome and better built) and my gender (even though I still ask myself, naively, whether I might have been better off had I been born a woman). This is my fate, and there’s sense arguing with it. This book is about fate

paragraph1: Much of the rest you will know. It was the perfect story. A wild storm surged through my house and Jocelyn’s. All the correct ingredients. A wretched villain, a quiet hero. A national treasure knocked flying from his pedestal, dishonest fingers deep in the till, an old friend down on his luck, betrayed, whole passages lifted, whole conception stolen, characters, too, no plausible explanation from the guilty man, whose friends now understood his reluctance to publish, tens of thousands of copies of “The Tumult” removed from the shops and pulped. And the old friend? Nobly refused to condemn, unavailable for interviews—and, of course, a genius revealed, best book in years, a modern classic, a mild man loved by his students and colleagues, dumped by his publisher, books out of print. Then a scramble to procure the rights, all the rights, to the backlist as well as “Dance,” agents and auctions involved, film rights and movie people involved. Then the prizes—Booker, Whitbread, Medici, Critics Circle, in one long noisy banquet. Copies of the Gorgeous edition selling for five thousand pounds on AbeBooks. Then, as the dust settled, and with my book still “flying” off the shelves, thoughtful articles on the nature of literary kleptomania, the strange compulsion to be caught, and acts of artistic self-destruction in late middle age.
paragraph2: That fateful storm raged through both our houses that night, but the real tempest was yet to come when we discovered what that wretched villain had done. I still remember the shock waves through our literary circles when it emerged he'd stolen entire passages for "The Tumult," shamelessly lifting concepts and words from my old friend's work. The scandal was devastating, forcing publishers to withdraw and destroy every copy of that plagiarized book, but what emerged from those ashes was truly remarkable. My friend, who had always been a quiet hero in our circle, had endured years of setbacks and hardship, watching silently as his work was stolen. Yet fate has a way of setting things right - his genuine brilliance could no longer be contained or denied. I watched with a mixture of joy and vindication as his original works were finally recognized, becoming modern classics that sparked a fierce bidding war for rights. The awards and commercial success that followed were merely confirmation of what we'd always known about his talent. Looking back now, I can't help but reflect on how the plagiarist's self-destructive behavior ultimately served to illuminate the true genius among us, though the scars of that betrayal never fully healed.

paragraph1: I remember when she finally returned to Bombay, finding relief from her heart troubles at the remarkable age of ninety-one. Stella, her niece, wrote to inform us of her improved condition, bringing a momentary sense of peace to our scattered family narrative. The memory intertwines with my own story of displacement, when my father's unilateral decision to relocate to Pakistan left me stranded in a peculiar limbo. While my family packed up our lives from Waverley House that summer, I remained behind at school, eventually claiming British citizenship – a turn of events that would have surely dismayed my father. This passport, this small booklet of freedom, became both my liberation and my burden. It granted me the very independence my father had sought to prevent, yet it also intensified the internal tug-of-war I constantly experience. I feel myself pulled by invisible ropes in multiple directions, never fully committing to one path or another. These conflicting forces – East and West, tradition and modernity, family loyalty and personal freedom – continue to shape my identity, leaving me suspended between worlds, much like a puppet caught in opposing strings, neither fully here nor there.
paragraph2: As it happened, she was right about the homesickness. After her return to Bombay, she never had a day’s heart trouble again; and, as the letter from her niece Stella confirmed, at ninety-one she was still going strong. Soon after she left, my father told us he had decided to "shift location" to Pakistan. As usual, there were no discussions, no explanations, just the simple fiat. He gave up the lease on the flat in Waverley House at the end of the summer holidays, and they all went off to Karachi, while I went back to school. I became a British citizen that year. I was one of the lucky ones, I guess, because in spite of that chess game I had the Dodo on my side. And the passport did, in many ways, set me free. It allowed me to come and go, to make choices that were not the ones my father would have wished. But I, too, have ropes around my neck, I have them to this day, pulling me this way and that, East and West, the nooses tightening, commanding, choose, choose. I buck, I snort, I whinny, I rear, I kick. Ropes, I do not choose between you.Lassoes, lariats, I choose neither of you, and both. Do you hear? I refuse to

paragraph1: After kissing me at the door, she tried to keep talking. Last image of herin the doorway, rounded arms framing her heavy silhouette in a yellow dress—her prettiest one, tight around the chest and the belly—a wide, fixed smile. This time, once again, I felt that I was leaving badly, in a cowardly way.I took the shortest route to the train, the one that goes past the Shell station. There, in the old days, I’d stop to prepare myself for her interrogating look when I returned from the cinema, bracing myself, wiping off what was left of my lipstick. What will people think of you?On the train, I couldn’t help imagining her, washing the dishes in a solitary silence, all sign of my presence soon erased. I watched C. disappear—the Sernam buildings, the railway workers’ housing beside the tracks.
paragraph2: I watched her diminish in the doorway, her yellow dress a bright spot against the darkening threshold, her smile fixed and brave. The guilt gnawed at me as the distance grew between us, and I felt like a coward for leaving this way. My mind drifted to those evenings when I would return from the cinema, mentally rehearsing answers to her inevitable questions, preparing myself for her searching gaze. Now, as the train pulled away, I could picture her alone in the house, methodically removing traces of my existence – perhaps folding away clothes I'd left behind or rearranging furniture to fill the spaces I once occupied. Through the window, I observed the Sernam buildings sliding past, then the railway workers' houses growing smaller and smaller, each vanishing sight a reminder of what I was leaving behind, of what I was choosing to forget.

paragraph1: Corrie moves through her morning routine with mechanical precision, her body following familiar patterns while an inexplicable void grows in her chest. She dresses methodically, each gesture deliberate, as if trying to anchor herself to normalcy. The coffee she prepares sits untouched, its aroma filling the kitchen but failing to provide its usual comfort. Throughout the morning, she repeatedly attempts to acclimate herself to her new reality, silently mouthing words that might make Sadie's death more tangible, more real. The weight of this unshared knowledge hangs heavy, particularly when she considers him—the one person who remains blissfully unaware. A peculiar power settles over her as she realizes she alone controls this information, this devastating truth that could shatter their carefully maintained equilibrium. The recognition of her role as keeper of this secret brings both burden and clarity, as she acknowledges her willingness to shoulder whatever consequences their shared past might bring. Moving cautiously through her house, Corrie's steps betray her attempt to maintain order in a world suddenly thrown into chaos.
paragraph2: She gets up and quickly dresses and walks through every room in the house, introducing the walls and the furniture to this new idea. A cavity everywhere, most notably in her chest. She makes coffee and doesn’t drink it. She ends up in her bedroom once more, and finds that the introduction to the current reality has to be done all over again.But then there is a surprise. She is capable, still, of shaping up another possibility.If he doesn’t know that Sadie is dead he will just expect things to go on as usual. And how would he know, unless he is told? And who would he be told by, unless by Corrie herself?She could say something that would destroy them, but she does not have to.What a time it has taken her, to figure this out.And after all, if what they had—what they have—demands payment, she is the one who can afford to pay.When she goes down to the kitchen again she goes gingerly, making everything fit into its proper place.

Paragraph 2:
She gets up and quickly dresses and walks through every room in the house, introducing the walls and the furniture to this new idea. A cavity everywhere, most notably in her chest. She makes coffee and doesn’t drink it. She ends up in her bedroom once more, and finds that the introduction to the current reality has to be done all over again.But then there is a surprise. paragraph1: In Portugal, I swam with Mary and Sarah while the three of us were recovering from the COVID we gave each other. In Greece, I swam alone and with my husband Brian and with our friends Rachel and Zayd and with all four of our collective kids and off the side of a boat with a good number of the sixty people who were taking our writing workshop. In Norway, I swam with my family and our friends Roda and Tor and their kids in the middle of Oslo.I floated. I paddled and kicked. I waded and wavered and eventually dove in. And I remembered how I used to love to do those things. I realized that I still do.It made me think about what mustering up the energy to dive in gives us, in a larger sense—both in the water and out of it. It rattles the bones. It makes us shiver and squeal. It wakes us up and gives us the chance to feel the kind of liberation one feels when you plunge ahead and dive in, which is another way of saying let go.
paragraph2: Throughout this year, swimming became my sanctuary in diverse waters across Europe, each dip carrying its own story and significance. In Portugal, Mary, Sarah, and I found healing in the Atlantic waves as we recovered from COVID, our bodies gradually regaining strength in the salty embrace. Later, I alternated between solitary swims and shared moments with Brian, finding both solitude and connection in the water. The Mediterranean beckoned in Greece, where Rachel, Zayd, and our four children created lasting memories, their laughter echoing across the crystal-clear bays. The writing workshop participants joined me there too, turning our aquatic adventures into inspiration for stories yet untold. In Oslo, the bracing Nordic waters provided a different kind of awakening as Roda and Tor's children showed us their favorite swimming spots, their fearless plunges inspiring our own courage. Each immersion felt like a rebirth, a metaphorical letting go of worries and inhibitions. As I dove beneath the surface in these various locations, I discovered that swimming wasn't just about physical movement—it was about awakening to new experiences and embracing the freedom that comes with surrendering to the water's embrace.

paragraph1: More practically, we intended to devise an improved, more modern version of ourselves and exult in the joy of invention, the thrill of mastery. In the autumn of the twentieth century, it came about at last, the first step towards the fulfilment of an ancient dream, the beginning of the long lesson we would teach ourselves that however complicated we were, however faulty and difficult to describe in even our simplest actions and modes of being, we could be imitated and bettered. And I was there as a young man, an early and eager adopter in that chilly dawn.But artificial humans were a cliché long before they arrived, so when they did, they seemed to some a disappointment. The imagination, fleeter than history, than technological advance, had already rehearsed this future in books, then films and TV dramas, as if human actors, walking with a certain glazed look, phony head movements, some stiffness in the lower back, could prepare us for life with our cousins from the future.
paragraph2: I remember being there when artificial humans first emerged, a moment that felt both revolutionary and strangely familiar. As a young engineer deeply involved in the field, I witnessed how this breakthrough simultaneously fulfilled and fell short of humanity's age-old aspirations. We had finally achieved what generations before us had only dreamed of – creating beings that mirrored our own existence. Yet, I couldn't help but notice how the public's reaction was more subdued than expected. Years of science fiction had already painted vivid pictures of robot companions and synthetic humans in our collective imagination, making the actual arrival of artificial humans seem almost ordinary. The carefully programmed imperfections and human-like quirks we built into them were nothing new to a society raised on stories of android companions and robotic friends. It was as if popular culture had unknowingly prepared us for this moment, smoothing the path for acceptance but also diminishing the impact of what was, objectively, one of humanity's greatest technological achievements.

paragraph1: But what is the sense in forever speculating what might have happened had such and such a moment turned out differently? One could presumably drive oneself to distraction in this way. In any case, while it is all very well to talk of 'turning points', one can surely only recognize such moments in retrospect. Naturally, when one looks back to such instances today, they may indeed take the appearance of being crucial, precious moments in one's life; but of course, at the time, this was not the impression one had. Rather, it was as though one had available a never-ending number of days, months, years in which to sort out the vagaries of one's relationship with Miss Kenton; an infinite number of further opportunities in which to remedy the effect of this or that misunderstanding. There was surely nothing to indicate at the time that such evidently small incidents would render whole dreams forever irredeemable.
paragraph2: I find myself caught in an endless loop of wondering how differently everything might have turned out had I acted with more courage in those fleeting moments with Miss Kenton. It's remarkable how certain instances, which seemed so ordinary and unremarkable at the time, now loom large in my memory as crossroads where everything could have changed. A casual conversation in the pantry, a brief exchange in the hallway - these seemingly insignificant encounters now reveal themselves as opportunities lost to time. I believed, perhaps foolishly, that there would always be another chance, another moment to speak what lay in my heart. How wrong I was to take time for granted, to assume that Miss Kenton and I would have countless more occasions to bridge the growing distance between us. Now, these memories haunt me like shadows at dusk, reminding me that what appears inconsequential in the present moment may later prove to be the very pivot upon which one's entire life turns.

paragraph1: Michael could hear Marlon’s TV in the background. It was tuned to the same channel Michael was watching, but only Michael could see the images on the screen replicated simultaneously through his own window, a strange doubling sensation, like when you stand on a stage and look up at yourself on the Jumbotron. Elizabeth and Marlon were staying uptown; normally Michael, too, would be staying uptown—until five days ago he’d almost never set foot below Forty-second Street. Everyone—his brothers and sisters, all his West Coast friends—had warned him not to go downtown. It’s dangerous downtown, it’s always been that way, just stick with what you know, stay at the Carlyle. But because the helipad near the Garden had, for some reason, been out of commission it had been decided he should stay downtown, for reasons of proximity and to avoid traffic. Now Michael looked south and saw a sky darkened with ash. The ash seemed to be moving toward him. Downtown was really so much worse than anyone in L.A. could even begin to imagine.
paragraph2: Michael sat uneasily in his downtown apartment, acutely aware of the strange synchronicity unfolding around him. Through the walls, he could hear Marlon's television echoing the same broadcast playing on his own screen, creating an unsettling stereo effect that only heightened his sense of displacement. While Elizabeth and Marlon remained safely uptown, where he too should have been, circumstances involving an inoperable helipad near the Garden had forced him into this downtown location, despite the vehement protests of his family and friends. Their warnings about downtown's dangers now seemed eerily prophetic as he stood at his window, transfixed by the ominous sight before him. The southern sky had transformed into a canvas of destruction, with waves of ash advancing toward him like a slow-moving storm. The severity of the situation dawning on him, Michael realized that his West Coast connections had severely underestimated the magnitude of what was unfolding in downtown Manhattan. The doubled images on the televisions continued to play, providing a surreal backdrop to the real horror developing outside his window.

paragraph1: Outside the sky was shimmering as it does only in Istanbul in the spring. In the streets people still in their winter clothes were perspiring, but inside shops and buildings, and under the linden and chestnut trees, it was still cool. We felt the same coolness rising from the musty mattress on which we were making love, the way children play, happily forgetting everything else. A breeze wafted in through the balcony window, tinged with the sea and linden leaves; it lifted the tulle curtains, and they billowed down again in slow motion, chilling our naked bodies. From the bed of the back bedroom of the second- floor apartment, we could see a group of boys playing football in the garden below, swearing furiously in the May heat, and as it dawned on us that we were enacting, word for word, exactly those indecencies, we stopped making love to look into each other’s eyes and smile. But so great was our elation that the joke life had sent us from the back garden was forgotten as quickly as the earring.
paragraph2: On this spring afternoon in Istanbul, my partner and I find ourselves intertwined on a musty mattress, our bodies moving in perfect synchronicity as the warmth from the bustling streets seeps through the walls of our cool sanctuary. The contrast between the heat outside and the refreshing atmosphere in our room only heightens our sensations, while a gentle breeze drifts through the window, kissing our skin with its delicate chill. Our rhythm momentarily falters when we hear the unmistakable sounds of young boys playing football in the garden below, their innocent game punctuated by not-so-innocent swearing that floats up to our window. We catch each other's eyes and share a knowing smile, amused by how our own indecencies mirror theirs in an oddly innocent way. But this moment of shared humor dissolves quickly as our passion reignites, and we lose ourselves once again in our intimate dance, forgetting both the children's playful profanities and my partner's earring that has somehow slipped away in our fervor.

paragraph1: Five straight days she spent in front of the television, staring at crumbled banks and hospitals, whole blocks of stores in flames, severed rail lines and expressways. She never said a word. Sunk deep in the cushions of the sofa, her mouth clamped shut, she wouldn’t answer when Komura spoke to her. She wouldn’t shake her head or nod. Komura could not be sure that the sound of his voice was even getting through to her.Komura’s wife came from way up north in Yamagata, and, as far as he knew, she had no friends or relatives who could have been hurt in Kobe. Yet she stayed planted in front of the television from morning to night. When he got up, Komura would make his own toast and coffee, and head off to work. When he came home in the evening, he’d fix himself a snack with whatever he found in the refrigerator and eat it by himself. She’d still be glaring at the late news when he dropped off to sleep. In his presence, at least, she ate nothing and drank nothing and never went to the toilet. A stone wall of silence surrounded her. Komura gave up trying to break through.And when he came home from work on Sunday, the sixth day, his wife had disappeared.
paragraph2: The wife from Yamagata sat motionless before the television for five straight days, her eyes fixed on the endless stream of disaster coverage from Kobe, though she had no known connections to the area. Her body remained rigid, creating an invisible barrier between herself and her husband, Komura, who watched helplessly as she refused food, conversation, or any form of acknowledgment. The television's glow cast shifting shadows across her face, which had become as expressionless as a stone mask, while news anchors detailed the mounting casualties and destruction. Komura's attempts to penetrate this wall of silence proved futile; his words seemed to dissolve into the air between them, never reaching their intended destination. He found himself adapting to a strange new routine, preparing his own meals and moving through their shared space like a ghost, careful not to disturb the eerie tableau his wife had become. The air in their apartment grew heavy with unspoken words and mounting tension, until finally, on the sixth day, the spell broke in an unexpected way. Komura returned home to find the television still humming but his wife gone, leaving behind only the lingering echo of her five-day vigil and the unanswered question of what had drawn her so completely into that distant tragedy.

He found himself adapting to a strange new routine, preparing his own meals and moving through their shared space like a ghost, careful not to disturb the eerie tableau his wife had become. The air in their apartment grew heavy with unspoken words and mounting tension, until finally, on the sixth day, the spell broke in an unexpected way. Komura returned home to find the television still humming but his wife gone, leaving behind only the lingering echo of her five-day vigil and the unanswered question of what had drawn her so completely into that distant tragedy.

paragraph1: She parked the car outside the building, telling him he could give her his number though she wasn't sure if she'd use it, watching as he input the digits into her phone while the dashboard clock showed 8:56 a.m. in its green digital glow. He stepped out into the morning air, choosing to carry his suitcase with its broken wheel rather than drag it across the pavement, and turned back once to look at her before disappearing through the building's entrance. Sitting alone in the driver's seat, she found herself contemplating how her life had shifted, no longer feeling bound by the usual parameters that had once seemed to direct every decision, every moment. This new freedom felt both liberating and strange, like walking in a familiar room where all the furniture had been rearranged in the dark. She thought about how young men now invited her into their worlds, into their beds, casual propositions that should mean nothing yet somehow carried an weight she couldn't quite define. These invitations, including the phone number now stored in her device, existed in a space between meaningless and meaningful, much like the broken wheel on his suitcase – a small imperfection that somehow made the entire scene more real, more memorable. The morning light streamed through her windshield, and she sat there, aware that she was experiencing something that felt both insignificant and monumental at the same time.
paragraph2: Once she has parked outside the building, she saysYou can give me your number. But I don’t know if I’ll get in touch or not. O.K.? And, if you don’t hear from me, it won’t be because I haven’t thought about you. I will think about you. I just have to figure out what’s best. He says he understands, and he keys the number into her phone. The time on the dashboard is 8:56 a.m. He gets out of the car, and she watches him walk up to the main entrance of the building, carrying his black suitcase. One of the wheels on the case is hanging askew, broken—she can see that now. That’s probably why he carries it, instead of using the wheels.At the entrance, he turns back and looks at her over his shoulder. Then he’s gone, the door swinging shut behind him. The door of her own workplace, with its flat rectangular handle, with one glass panel broken at the bottom and patched with brown tape. She has been contained before, contained and directed, by the trappings of ordinary life. Now she no longer feels contained or directed by these forces; no longer directed by anything at all. Life has slipped free of its netting. She can do very strange things now; she can find herself a very strange person. Young men can invite her into holiday cottages for sexual reasons. It means nothing. That isn’t trueit means something, but the meaning is unfamiliar.

paragraph1: We drift along the Lazy River each afternoon, our bodies buoyed by inflatable rings and our minds pleasantly numbed by the steady stream of all-inclusive cocktails that we've calculated will eventually make this holiday pay for itself. None of us speaks about this particular math out loud, but we all know the score, keeping mental tallies of our drinks against the package price. The Spanish sun beats down on our British skin as we float past each other, exchanging knowing glances and bits of conversation about last night's karaoke triumphs. We stick to what we know best – the comfort of familiar sausages and chips at the buffet, barely glancing at the paella that sits untouched. Old Dave's Amy Winehouse tattoos on his shins have become something of a legend among us; we've all stopped to admire them at some point, understanding without saying that they represent more than just fan art – they're a marker of our shared cultural grief, a connection to home even here in Almería. The days blur together in a pleasant haze of poolside sudoku and gossip about the other guests, while evenings find us gathered around the karaoke machine, belting out "Rehab" and "Back to Black" with a passion that surprises the hotel staff. We're not here for authentic Spanish experiences or cultural enlightenment; we're here to be together, to be ourselves, to float along our own familiar current while technically being abroad.
paragraph2: The Lazy River is a metaphor and at the same time a real body of artificial water, in an all-inclusive hotel, in Almería, somewhere in southern Spain. We do not leave the hotel (except to buy flotation devices). The plan is to beat our hotel at its own game. What you do is you do thisyou drink so much alcohol that your accommodation is effectively free. (Only the most vulgar among us speak this plan aloud but we are all on board.) For in this hotel we are all British, we are en masse, we are unashamed. We enjoy one another’s company. There is nobody French or German here to see us at the buffet, rejecting paella and swordfish in favor of sausages and chips, nor anyone to judge us as we lie on our loungers, turning from the concept of literature toward the reality of sudoku. One of our tribe, an older gentleman, has a portrait of Amy Winehouse on each shin, and we do not judge him, not at all, how could we? We do not have so many saints of Amy’s calibre left to us; we cherish her. She was one of the few who expressed our pain without ridiculing or diminishing it. It is therefore fitting that in the evenings, during the brief spell in which we emerge from the Lazy River, we will, at karaoke hour, belt out her famous torch songs—full-throated, already drunk—content in the knowledge that later, much later, when all of this is over, these same beloved verses will be sung at our funerals.

paragraph1: This summer, for the first time, I watched an X-rated film on Canal Plus. My television set doesn't have a decoder; the images on the screen were blurred, the words replaced by strange sound effects, hissing and babbling, a different sort of language, soft and continuous. One could make out the figure of a woman in a corset and stockings, and a man. The story was incomprehensible; it was impossible to predict any of their actions or movements. The man walked up to the woman. There was a close-up of the woman's genitals, clearly visible among the shimmerings of the screen, then of the man's penis, fully erect, sliding into the woman's vagina. For a long time this coming and going of the two sex organs was shown from several angles. The cock reappeared, in the man's hand, and the sperm spilled on to the woman's belly. No doubt one gets used to such a sight; the first time is shattering. Centuries and centuries, hundreds of generations have gone by, and it is only now that one can see this—a man's penis and a woman's vagina coming together, the sperm—something one could barely take in without dying has become as easy to watch as a handshake.It occurred to me that writing should also aim for that—the impression conveyed by sexual intercourse, a feeling of anxiety and stupefaction, a suspension of moral judgment.
paragraph2: My first encounter with an X-rated film on Canal Plus became a peculiar meditation on the nature of censorship and perception. Without a decoder, the television screen offered only scrambled images and garbled sounds, yet somehow this technical limitation created its own kind of voyeuristic intrigue. Through the electronic snow and distortion, I could make out the silhouette of a woman dressed in corset and stockings, accompanied by a male figure whose movements remained largely mysterious. The visual interference transformed what should have been explicit into something almost abstract – body parts appearing and disappearing like fragments of a dream, their actions impossible to anticipate or fully comprehend. As the scene progressed, the focus shifted deliberately to their most intimate parts, the camera exploring their coupling from various angles until reaching its inevitable conclusion with his release onto her stomach. This experience led me to contemplate how something once considered unviewable had become commonplace in our modern world. More than just a censored peep show, it sparked thoughts about the raw power of unfiltered human experience and how writing might capture that same visceral quality – that mixture of anticipation, wonder, and suspension of judgment that comes with witnessing such primal acts, even through a veil of electronic interference.

paragraph1: In the old days when there was a movie theatre in every town there was one in this town, too, in Maverley, and it was called the Capital, as such theatres often were. Morgan Holly was the owner and the projectionist. He didn’t like dealing with the public—he preferred to sit in his upstairs cubbyhole managing the story on the screen—so naturally he was annoyed when the girl who took the tickets told him that she was going to have to quit, because she was having a baby. He might have expected this—she had been married for half a year, and in those days you were supposed to get out of the public eye before you began to show—but he so disliked change and the idea of people having private lives that he was taken by surprise.
paragraph2: Morgan Holly, the reclusive owner and projectionist of the Capital theatre in Maverley, found solace in his upstairs cubbyhole, deliberately distancing himself from the bustling crowds below. His carefully maintained routine faced an unwelcome disruption when his ticket girl announced her impending departure due to pregnancy. Though she had married recently, and the social expectations of the era would naturally lead to such an outcome, Morgan struggled to accept this development. The news struck him with unexpected force, despite its predictability, as he harbored a deep-seated aversion to both change and the intrusion of others' personal affairs into his ordered world. The small-town theatre, which had long served as his sanctuary from human complications, now forced him to confront the very interactions he had so meticulously avoided in his self-imposed isolation.

paragraph1: While saying goodnight to Rico and Rocco, the charismatic Tunisian twins who'd just wrapped up their performance and proudly shared their X Factor Spain success story, I found myself strategically positioning myself to block my children's view of their protruding iPhones - a technology we'd agreed to withhold until they turned twelve. The twins' identical features and synchronized movements still lingered in my mind as our families parted ways to our mirror-image hotel rooms for the night. Once the kids had drifted off to sleep, we adults gravitated to our usual evening ritual, gathering on the balcony with our devices glowing in the darkness. Like clockwork, we joined the silent community of other guests, all of us perched on our respective balconies, united in our nightly ritual of checking that particular Twitter feed. Below us, the Lazy River attraction curved through the property, its Facebook-blue illumination casting an ethereal glow across the night landscape. The scene was made even more surreal by the sight of a fully clothed man, assisted by his colleague, determinedly working against the current with a mop, methodically cleaning the river's edges in what seemed like an endless battle against the perpetual flow.
paragraph2: By the time we reach the gates of the hotel all is dark. A pair of identical twins, Rico and Rocco, in their twenties, with oily black curls and skinny white jeans—twin iPhones wedged in their tight pockets—have just finished their act and are packing up their boom box. "We come runner-up "X Factor" Spain,” they say, in answer to our queries. "We are Tunisia for birth but now we are Spain.” We wish them well and good night, and divert our children’s eyes from the obscene bulge of those iPhones, the existence of which we have decided not to reveal to them for many years, or at least until they are twelve. At the elevators, we separate from our friends and their children and ascend to our room, which is the same as their room and everybody’s room, and put the children to bed and sit on the balcony with our laptops and our phones, where we look up his Twitter, as we have every night since January. Here and there, on other balconies, we spot other men and women on other loungers with other devices, engaged in much the same routine. Down below, the Lazy River runs, a neon blue, a crazy blue, a Facebook blue. In it stands a fully clothed man armed with a long mop—he is being held in place by another man, who grips him by the waist, so that the first man may angle his mop and position himself against the strong yet somniferous current and clean whatever scum we have left of ourselves off the sides.

paragraph1: Doree and Maggie got into the habit of shopping for groceries together, after they’d picked up the papers at the school. Then sometimes they got take-out coffees at Tim Horton’s and took the children to Riverside Park. They sat on a bench while Sasha and Maggie’s boys raced around or hung from the climbing contraptions, and Barbara Ann pumped on the swing and Dimitri played in the sandbox. Or they sat in the mini, if it was cold. They talked mostly about the children, and things they cooked, but somehow Doree found out about how Maggie had trekked around Europe before training as an optometrist and Maggie found out how young Doree had been when she got married. Also about how easily she had become pregnant at first, and how she didn’t so easily anymore, and how that made Lloyd suspicious, so that he went through her dresser drawers looking for birth-control pills—thinking she must be taking them on the sly.
paragraph2: Doree and Maggie's friendship blossomed around their weekly ritual of collecting school papers and grocery shopping, their children in tow as they navigated the aisles together. When weather permitted, they would extend their outings to Riverside Park, where they could observe their little ones from the comfort of a park bench, or during colder days, retreat to the warmth of Maggie's mini van. Their conversations flowed naturally, weaving between practical discussions about meal preparations and their children's latest adventures. As their bond deepened, they began sharing more intimate details of their lives. Maggie painted vivid pictures of her European adventures before settling into her career as an optometrist, while Doree opened up about her early marriage and the initial joy of effortless pregnancies. She even confided in Maggie about Lloyd's growing suspicions regarding her later fertility challenges, their shared moments of vulnerability strengthening their connection beyond mere grocery store companions.

paragraph1: The memory would never leave him. The bed was a double by the standards of the time, less than five feet across. Two sets of two pillows. She sat against one set with her knees drawn up. While he was undressing, she had taken off her cardigan and jeans. Her knickers, like her T-shirt, were green. Cotton, not silk. The T-shirt was a large man’s size, and perhaps he should have worried about a rival. The folds of the material, brushed cotton, seemed to him voluptuous in his heightened state. Her eyes were also green. He had once thought there was something cruel about them. Now their color suggested daring. She could do anything she wanted. Her bare legs had traces of a summer tan. Her round face, which once had the quality of a mask, now had a soft and open look. The light through the small bedroom window picked out the strength of her cheekbones. No lipstick this Saturday morning. The hair she had worn in a bun for lessons was very fine and strands of it floated up when she moved her head. She was looking at him in that patient, wry way she had. Something about him amused her. She pulled her T-shirt off and let it fall to the floor.
paragraph2: He methodically unbuttoned his shirt while watching her recline against the pillows, her knees drawn up in a casual yet enticing pose. The green cotton knickers matched her oversized T-shirt, and he couldn't help but wonder momentarily about its origin - the shirt was clearly meant for a man's frame. The thought of a potential rival flickered briefly through his mind before dissipating as he focused on the soft, worn quality of the cotton material, imagining how it would feel beneath his fingers. Her green eyes, which he had once mistaken for cruelty, now held a different quality altogether - a daring glint that spoke of confidence and desire. The afternoon light streaming through the window cast gentle shadows across her face, softening her features and accentuating her cheekbones in a way that made her round face appear more vulnerable than usual. She returned his gaze with a patient, almost knowing expression, a slight curve playing at the corners of her mouth as she maintained eye contact. The wry smile lingered as she gradually pulled the T-shirt over her head, the deliberate movement transforming the atmosphere in the room from contemplative to charged with anticipation.

paragraph1: That day on the tennis court with Tony Canning remains etched in my memory, a bitter reminder of my inadequacies and shattered confidence. Though I had always prided myself on my tennis abilities, something entirely different was at play that afternoon - a power dynamic that left me feeling helpless and small. When Tony reached for my keys, I couldn't muster the strength to resist, watching passively as they slipped from my grasp into his waiting hand. The disappointment in his eyes was palpable, cutting through me like a knife, and when he threw my bag to the ground with such dismissive force, I felt my heart sink to the depths of my stomach. The gentle purr of his car's engine seemed to mock me as I stood there, desperately trying to make him understand, to acknowledge the truth that hung heavy between us. But he wouldn't - or couldn't - give me that closure. As his car disappeared into the distance, I was left standing there, feeling every bit the tragic fool I'd become in his eyes. The irony wasn't lost on me that just two days later, I would sit through an interview that would launch my career, but that small victory felt hollow without Tony's presence. He never returned to my life after that day, leaving me with nothing but questions and the lingering taste of regret that accompanies unfinished conversations and unresolved emotions.
paragraph2: After three years of Newnham tennis, my throw would have been reasonably strong. But I wasn’t able to show it off. My arm was at the limit of its backswing when I felt his fingers curl around my wrist and tighten. He had the keys off me in seconds. He wasn’t rough, and I put up no struggle. He pushed around me and got into his car without speaking. He had said enough, and, besides, I had just confirmed the worst of his expectations. He tossed my bag onto the ground, slammed the door, and started the engine. Now that I had my voice back, what did I say? Again, I was pathetic. I didn’t want him to leave. I called stupidly through the car’s canvas top, “Tony, stop pretending that you don’t know the truth.”How ridiculous. Of course he wasn’t pretending. That was precisely his failure. He gunned the engine a couple of times, in case I wanted to say anything else that needed drowning out. Then he pulled forward—slowly at first, concerned perhaps that I would throw myself onto the car or under its wheels. But I just stood there like a tragic fool and watched him go. I saw his brake lights come on as he slowed to join the traffic. Then he was gone, and it was over.Two days later, I attended the interview and was accepted. Tony Canning delivered me to my career, but I never saw him again.

paragraph1: I didn't know, nor have I ever discovered, who let go first. I'm not prepared to accept that it was me. But everyone claims not to have been first. What is certain is that if we had not broken ranks, our collective weight would have brought the balloon to earth a quarter of the way down the slope a few seconds later as the gust subsided. But as I've said, there was no team, there was no plan, no agreement to be broken. No failure. So can we accept that it was right, every man for himself? Were we all happy afterwards that this was a reasonable course? We never had that comfort, for there was a deeper covenant, ancient and automatic, written in our nature. Co-operation - the basis of our earliest hunting successes, the force behind our evolving capacity for language, the glue of our social cohesion. Our misery in the aftermath was proof that we knew we had failed ourselves. But letting go was in our nature too. Selfishness is also written in our hearts.
paragraph2: As I replay those crucial moments in my mind, I can't shake the crushing weight of our collective failure when that sudden gust hit the balloon. We had been holding on together, our hands white-knuckled and determined, but something primitive took over when the wind threatened to lift us all. One by one, we let go, each person's release triggering a cascade of abandonment that seemed to unfold in slow motion. The irony isn't lost on me – our strength lay in unity, yet we succumbed to our basest instincts for self-preservation. I keep wondering if I was any better than the others, having released my grip when the situation became dire. The misery that followed wasn't just about the physical consequences; it was the stark realization of how quickly our social bonds could unravel under pressure. Perhaps this is the uncomfortable truth about human nature – we're social creatures who preach cooperation, yet when pushed to our limits, we often choose ourselves over the collective good. This duality haunts me, forcing me to confront the selfish impulses that lurk beneath our civilized veneer.

paragraph1: Halfway through June of 1965, the term at Torrance House School for Girls is over. Juliet has not been offered a permanent job—the teacher she was replacing has recovered from a bout of depression—and she could now be on her way home. Instead, she is taking what she has described as a little detour. A little detour to see a friend who lives up the coast.About a month ago, she went with another teacher—Juanita, the only person on the staff who is near her age, and her only friend—to see a revival of a movie called “Hiroshima, Mon Amour.” Juanita confessed afterward that she herself, like the woman in the picture, was in love with a married man—the father of one of her students. Then Juliet said that she had found herself in somewhat the same situation but had not allowed things to go on because of the tragic plight of the man’s wife, who was a total invalid, more or less brain-dead. Juanita said she wished that her lover’s wife were brain-dead, but she was not—she was vigorous and powerful and could get Juanita fired.
paragraph2: Juliet pulled away from Torrance House School for Girls on that warm June afternoon in 1965, her temporary teaching position having come to an end as the original instructor had recovered. Rather than heading straight home, she chose to meander up the coast to visit a friend, her mind drifting to her recent conversation with Juanita after their viewing of "Hiroshima, Mon Amour." The two teachers, close in age and united in their shared secrets, had formed an unlikely friendship in the halls of Torrance House. That evening, Juanita had confessed her love for a married man - one of her student's fathers - while Juliet admitted to a similar forbidden attraction, though she had chosen not to pursue it due to the man's wife being gravely ill. The confession had prompted Juanita to express a dark wish, one that made Juliet shiver even now as she drove: if only her lover's wife were similarly incapacitated, instead of being the formidable woman who held the power to end Juanita's career with a single complaint to the school board.

paragraph1: Avie sat with Grace's letter in her hands, her own pregnancy making the words feel heavier than they should. The correspondence detailed Grace's withdrawal from college and her subsequent battles with health issues and frayed nerves, intertwining with a haunting dream Avie had once shared. The memory of past conversations with Marsha surfaced, particularly one about colitis, adding another layer of complexity to Grace's desperate tone. Something about the pleading nature of the letter made Avie hesitate, and she found herself postponing her response indefinitely. During this period, Avie was wrapped up in the cocoon of her new life, feeling increasingly disconnected from the deep, philosophical discussions she once shared with Grace during their college days. The busyness of life provided a convenient excuse to maintain this distance, and the connection continued to fade. When she finally broached the subject with Royce, seeking any information about Grace's whereabouts or well-being, his response was dismissive and tinged with disappointment. He interpreted her questioning as unnecessary dwelling on past regrets, creating a subtle tension between them that mirrored the unresolved nature of her relationship with Grace.
paragraph2: When that first pregnancy was well advanced, around Christmas time, Avie had received a brief letter from Grace."I hear you are married and expecting. You may not have heard I have dropped out of college, due to some troubles I have had with my health and my nerves. I often think of our talks and particularly the dream you told me about. It still scares the daylights out of me. Love, Grace."Avie remembered then the conversation with Marsha. The colitis. The tone of Grace’s letter seemed off kilter, with some pleading note in it that made her put off answering. She herself was feeling quite happy at the time, full of practical concerns, light-years away from whatever stuff they had talked about in college. She didn’t know if she could ever find her way back there or find a way to talk to Grace as she was now. And later, of course, she got too busy.She asks Royce if he heard anything from Grace, ever."No. No. Why should I?" "I just thought." "No.""I thought you might have looked her up later on."Not a good idea."She has disappointed him. Prying. Trying to get at some spot of live regret right under the ribs. A woman.

paragraph1: "Well, I won’t be here for lunch. I can only really eat one meal a day at this point. I’m going shopping – you should come," offered Zora, without enthusiasm. "We haven’t done that in for ever. I need some new shit to wear. I  hate everything I own." "You look fine." "Right. I look fine. Except I don't," said Zora, tugging sadly at her man's nightshirt. This was why Kiki had dreaded having girlsshe knew she wouldn't be able to protect them from self-disgust. To that end she had tried banning television in the early years, and never had a lipstick or a woman's magazine crossed the threshold of the Belsey home to Kiki's knowledge, but these and other precautionary measures had made no difference. It was in the air, or so it seemed to Kiki, this hatred of women and their bodies-- it seeped in with every draught in the house; people brought it home on their shoes, they breathed it in off their newspapers. There was no way to control it.
paragraph2: Zora declined the lunch invitation, explaining that she had limited herself to just one meal per day, her voice tinged with resignation. When Kiki suggested an alternative activity, Zora halfheartedly proposed shopping, though her demeanor suggested deep dissatisfaction with her wardrobe and, more importantly, herself. As Kiki attempted to offer reassurance about Zora's appearance, the younger woman responded by tugging anxiously at her clothes, her gestures revealing a profound self-loathing that words couldn't mask. This interaction stirred something deep within Kiki, bringing to the surface her long-held anxieties about raising daughters in a world that seemed determined to undermine their self-worth. Despite her conscious efforts to shield them from harmful influences by carefully monitoring their media exposure and creating a nurturing environment, Kiki felt an overwhelming sense of helplessness in the face of society's relentless assault on women's body image. The pervasive negativity seemed to seep through every crack, making her protective measures feel futile against the tide of cultural pressures.

paragraph1: Tâm, at seventeen, used her nón lá as a hamper for the clean clothes. At the moment it held only two pairs of tiny pants belonging to her little brother. Hung Sang, an unplanned surprise five years earlier, was now the prince of the family. According to their parents, no boy was as handsome, as talented, as lucky. With his arrival the girls’ status declined. They had become afterthoughts, to be married off quickly. Sang should not be burdened with his sisters’ care. When he grew up, he would have enough to do for his own family and his parents.Tâm wiped sweat from her brow. Mai, three years younger, nattered on, but Tâm only half listened. She was about to graduate from the Catholic school two villages away, and she was wondering how she would continue her studies. Where would she find the money to pay for university? What would her parents say when she confessed that was her goal?"I’m sure you know him. Lanh Phuc. He’s handsome. His is the wealthiest family in their village,” Mai said. “Their home has a real roof. And windows. His father makes sampans…" Mai giggled. “I think he likes me, Chị Tâm. I hope Mama and Papa will agree to a match. I can already picture our wedding.
paragraph2: Balancing her nón lá filled with freshly washed clothes, Tâm navigates the familiar path home while contemplating her increasingly uncertain future. As a seventeen-year-old attending Catholic school, she harbors dreams of university education, though these aspirations seem to dim with each passing day under the weight of financial constraints and familial expectations. Her younger sister Mai, walking beside her, bubbles with enthusiasm about Lanh Phuc, a prosperous young man who has caught her eye, weaving elaborate fantasies about their potential wedding celebration. The sisters' lives have shifted dramatically since their brother Hung Sang's birth, as their parents shower him with preferential treatment, proudly dubbing him the family's prince. This favoritism has relegated the girls to secondary status within the household, intensifying the pressure for them to secure advantageous marriages rather than pursue their individual ambitions. Tâm listens half-heartedly to Mai's animated chatter about Lanh Phuc's family wealth, her thoughts drifting to the mounting stack of university brochures hidden beneath her bed. The traditional nón lá on her head, while practical for carrying laundry, serves as a poignant reminder of the cultural expectations that increasingly threaten to overshadow her educational dreams.

paragraph1: I packed a few things and called Paul. When he pulled up to the corner where I was waiting, I got into his car. By sunset Portland was long gone. In Montana we checked into a motel to sleep. I held myself in bed, rocking with a headache, a sickness in my gut. Paul brought me water and chocolate and watched television. I sat in the car as we drove across the country, and I felt my real life present but unattainable, as if heroin had taken me entirely from myself. Paul and I fought and cried and shook the car with our fighting. We were monstrous in our cruelty. We talked kindly afterward, shocked at ourselves and each other. We decided that we would get divorced. I hated him and I loved him. He had known my mother. I felt trapped, branded, held, and beloved. Like a daughter. “I didn’t ask you to come to Portland,” I screamed. “You came for your own reasons,” I said.
paragraph2: Driving east from Portland with Paul, I watched the landscape blur past our windows as we made our way to Montana, my head throbbing with a familiar ache that reminded me of darker days. The sickness crept through my body, not entirely unlike the heroin that once coursed through my veins, making everything feel distant and unreal. Our relationship had always been a complicated dance of extremes, and this journey was no different. The tension between us built like a pressure cooker until it finally exploded in a violent outburst of screaming and accusations inside the confined space of our car. Later, as we sat in a roadside diner discussing divorce with surprising calmness, I felt the paradoxical pull of both hatred and love for him. Paul's connection to my mother had always added another layer of complexity to our relationship, making me feel simultaneously trapped and treasured. I couldn't shake the feeling that he held me in a grip that was both protective and suffocating, much like the Montana sky that stretched endlessly above us.

paragraph1: Yet I went on living. In other words, the act of writing didn’t lessen my grief. As soon as I had set down my pen, I felt pangs for the man whose voice and foreign accent I could no longer hear, whose skin I could no longer touch, living an unknown life in some cold city—the real man, far more inaccessible than the written man designated by the letter A. And so I went on doing the things that help alleviate sorrow, offering hope when, theoretically, there is no longer cause for anyplaying patience, slipping a ten-franc coin into a beggar’s paper cup at Auber Metro station, making the wish that “he’ll call, he’ll come back.” (Perhaps, after all, writing is one of these things.)Despite my aversion to meeting people, I agreed to attend a seminar in Copenhagen because it was an opportunity to send him news of me discreetlya postcard I felt he would have to answer. As soon as I arrived in Copenhagen, I thought of nothing elsebuying a card, copying out the few sentences I had carefully written before leaving, finding a letter box. On the plane, on the way back, I reflected that I had traveled to Denmark simply to send a postcard to a man.
paragraph2: Every morning I wake up and write, hoping the words will somehow ease the ache of A's absence, but they never do. The pain remains stubbornly present, like a shadow that refuses to fade even in darkness. I find myself performing small rituals of consolation – dropping coins into a beggar's cup, arranging and rearranging cards in endless games of patience, as if these acts might somehow restore balance to my disrupted world. Though I've grown increasingly averse to company, preferring the quiet company of my thoughts, I surprised myself by agreeing to attend a seminar in Copenhagen. The truth is, I had an ulterior motive, one that made my heart race with equal parts hope and anxiety: sending A a postcard. The moment I arrived, the city's charm and the seminar's content became mere background noise to my singular mission. I wandered the streets, carefully selecting the perfect card, agonizing over every word I wrote, imagining his hands holding it, his eyes scanning my carefully crafted message. It wasn't until I was on the flight home, watching Copenhagen shrink beneath the clouds, that the reality hit me – I had traveled across countries, not for knowledge or culture, but for the desperate chance to reach someone who might never respond.

paragraph1: During those restless nights when sleep eludes me, a strange thought occasionally creeps into my consciousness - the peculiar urge to steal a woman's identity, not in any criminal sense, but in a symbolic way, perhaps by taking her nametag or ID card. I quickly brush this notion aside, knowing full well I lack both the nerve and skill for such endeavors, yet the thought lingers like a persistent shadow. It reminds me of my extraordinary encounter with the Shinagawa Monkey, that enigmatic elderly primate who lived secretly in an attic in that sleepy hot-springs town. We shared an unusual connection, drinking beer and munching on snacks while he revealed his own compulsion for collecting names and identities. The memory of those surreal moments remains vivid - the warm amber glow of the attic light, the monkey's weathered face, and his surprisingly articulate confessions about his peculiar habit. Sometimes I wonder about that travel-magazine editor whose name might have been affected by the monkey's mysterious activities. I should probably reach out to her, check if she's doing alright, but something always holds me back, perhaps the fear of confronting the reality of that bizarre experience or maybe the possibility that she wouldn't believe my story about a name-stealing monkey in an attic.
paragraph2: Maybe I’ll try it myself sometime. On sleepless nights, that random, fanciful thought sometimes comes to me. I’ll filch the I.D. or the nametag of a woman I love, focus on it like a laser, pull her name inside me, and possess a part of her, all to myself. What would that feel like?No. That’ll never happen. I’ve never been deft with my hands, and would never be able to steal something that belonged to someone else. Even if that something had no physical form, and stealing it wasn’t against the law.Extreme love, extreme loneliness. Ever since then, whenever I listen to a Bruckner symphony I ponder that Shinagawa Monkey’s personal life. I picture the elderly monkey in that tiny hot-springs town, in an attic in a rundown inn, asleep on a thin futon. And I think of the snacks—the kakipi and the dried squid—that we enjoyed as we drank beer together, propped up against the wall.I haven’t seen the beautiful travel-magazine editor since then, so I have no idea what fate befell her name after that. I hope it didn’t cause her any real hardship. She was blameless, after all. Nothing was her fault. I do feel bad about it, but I still can’t bring myself to tell her about the Shinagawa Monkey.

paragraph1: That summer of 1964, when I was barely thirteen, remains etched in my memory like a perfectly preserved seashell. Our family had rented a modest house along the Istanbul coast, where I spent countless hours wandering the rocky shoreline, lost in my own world of discovery. One day, I stumbled upon what would become my private sanctuary - a natural pool nestled among the weathered rocks, its crystal-clear waters revealing an entire universe below. I would lie on my stomach for hours, my face hovering inches above the surface, mesmerized by the tiny fish darting between swaying seaweed and the hermit crabs scuttling across the sandy bottom. This pool became my window into a whole civilization, teeming with life and hidden dramas. The anemones would wave their delicate tentacles in the gentle current, while occasionally, a bold octopus would emerge from its rocky hideout, transforming my quiet observation into an extraordinary event. In those solitary moments, I felt like both an explorer and a guardian of this miniature marine world.
paragraph2: In 1964, when I was about 12 or 13, I spent the summer at a house by the seaside 35 miles from Istanbul. I would leap over the low garden wall and walk towards the beach through the rocks and empty fields that lined the shore, inspecting all the marvelous little surprises that nature would lay upon my path. One day I came across a small pool of water among the rocks. It wasn’t exactly a pool. The sea kept pouring in through the gaps among the rocks and stones. But like a real pool, it was about one foot deep and six or seven meters wide, and shielded from the assault of the sea’s unruly waves. I quickly discovered that below the unruffled and perfectly transparent surface of my “pool” was another world, a whole civilization, and I began to spend more and more time there, alone in the summer heat, fascinated by the bustling realm submerged in the tepid seawater.

paragraph1: Growing up in the post-war years, I never imagined how profoundly the late sixties would shape my life. Starting high school in '63, I was still that clean-cut kid my parents raised, but by the time I hit college in '67, everything had changed. 1968 was when I truly found myself, right in the thick of it all. We weren't just rebelling; we were revolutionaries in our own minds, kicking down doors both literal and metaphorical. The soundtrack of our defiance played constantly - Morrison's hypnotic voice, the Beatles' evolving genius, and Dylan's protest anthems became our daily bread. Looking back now, those moments of raw energy and unbridled idealism defined who I became. We weren't just living through history; we were making it, one protest, one song, one kicked-in door at a time.
paragraph2: I was born in 1949. I started high school in 1963 and went to college in 1967. And so it was amid the crazy, confused uproar of 1968 that I saw in my otherwise auspicious twentieth year. Which, I guess, makes me a typical child of the sixties. It was the most vulnerable, most formative, and therefore most important period in my life, and there I was, breathing in deep lungfuls of abandon and quite naturally getting high on it all. I kicked in a few deserving doors—and what a thrill it was whenever a door that deserved kicking in presented itself before me, as Jim Morrison, the Beatles, and Bob Dylan played in the background. The whole shebang.

paragraph1: Looking back on six decades of life in Istanbul, Taksim Square has been an ever-present witness to both my personal journey and the city's transformation. I vividly remember the old artillery barracks that found new life as a football stadium in the 1930s, where the roar of crowds would echo across the square on match days. The Taksim Gazino was the crown jewel of Istanbul's nightlife during the 1940s and 1950s, its music and laughter spilling onto the streets as the city's elite gathered there evening after evening. I watched as buildings were torn down and replaced by rows of trees, changing the square's character but adding welcome shade to its open spaces. The establishment of the art gallery particularly touched my heart, as I spent countless hours in the 1960s dreaming of seeing my own paintings hanging on its prestigious walls. When the 1970s arrived, the square took on a different energy as I joined the Labor Day marches alongside fellow activists, trade unionists, and NGO workers, our voices rising in unison for workers' rights. Each stone in Taksim Square holds a fragment of my memories, intertwined with the city's evolving story.
paragraph2: Today, Taksim Square is Istanbul's chestnut tree. I've been living in Istanbul for sixty years, and I cannot imagine that there is a single inhabitant of this city who does not have at least one memory connected to Taksim Square. In the nineteen-thirties, the old artillery barracks, which the government now wants to convert into a shopping mall, contained a small football stadium that hosted official matches. The famous club Taksim Gazino, which was the center of Istanbul night life in the nineteen-forties and fifties, stood on a corner of Gezi Park. Later, buildings were demolished, trees were cut down, new trees were planted, and a row of shops and Istanbul's most famous art gallery were set up along one side of the park.In the nineteen-sixties, I used to dream of becoming a painter and displaying my work at this gallery. In the seventies, the square was home to enthusiastic celebrations of Labor Day, led by leftist trade unions and N.G.O.s; for a time, I took part in these gatherings.

Paragraph 1:
Looking back on six decades of life in Istanbul, Taksim Square has been an ever-present witness to both my personal journey and the city's transformation. I vividly remember the old artillery barracks that found new life as a football stadium in the 1930s, where the roar of crowds would echo across the square on match days. The Taksim Gazino was the crown jewel of Istanbul's nightlife during the 1940s and 1950s, its music and laughter spilling onto the streets as the city's elite gathered there evening after evening. I watched as buildings were torn down and replaced by rows of trees, changing the square's character but adding welcome shade to its open spaces. The establishment of the art gallery particularly touched my heart, as I spent countless hours in the 1960s dreaming of seeing my own paintings hanging on its prestigious walls. When the 1970s arrived, the square took on a different energy as I joined the Labor Day marches alongside fellow activists, trade unionists, and NGO workers, our voices rising in unison for workers' rights. Each stone in Taksim Square holds a fragment of my memories, intertwined with the city's evolving story.

Paragraph 2:
Today, Taksim Square is Istanbul's chestnut tree. I've been living in Istanbul for sixty years, and I cannot imagine that there is a single inhabitant of this city who does not have at least one memory connected to Taksim Square. In the nineteen-thirties, the old artillery barracks, which the government now wants to convert into a shopping mall, contained a small football stadium that hosted official matches. The famous club Taksim Gazino, which was the center of Istanbul night life in the nineteen-forties and fifties, stood on a corner of Gezi Park. Later, buildings were demolished, trees were cut down, new trees were planted, and a row of shops and Istanbul's most famous art gallery were set up along one side of the park.In the nineteen-sixties, I used to dream of becoming a painter and displaying my work at this gallery. In the seventies, the square was home to enthusiastic celebrations of Labor Day, led by leftist trade unions and N.G.O.s; for a time, I took part in these gatherings.

paragraph1: For the rest of her life, Pampa Kampana, who shared a name with the river on whose banks all this happened, would carry the scent of her mother’s burning flesh in her nostrils. The pyre was made of perfumed sandalwood, and an abundance of cloves, garlic, cumin seeds, sticks of cinnamon, and other spices had been added to it as if the burning women were being prepared as a gourmet dish to set before the sultan’s victorious generals, but those fragrances—the turmeric, the big cardamoms, and the little cardamoms, too—failed to mask the unique, cannibal pungency of women being cooked alive, and made the odor, if anything, even harder to bear. Pampa Kampana never ate meat again, and could not bring herself to remain in any kitchen in which it was being prepared. All meat dishes exuded the memory of her mother, and when other people ate dead animals she had to avert her gaze.
paragraph2: The haunting memory of her mother's cremation became an indelible part of Pampa Kampana's consciousness, forever marked by the distinctive scent of burning flesh that permeated the air that day. Despite the traditional inclusion of sandalwood and aromatic spices in the funeral pyre, meant to mask the underlying odors with their sweet fragrance, these additions served only to create a more complex and disturbing olfactory experience. The combination of perfumed wood, exotic spices, and burning human remains created an unforgettable sensory imprint that would pursue her throughout her life. This traumatic event fundamentally altered her relationship with certain smells and spaces, compelling her to adopt a meatless diet and avoid kitchens where flesh was being cooked. The similarity between cooking meat and the memory of her mother's cremation proved too overwhelming, forcing her to create physical and emotional boundaries that would shield her from these triggering reminders of her loss.

paragraph1: Each morning unfolds with familiar rhythms in the house where we raised our son, though the memories of those earlier days have grown hazier with time. I spend my days writing at home, working on my novel and various articles while my wife pursues her interests, visiting galleries or traveling for business. Our evenings follow a cherished pattern: sharing wine as she recounts her day's adventures, her voice filling our living room where we've hosted countless dinners with friends over the years. The intimate moments we share, from morning coffee to goodnight kisses, weave through our daily existence like a well-worn path. Weekends bring cultural pleasures - classical concerts that move us both, new restaurants to discover, and art exhibitions that spark lengthy discussions. Our traditions anchor us: weekly library visits that feel almost sacred, and our annual escapes to the mountains and seaside to celebrate our birthdays, creating new memories as older ones slowly fade into the gentle mist of time.
paragraph2: Over time, the memory began to dim. I went on living with my wife, in the house where we’d raised our son. I made love to her still slender body, I invited the same friends over for dinner, cooked the same reliable recipes. While my wife went to the gallery or away on the occasional business trip, I worked at home, in the corner of our bedroom, making slow progress on my fifth novel, my articles, my tepid reviews. When she returned in the evenings, I’d pour us some wine and pretend to listen while she gave me the full rundown of her complicated days. On Saturdays, once a month, we’d go to hear classical music, then out to a restaurant, or else to the opening of a new art exhibit. I would go to the library, and we’d go on vacationto the mountains every year, for her birthday, and to the sea, in the off-season, for mine.
