paragraph1: Through his presence in my life, I discovered dimensions of human experience I never knew existed, transforming my understanding of connection and desire in ways I couldn't have imagined. Before him, I observed the world from a calculated distance, dismissing certain behaviors as irrational or beneath contemplation. But he became my bridge to understanding the depths of human emotion and the intricate web of relationships that define our existence. While I had sworn I wouldn't chronicle our story or pen anything about him, here I am, crafting these words—not for his eyes, but as a testament to the profound impact he's had on my journey. It's fascinating how he shifted my perception of luxury; I once believed it resided in material abundance and intellectual pursuits, in carefully curated libraries and sophisticated dinner conversations. Now I recognize that true luxury lies in the ability to feel deeply, to forge genuine connections that transcend superficial interactions. The way he helped me navigate the landscape of human desire, even those aspects I once deemed absurd, has become an integral part of my personal evolution. This writing, though not intended for him, serves as an offering to the universe, acknowledging how one person's presence can fundamentally alter another's way of being in the world.
paragraph2: Whether or not he was “worth it” is of no consequence. And the fact that all this is gradually slipping away from me, as if it concerned another woman, does not change this one truththanks to him, I was able to approach the frontier separating me from others, to the extent of actually believing that I could sometimes cross over it.I measured time differently, with all my body.I discovered what people are capable of, in other words, anythingsublime or deadly desires, lack of dignity, attitudes and beliefs I had found absurd in others until I myself turned to them. Without knowing it, he brought me closer to the world.He had said, "You won’t write a book about me." But I haven’t written a book about him, neither have I written a book about myself. All I have done is translate into words—words he will probably never read; they are not intended for him—the way in which his existence has affected my life. An offering of a sort, bequeathed to others.When I was a child, luxury was fur coats, evening dresses, and villas by the sea. Later on, I thought it meant leading the life of an intellectual. Now I feel that it is also being able to live out a passion for a man or a woman.

paragraph1: On the day of the new president’s inauguration, when we worried that he might be murdered as he walked hand in hand with his exceptional wife among the cheering crowds, and when so many of us were close to economic ruin in the aftermath of the bursting of the mortgage bubble, and when Isis was still an Egyptian mother-goddess, an uncrowned seventy-something king from a faraway country arrived in New York City with his three motherless sons to take possession of the palace of his exile, behaving as if nothing was wrong with the country or the world or his own story. He began to rule over his neighborhood like a benevolent emperor, although in spite of his charming smile and his skill at playing his 1745 Guadagnini violin he exuded a heavy, cheap odor, the unmistakable smell of crass, despotic danger, the kind of scent that warned us, look out for this guy, because he could order your execution at any moment, if you’re wearing a displeasing shirt, for example, or if he wants to sleep with your wife. The next eight years, the years of the forty-fourth president, were also the years of the increasingly erratic and alarming reign over us of the man who called himself Nero Golden, who wasn’t really a king, and at the end of whose time there was a large—and, metaphorically speaking, apocalyptic—fire.
paragraph2: As the new president took his oath amid palpable tension and heightened security concerns, another figure of intrigue made his calculated entrance into American society. Nero Golden, a self-styled sovereign without a crown, chose this pivotal moment of national uncertainty to transplant himself and his three sons into the heart of New York City. His timing seemed almost theatrical, coinciding with a period when the nation grappled with economic instability and global challenges. Golden's presence was immediately felt in his new environment, where he masterfully cultivated an image of refined sophistication through his accomplished violin performances and magnetic personality. Yet beneath this carefully constructed facade of cultural refinement and paternal authority lurked something more sinister. His smile, though charming, carried undertones of menace, and his carefully orchestrated public appearances seemed designed to mask deeper, darker intentions. As the forty-fourth president's terms unfolded over eight years, Golden's influence grew increasingly erratic and threatening, casting an ever-lengthening shadow over his adopted neighborhood. His trajectory from mysterious newcomer to feared local figure paralleled the mounting tensions of the era, ultimately culminating in a catastrophic fire that seemed to embody both his destructive nature and the symbolic end of an era marked by uncertainty and hidden dangers.

paragraph1: Your wound, your silly little wound! That's your real love, Leo, that wound, the one true love of your life! I know how it will be, even if we tried, even if we managed to build something all over again. The music too, that would be no different. Even if they'd accepted you tonight, even if you became celebrated in this town, you'd destroy it all, you'd destroy everything, pull it all down around you just as you did before. And all because of that wound. Me, the music, we're neither of us anything more to you than mistresses you seek consolation from. You'll always go back to your one real love. To that wound! And you know what makes me so angry? Leo, are you listening to me? Your wound, it's nothing special, nothing special at all. In this town alone, I know there are many people with far worse. And yet they carry on, every one of them, with far greater courage than you ever did. They go on with their lives. They become something worthwhile. But you, Leo, look at you. Always tending your wound.
paragraph2: You cling to that wound like it's your most prized possession, Leo, nurturing it day after day while pushing away anything that might actually heal you. I've watched you sabotage every chance at happiness, every opportunity for growth, because you're so desperately in love with your own pain. The music that once moved you, the people who tried to reach out - we've all become mere distractions, temporary bandages you discard when they threaten to actually close your wounds. It's almost impressive how skillfully you demolish every bridge you build, how masterfully you orchestrate your own isolation. While others face unimaginable hardships and still find the strength to embrace life, you wear your relatively minor struggles like a crown of thorns, using them to justify your retreat from the world. The saddest part is that you possess real talent, genuine charm, and the potential for greatness, yet you choose to remain trapped in this self-imposed prison of past hurts. Paragraph 1:
Your wound, your silly little wound! That's your real love, Leo, that wound, the one true love of your life! I know how it will be, even if we tried, even if we managed to build something all over again. The music too, that would be no different. Even if they'd accepted you tonight, even if you became celebrated in this town, you'd destroy it all, you'd destroy everything, pull it all down around you just as you did before. And all because of that wound. Me, the music, we're neither of us anything more to you than mistresses you seek consolation from. You'll always go back to your one real love. To that wound! And you know what makes me so angry? Leo, are you listening to me? Your wound, it's nothing special, nothing special at all. In this town alone, I know there are many people with far worse. And yet they carry on, every one of them, with far greater courage than you ever did. They go on with their lives. They become something worthwhile. But you, Leo, look at you. Always tending your wound.

Paragraph 2:
You cling to that wound like it's your most prized possession, Leo, nurturing it day after day while pushing away anything that might actually heal you. paragraph1: Your friend Eric called me flat-chested today in front of everyone.Connell paused. She felt his breathing. I didn’t hear that, he said. You were in the bathroom or somewhere. He said I looked like an ironing board.Fuck's sake, he's such a prick. Is that why you're in a bad mood? She shrugged. Connell put his arms around her belly. He's only trying to get on your nerves, he said. If he thought he had the slightest chance with you, he would be talking very differently. He just thinks you look down on him. She shrugged again, chewing on her lower lip.You have nothing to worry about with your appearance, Connell said.Hm.I don’t just like you for your brains, trust me.She laughed, feeling silly.He rubbed her ear with his nose and addedI would miss you if you didn’t want to see me anymore. Would you miss sleeping with me? she said. He touched his hand against her hipbone, rocking her back against his body, and said quietlyYeah, a lot. Can we go back to your house now? He nodded. For a few seconds they just stood there in stillness, his arms around her, his breath on her ear. Most people go through their whole lives, Marianne thought, without ever really feeling that close with anyone.
paragraph2: In the quiet aftermath of a hurtful incident, Marianne finds herself sharing with Connell how his friend Eric had publicly mocked her physical appearance, specifically calling attention to her being flat-chested. Though Connell wasn't present during the incident, his response to hearing about it reveals the depth of his care for her. He wraps his arms around her protectively, his words carefully chosen to counter Eric's cruel remarks, emphasizing that her worth extends far beyond physical attributes. The tenderness of their embrace evolves into an intimate exchange, their voices dropping to whispers as they explore their feelings for one another and contemplate what lies ahead in their relationship. There's a profound vulnerability in their interaction, particularly as Marianne considers how rare and precious their connection is. The moment transcends the initial hurt that prompted their conversation, transforming into something more meaningful – a testament to their unique bond. Their physical closeness mirrors their emotional intimacy, creating a safe space where past hurts can be acknowledged and healed through understanding and acceptance. Marianne's recognition of the exceptional nature of their relationship underscores how their connection stands apart from ordinary interactions, suggesting that such depth of understanding and mutual care is a rare gift in life.

paragraph1: I didn’t know which was worse—the idea of my father’s remarrying for love or of his actively seeking out a stranger for companionship. My parents had had an arranged marriage, but there was a touch of romance about it, too, my father seeing my mother for the first time at a wedding and being so attracted that he had asked, the following week, for her hand. They had always been affectionate with each other, but it wasn’t until her illness that he seemed fully, recklessly, to fall in love with her, so that I was witness to a courtship that ought to have faded before I was born. He doted on her then, arriving home at our Bombay flat with flowers, lingering in bed with her in the mornings, going in late to work, wanting to be alone with her to the point where I, a teen-ager, felt in the way. “I thought,” he continued, “since your bedroom is a good size, of putting the girls together there. Would you mind terribly staying in the guest room when you visit, Kaushik? Most of your things are with you now anyway. It is just a matter of where to sleep. But please tell me if you mind.” He seemed more concerned about my reaction to a new room than the fact that I had just acquired a new family.
paragraph2: I find myself grappling with the news of Dad's potential remarriage, unsure whether to feel relief that he's found love again or unease at the thought of him seeking companionship with someone he barely knows. My parents' arranged marriage, though traditional in its beginnings, had blossomed into something genuinely special over the years. I remember how Dad's devotion to Mom only grew stronger during her illness, his love manifesting in countless small gestures and unwavering support until the very end. Now, as he casually mentions rearranging the house to accommodate "the girls," I'm struck by how much our family dynamic is about to change. My childhood room, still preserved with its memories and familiar comfort, will be transformed into a space for these newcomers, while I'm relegated to the guest room during my visits. What's particularly surprising is how Dad seems more concerned about my feelings regarding the room switch than about how I'm processing this massive shift in our family structure. It's almost as if he's using the practical matter of room arrangements as a buffer, a way to ease into the larger conversation about welcoming strangers into our carefully preserved family unit. The thought of these unknown women occupying Mom's space, rearranging our home, and becoming part of our daily lives fills me with a complex mixture of emotions I'm not quite ready to untangle.

paragraph1: I still remember that night at the party when we kissed in the utility room, though I couldn't shake the feeling that it wasn't the right place for such an intimate moment. After leaving that cramped space, I retreated to my room, where minutes stretched into hours as I waited, desperately hoping to hear your footsteps approaching my door. The anticipation held me hostage, creating an invisible barrier that kept me from leaving, even as hope gradually gave way to disappointment. I sat there, frozen in place, my ears straining to catch any sound that might signal your arrival, while my mind cycled through endless possibilities of what could have been. It's strange how that same paralyzing sensation has returned now, years later, triggered by your phone call. Just like that night, knowing where my car is parked feels like both a blessing and a curse – the knowledge anchors me in place, making it impossible to leave, as if the mere awareness of its location has created another invisible chain binding me to this moment, to these feelings, to you.
paragraph2: Remember the first time we kissed? he said. At the party. And I said I didn’t think the utility room was a good place to be kissing and we left. You know I went up to my room and waited for you, right? I mean for hours. And at first I really thought you would come. It was probably the most wretched I ever felt in my life, this kind of ecstatic wretchedness that in a way I was practically enjoying. Because even if you did come upstairs, what then? The house was full of people, it’s not like anything was going to happen. But every time I thought of going back down again I would imagine hearing you on the stairs, and I couldn’t leave, I mean I physically couldn’t. Anyway, how I felt then, knowing that you were close by and feeling completely paralysed by it, this phone call is very similar. If I told you where my car is right now, I don’t think I’d be able to leave, I think I would have to stay here just in case you

paragraph1: At dawn the haunting sandstone palaces of the new “victory city” of Akbar the Great looked as if they were made of red smoke. Most cities start giving the impression of being eternal almost as soon as they are born, but Sikri would always look like a mirage. As the sun rose to its zenith, the great bludgeon of the day’s heat pounded the flagstones, deafening human ears to all sounds, making the air quiver like a frightened blackbuck, and weakening the border between sanity and delirium, between what was fanciful and what was real.Even the Emperor succumbed to fantasy. Queens floated within his palaces like ghosts, Rajput and Turkish sultanas playing catch-me-if-you-can. One of these royal personages did not really exist. She was an imaginary wife, dreamed up by Akbar in the way that lonely children dream up imaginary friends, and in spite of the presence of many living, if floating, consorts, the Emperor was of the opinion that it was the real queens who were the phantoms and the nonexistent beloved who was real. He gave her a name, Jodha, and no man dared gainsay him.
paragraph2: In the mystical city of Sikri, where Emperor Akbar's grand vision materialized in sandstone, reality and fantasy intertwine in a perpetual dance at daybreak. The first light of dawn transforms the magnificent palaces into structures seemingly crafted from red smoke, their solid forms dissolving into the morning haze like apparitions from a fever dream. As the sun climbs higher, the scorching heat bends light and warps perception, creating a realm where the boundaries between the tangible and the ethereal become increasingly indistinct. Within this enchanted setting, even the mighty Akbar finds himself susceptible to the city's bewitching influence, his court becoming populated with spectral queens who drift through the corridors of his imagination. Most remarkable among these ethereal figures is Jodha, a wife who exists purely in the emperor's mind yet commands a presence more powerful than his living consorts. The peculiarity of Akbar's unwavering belief in this imaginary queen goes unchallenged by his courtiers, who accept this manifestation of royal fancy as readily as they accept the shimmering mirages that dance across their desert city's horizon.

paragraph1: I still remember that day with perfect clarity, when my sister and I emerged from the wind cave's cool darkness into the blinding summer light. Just moments before, she had been whispering excitedly about Alice in Wonderland, convinced that somewhere, perhaps in places like this cave, those characters truly existed. Her childish conviction was so pure, so unshakeable, that I found myself almost believing her. The sudden brightness made us squint, and the deafening chorus of cicadas enveloped us as we stepped out, their sound a sharp contrast to the cave's hushed atmosphere. Our uncle sat nearby, looking up from his book with that gentle smile of his, watching us explore and dream. It's strange how certain memories become anchored in our minds, refusing to fade even as years pass. Two years after that day, when I was sitting alone during her cremation, that cave moment kept replaying in my thoughts – her twelve-year-old face animated with wonder, her whispers echoing off the cave walls, the way her hair caught the sunlight as we emerged. I can still picture every detail: her small hand gripping mine in the dark, her excited breathing as she shared her secrets, and that transition from shadow to light that seemed to make everything magical, if only for a moment.
paragraph2: “Do you know?” my sister said in a small voice as we walked, so no one else would hear (though there wasn’t anyone else around). “Alice really existed. It wasn’t made up. It was real. The March Hare, the Mad Hatter, the Cheshire Cat, the Playing Card soldiers—they all really exist.”“Maybe so,” I said.We emerged from the wind cave, back into the bright real world. There was a thin layer of clouds in the sky that afternoon, but I remember how terribly glaring the sunlight seemed. The screech of the cicadas was overpowering, like a violent squall drowning everything out. My uncle was seated on a bench near the entrance, absorbed in his book. When he saw us, he grinned and stood up.Two years later, my sister died. And was put in a tiny coffin and cremated. I was fifteen, and she was twelve. While she was being cremated I went off, apart from the rest of the family, sat on a bench in the courtyard of the crematorium, and remembered what had happened in that wind cavethe weight of time as I waited for my little sister to come out, the thickness of the darkness enveloping me, the profound chill I felt. Her black hair emerging from the hole, then her shoulders. All the random dirt and dust stuck to her white T-shirt.

paragraph1: The profound metaphorical significance of airplanes emerges as a powerful tool for navigating emotional landscapes and confronting past experiences. As metal vessels slice through clouds at remarkable speeds, they compress not only physical distance but also the psychological space between present reality and lingering memories. She observes how this swift traversal of space fundamentally alters one's relationship with past grievances, watching as he touches his heart before gesturing toward a dusty road below. The juxtaposition becomes clear - what exists in memory often bears little resemblance to current reality. Through repeated visits, these once-powerful emotional anchors gradually lose their hold, transforming from vivid, haunting presences into abstract concepts that exist solely within the mind's confines. The airplane serves as both literal vessel and symbolic gateway, enabling travelers to physically return to spaces where memories dwell, only to discover that time has rendered these emotional landmarks into something entirely different, something less commanding of their present selves.
paragraph2: But the airplane is a wonderful thing. You are still in one place when you arrive at the other. The airplane is faster than the heart. You arrive quickly and you leave quickly. You don't grieve too much. And there is something else about the airplane. You can go back many times to the same place. And something strange happens if you go back often enough. You stop grieving for the past. You see that the past is something in your mind alone, that it doesn't exist in real life. You trample on the past, you crush it. In the beginning it is like trampling on a garden. In the end you are just walking on ground. That is the way we have to learn to live now. The past is here." He touched his heart. "It isn't there." And he pointed at the dusty road.

paragraph1: Komura was tall and slim and a stylish dresser. He was good with people. In his bachelor days, he had dated a lot of women. But after getting married, at twenty-six, he found that his desire for sexual adventures simply—and mysteriously—vanished. He hadn’t slept with any woman but his wife during the five years of their marriage. Not that the opportunity had never presented itself—but he had lost all interest in fleeting affairs and one-night stands. He much preferred to come home early, have a relaxed meal with his wife, talk with her awhile on the sofa, then go to bed and make love. This was everything he wanted. Komura’s friends were puzzled by his marriage. Next to his clean, classic looks, his wife could not have seemed more ordinary. She was short, with thick arms, and she had a dull, even stolid, appearance. And it wasn’t just physicalthere was nothing attractive about her personality, either. She rarely spoke, and her expression was often sullen.Still, though he himself did not quite understand why, Komura always felt his tension dissipate when he and his wife were together under one roof; it was the only time he could truly relax. He slept well with her, undisturbed by the strange dreams that had troubled him in the past. His erections were hard; his sex life was warm. He no longer had to worry about death or venereal disease or the vastness of the universe.
paragraph2: Komura, a tall and fashionable figure who once commanded significant attention from women, underwent a profound transformation after entering matrimony at twenty-six. His previous life as a sought-after bachelor, marked by numerous romantic possibilities, gave way to an unexpectedly content existence in monogamy. Despite his friends' bewilderment at his choice of partner, whom they considered unremarkable in both looks and character, Komura discovered a deep and genuine satisfaction in his marriage. The relationship offered him a sanctuary from life's complexities, with his wife's presence acting as a balm for his existential concerns. Their five years together demonstrated a remarkable stability, characterized by unwavering fidelity and a fulfilling intimate life that surpassed his earlier casual encounters. His wife's seemingly ordinary nature, rather than being a limitation, became the very source of their domestic harmony. While others struggled to understand the appeal of their partnership, Komura found himself increasingly drawn to the peaceful simplicity of their shared life. The contrast between his previous reputation as a ladies' man and his current contentment in marriage highlighted a maturity that surprised many who knew him. His transformation from a social butterfly to a devoted husband illustrated how the right partnership, regardless of external perceptions, could provide profound personal fulfillment and emotional security.
text_input:
You are given two pararaphs of creative writing for a given writing instruction.
Your task is to determine which paragraph is overall better in terms of writing quality.

Paragraph 1:
Komura was tall and slim and a stylish dresser. He was good with people. In his bachelor days, he had dated a lot of women. But after getting married, at twenty-six, he found that his desire for sexual adventures simply—and mysteriously—vanished. He hadn’t slept with any woman but his wife during the five years of their marriage. Not that the opportunity had never presented itself—but he had lost all interest in fleeting affairs and one-night stands. He much preferred to come home early, have a relaxed meal with his wife, talk with her awhile on the sofa, then go to bed and make love. This was everything he wanted. Komura’s friends were puzzled by his marriage. Next to his clean, classic looks, his wife could not have seemed more ordinary. She was short, with thick arms, and she had a dull, even stolid, appearance. And it wasn’t just physicalthere was nothing attractive about her personality, either. She rarely spoke, and her expression was often sullen.Still, though he himself did not quite understand why, Komura always felt his tension dissipate when he and his wife were together under one roof; it was the only time he could truly relax. He slept well with her, undisturbed by the strange dreams that had troubled him in the past. His erections were hard; his sex life was warm. He no longer had to worry about death or venereal disease or the vastness of the universe.

Paragraph 2:
Komura, a tall and fashionable figure who once commanded significant attention from women, underwent a profound transformation after entering matrimony at twenty-six. His previous life as a sought-after bachelor, marked by numerous romantic possibilities, gave way to an unexpectedly content existence in monogamy. Despite his friends' bewilderment at his choice of partner, whom they considered unremarkable in both looks and character, Komura discovered a deep and genuine satisfaction in his marriage. The relationship offered him a sanctuary from life's complexities, with his wife's presence acting as a balm for his existential concerns. Their five years together demonstrated a remarkable stability, characterized by unwavering fidelity and a fulfilling intimate life that surpassed his earlier casual encounters. His wife's seemingly ordinary nature, rather than being a limitation, became the very source of their domestic harmony. While others struggled to understand the appeal of their partnership, Komura found himself increasingly drawn to the peaceful simplicity of their shared life. The contrast between his previous reputation as a ladies' man and his current contentment in marriage highlighted a maturity that surprised many who knew him. His transformation from a social butterfly to a devoted husband illustrated how the right partnership, regardless of external perceptions, could provide profound personal fulfillment and emotional security.

{"preference": "1|2"}

where `preference` should be "1" if you think Paragraph 1 is better, "2" if you think Paragraph 2 is better.

paragraph1: I sit here, weary to my bones, watching the snow blanket the world in its cold embrace while contemplating the weight of existence pressing down on me. Through the window's reflection, I can see her, my ancestress, turning gracefully in the air behind me like a cosmic dancer caught between worlds. She's always been there, I realize now, a constant companion through every moment of my solitude, though I've never truly been alone. Her presence is both comforting and unsettling, a reminder of the generations that flow through my veins. I can sense her growing restless, her ethereal form shifting impatiently as she whispers of her weariness with this endless silence. Her words echo in my mind, urging me to bring this chapter to a close, suggesting with a haunting certainty that my existence holds little significance to anyone in this vast, indifferent world. The snow continues to fall outside, each flake a testament to the temporary nature of all things, while I remain frozen in this moment of connection with my spectral guardian.
paragraph2: I consider these things idly. Each one of them seems the same size as all the others. Not one seems preferable. Fatigue is here, in my body, in my legs and eyes. That is what gets you in the end. Faith is only a word, embroidered. I look out at the dusk and think about its being winter. The snow falling, gently, effortlessly, covering everything in soft crystal, the mist of moonlight before a rain, blurring the outlines, obliterating color. Freezing to death is painless, they say, after the first chill. You lie back in the snow like an angel made by children and go to sleep. Behind me I feel her presence, my ancestress, my double, turning in midair under the chandelier, in her costume of stars and feathers, a bird stopped in flight, a woman made into an angel, waiting to be found. By me this time. How could I have believed I was alone in here? There were always two of us. Get it over, she says. I'm tired of this melodrama, I'm tired of keeping silent. There's no one you can protect, your life has value to no one. I want it finished.

paragraph1: The two men materialized at the edge of the village, their presence marked by the pungent aroma of tilefish wafting through the humid air. The taller of the pair cut an imposing figure with his rough-hewn good looks and brutish demeanor, his dim eyes betraying a capacity for thoughtless violence. His shorter companion, whose features bore an unmistakable resemblance to a weasel, possessed a calculating air that seemed to assess every detail of their surroundings. While the village's daily fare of couscous and tilefish set it apart from regions where borscht might fill local bowls, today these familiar scents mingled with an undercurrent of approaching trouble. The shorter man casually propped himself against a weather-worn Coca-Cola billboard, offering a deceptively friendly wave to no one in particular, as his companion spat out the remnants of a gnawed stick, his lips curling into an unsettling smile that promised nothing good.
paragraph2: It goes without saying that one of the men is tall, rather handsome—in a vulgar way—a little dim and vicious, while the other man is shorter, weasel-faced, and sly. This short, sly man leaned on the Coca-Cola hoarding that marked the entrance to the village and raised a hand in friendly greeting, while his companion took the small stick that he had, up to that point, been chewing, threw it on the ground, and smiled. They could just as well have been leaning on a lamppost and chewing gum, and the smell of borscht could have been in the air, but in our village we do not make borscht—we eat couscous and tilefish and that was the smell in the air, tilefish, which even to this day we can hardly bear to smell because it reminds us of the day the two men arrived in the village.

The shorter man casually propped himself against a weather-worn Coca-Cola billboard, offering a deceptively friendly wave to no one in particular, as his companion spat out the remnants of a gnawed stick, his lips curling into an unsettling smile that promised nothing good.

Paragraph 2:
It goes without saying that one of the men is tall, rather handsome—in a vulgar way—a little dim and vicious, while the other man is shorter, weasel-faced, and sly. This short, sly man leaned on the Coca-Cola hoarding that marked the entrance to the village and raised a hand in friendly greeting, while his companion took the small stick that he had, up to that point, been chewing, threw it on the ground, and smiled. paragraph1: Life in these circumstances becomes, in a small way, a constant gamble and an anxiety. We all learn to live with it. And, in fact, after much coming and going we at last found someone suitable for my father’s house. Jo was a country girl, but very much up to the minute, single, with a couple of children, dually fathered, if that is grammatically possible, who brought her quite a tidy sum every week. She spoke of people being of “good stock,” and she seemed to suggest that after her early mistakes she was striving for higher things.This didn’t impress me. I took it as a mark of criminality. I have known criminals all my professional life, and in my experience this is how criminals like to present themselves. But I was wrong about this woman. She stayed, and was good and reliable. She was in her thirties, educated, able to write reasonably well, an elegant dresser (buying stylish things cheap from mail-order firms), and her manners were good. She stayed for six, seven, eight years. She became a fixture. I began—almost—to take her for granted.
paragraph2: When Jo first arrived to help with my father's house, I couldn't shake my professional cynicism. Her modern country style, two children from different fathers, and constant talk about coming from "good stock" set off alarm bells in my mind. Years of working with criminals had taught me to be wary of those who overemphasized their desire for self-improvement and respectability. I watched her carefully, half-expecting to discover missing valuables or signs of deceit. But as weeks turned into months, and months into years, Jo systematically dismantled every preconception I had formed. She proved to be not only reliable but remarkably well-educated, handling her duties with an efficiency that impressed even my skeptical father. Her good manners weren't a facade but a genuine reflection of her character. The decent income she earned was well-deserved, and she managed her responsibilities while raising her children with admirable dedication. Looking back, I'm ashamed of my initial judgment. Jo became more than just help; she became an essential part of our household, teaching me a valuable lesson about the dangers of prejudice and the importance of giving people a chance to prove themselves.

paragraph1: I stared at her stern face as she insisted, "You must love your father." Shaking my head, I questioned why blood ties alone should command my heart's devotion.
paragraph2: You must love him, she told me when I was sixteen. He's your father. Who says I have to love him? I said.

paragraph1: Lying in bed, Kino's mind wandered through a collection of soothing images as he sought refuge from his troubled thoughts. The gentle sway of a willow tree's branches danced in his imagination, followed by the graceful movements of a slim gray cat that had once crossed his path. His thoughts drifted to Kamita's familiar presence at the counter, a scene that brought him unexpected comfort, along with the determined faces of young athletes circling the track in their relentless pursuit of excellence. The haunting notes of a jazz solo floated through his consciousness, its melody both melancholic and beautiful. His wife's image emerged unbidden - her figure perfectly complemented by a new blue dress, and he pictured her in her new home, hoping she had found peace and safety there. Their last exchange of apologies echoed in his memory, a bittersweet reminder of what was lost and what might have been. As he lay there, Kino understood that moving forward required more than just forgetting the past; he needed to embrace forgiveness, both for her and for himself, though the path to such acceptance seemed dauntingly long.
paragraph2: Under the covers, Kino curled up like a worm, shut his eyes tight, and thought of the willow. One by one, he pictured its qualities—its color and shape and movements. And he prayed for dawn to come. All he could do was wait like this, patiently, until it grew light out and the birds awoke and began their day. All he could do was trust in the birds, in all the birds, with their wings and beaks. Until then, he couldn’t let his heart go blank. That void, the vacuum created by it, would draw them in.When the willow tree wasn’t enough, Kino thought of the slim gray cat, and its fondness for grilled seaweed. He remembered Kamita at the counter, lost in a book, young runners going through gruelling repetition drills on a track, the lovely Ben Webster solo on “My Romance.” He remembered his wife in her new blue dress, her hair trimmed short. He hoped that she was living a healthy, happy life in her new home. Without, he hoped, any wounds on her body. She apologized right to my face, and I accepted that, he thought. I need to learn not just to forget but to forgive.

paragraph1: Marcia's thought-provoking column delves deep into the heart of contemporary social challenges, offering readers intimate glimpses into struggles many face daily. Rather than relying on cold statistics, she masterfully weaves personal narratives about individuals grappling with issues like elderly care and workplace eating disorders, making these complex problems more relatable and human. However, her recent shift toward darker subject matter, including detailed explorations of malnutrition, domestic abuse, and the growing homeless crisis, has drawn criticism from some quarters, particularly Ian. He argues that the business-oriented readership of The World has little appetite for such somber topics, dismissively characterizing her writing style as "hysterical" and overly emotional. Ian's vocal disapproval of her editorial choices has left Marcia increasingly anxious about her professional future at the publication, as she senses her position might be at risk. Despite these pressures, her commitment to highlighting these crucial social issues remains unwavering, though the mounting tension has created an uncomfortable dynamic within the newsroom.
paragraph2: Her column, which is read by some men as well as by many women, is about issues. Social issues, problems that may come upcaring for the aged at home, breast-feeding in public, bulimia in the workplace. She interviews people, she writes from the particular to the general; she believes, in what she considers to be an old-fashioned, romantic way, that life is something that happens to individuals, despite the current emphasis on statistics and trends. Lately things have taken a grimmer turn in Marcia’s columnthere’s been more about such things as malnutrition in kindergartens, wife beating, overcrowding in prisons, child abuse. How to behave if you have a friend with AIDS. Homeless people who ask for handouts at the entrances to subway stations.Ian does not like this new slant of Marcia’s; he doesn’t like her bad news. Businessmen don’t want to read about this stuff, about people who can’t work the system; or so Ian says. She’s heard this through the grapevine. He has called her style “hysterical.” He thinks she’s too soppy. Probably she is too soppy. Her days at The World are probably numbered.

paragraph1: Drifting along the river at night fills me with an unsettling mixture of dread and fascination. Even with moonlight dancing on the water's surface, I can barely make out the looming shapes of trees along the banks, their shadows merging into an impenetrable wall of darkness. The gentle current guides my boat, but this lack of control over my journey leaves me feeling exposed and vulnerable. The forest seems to press in from all sides, its ancient presence both intimidating and watchful, as if I'm trespassing in a realm where humans don't belong. Yet beneath this discomfort, I sense something pulling at me – a mysterious connection to this wild place that feels oddly familiar. It's as though the river and forest are awakening something primitive within me, a dormant memory of when we were one with these untamed spaces, before civilization drew its lines between nature and humanity.
paragraph2: Going home at night! It wasn't often that I was on the river at night. I never liked it. I never felt in control. In the darkness of river and forest you could be sure only of what you could see — and even on a moonlight night you couldn't see much. When you made a noise — dipped a paddle in the water — you heard yourself as though you were another person. The river and the forest were like presences, and much more powerful than you. You felt unprotected, an intruder ... You felt the land taking you back to something that was familiar, something you had known at some time but had forgotten or ignored, but which was always there. You felt the land taking you back to what was there a hundred years ago, to what had been there always.

paragraph1: Being a man of reason, Ibn Rushd did not guess that the girl was a supernatural creature, a jinnia, of the tribe of female jinna grand princess of that tribe, on an earthly adventure, pursuing her fascination with human men in general and brilliant ones in particular. He took her into his cottage as his housekeeper and lover, and in the muffled night she whispered her “true”—that is to say, false—Jewish name into his ear, and that was their secret. Dunia the jinnia was as spectacularly fertile as her prophecy had implied. In the two years, eight months, and twenty-eight days and nights that followed, she was pregnant three times and brought forth a multiplicity of children, at least seven on each occasion, it would appear, and on one occasion eleven, or possibly nineteen; the records are vague. All the children inherited her most distinctive featurethey had no earlobes.If Ibn Rushd had been a scholar of the occult arcana, he would have realized then that his children were the offspring of a non-human mother, but he was too wrapped up in himself to work it out.
paragraph2: Ibn Rushd, a man deeply rooted in rational thought and philosophical contemplation, remained oblivious to the extraordinary nature of his housekeeper and lover, Dunia, who harbored a profound secret beneath her human facade. As a jinnia with an inexplicable attraction to intelligent human men, she cleverly wove her way into his household, presenting herself under a fabricated Jewish identity that Ibn Rushd never thought to question. Their relationship, spanning two years and eight months, proved remarkably fertile as Dunia's supernatural nature manifested in her ability to bear numerous children in rapid succession. Each child carried a telling mark of their otherworldly heritage - the absence of earlobes - yet this distinctive trait went unnoticed by their father, who remained absorbed in his scholarly pursuits and philosophical writings. Ibn Rushd's steadfast commitment to rational explanation and his dismissal of the supernatural rendered him blind to the extraordinary reality before him, even as his household grew with children who bore unmistakable evidence of their mother's true nature. His failure to recognize these signs spoke volumes about his unwavering devotion to reason, while Dunia continued to maintain her elaborate deception with practiced ease.

As a jinnia with an inexplicable attraction to intelligent human men, she cleverly wove her way into his household, presenting herself under a fabricated Jewish identity that Ibn Rushd never thought to question. Their relationship, spanning two years and eight months, proved remarkably fertile as Dunia's supernatural nature manifested in her ability to bear numerous children in rapid succession. Each child carried a telling mark of their otherworldly heritage - the absence of earlobes - yet this distinctive trait went unnoticed by their father, who remained absorbed in his scholarly pursuits and philosophical writings. Ibn Rushd's steadfast commitment to rational explanation and his dismissal of the supernatural rendered him blind to the extraordinary reality before him, even as his household grew with children who bore unmistakable evidence of their mother's true nature. His failure to recognize these signs spoke volumes about his unwavering devotion to reason, while Dunia continued to maintain her elaborate deception with practiced ease.

paragraph1: Mr. Biswas's childhood was marked by both physical hardships and simple pleasures, as he navigated life with a frail constitution that set him apart from his siblings. His body, weakened by malnutrition, bore the visible signs of his struggles through persistent eczema and stunted growth, conditions that would shape his early experiences. The family dynamic took on a particular pattern every Sunday when his father, Raghu, would take his brothers to the river for swimming lessons, leaving Mr. Biswas behind due to a pundit's ominous warning about water. While this exclusion might have been a source of distress for another child, Mr. Biswas found solace and joy in alternative activities with his sister Dehuti. Together, they would create elaborate imaginary scenarios, constructing mud fireplaces and preparing pretend meals, transforming their limitations into opportunities for creative play. His mother Bipti's attention during these times, though not particularly gentle, manifested in the practical care of cleaning his sores, adding another layer to his complex childhood experience. Despite being denied participation in what might be considered normal childhood activities and enduring physical discomfort, Mr. Biswas demonstrated remarkable resilience and adaptability, finding ways to create his own happiness through imaginative play and sibling companionship, even as his health conditions and the pundit's prohibition shaped the boundaries of his young world.
paragraph2: Mr Biswas grew. The limbs that had been massaged and oiled twice a day now remained dusty and muddy and unwashed for days. The malnutrition that had given him the sixth finger of misfortune pursued him now with eczema and sores that swelled and burst and scabbed and burst again, until they stank; his ankles and knees and wrists and elbows were in particular afflicted, and the sores left marks like vaccination scars. Malnutrition gave him the shallowest of chests, the thinnest of limbs; it stunted his growth and gave him a soft rising belly. And yet, perceptibly, he grew. He was never aware of being hungry. It never bothered him that he didn't go to school. Life was unpleasant only because the pundit had forbidden him to go near ponds and rivers.Raghu was an excellent swimmer and Bipti wished him to train Mr Biswas's brothers. So every Sunday morning Raghu took Pratap and Prasad to swim in a stream not far off, and Mr Biswas stayed at home, to be bathed by Bipti and have all his sores ripped open by her strong rubbing with the blue soap. But in an hour or two the redness and rawness of the sores had faded, scabs were beginning to form, and Mr Biswas was happy again. He played at house with his sister Dehuti. They mixed yellow earth with water and made mud fireplaces; they cooked a few grains of rice in empty condensed milk tins; and, using the tops of tins as baking-stones, they made rotis.

paragraph1: Two weeks later Wellington College closed for the Christmas recess. The snow continued. Every night unseen Wellington street workers shovelled it back from the sidewalk. After a while every road was edged with grey ice banks, some over five feet high. Jerome came home. Many dull parties followedfor the Art History Department, drinks at the President’s house, and at the Vice-President’s, at Kiki’s hospital, at Levi’s school. More than once Kiki found herself walking around the perimeters of these hot, crowded rooms, champagne in hand, hoping to see Carlene Kipps somewhere among the tinsel and the quiet black maids, circulating with their trays of shrimp. Often enough she spotted Monty, leaning against the wainscoting in one of his absurd nineteenth-century three-piece suits, with his timepiece on a chain, bombastically opinionated, and almost always eating – but Carlene was never with him. Was Carlene Kipps one of these women who promises friendship but never truly delivers it? A friendship flirt? Or was Kiki herself mistaken in her expectations? This, after all, was the month in which families began tightening and closing and sealing; from Thanksgiving to the New Year, everybody’s world contracted, day by day, into the microcosmic single festive household, each with its own rituals and obsessions, rules and dreams. You didn’t feel you could call people. They didn’t feel they could phone you. How does one cry for help from these seasonal prisons?
paragraph2: The pristine snowfall at Wellington College had created towering icebanks along the streets as the campus emptied for the holiday break, leaving Jerome to return home amidst a whirlwind of social obligations. The Art History Department's gatherings and functions at the President's house merged into a monotonous parade of festivities, each indistinguishable from the last. Through these events, Kiki navigated with practiced grace, champagne glass perpetually in hand, her eyes scanning the crowds for Carlene Kipps's familiar figure. Instead, she repeatedly encountered Monty, whose garish clothing choices and booming proclamations had become an unavoidable fixture of these gatherings. As she drifted from one party to another, Kiki found herself increasingly preoccupied with thoughts of her friendship with Carlene, questioning whether their connection was merely a superficial product of circumstance or something deeper she had failed to fully comprehend. The holiday season's peculiar ability to simultaneously bring families closer while creating barriers to outside connections weighed heavily on her mind, as she recognized how the strengthening of familial bonds paradoxically made it more challenging to seek support beyond those immediate circles. The festive atmosphere, rather than fostering connection, seemed to highlight the subtle distances between people, leaving Kiki to contemplate the true nature of friendship amid the seasonal celebrations.

paragraph1: Molly and Vernon's time together in their small rooftop apartment on the rue de Seine was marked by a striking contrast between order and chaos. While the flat itself was perpetually engulfed in Molly's ever-expanding collection of fashion items, with clothes draped over every available surface and magazines scattered across tables and floors, she somehow emerged each morning as a vision of perfection before heading to her position at Paris Vogue. The cramped space, barely large enough for two people, had become a repository for her professional life, with no surface left untouched by her personal belongings and industry materials. Vernon, finding it impossible to concentrate amidst the clutter, had eventually surrendered any attempt to work from home, seeking refuge in a nearby café where he could focus without the distraction of wayward scarves and teetering piles of fashion periodicals. Their nearly year-long cohabitation highlighted the delicate balance required when sharing space with someone whose professional life seemed to physically overflow into their domestic sphere.
paragraph2: Over a quarter of a century ago she and Vernon had made a household for almost a year, in a tiny rooftop flat on the rue de Seine. There were always damp towels on the floor then, and cataracts of her underwear tumbling from drawers she never closed, a big ironing board that was never folded away, and in the one overfilled wardrobe dresses , crushed and shouldering sideways like commuters on the metro. Magazines, makeup, bank statements, bead necklaces, flowers, knickers, ashtrays, invitations, tampons, LPs, airplane tickets, high heeled shoes- not a single surface was left uncovered by something of Molly's, so that when Vernon was meant to be working at home, he took to writing in a cafe along the street. And yet each morning she arose fresh from the shell of this girly squalor, like a Botticelli Venus, to present herself, not naked, of course, but sleekly groomed, at the offices of Paris Vogue.

paragraph1: But this isn’t fiction. Sometimes a story is not about anything except what it is about. Sometimes you wake up and find that you actually have lost your nose. Losing my mother’s wedding ring in the Tongue River was not OK. I did not feel better for it. It was not a passage or a release. What happened is that I lost my mother’s wedding ring and I understood that I was not going to get it back, that it would be yet another piece of my mother that I would not have for all the days of my life, and I understood that I could not bear this truth, but that I would have to.Healing is a small and ordinary and very burnt thing. And it’s one thing and one thing onlyit’s doing what you have to do. It’s what I did then and there. I stood up and got into my truck and drove away from a part of my mother. The part of her that had been my lover, my wife, my first love, my true love, the love of my life.
paragraph2: I watched helplessly as my mother's wedding ring slipped from my trembling fingers and disappeared into the murky depths of the Tongue River, taking with it another precious fragment of her memory. This wasn't the cleansing moment of release I'd secretly hoped for; instead, it felt like losing her all over again, another piece of her existence vanishing before my eyes. The gold band that once symbolized her roles as a wife, mother, and the cornerstone of our family now lay somewhere in the river's bed, unreachable and lost to time. Standing at the water's edge, I struggled to accept this new void, knowing full well that healing wouldn't come in dramatic gestures or symbolic moments, but in the quiet, often painful steps of moving forward. My legs felt heavy as I turned away from the river, each step back to my truck a reminder that life continues its relentless march forward, even when we're not ready. As I drove away, leaving behind not just a ring but another piece of the woman who had been my first love, my protector, and my guiding light, I understood that grief doesn't end – we just learn to carry it differently.

paragraph1: Ivan is standing on his own in the corner while the men from the chess club move the chairs and tables around. The men are saying things to one another likeBack a bit there, Tom. Mind yourself now. Alone, Ivan is standing, wanting to sit down but uncertain which of the chairs need to be rearranged still and which are in their correct places already. This uncertainty arises because the way in which the men are moving the furniture corresponds to no specific method Ivan has been able to discern. A familiar arrangement is slowly beginning to emerge—a central U shape composed of ten tables, with ten chairs along the outer rim of the shape, and a general seating area around the outside—but the process by which the men are reaching this arrangement seems haphazard. Standing on his own in the corner, Ivan thinks with no especially intense focus about the most efficient method of arranging, say, a random distribution of a given number of tables and chairs into the aforementioned shape. It’s something he has thought about before, while standing in other corners, watching other people move similar furniture around similar indoor spacesthe different approaches you could use, if you happened to be writing a computer program to maximize process efficiency. The accuracy of these particular men would be, Ivan thinks, pretty low, like actually very low.
paragraph2: Ivan stands motionless in the corner of the room, his analytical mind scrutinizing the seemingly chaotic movement of chess club members as they shuffle chairs and tables across the floor. The casual exchanges between members - "Back a bit there, Tom" and "Mind yourself now" - float through the air, but to Ivan's systematic mindset, these verbal cues represent an inefficient and disorganized approach to what should be a straightforward task. As he watches the gradual emergence of their familiar U-shaped table arrangement, his fingers twitch slightly, itching to implement a more structured solution. The apparent randomness of their chair placement process particularly irks him, leaving him uncertain about which pieces of furniture are in their final positions and which still require adjustment. Lost in his own world of algorithms and optimization, Ivan's mind automatically begins crafting a computer program that could execute this same setup with mathematical precision. This isn't the first time he's found himself mentally redesigning everyday scenarios into programmatic solutions, a habit that speaks to his deep-seated desire for efficiency in all aspects of life. As the club members continue their haphazard arrangement, Ivan calculates their accuracy rate in his head, concluding with a slight frown that their current method falls far below acceptable standards of precision.

paragraph1: Driving east from Portland with Paul, I watched the landscape blur past our windows as we made our way to Montana, my head throbbing with a familiar ache that reminded me of darker days. The sickness crept through my body, not entirely unlike the heroin that once coursed through my veins, making everything feel distant and unreal. Our relationship had always been a complicated dance of extremes, and this journey was no different. The tension between us built like a pressure cooker until it finally exploded in a violent outburst of screaming and accusations inside the confined space of our car. Later, as we sat in a roadside diner discussing divorce with surprising calmness, I felt the paradoxical pull of both hatred and love for him. Paul's connection to my mother had always added another layer of complexity to our relationship, making me feel simultaneously trapped and treasured. I couldn't shake the feeling that he held me in a grip that was both protective and suffocating, much like the Montana sky that stretched endlessly above us.
paragraph2: I packed a few things and called Paul. When he pulled up to the corner where I was waiting, I got into his car. By sunset Portland was long gone. In Montana we checked into a motel to sleep. I held myself in bed, rocking with a headache, a sickness in my gut. Paul brought me water and chocolate and watched television. I sat in the car as we drove across the country, and I felt my real life present but unattainable, as if heroin had taken me entirely from myself. Paul and I fought and cried and shook the car with our fighting. We were monstrous in our cruelty. We talked kindly afterward, shocked at ourselves and each other. We decided that we would get divorced. I hated him and I loved him. He had known my mother. I felt trapped, branded, held, and beloved. Like a daughter. “I didn’t ask you to come to Portland,” I screamed. “You came for your own reasons,” I said.

paragraph1: Prue lowered her sunglasses deliberately, fixing George with that mischievous smile he knew all too well, the same one that had first caught his attention at a Toronto party in the late fifties when he was still finding his footing as a newly arrived Hungarian refugee. "You're absolutely shameless," she teased, her eyes twinkling with the weight of their shared history and unspoken understanding. The familiar curve of her lips transported him instantly back to that evening, when the world seemed full of possibilities and his new life in Canada was just beginning to unfold. Even now, decades later, her smile carried the same magnetic pull, a reminder of youth and desire that had somehow survived the passage of time. Yet George found himself hesitating, acutely aware of their surroundings at Wacousta Lodge, a place he had come to view as his personal sanctuary. The lodge's weathered walls and peaceful atmosphere seemed to demand a certain reverence, and despite the temptation that Prue's smile still held, he chose to honor the sanctity of this retreat, letting the moment pass with nothing more than a knowing look between old friends who carried too many memories to count.
paragraph2: Prue lowers the sunglasses to the end of her nose and looks at him over the plastic rims. “George, you are totally shameless,” she says. “You always were.” She gives him an innocent smile, a mischievous smile, a smile with a twist of real evil in it. It’s a smile that waves like a gasoline slick on water, shining, changing tone.This smile of Prue’s was the first interesting thing George stumbled on when he hit Toronto, back in the late fifties. It was at a party thrown by a real-estate developer with Eastern European connections. He’d been invited because refugees from Hungary were considered noteworthy back then, right after the uprising. At that time he was young, thin as a snake, with a dangerous-looking scar over one eye and a few bizarre stories. A collectible. Prue had been there in an off-the-shoulder black dress. She’d raised her glass to him, looked over the rim, hoisted the smile like a flag.The smile is still an invitation, but it’s not something George will follow up on—not here, not now. Later, in the city, perhaps. But this lake, this peninsula, Wacousta Lodge itself, are his refuge, his monastery, his sacred ground. Here he will perform no violations.

The lodge's weathered walls and peaceful atmosphere seemed to demand a certain reverence, and despite the temptation that Prue's smile still held, he chose to honor the sanctity of this retreat, letting the moment pass with nothing more than a knowing look between old friends who carried too many memories to count.

Prue lowers the sunglasses to the end of her nose and looks at him over the plastic rims. “George, you are totally shameless,” she says. “You always were.” She gives him an innocent smile, a mischievous smile, a smile with a twist of real evil in it. It’s a smile that waves like a gasoline slick on water, shining, changing tone.This smile of Prue’s was the first interesting thing George stumbled on when he hit Toronto, back in the late fifties. It was at a party thrown by a real-estate developer with Eastern European connections. He’d been invited because refugees from Hungary were considered noteworthy back then, right after the uprising. At that time he was young, thin as a snake, with a dangerous-looking scar over one eye and a few bizarre stories. A collectible. Prue had been there in an off-the-shoulder black dress. She’d raised her glass to him, looked over the rim, hoisted the smile like a flag.The smile is still an invitation, but it’s not something George will follow up on—not here, not now. Later, in the city, perhaps. But this lake, this peninsula, Wacousta Lodge itself, are his refuge, his monastery, his sacred ground. Here he will perform no violations.

paragraph1: Halfway through June of 1965, the term at Torrance House School for Girls is over. Juliet has not been offered a permanent job—the teacher she was replacing has recovered from a bout of depression—and she could now be on her way home. Instead, she is taking what she has described as a little detour. A little detour to see a friend who lives up the coast.About a month ago, she went with another teacher—Juanita, the only person on the staff who is near her age, and her only friend—to see a revival of a movie called “Hiroshima, Mon Amour.” Juanita confessed afterward that she herself, like the woman in the picture, was in love with a married man—the father of one of her students. Then Juliet said that she had found herself in somewhat the same situation but had not allowed things to go on because of the tragic plight of the man’s wife, who was a total invalid, more or less brain-dead. Juanita said she wished that her lover’s wife were brain-dead, but she was not—she was vigorous and powerful and could get Juanita fired.
paragraph2: Juliet stood at the threshold of change as the summer term at Torrance House School for Girls drew to a close in June 1965. Her temporary position, filling in for a teacher battling depression, was ending without the promise of permanence she had quietly hoped for. The weight of uncertainty pressed against her chest as she contemplated her next move, deciding to postpone her homeward journey in favor of visiting a friend up the coast. Her mind wandered to the recent evening spent with Juanita, her sole confidante among the teaching staff, at a screening of "Hiroshima, Mon Amour." The film's aftermath had led to startling confessions between the two women of similar age, with Juanita revealing her ongoing affair with a student's father. Juliet had found herself sharing her own parallel experience, though she had stepped back from pursuing it, mindful of the man's gravely ill wife. Juanita's subsequent wish for her lover's wife to be similarly indisposed had sent a chill through Juliet, particularly as Juanita admitted her fear of losing her position should the wife discover their entanglement.

paragraph1: There was once, in the country of Alifbay, a sad city, the saddest of cities, a city so ruinously sad that it had forgotten its name. It stood by a mournful sea full of glumfish, which were so miserable to eat that they made people belch with melancholy even though the skies were blue. In the north of the sad city stood mighty factories in which (so I’m told) sadness was actually manufactured, packaged and sent all over the world, which never seemed to get enough of it. Black smoke poured out of the chimneys of the sadness factories and hung over the city like bad news. And in the depths of the city, beyond an old zone of ruined buildings that looked like broken hearts, there lived a happy young fellow by the name of Haroun, the only child of the storyteller Rashid Khalifa, whose cheerfulness was famous throughout that unhappy metropolis, and whose never-ending stream of tall, short and winding tales had earned him not one but two nicknames. To his admirers he was Rashid the Ocean of Notions, as stuffed with cheery stories as the sea was full of glumfish; but to his jealous rivals he was the Shah of Blah. To his wife, Soraya, Rashid was for manyyears as loving a husband as anyone could wish for, and during these years Haroun grew up in a home in which, instead of misery and frowns, he had his father’s ready laughter and his mother’s sweet voice raised in song. Then something went wrong. (Maybe the sadness of the city finally crept in through their windows.) The day Soraya stopped singing, in the middle of a line, as if someone had thrown a switch, Haroun guessed there was trouble brewing. But he never suspected how much.
paragraph2: In a gloomy corner of Alifbay stands a city so consumed by melancholy that its very name has slipped into the depths of forgetfulness. This sorrowful metropolis, perched beside a sea of equal despondency, harbors peculiar glumfish whose belches release waves of sadness into the otherwise blue-skied atmosphere. The city's northern district houses factories dedicated to manufacturing pure sadness, methodically packaging and shipping this emotional export across the globe, ensuring their particular brand of misery touches lives far beyond their borders. Yet within this landscape of perpetual gloom dwells young Haroun, a remarkably cheerful soul who seems to defy the city's oppressive atmosphere. He is the son of the celebrated Rashid Khalifa, a master storyteller whose reputation precedes him - admirers call him the "Ocean of Notions," while those less enchanted prefer the somewhat mocking "Shah of Blah." Together with his wife Soraya, whose melodious singing once filled their home with joy, Rashid created a sanctuary of happiness within the dreary city. Their household stood as a beacon of light amidst the surrounding darkness, until the day Soraya's songs suddenly ceased, her silence echoing through their home like a harbinger of approaching shadows. This unexpected quieting of her voice serves as the first crack in their fortress of joy, suggesting that perhaps even the most resilient spirits cannot indefinitely resist the city's creeping melancholy. The weight of the city's sadness, it seems, finds ways to seep through even the strongest defenses, threatening to dim the brightest of lights.

paragraph1: Standing here at the summit, breathing in the crisp mountain air, I feel a profound sense of truth wash over me, even if I can't quite put it into words. The long climb has left me exhausted yet oddly fulfilled, reminiscent of those moments described in "The Dream of a Common Language" where understanding transcends verbal expression. Like watching fish glide beneath the water's surface, I've come to realize that simply being present, witnessing life's unfolding moments, is enough. Each step of this hike has revealed something sacred about existence – the way sunlight filters through leaves, how my breath synchronizes with the rhythm of my footsteps, the gentle rustling of wind through trees. There's a wild, mysterious quality to life that can't be tamed or fully explained, and for the first time, I'm at peace with that irrevocable truth. This journey has taught me that sometimes the most profound meanings lie in simply experiencing the world around us.
paragraph2: It was all unknown to me then, as I sat on that white bench on the day I finished my hike. Everything except the fact that I didn't have to know. That is was enough to trust that what I'd done was true. To understand its meaning without yet being able to say precisely what it was, like all those lines from The Dream of a Common Language that had run through my nights and days. To believe that I didn't need to reach with my bare hands anymore. To know that seeing the fish beneath the surface of the water was enough. That it was everything. It was my life - like all lives, mysterious and irrevocable and sacred. So very close, so very present, so very belonging to me.How wild it was, to let it be.

paragraph1: The train's doors banged shut and lurched forward, giving way to an eerie silence as icy air pressed against the windows. Through the glass, brittle birch trees stood like sentinels, their bark marked with distinctive black stripes, while small evergreens huddled nearby like drowsy bears in winter slumber. A frozen lake stretched out, its shoreline decorated with wavy mounds caught in suspended animation beneath the austere northern sky. A solitary building punctuated the monochromatic landscape, its structured rows of windows and glass porches reflecting the diffused light from the clouded dome above. Upon closer inspection, the seemingly white birch bark revealed subtle variations of grayish yellow, blue, and pure gray, adding unexpected depth to the otherwise stark winter tableau.
paragraph2: The doors banged together, and the train started back.Then there was silence, the air like ice. Brittle-looking birch trees with black marks on their white bark, and some small, untidy evergreens, rolled up like sleepy bears. The frozen lake not level but mounded along the shore, as if the waves had turned to ice in the act of falling. And the building, with its deliberate rows of windows and its glassed-in porches at either end. Everything austere and northerly, black-and-white under the high dome of clouds. So still, so immense an enchantment.But the birch bark not white after all, as you got closer. Grayish yellow, grayish blue, gray.

paragraph1: Flajsman found himself increasingly drawn to Elisabet's refined nature and exceptional qualities, feeling an overwhelming urge to propose marriage as he stood before her. The intensity of his emotions threatened to overcome his usual measured demeanor, yet he managed to regain his composure at the crucial moment. Instead of following through with a proposal, he chose to present her with a carefully selected bouquet of roses, his hands trembling slightly as he extended them toward her. His words, though carefully chosen, carried deep meaning as he expressed his profound appreciation for her mere existence in his life, subtly conveying his love without explicitly declaring it. In that moment of clarity, Flajsman contemplated how love might actually flourish more freely when unburdened by the conventional constraints of shared living and formal commitments. Elisabet's reaction was a mixture of bewilderment and joy, her brow furrowing slightly as she attempted to decipher the full meaning behind his gesture and words. Though she couldn't fully grasp the implications of his carefully veiled message, a hopeful smile gradually spread across her face, illuminating her features as she accepted both the roses and the unspoken sentiment they represented. The ambiguity of the moment hung between them, creating a delicate balance of understood and unspoken emotions.
paragraph2: He understood that he wouldn't find such refinement, devotion, and consideration in any other woman, and a terrible desire to give in to this fit of rashness and ask her to become his wife swept over him. At the last moment, however, he regained his self-control (there's always enough time for a marriage proposal), and he said only this"Elisabet, Elisabet, my girl. I brought these roses for you." Elisabet gaped at Flajsman and said"For me?" "Yes, for you. Because I'm happy to be here with you. Because I'm happy that you exist at all, Elisabet. Perhaps I love you. Perhaps I love you very much. But probably just for this reason it would be better if we remain as we are. I think a man and a woman love each other all the more when they don't live together and when they know about each other only that they exist, and when they are grateful to each other for the fact that they exist and that they know they exist. And that alone is enough for their happiness. I thank you, dear Elisabet, I thank you for existing." Elisabet didn't understand any of it, but a foolish, blissful smile full of vague happiness and indistinct hope spread across her face.

paragraph1: Sitting in Shiva's flat with a cup of tea, Kamla and I found ourselves revisiting that terrifying day from his childhood. The image of my little brother choking on a plum remains etched in my memory - his face turning blue, his tiny hands flailing in panic. If it hadn't been for that doctor who lived next door, rushing in and performing the Heimlich maneuver, we might have lost him then. The irony of that memory hits me now, how we saved him that day only to lose him years later. "It's strange being here without him," Kamla whispered, her voice heavy with the same emptiness that's been my constant companion. These past two years since his passing have been measured not in months or seasons, but in the distance from that final day - every moment defined by his absence, every memory tinged with the realization that we can no longer create new ones together.
paragraph2: Afterward, at tea in Shiva’s flat, I talked to my elder sister Kamla. We talked about Shiva as a child; we remembered how, shortly after we had moved to our own house, he had once swallowed a plum and had begun seriously to choke. Fortunately, our house was next door to a doctor’s office, and he was in attendance that afternoon. He swiftly attended to the matter. It was a small crisis, but we could still, my sister and I, after all these years, celebrate the little boy’s escape from death, as though it were something final.I said to Kamla, expecting some solace from her, "And now we have nothing." She said, "And now we have nothing." My sorrow lasted for two years. For two years I mentally dated everything, even the purchase of a book, by its distance from Shiva's death.

paragraph1: What I find strange about growing old isn’t that I’ve got older. Not that the youthful me from the past has, without my realizing it, aged. What catches me off guard is, rather, how people from the same generation as me have become elderly, how all the pretty, vivacious girls I used to know are now old enough to have a couple of grandkids. It’s a little disconcerting—sad, even. Though I never feel sad at the fact that I have similarly aged.I think what makes me feel sad about the girls I knew growing old is that it forces me to admit, all over again, that my youthful dreams are gone forever. The death of a dream can be, in a way, sadder than that of a living being.There’s one girl—a woman who used to be a girl, I mean—whom I remember well. I don’t know her name, though. And, naturally, I don’t know where she is now or what she’s doing. What I do know about her is that she went to the same high school as I did, and was in the same year (since the badge on her shirt was the same color as mine), and that she really liked the Beatles.
paragraph2: The realization hits me hardest not when I look in the mirror, but when I scroll through social media and see familiar faces from my past transformed by time. These women I once knew, who shared my youth and vitality, are now posting pictures of their grandchildren and celebrating retirement parties. It's a peculiar kind of heartache, watching those who walked the same hallways as me morphing into their autumn years. I find myself particularly haunted by the memory of a girl from my high school days - we were in the same year, both seventeen and drunk on Beatles songs, though her name now escapes me like morning mist. She had this way of humming "Yesterday" during chemistry class, and I wonder if she still does that, perhaps now for her grandchildren. The transformation of my peers into grandmothers forces me to confront not just the passage of time, but the quiet death of youthful dreams we all carried. It's not my own aging that brings this melancholy; rather, it's witnessing the collective journey of my generation from wide-eyed teenagers to silver-haired elders, each face a mirror reflecting back the decades we've traveled.

She had this way of humming "Yesterday" during chemistry class, and I wonder if she still does that, perhaps now for her grandchildren. The transformation of my peers into grandmothers forces me to confront not just the passage of time, but the quiet death of youthful dreams we all carried. It's not my own aging that brings this melancholy; rather, it's witnessing the collective journey of my generation from wide-eyed teenagers to silver-haired elders, each face a mirror reflecting back the decades we've traveled.
