paragraph1: Standing at the platform, I watched the empty electric train idling across the tracks, its pristine interior visible through spotless windows. The stillness was broken when the stationmaster's voice rang out, calling what sounded like "Sam," though I later realized it was "San." My momentary confusion was interrupted by the appearance of an official-looking gentleman who confidently strode toward the train and boarded it. A woman laden with parcels followed his lead, and seeing their decisive movements, I felt compelled to do the same. Just as I settled into my seat, chaos erupted outside as a group of men exploded from a nearby building, their urgent voices and hurried footsteps creating quite a spectacle. They scrambled onto the train, frantically counting heads and calling out numbers, only to realize with visible relief that their missing companion hadn't even shown up for work that day. The whole scene had an almost comedic quality to it, and I couldn't help but wonder if the train's eventual departure was timed to accommodate their dramatic entrance or if the driver had simply adhered to his schedule, completely indifferent to the commotion that had just unfolded on his platform.
paragraph2: Across the tracks was the electric train, empty, waiting. No other passengers showed up, and after a while the stationmaster stuck his head out the station window and called, "San."" At first I thought he was calling a man’s name, Sam. And another man wearing some kind of official outfit did come around the end of the building. He crossed the tracks and boarded the electric car. The woman with the parcels stood up and followed him, so I did the same. There was a burst of shouting from across the street, and the doors of a dark-shingled flat-roofed building opened, letting loose several men, who were jamming caps on their heads and banging lunch buckets against their thighs. By the noise they were making, you’d have thought the car was going to run away from them at any minute. But when they settled on board nothing happened. The car sat while they counted one another and worked out who was missing and told the driver that he couldn’t go yet. Then somebody remembered that the missing man hadn’t been around all day. The car started, though I couldn’t tell if the driver had been listening to any of this, or cared.

The whole scene had an almost comedic quality to it, and I couldn't help but wonder if the train's eventual departure was timed to accommodate their dramatic entrance or if the driver had simply adhered to his schedule, completely indifferent to the commotion that had just unfolded on his platform.

Paragraph 2:

paragraph1: Agnes lay motionless beside Paul's sleeping form, her mind wrestling with thoughts that had long haunted their relationship. The gentle rhythm of his breathing contrasted sharply with the turbulent dialogue unfolding in her imagination, where a mysterious visitor, detached from human sentiment, posed an impossible choice. This ethereal figure, naive to the complexities of human emotions, asked whether she would choose to reunite with Paul in another life or forever remain strangers. The question, though hypothetical, crystallized years of unspoken doubts and suppressed desires. Agnes mentally rehearsed her response, each imagined word building her courage like a slowly fortifying wall. In the darkness of their shared bedroom, she finally embraced the truth she had been avoiding: she would choose never to meet him again. This realization, though painful, felt like removing a mask she had worn for too long. The imagined conversation became a private ceremony of liberation, allowing Agnes to acknowledge that their love, beautiful as it once seemed, was an illusion she could no longer sustain.
paragraph2: But today for the first time she was certain that even in Paul’s presence she would find the courage to say what she wanted, what she really wanted, in the depth of her soul; she was certain that she would find this courage even at the price of ruining everything between them. Next to her, she heard the sound of loud breathing. Paul had really fallen asleep. As if she were putting the same reel of film back in the projector, she ran through the whole scene once againshe is speaking to the visitor, Paul is watching them with astonishment, and the guest is saying, “In your next life, do you want to stay together or never meet again?" (It is strangeeven though he has all the necessary information about them, terrestrial psychology is incomprehensible to him, the concept of love unfamiliar, so he cannot guess what a difficult situation he would create by his sincere, practical, and well-intended question.)Agnes gathers all her inner strength and answers in a firm voice, “We prefer never to meet again.”These words are like the click of a door shutting on the illusion of love.

paragraph1: Time ceased to be a series of meaningless days punctuated by university talks and lectures, afternoons spent in cafés and at the library, leading up to exams and the summer vacation, to the future. It became a shapeless entity growing inside me which had to be destroyed at all costs.I attended literature and sociology classes, I ate in the university canteen, I drank coffee twice a day at La Faluche, the students’ hangout. Yet I was living in a different world. There were the other girls, with their empty bellies, and there was me. To convey my predicament, I never resorted to descriptive terms or expressions such as "I’m expecting," "pregnant" or "pregnancy." They endorsed a future event that would never materialize. There was no point naming something that I was planning to get rid of. In my diary I would write, "it" or "that thing,"" only once “pregnant."
paragraph2: Time no longer flows as it once did through my university days, no longer marked by the comforting rhythm of lectures and coffee breaks at La Faluche. I still go through these motions, clutching my books and forcing down bland canteen meals, but everything has shifted since that moment I learned about it - that thing I refuse to name even in my private diary. I watch the other girls, with their empty bellies, laughing and planning their futures with such certainty, while my own has become a maze of undefined moments, each weighted with a decision I never wanted to make. My body moves through familiar spaces - lecture halls, cafeteria queues, library corners - but I feel like a ghost, separated from everyone by this secret that grows heavier each day. I carefully avoid certain words, certain thoughts, referring to it only in vague terms, as if language itself could keep this unwanted reality at bay.

paragraph1: Every Monday and Tuesday, I rush through my college classes in Minneapolis, my mind already halfway home to where Mom needs me. The rest of the week unfolds in a routine I never imagined would become my senior year reality. The three-hour drive to our rural Minnesota farmhouse has become as familiar as my daily commute to campus, with each mile bringing me closer to the place where cancer has reshaped our lives. While my stepfather works tirelessly as a carpenter to keep up with the mounting medical bills, I've stepped into a role that feels both foreign and deeply natural. Mom, once the master of our kitchen, now guides me through recipes from her chair at the table, her voice weaker but her instructions still precise. Between managing her medications and tackling the endless housework, I find moments of unexpected grace - watching her face light up when she manages to finish a small meal I've prepared, or losing track of time as we discuss the latest chapter in whatever book she's reading on her good days. The quiet afternoons when she drifts to sleep mid-conversation remind me why I rearranged my entire academic schedule, why the long drives and missed campus events don't matter. This wasn't the senior year I planned, but it's the one that matters most.
paragraph2: When my mother got cancer I’d folded my life down. I was a senior in college in Minneapolis, and I’d convinced my professors to allow me to be in class only two days each week. As soon as those days were over, I drove north to the house in rural Minnesota where I’d grown up, racing home, to my mother. I could not bear to be away from her. Plus, I was needed. My stepfather was with my mother when he could be, when he wasn’t working as a carpenter in an attempt to pay the bills. I cooked food that my mother tried to eat. She’d saypork chops and stuffed green peppers, cherry cheesecake and chicken with rice, and then holler the recipes out to me from her bed. When I’d finished she’d sit like a prisoner staring down at her steaming plate. “It smells good,” she’d say. “I think I’ll be able to eat it later.” I scrubbed the floors. I took everything from the cupboards and put new paper down. My mother slept and moaned and counted and swallowed her pills, or on good days she sat in a chair and talked to me, she paged through books.

paragraph1: Growing up in Beşiktaş near the majestic Ihlamur Palace in 1984, I spent countless hours at my father's pharmacy, Hayat, where the distinct medicinal scents became an integral part of my childhood memories. Those late evenings watching him work diligently, mixing medications and attending to patients, left an indelible mark on my young mind. Though I had always dreamed of becoming a writer, life's unexpected turns steered me toward engineering geology and eventually into the building contractor business. The familiar aroma of that pharmacy still follows me today at forty-five, offering a peculiar comfort when memories resurface. My relationship with my father, complex and multifaceted, continues to influence my life choices and emotional landscape. Sometimes, walking past old pharmacies in Istanbul, I catch a whiff of that distinctive smell, and suddenly, I'm transported back to those evenings at Hayat, where my father's dedication to his profession unknowingly shaped the man I would become, even if my path diverged from my original literary aspirations.
paragraph2: I had wanted to be a writer. But after the events I am about to describe, I studied engineering geology and became a building contractor. Even so, readers shouldn’t conclude from my telling the story now that it is over, that I’ve put it all behind me. The more I remember, the deeper I fall into it. Perhaps you, too, will follow, lured by the enigma of fathers and sons.In 1984, we lived in a small apartment deep in Beşiktaş, near the nineteenth-century Ottoman Ihlamur Palace. My father had a little pharmacy called Hayat, meaning “Life.” Once a week, it stayed open all night, and my father took the late shift. On those evenings, I’d bring him his dinner. I liked to spend time there, breathing in the medicinal smells while my father, a tall, slim, handsome figure, had his meal by the cash register. Almost thirty years have passed, but even at fortyfive I still love the smell of those old pharmacies lined with wooden drawers and cupboards.

paragraph1: There once lived, at a series of temporary addresses across the United States of America, a travelling man of Indian origin, advancing years, and retreating mental powers, who had developed an unwholesome, because entirely one-sided, passion for a certain television personality, the beautiful, witty, and adored talk-show host Miss Salma R., whom he had never metan infatuation that he characterized, quite inaccurately, as love. In the name of this so-called love, he christened himself Quichotte, for the opera “Don Quichotte,” and resolved to be his “beloved” ’s knight-errant, to pursue her zealously right through the television screen into whatever exalted high-definition reality she and her kind inhabited, and, by deeds as well as by grace, to win her heart.
paragraph2: Driven by an increasingly fragile mind, an aging Indian man traverses the vast American landscape while harboring an all-consuming obsession with the charismatic television personality, Miss Salma R. As his rational judgment wanes, he transforms his simple infatuation into what he perceives as profound love, drawing parallels between his situation and the romantic tales of classical literature. Inspired by the operatic rendition of Don Quichotte, he adopts this noble moniker for himself, fashioning his identity after the legendary knight-errant. With unwavering determination, he embarks on a quixotic quest to transcend the boundary between viewer and star, convinced that his gallant actions and magnetic personality will ultimately lead him into Miss Salma R.'s glittering world of fame and eventually capture her affections.

paragraph1: The river was called the Avon—not the one connected with Shakespeare. Later—when the land had more meaning, when it had absorbed more of my life than the tropical street in Trinidad where I grew up—I was able to think of the flat, wet fields with the ditches as 'water meadows' or 'wet meadows,' and the low, smooth hills in the background, beyond the river, as 'downs.' But just then, after the rain, all that I saw—though I had been living in England for twenty years—was flat fields and a narrow river.It was winter. This idea of winter and snow had always excited me, but in England the word had lost some of its romance for me, because the winters I found in England had seldom been as extreme as I had imagined they would be when I was far away on my tropical island. I had experienced severe weather in other places, but in England this kind of weather hardly seemed to come. In England, I wore the same kind of clothes all through the year—seldom wore a pullover, hardly needed an overcoat. And though I knew that summers were sunny and in winter the trees went bare and brush-like, as in the watercolors of Rowland Hilder, the year—so far as vegetation, and even temperature, went—was a blur to me. It was hard for me to distinguish one section or season from another; I didn’t associate flowers or the foliage of trees with any particular month. And yet I liked to look; I noticed everything, and could be moved by the beauty of trees and flowers and early sunny mornings and late light evenings. Winter was to me a time mainly of short days, and of electric lights everywhere at working hours; also a time when snow was a possibility.
paragraph2: Living in England has reshaped my understanding of landscapes and seasons in ways I never anticipated when I first arrived from Trinidad. The flat, methodically arranged fields and the narrow rivers that wind through them initially felt underwhelming compared to the lush, wild topography of my tropical homeland. I remember expecting dramatic winters with bitter cold and endless snowfall, having been influenced by romantic literature and films, but the reality proved quite different. The mild temperatures meant I found myself wearing nearly identical clothing throughout the year - a light jacket, perhaps a sweater, and occasionally an umbrella for the perpetual drizzle. This constant moderateness of the weather created a curious blending of seasons, where one month seemed to melt imperceptibly into the next. Yet, as time passed, I began to discover the subtle charms of the English countryside. The trees here possess a different kind of majesty - their bare winter branches creating intricate patterns against the grey sky, their spring buds emerging with a delicate persistence that feels almost miraculous. The flowers, though less flamboyant than their tropical counterparts, display a quiet beauty that rewards careful observation. What has particularly captivated me is the ever-changing quality of light - how it shifts and plays across the landscape, creating new moods and atmospheres throughout the day. Even now, after years of living here, the prospect of winter snow still fills me with childlike anticipation, though it rarely materializes as dramatically as I once imagined. This land has taught me to appreciate a different kind of natural beauty, one that reveals itself gradually and rewards patient observation.

She’d saypork chops and stuffed green peppers, cherry cheesecake and chicken with rice, and then holler the recipes out to me from her bed. When I’d finished she’d sit like a prisoner staring down at her steaming plate. “It smells good,” she’d say. “I think I’ll be able to eat it later.” I scrubbed the floors. I took everything from the cupboards and put new paper down. My mother slept and moaned and counted and swallowed her pills, or on good days she sat in a chair and talked to me, she paged through books.
paragraph2: Every Monday and Tuesday, I rush through my college classes in Minneapolis, my mind already halfway home to where Mom needs me. The rest of the week unfolds in a routine I never imagined would become my senior year reality. The three-hour drive to our rural Minnesota farmhouse has become as familiar as my daily commute to campus, with each mile bringing me closer to the place where cancer has reshaped our lives. While my stepfather works tirelessly as a carpenter to keep up with the mounting medical bills, I've stepped into a role that feels both foreign and deeply natural. Mom, once the master of our kitchen, now guides me through recipes from her chair at the table, her voice weaker but her instructions still precise. Between managing her medications and tackling the endless housework, I find moments of unexpected grace - watching her face light up when she manages to finish a small meal I've prepared, or losing track of time as we discuss the latest chapter in whatever book she's reading on her good days. The quiet afternoons when she drifts to sleep mid-conversation remind me why I rearranged my entire academic schedule, why the long drives and missed campus events don't matter. This wasn't the senior year I planned, but it's the one that matters most.

paragraph1: Michael lay in the darkness, his mind swirling with conflicting emotions as he contemplated the imminent end of his marriage to Maisie. The promise of freedom tantalized him, painting vivid pictures of an unrestrained future where he could bring home other women and shed the weight of marital obligations that had become increasingly suffocating. A solitary tear of gratitude rolled down his cheek as he imagined this liberation, though his anticipation was tinged with an urgent desire for Maisie's departure. She, however, proved more perceptive than he anticipated, abruptly illuminating the room and declaring her refusal to be emotionally manipulated into remaining. The dissolution of their union proceeded with remarkable speed, as Maisie relocated to a hill farm in Powys within the week, eventually finding her way to an ashram in India. Their communication dwindled to a sparse exchange of postcards over the years, with the final correspondence bringing news of Maisie's willingness to divorce. Their paths wouldn't cross again until Michael's twenty-sixth birthday, when she appeared before him as someone fundamentally changed from the woman he had known. The surprising ease with which their marriage had unraveled seemed to set a precedent in Michael's life, as he found himself moving through subsequent marriages with a similar detachment, collecting wives and divorces with an almost casual regularity that echoed the pattern established in that first, fateful separation.
paragraph2: Suddenly, it was all before him, the prospect of freedom, of working whenever he wanted, of inviting home some of the women he had seen on the Falmer campus, lolling on the steps outside the library, of returning to his unexamined self and being guiltlessly shot of Maisie. All this caused a tear of gratitude to roll down his cheek. He also felt fierce impatience for her to be gone. It crossed his mind to offer to drive her to the station now, but there were no trains from Lewes at 3 A.M., and she had not packed. Hearing his sob, she reached for the bedside light and, leaning over to look into his face, saw the dampness around his eyes. Firmly and deliberately she whispered, “I will not be blackmailed, Michael. I will not, repeat not, be emotionally manipulated by you into staying.”Was ever a marriage dissolved so painlessly? Within a week she had left for the hill farm in Powys. In the course of a year they exchanged a couple of postcards. Then one came from an ashram in India, where she remained for three years and from where she sent one day her cheery acceptance of a divorce, all papers duly signed. He did not see her until his twenty-sixth birthday, at which she appeared with a shaved head and a jewel in her nose. Many years later, he spoke at her funeral. Perhaps it was the ease of their parting in the old rectory that made him so incautious about marrying again, and again

paragraph1: Memory flows through me like Mary Pereira's green chutney, that extraordinary concoction from 1957 which still lingers on my tongue and in my mind's deepest recesses. I find myself wielding these preserved moments like weapons against the green-medicine men, who hover at the edges of my consciousness, threatening to strip away the very essence of who I am. When I share these stories with Padma, I watch her eyes grow wide with wonder, and I know the power of my memories has captured her completely, just as that chutney once captured my childhood senses. But it's not just for her that I unravel these threads of the past; my son must know these truths, must understand the tapestry of events that shaped his father's life. Yet even as I recount these tales, I'm acutely aware of how memory bends and shifts, how it selects certain moments while discarding others, creating its own version of reality that might not perfectly align with what others remember. Perhaps that's the beauty of it all – the way our minds craft these personal truths, these intimate histories that become as real and tangible as Mary's chutney, preserved in the jar of time.
paragraph2: And while chutney - the same chutney which, back in 1957, my ayah Mary Pereira had made so perfectly; the grasshopper-green chutney which is forever associated with those days - carried them back into the world of my past, while chutney mellowed them and made them receptive, I spoke to them, gently, persuasively, and by a mixture of condiment and oratory kept myself out of the hands of the pernicious green-medicine men. I said"My son will understand. As much as for any living being, I'm telling my story for him, so that afterwards, when I've lost my struggle against cracks, he will know. Morality, judgment, character ... it all starts with memory ... and I am keeping carbons." Green chutney on chilli-pakoras, disappearing down someone's gullet; grasshopper-green on tepid chapatis, vanishing behind Padma's lips. I see them begin to weaken, and press on. 'I told you the truth,' I say yet again, "Memory's truth, because memory has its own special kind. It selects, eliminates, alters, exaggerates, minimizes, glorifies, and vilifies also; but in the end it creates its own reality, its heterogeneous but usually coherent version of events; and no sane human being ever trusts someone else's version more than his own."

paragraph1: Michael Beard's formative years as an only child profoundly shaped his emotional landscape, leaving him devoid of any fraternal instincts or understanding of sibling bonds. His mother Angela, a striking and devoted woman, channeled her maternal affection primarily through culinary expressions, lavishing him with food from his earliest days. This nurturing approach bore fruit when young Michael's robust physique earned him recognition in a local baby competition, an early triumph that would foreshadow his later accomplishments, most notably his Nobel Prize. Angela's ambitious nature manifested in her unwavering faith in Michael's potential, particularly regarding his academic prospects at Oxford, where she correctly predicted he would earn a scholarship. Even as illness began to take its toll, she remained determined to expand her culinary expertise, learning new techniques and recipes specifically to impress her son during his homecomings. In stark contrast, his father Henry embodied simpler tastes, preferring traditional British fare and showing little interest in the exotic ingredients that increasingly appeared in their household. The emotional dynamics of the family were significantly impacted by Angela's early withdrawal from her marriage to Henry, as she redirected her emotional energy entirely toward Michael. This intense mother-son relationship ultimately molded Michael into a man who would consistently seek out relationships with accomplished, attractive women who reminded him of his mother, perpetuating a pattern established in his childhood. The psychological imprint of Angela's devoted yet consuming love would continue to influence Michael's romantic choices throughout his adult life, creating a complex legacy of maternal influence that shaped his relationships with women.
paragraph2: It surprised no one to learn that Michael Beard had been an only child, and he would have been the first to concede that he’d never quite got the hang of brotherly feeling. His mother, Angela, was an angular beauty who doted on him, and the medium of her love was food. She bottle-fed him with passion, surplus to demand. Some four decades before he won the Nobel Prize in Physics, he came top in the Cold Norton and District Baby Competition, birth-to-six-months class. In those harsh postwar years, ideals of infant beauty resided chiefly in fat, in Churchillian multiple chins, in dreams of an end to rationing and of the reign of plenty to come. Babies were exhibited and judged like prize marrows, and, in 1947, the five-month-old Michael, bloated and jolly, swept all before him. However, it was unusual at a village fête for a middle-class woman, a stockbroker’s wife, to abandon the cake-and-chutney stall and enter her child for such a gaudy event. She must have known that he was bound to win, just as she later claimed always to have known that he would get a scholarship to Oxford. Once he was on solids, and for the rest of her life, she cooked for him with the same commitment with which she had held the bottle, sending herself in the mid-sixties, despite her illness, on a Cordon Bleu cookery course so that she could try new meals during his occasional visits home. Her husband, Henry, was a meat-and-two-veg man, who despised garlic and the smell of olive oil. Early in the marriage, for reasons that remained private, Angela withdrew her love from him. She lived for her son, and her legacy was cleara fat man who restlessly craved the attentions of beautiful women who could cook.

paragraph1: Those first years of marriage in that rickety house still flood my mind with bittersweet memories. My wife and I, along with our faithful cat, struggled through each winter in that poorly insulated dwelling, where our financial constraints meant no space heater to ward off the biting cold. We'd create our own warmth by huddling together under layers of futons, our cat nestled between us, while the kitchen faucet regularly froze solid, a testament to our spartan living conditions. But spring, oh spring was our salvation, bringing with it a warmth that melted away our winter hardships. I particularly remember that April during the railroad strike, when the usual clamor of trains fell silent. We seized that rare moment of tranquility to bask in the sunshine on the empty tracks, our cat contentedly purring beside us, young love making everything seem somehow perfect despite our circumstances. Even now, years later, whenever I hear the word "poor," my thoughts drift back to that humble abode, and I find myself wondering about its current inhabitants, hoping they too find moments of joy amidst the challenges, just as we did in our youth.
paragraph2: It was a poorly built house in a way, since wind blew in through cracks and gaps all over the place. Pleasant enough in the summer, but, come winter, it was hell. With no money to buy a space heater, my wife and I and the cat would crawl under the futons once the sun set, literally clinging to each other to keep warm. Many a time we’d wake up to find the water in the kitchen faucet frozen solid.Once winter passed, the spring would come. And spring was a lovely season. She and I and the cat would breathe a sigh of relief. In April, the railroads went on strike for a few days, and we were ecstatic. Not a single train came rumbling by all day. We carried the cat down to the railroad tracks and sat there sunning ourselves. It was so quiet it was as if we were sitting at the bottom of a lake. We were young, just married, and the sunshine was free!Even now, when I hear the word “poor,” I remember that thin, triangular sliver of land. And I wonder, Who could be living there now?

paragraph1: Verna shuffles through her daily routine alongside other fallen girls, their collective punishment manifesting in endless cycles of potato peeling, floor scrubbing, and toilet scouring. Their identical gray maternity dresses, donated wool stockings, and heavy brown shoes strip away any remnants of individuality, marking them as society's cautionary tales. Daily prayer sessions and stern lectures hammer home their moral failings, with authority figures constantly reminding them that their predicament stems from their own misdeeds, offering salvation only through backbreaking work and rigid self-control. The girls endure repeated warnings against various vices - alcohol, tobacco, and even the seemingly innocent act of chewing gum - while being reminded that finding a future husband would be nothing short of divine intervention. After enduring an agonizing labor, Verna faces the cruel reality of immediate separation from her baby, a policy designed to prevent maternal bonding. Her postpartum illness becomes merely another opportunity for nurses to dismiss her as an unfit mother, their harsh words reaching her fever-addled consciousness. Finally, with minimal resources and a bus ticket in hand, she's sent back to her mother's care, her youth paradoxically both her burden and her only remaining protection.
paragraph2: There Verna spent the days peeling potatoes and scrubbing floors and scouring toilets along with her fellow-delinquents. They wore gray maternity dresses and gray wool stockings and clunky brown shoes, all paid for by generous donations, they were informed. In addition to their scouring and peeling chores, they were treated to bouts of prayer and self-righteous hectoring. What had happened to them was justly deserved, the speeches went, because of their depraved behavior, but it was never too late to redeem themselves through hard work and self-restraint. They were cautioned against alcohol, tobacco, and gum chewing, and were told that they should consider it a miracle of God if any decent man ever wanted to marry them.Verna’s labor was long and difficult. The baby was taken away from her immediately so that she would not get attached to it. There was an infection, with complications and scarring, but it was all for the best, she overheard one brisk nurse telling another, because those sorts of girls made unfit mothers anyway. Once she could walk, Verna was given five dollars and a bus ticket and instructed to return to the guardianship of her mother, because she was still a minor.

paragraph1: Robbie Turner's position in the social hierarchy was marked by his modest origins as the son of a cleaning lady, yet his trajectory had been altered by the generosity of Briony's father, who funded his education and nurtured his ambitions. With determination and intellectual promise, Robbie pursued dual aspirations: first to become a landscape gardener, and subsequently, to enter the medical profession, all while harboring deeper feelings for Cecilia. The complexity of their relationship manifested in a peculiar scene by the pond, where Robbie's apparent authority over Cecilia emerged in an unexpected display of power dynamics. Cecilia's willing compliance with his command to undress and enter the water revealed a layer of their relationship that transcended social boundaries and conventional expectations. This moment, witnessed by young Briony, created a profound disturbance in her understanding of narrative structure and romantic relationships. The scene's defiance of traditional storytelling logic particularly troubled Briony, who struggled to reconcile the apparent reversal of social roles and the inexplicable urgency of Cecilia's actions. The interaction challenged her preconceptions about class, authority, and romantic behavior, forcing her to confront the limitations of her own narrative framework and her understanding of adult relationships, while simultaneously highlighting the complex web of emotions and power dynamics at play between Robbie and Cecilia.
paragraph2: Robbie Turner, only son of a humble cleaning lady and of no known father, Robbie who had been subsidized by Briony’s father through school and university, had wanted to be a landscape gardener, and now wanted to take up medicine, had the boldness of ambition to ask for Cecilia’s hand. It made perfect sense. Such leaps across boundaries were the stuff of daily romance. What was less comprehensible, however, was how Robbie imperiously raised his hand now, as though issuing a command which Cecilia dared not disobey. It was extraordinary that she was unable to resist him. At his insistence she was removing her clothes, and at such speed. She was out of her blouse, now she had let her skirt drop to the ground and was stepping out of it, while he looked on impatiently, hands on hips. What strange power did he have over her? Blackmail? Threats? Briony raised two hands to her face and stepped back a little way from the window. She should shut her eyes, she thought, and spare herself the sight of her sister’s shame. But that was impossible, because there were further surprises. Cecilia, mercifully still in her underwear, was climbing into the pond, was standing waist deep in the water, was pinching her nose—and then she was gone. There was only Robbie, and the clothes on the gravel, and beyond, the silent park and the distant, blue hills. The sequence was illogical—the drowning scene, followed by a rescue, should have preceded the marriage proposal. Such was Briony’s last thought before she accepted that she did not understand, and that she must simply watch.

paragraph1: Their bodies melded together on the bustling platform, creating an island of intimacy amid the station's chaos. As Sarah and Michael held each other with desperate intensity, the world around them continued its mundane dance: a businessman's explosive sneeze echoed through the space, an empty Coca-Cola bottle skittered across the concrete, pushed by gusts from approaching trains, and the electronic billboard above cycled through its endless parade of advertisements. Yet in their embrace, they seemed to exist in a parallel dimension, one where the universe's hidden poetry revealed itself through their connection. Their public display of affection, perhaps inappropriate to some passing commuters, transcended the station's grime and commercialism, suggesting that genuine beauty could emerge even in the most prosaic settings. They remained suspended in their moment, untouched by the vulgarity of their surroundings, as if their love had temporarily pierced the veil between ordinary reality and something far more profound.
paragraph2: Were they aware, in the intensity of their embrace, of something slightly ridiculous about this tableau, something almost comical, as someone nearby sneezed violently into a crumpled tissue; as a dirty discarded plastic bottle scuttled along the platform under a breath of wind; as a mechanised billboard on the station wall rotated from an advertisement for hair products to an advertisement for car insurance; as life in its ordinariness and even ugly vulgarity imposed itself everywhere all around them? Or were they in this moment unaware, or something more than unaware—were they somehow invulnerable to, untouched by, vulgarity and ugliness, glancing for a moment into something deeper, something concealed beneath the surface of life, not unreality but a hidden realitythe presence at all times, in all places, of a beautiful world?

paragraph1: “Do you know?” my sister said in a small voice as we walked, so no one else would hear (though there wasn’t anyone else around). “Alice really existed. It wasn’t made up. It was real. The March Hare, the Mad Hatter, the Cheshire Cat, the Playing Card soldiers—they all really exist.”“Maybe so,” I said.We emerged from the wind cave, back into the bright real world. There was a thin layer of clouds in the sky that afternoon, but I remember how terribly glaring the sunlight seemed. The screech of the cicadas was overpowering, like a violent squall drowning everything out. My uncle was seated on a bench near the entrance, absorbed in his book. When he saw us, he grinned and stood up.Two years later, my sister died. And was put in a tiny coffin and cremated. I was fifteen, and she was twelve. While she was being cremated I went off, apart from the rest of the family, sat on a bench in the courtyard of the crematorium, and remembered what had happened in that wind cavethe weight of time as I waited for my little sister to come out, the thickness of the darkness enveloping me, the profound chill I felt. Her black hair emerging from the hole, then her shoulders. All the random dirt and dust stuck to her white T-shirt.
paragraph2: I still remember that day with perfect clarity, when my sister and I emerged from the wind cave's cool darkness into the blinding summer light. Just moments before, she had been whispering excitedly about Alice in Wonderland, convinced that somewhere, perhaps in places like this cave, those characters truly existed. Her childish conviction was so pure, so unshakeable, that I found myself almost believing her. The sudden brightness made us squint, and the deafening chorus of cicadas enveloped us as we stepped out, their sound a sharp contrast to the cave's hushed atmosphere. Our uncle sat nearby, looking up from his book with that gentle smile of his, watching us explore and dream. It's strange how certain memories become anchored in our minds, refusing to fade even as years pass. Two years after that day, when I was sitting alone during her cremation, that cave moment kept replaying in my thoughts – her twelve-year-old face animated with wonder, her whispers echoing off the cave walls, the way her hair caught the sunlight as we emerged. I can still picture every detail: her small hand gripping mine in the dark, her excited breathing as she shared her secrets, and that transition from shadow to light that seemed to make everything magical, if only for a moment.

paragraph1: Standing there in the biting cold of Istanbul's January air in 1964, I found myself outside a buffet restaurant in Taksim Square, my heart racing with a peculiar mixture of dread and excitement. The frankfurter sandwich in my hands was both a source of forbidden pleasure and mounting anxiety, as Mother had strictly prohibited eating on the street. Each bite filled me with an intoxicating sense of rebellion, the warm, savory meat providing a momentary escape from the winter chill. Yet this fleeting moment of culinary defiance was destined to be short-lived. My stomach dropped when I spotted my brother approaching through the crowd, his face lighting up with unmistakable glee at catching me in the act. The triumphant smirk on his face told me everything I needed to know – he would relish this moment of superiority. True to form, later that evening at home, he wasted no time in reporting my transgression to Mother, his voice dripping with self-righteousness as he detailed how he had caught me brazenly consuming the sandwich in public view. The way he savored each word of his account made it clear that my moment of rebellion had become his moment of victory.
paragraph2: It was a cold afternoon in Istanbul, in January, 1964. I was standing just outside a buffet restaurant that occupied the ground floor of a Greek apartment building in a corner of Taksim Square (which was much smaller and more run-down then, because the old buildings hadn’t yet been demolished to open up lanes for the avenues). I was awash in fear but also euphoricin my hand was a frankfurter sandwich I’d just bought from the buffet. I took a big bite, but as I stood there, chewing away amid the great chaos of the city, watching the circling trolleybuses and the swarms of shoppers and young people rushing off to the movies, my joy left meI had been caught. My brother was heading toward me down the sidewalk, and he had seen me. As he came closer, I could tell instantly that he was thrilled to have caught me committing a crime. “What do you think you’re doing, eating that frankfurter sandwich?” he asked with a supercilious smile. I lowered my head and finished the sandwich guiltily. At home that night, it was just as I expectedmy brother told my mother about my transgression in a lofty voice tinged with compassion. Eating frankfurter sandwiches on the street was one of the many things that my mother forbade us to do.

paragraph1: They will all vanish at the same time, like the millions of images that lay behind the foreheads of the grandparents, dead for half a century, and of the parents, also dead. Images in which we appeared as a little girl in the midst of beings who died before we were born, just as in our own memories our small children are there next to our parents and schoolmates. And one day we’ll appear in our children’s memories, among their grandchildren and people not yet born. Like sexual desire, memory never stops. It pairs the dead with the living, real with imaginary beings, dreams with history.
paragraph2: Memories slip away like water through cupped hands, destined to vanish just as the vivid images once held by our departed grandparents and parents have faded into nothingness. We are but a thread in this vast tapestry of remembrance, connected to those who came before and those yet to emerge from the mists of time. Our own cherished moments will one day dissolve, joining the countless lost recollections of our ancestors, while our children and their children will weave new memories into this endless fabric. Like the persistent pulse of desire that flows through generations, memory binds us together across time, connecting the living with the dead, the real with the imagined, in an eternal dance of consciousness that neither begins nor ends.

paragraph1: Generally, women can’t do this, but men retain the ancient ability to leave a family and a past. They just unhook themselves, like removing a fake beard, and skulk discreetly back into society, changed men. Unrecognizable. In this manner, a new Archie is about to emerge. We have caught him on the hop. For he is in a past-tense, future-perfect kind of mood. He is in a maybe this, maybe that kind of mood. Approaching a forked road, he slows down, checks his undistinguished face in the wing-mirror, and quite indiscriminately chooses a route he’s never taken before, a residential street leading to a place called Queens Park. Go straight pastGo!, Archie-boy, he tells himself; collect two hundred and don’t for gawd’s sake look back.
paragraph2: Archie possessed a remarkable talent for shedding his past and family connections as effortlessly as one might discard an old costume. Standing at this pivotal moment, he found himself contemplating his next move while his identity seemed to shift and reshape itself like clay in his hands. The metaphorical fork in the road before him demanded a choice, and as he caught a glimpse of his plain, forgettable features in a nearby window, he made his decision with surprising casualness. Queens Park lay ahead on the unfamiliar path he selected, its unknown territory both daunting and oddly appealing. Like a determined Monopoly player advancing across the board, Archie steeled himself against the urge to look backward, choosing instead to press forward into his self-imposed exile, leaving behind all that was familiar in pursuit of reinvention.

paragraph1: There will be a moment of truth at the end of the voyage, when Bob will not appear to pay his bill and pick up his passport; nor will he pack his bags. There will be a flurry of concern, followed by a staff meeting—behind closed doors, so as not to alarm the passengers. Ultimately, there will be a news itemBob, tragically, must have fallen off the ship on the last night of the voyage while leaning over to get a better camera angle on the northern lights. No other explanation is possible.Meanwhile, the passengers will have scattered to the winds, Verna among them. If, that is, she pulls it off. Will she or won’t she? She ought to care more about that—she ought to find it an exciting challenge—but right now she just feels tired and somewhat empty.Though at peace, though safe. Calm of mind all passion spent, as her third husband used to say so annoyingly after his Viagra sessions. Those Victorians always coupled sex with death. Who was that poet anyway? Keats? Tennyson? Her memory isn’t what it was. But the details will come back to her later.
paragraph2: The peculiar circumstances surrounding Bob's disappearance cast a shadow over the final days of the voyage, with his unpaid bill and abandoned passport raising quiet alarms among the ship's personnel. During their discreet staff meeting, carefully orchestrated to maintain calm among the passengers, theories circulated about his last known whereabouts while photographing the northern lights. The timing and location of his vanishing sparked whispers of both tragic accident and something more sinister. Meanwhile, Verna sat alone in her cabin, her mind drifting between satisfaction and exhaustion as she contemplated the success of her carefully constructed plan. The emptiness she felt wasn't entirely unwelcome; rather, it brought an unexpected sense of peace she hadn't experienced since before her marriages. As she gazed out at the dark waters, fragments of Victorian poetry floated through her consciousness, remnants of her third husband's irritating habit of spontaneous recitation. Try as she might, she couldn't place which poet he had so frequently quoted, though the memory of his pretentious literary displays still made her grimace. The ship's gentle swaying seemed to mock the gravity of Bob's absence, as if holding secrets beneath its steady rhythm.

paragraph1: As I sit here contemplating the classical Roman world, with its ordered structures and clear hierarchies, I can't help but feel drawn to its apparent simplicity, especially in contrast to the complex narrative I've been wrestling with for nearly nine months. My current manuscript, still refusing to yield a complete draft, transports readers to a post-colonial African nation where tribal tensions simmer beneath a fragile surface. The story follows two white characters navigating a single day's journey through this precarious landscape, their every mile weighted with unspoken fears and the crumbling remnants of colonial authority. Though I've deliberately avoided explicit violence, the emotional intensity pulses through every page, much like the anxiety that grips my characters as they traverse their uncertain path. The mist gathering outside my window and the encroaching darkness seem to seep into my writing, their nebulous quality perfectly mirroring the ambiguous terrain of my fictional Africa. Sometimes I wonder if this perpetual fog in my surroundings is unconsciously shaping the atmospheric tension in my narrative, as if the physical world around me is bleeding into the imagined one I'm creating on the page.
paragraph2: The idea of living in my imagination in that classical Roman world was attractive to me. A beautiful, clear, dangerous world, far removed from the setting in which I had found myself; the story, more a mood than a story, so different from the book on which I was working. A taxing bookit had been occupying me for eight or nine months, and I still hadn’t completed a draft. At the center of the book I was writing was a story set in an African country, once a colony, with white and Asian settlers, and now independent. It was the story of a daylong journey made in a car by two white people at a time of tribal war—war suddenly coming, suddenly overwhelming colonial order and simplicity. Africa had given both those white people a chance, made them bigger, brought out their potential; now, when they were no longer so young, it was consuming them. It was a violent book—violent not in its incidents but in its emotions.It was a book about fear. All the jokes were silenced by this fear. And the mist that hung over the valley where I was writing, the darkness that came early, the absence of knowledge of where I was—all this uncertainty emanating from the valley I transferred to my Africa.

And the mist that hung over the valley where I was writing, the darkness that came early, the absence of knowledge of where I was—all this uncertainty emanating from the valley I transferred to my Africa.

paragraph1: That evening I thought about my father’s phone call from the night before, and how I had wanted to tell Nick about it, and for a moment I really thoughtI will call Nick and he will come back. Things like this can be undone. But I knew that he would never come back again, not really. He wasn’t only mine any more, that part was over. Melissa knew things that I didn’t know. After everything that had happened between them they still desired one another. I thought about her email, and about how I was sick and probably infertile anyway, and how I could give Nick nothing that would mean anything to him. For the next few days I stared at my phone for hours on end and accomplished nothing. The time moved past visibly on the illuminated onscreen clock and yet I still felt as though I didn’t notice it passing. Nick didn’t call me that evening, or that night. He didn’t call me the next day, or the day after that. Nobody did. Gradually the waiting began to feel less like waiting and more like this was simply what life wasthe distracting tasks undertaken while the thing you are waiting for continues not to happen. I applied for jobs and turned up for seminars. Things went on.
paragraph2: Every time my phone buzzes, my heart leaps with a desperate hope that quickly dissolves into familiar disappointment when I see it's not Nick's name on the screen. Last week's call with Dad only intensified this ache - his well-meaning advice about moving on felt like salt in an open wound. I know Nick has moved on with Melissa; their social media posts paint a picture of the happiness I once thought would be mine. The rational part of my brain understands it's over, but my heart refuses to accept this new reality, leaving me in this perpetual state of longing and self-doubt. I spend countless hours analyzing my flaws, wondering if I wasn't good enough, pretty enough, or interesting enough to keep him. Days blur together as I compulsively check my phone, watching hours turn into days, and days into weeks, all while pretending to function normally. I've started applying for jobs and attending professional development seminars - desperate attempts to fill the void and create the illusion of progress. But even as I sit in these crowded rooms, taking notes and nodding along, my mind wanders back to Nick, and I find myself trapped in this endless cycle of waiting for a call that I know, deep down, will never come. The weight of this unrequited hope has become my constant companion, following me through every mundane moment of my days.

paragraph1: The Lazy River is a metaphor and at the same time a real body of artificial water, in an all-inclusive hotel, in Almería, somewhere in southern Spain. We do not leave the hotel (except to buy flotation devices). The plan is to beat our hotel at its own game. What you do is you do thisyou drink so much alcohol that your accommodation is effectively free. (Only the most vulgar among us speak this plan aloud but we are all on board.) For in this hotel we are all British, we are en masse, we are unashamed. We enjoy one another’s company. There is nobody French or German here to see us at the buffet, rejecting paella and swordfish in favor of sausages and chips, nor anyone to judge us as we lie on our loungers, turning from the concept of literature toward the reality of sudoku. One of our tribe, an older gentleman, has a portrait of Amy Winehouse on each shin, and we do not judge him, not at all, how could we? We do not have so many saints of Amy’s calibre left to us; we cherish her. She was one of the few who expressed our pain without ridiculing or diminishing it. It is therefore fitting that in the evenings, during the brief spell in which we emerge from the Lazy River, we will, at karaoke hour, belt out her famous torch songs—full-throated, already drunk—content in the knowledge that later, much later, when all of this is over, these same beloved verses will be sung at our funerals.
paragraph2: We drift along the Lazy River each afternoon, our bodies buoyed by inflatable rings and our minds pleasantly numbed by the steady stream of all-inclusive cocktails that we've calculated will eventually make this holiday pay for itself. None of us speaks about this particular math out loud, but we all know the score, keeping mental tallies of our drinks against the package price. The Spanish sun beats down on our British skin as we float past each other, exchanging knowing glances and bits of conversation about last night's karaoke triumphs. We stick to what we know best – the comfort of familiar sausages and chips at the buffet, barely glancing at the paella that sits untouched. Old Dave's Amy Winehouse tattoos on his shins have become something of a legend among us; we've all stopped to admire them at some point, understanding without saying that they represent more than just fan art – they're a marker of our shared cultural grief, a connection to home even here in Almería. The days blur together in a pleasant haze of poolside sudoku and gossip about the other guests, while evenings find us gathered around the karaoke machine, belting out "Rehab" and "Back to Black" with a passion that surprises the hotel staff. We're not here for authentic Spanish experiences or cultural enlightenment; we're here to be together, to be ourselves, to float along our own familiar current while technically being abroad.

paragraph1: What if I forgave myself? I thought. What if I forgave myself even though I'd done something I shouldn't have? What if I was a liar and a cheat and there was no excuse for what I'd done other than because it was what I wanted and needed to do? What if I was sorry, but if I could go back in time I wouldn't do anything differently than I had done? What if I'd actually wanted to fuck every one of those men? What if heroin taught me something? What if yes was the right answer instead of no? What if what made me do all those things everyone thought I shouldn't have done was what also had got me here? What if I was never redeemed? What if I already was?
paragraph2: Looking back at my life's winding path, I find myself torn between the weight of guilt and the possibility of redemption. The lies I've told, the hearts I've broken, and the nights lost to chemical escapes - they all swirl in my consciousness like persistent ghosts. Sometimes I wonder if my actions were merely the desperate attempts of a soul seeking connection, or if I was simply following my selfish desires without regard for consequences. The men who drifted through my life, each leaving their mark on my story, now seem like chapters in a book I'm not sure I should have written. Yet there's a growing whisper inside me suggesting that perhaps redemption isn't something to be earned, but rather a state of being I've inhabited all along, even during my darkest moments. The journey of self-acceptance feels both liberating and terrifying.

paragraph1: In the dimly lit wine cellar, Tomas studied Tereza's face with growing apprehension, his fingers nervously tracing the rim of his wine glass. The weight of potential loss hung heavily between them as he voiced his fears about her slipping away, particularly troubled by her increasing preoccupation with death that manifested in her recurring dreams. Tereza's response came with a gentle understanding that surprised him; she spoke of his love and acknowledged his various infidelities without a trace of bitterness in her voice. Yet, her own confession revealed a deeper struggle—the terrifying nature of her nighttime visions that haunted her consciousness. Her existence had become a peculiar balancing act between two distinct realms: the rational clarity of daylight and the mysterious depths of night. This duality created within her a profound sense of vertigo, a simultaneous attraction and fear toward the void beneath their feet. Like a tightrope walker suspended between two worlds, Tereza found herself both drawn to and repelled by the emptiness below, her emotional equilibrium constantly threatened by this internal tension.
paragraph2: Dear Tereza, sweet Tereza, what am I losing you to? he once said to her as they sat face to face in a wine cellar. Every night you dream of death as if you really wished to quit this world. . . . It was day; reason and will power were back in place. A drop of red wine ran slowly down her glass as she answered. There's nothing I can do about it, Tomas. Oh, I understand. I know you love me. I know your infidelities are no great tragedy ... She looked at him with love in her eyes, but she feared the night ahead, feared her dreams. Her life was split. Both day and night were competing for her. Anyone whose goal is something higher must expect some day to suffer vertigo. What is vertigo? Fear of falling? Then why do we feel it even when the observation tower comes equipped with a sturdy handrail? No, vertigo is something other than the fear of falling. It is the voice of the emptiness below us which tempts and lures us, it is the desire to fall, against which, terrified, we defend ourselves.

paragraph1: All this happened in the seventies, though in that town and other small towns like it the seventies were not as we picture them now, or as I had known them even in Vancouver. The boys’ hair was longer than it had been, but not straggling down their backs, and there didn’t seem to be an unusual amount of liberation or defiance in the air.My uncle started off by teasing me about grace. About not saying grace. I was thirteen years old, living with him and my aunt for the year that my parents were in Africa. I had never bowed my head over a plate of food in my life.
paragraph2: Growing up in this small town during the seventies was nothing like what most people imagine of that era. While Vancouver embraced the counterculture movement wholeheartedly, our community seemed to exist in its own timeless bubble. I noticed this most clearly in the boys at school, whose hair barely touched their collars – a far cry from the flowing locks you'd see in the city. Living with my aunt and uncle while my parents were away in Africa brought its own cultural adjustments. I remember distinctly how Uncle Jim would tease me about my apparent ignorance of saying grace, something that had never been part of my thirteen-year-old life before. "Never bowed your head over a plate of food?" he'd ask with a mix of amusement and mild disapproval, making me acutely aware of how different their household customs were from my own upbringing.

paragraph1: As I journeyed by train toward my mother's home that sweltering Sunday in July, the brief pause at Motteville station allowed me to absorb the drowsy atmosphere of the summer afternoon. The stillness was palpable, broken only by the distant hum of insects and the occasional metallic creak of the train's cooling engine. I could sense C. drawing nearer with each passing moment, that familiar yet somehow foreign destination where my mother awaited. Upon arrival, I found myself in the peculiar position of failing to recognize faces that should have been familiar, their features somehow altered by time or perhaps my own shifting memories. The climate in C. had always been notably cooler and more wind-swept than surrounding areas, a fact my mother never failed to mention and one that all local residents seemed to accept as gospel truth. Rather than hailing a taxi, I embraced the local custom of walking into the town center, my footsteps echoing against the cobblestones as I made my way to purchase the customary offerings - delicate pastries from the corner bakery and a carefully selected bouquet of flowers. These simple rituals stirred memories of countless previous visits, each one marked by the same anticipatory flutter in my chest as I approached my mother's door. The weight of the pastry box in one hand and the fresh flowers in the other served as tangible anchors to this moment, bridging the gap between past visits and the present, all while my thoughts raced ahead to the imminent reunion with my mother.
paragraph2: The last time I saw my mother at her home, it was July, a Sunday. I travelled there by train. At Motteville, we sat in the station for a long time. It was hot. It was quiet, both in the compartment and outside. I looked out the open window; the platform was empty. On the other side of the S.N.C.F. railroad barriers, the tall grass almost touched the lowest branches of the apple trees. It was then that I could really feel that I was approaching C. and that I was going to see my mother. The train continued on to C. at a reduced speed.Leaving the station, I thought I recognized various faces, without being able to put a name to any of them. Perhaps I had never known the names. It was less hot, thanks to the wind. It’s always windy in C. Everyone, including my mother, believes that it’s colder in C. than in other places, even those just five kilometres away.I didn’t take the taxi that was parked in front of the railway hotel, as I would have anywhere else. As soon as I’m in C., I go back to my old waysa taxi is for communions, weddings, and burials. There’s no reason to spend money like that. I headed up Rue Carnot, to the town center. At the first pâtisserie, I bought cakes, éclairs, and apple tarts—the kind she used to tell me to bring home after midday Mass. I bought some flowers, too, gladioli, which last a long time. Until I got to the housing complex where she lives, I didn’t think anything besides, I’m going to see her again and She’s waiting for me.

paragraph1: Growing up in a working-class family where manual labor and small-scale trading defined our daily existence, I became determined to chart a different course through education. As the first in my family to attend university, I thought I had successfully distanced myself from the cycle of hardship that marked my upbringing. Yet here I am, confronting an unwanted pregnancy that threatens to drag me back into the very circumstances I fought so hard to escape. When I look at the pregnant teenager at the bus stop or the woman drinking alone at the corner store, I see reflections of the social struggles I thought I'd left behind. Their stories could easily become mine, but I refuse to let this pregnancy derail everything I've worked for. I approach the decision to abort with a clear-headed practicality, knowing countless women before me have walked this path and emerged intact, ready to reclaim their chosen trajectories.
paragraph2: Somehow I felt there existed a connection between my social background and my present condition. Born into a family of laborers and storekeepers, I was the first to attend higher education and so had been spared both factory work and commerce. Yet neither my baccalauréat nor my B.A. in liberal arts had waived that inescapable fatality of the working-class—the legacy of poverty—embodied by both the pregnant girl and the alcoholic. My ass had caught up with me, and the thing growing inside me I saw as the stigma of social failure. I wasn’t the least bit apprehensive about getting an abortion. It seemed a highly feasible undertaking, admittedly not an easy one, but one that did not require undue courage. A minor ordeal. All I needed to do was follow in the footsteps of the myriad women who had preceded me

paragraph1: Those two years after university were the height of our fraternal youth. We were growing up fast. We were both working on our first novels, and they had much in commonsex, mayhem, a touch of apocalypse, some violence, some fashionable despair, and very good jokes about all the things that can go wrong between a young man and a young woman. We were happy. Nothing stood in our way.Then two things did. Jocelyn, without telling me, wrote a TV play. That sort of thing, I thought at the time, was well beneath us. We worshipped at the temple of literature. TV was mere entertainment, dross for the masses. The screenplay was immediately produced, starred two famous actors, was passionate about a good cause—homelessness or unemployment—that I had never heard Jocelyn mention. It was a success; he was talked about, noted. His first novel was anticipated.
paragraph2: Those early post-university years with Jocelyn were filled with such unbridled creative energy as we both threw ourselves into writing our debut novels. We shared everything then - our manuscripts, our dreams, and our mutual fascination with weaving sex, chaos, and dark humor into our narratives. I felt we were kindred spirits, two serious writers carving our path in literature. The betrayal, when it came, was swift and unexpected. Jocelyn had secretly penned a television play, the sort of commercial venture we had always looked down upon in our literary discussions. What stung even more than the secrecy was its success - suddenly everyone was talking about Jocelyn's "fresh voice" and "innovative storytelling," eagerly awaiting the novel they assumed would follow. I watched from the sidelines as my friend crossed the line we had drawn between art and entertainment, feeling both bitter and bewildered by how easily our shared principles had been abandoned.

Paragraph 1:
Those two years after university were the height of our fraternal youth. We were growing up fast. We were both working on our first novels, and they had much in commonsex, mayhem, a touch of apocalypse, some violence, some fashionable despair, and very good jokes about all the things that can go wrong between a young man and a young woman. We were happy. Nothing stood in our way.Then two things did. Jocelyn, without telling me, wrote a TV play. That sort of thing, I thought at the time, was well beneath us. We worshipped at the temple of literature. TV was mere entertainment, dross for the masses. The screenplay was immediately produced, starred two famous actors, was passionate about a good cause—homelessness or unemployment—that I had never heard Jocelyn mention. It was a success; he was talked about, noted. His first novel was anticipated.

Paragraph 2:
Those early post-university years with Jocelyn were filled with such unbridled creative energy as we both threw ourselves into writing our debut novels. We shared everything then - our manuscripts, our dreams, and our mutual fascination with weaving sex, chaos, and dark humor into our narratives. I felt we were kindred spirits, two serious writers carving our path in literature. The betrayal, when it came, was swift and unexpected. Jocelyn had secretly penned a television play, the sort of commercial venture we had always looked down upon in our literary discussions. What stung even more than the secrecy was its success - suddenly everyone was talking about Jocelyn's "fresh voice" and "innovative storytelling," eagerly awaiting the novel they assumed would follow. I watched from the sidelines as my friend crossed the line we had drawn between art and entertainment, feeling both bitter and bewildered by how easily our shared principles had been abandoned.

paragraph1: "It’s the forties look," she says to George, hand on her hip, doing a pirouette. "Rosie the Riveter. From the war. Remember her?" George, whose name is not really George, does not remember. He spent the forties rooting through garbage heaps and begging, and doing other things unsuitable for a child. He has a dim memory of some film star posed on a calendar tattering on a latrine wall. Maybe this is the one Prue means. He remembers for an instant his intense resentment of the bright, ignorant smile, the well-fed body. A couple of buddies had helped him take her apart with the rusty blade from a kitchen knife they’d found somewhere in the rubble. He does not consider telling any of this to Prue.George is sitting in a green-and-white striped canvas deck chair, reading the Financial Post and drinking Scotch. The ashtray beside him overflows with butts; many women have tried to cure him of smoking; many have failed. He looks up at Prue from behind his paper and smiles his foxy smile. This is a smile he does with the cigarette held right in the center of his mouthon either side of it his lips curl back, revealing teeth. He has long canines, miraculously still his.
paragraph2: Striking a pose with her arm flexed and bandana tied just so, Prue did her best impression of "Rosie the Riveter," attempting to spark a shared memory of the 1940s with George, though that wasn't his real name. Her playful gesture hung in the air as George's mind wandered to darker corners of that decade, remembering not the celebrated workforce icon but the desperate child he had been, scrounging through streets and begging for scraps to survive. A particular memory surfaced of him defacing a film star's poster, his young hands tearing at the glossy paper with bitter satisfaction, though he kept this recollection locked away from Prue's eager eyes. Instead, he leaned back in his deck chair, the ice in his Scotch clinking softly as he took another slow drag from his cigarette. His response to her theatrical nostalgia was simply a smile, one that revealed his unusually long canines, while the gulf between her romanticized version of the war years and his harsh reality stretched wide and deep between them, unacknowledged in the warm afternoon air.

paragraph1: My mother said, “It must be an inch thick with dust,” but she went straight to her room to fetch the key to the building, which was attached to the apartment key by a red ribbon. “Do you remember that Kütahya vase with the red flowers?” she asked as she handed me the keys. “I can’t find it anywhere in the house, so can you check to see if I took it over there? And don’t work so hard. . . . Your father spent his whole life working hard so that you young ones could have some fun in life. You deserve to be happy. Take Sibel out and enjoy the spring air.” Then, pressing the keys into my hand, she gave me a strange look and said, “Be careful!” It was the look that she would give us when we were children, to warn us that life held unsuspected dangers that were far deeper and more treacherous than, for instance, failing to take proper care of a key.
paragraph2: Watching my mother fret about the gathered dust, I couldn't help but notice how her movements had slowed over the years. She disappeared into her room, emerging moments later with a key that seemed to unlock more than just doors – it unlocked memories. Her eyes lit up as she spoke of the Kütahya vase, its red flowers a vivid splash in her recollection, and she urged me to search for it in the other building. The way she described it made me wonder if she was seeing it right there before her, though it had been missing for years. Her voice softened as she cautioned me about working too hard, reminding me how father had toiled endlessly so we children could live more freely. "Why don't you take Sibel out? The spring air would do you both good," she suggested, her words carrying the weight of maternal wisdom. As she pressed the keys into my palm, her expression mirrored countless childhood moments when she'd tried to protect me from life's unseen perils, communicating volumes through just one careful look.

paragraph1: Somehow I felt there existed a connection between my social background and my present condition. Born into a family of laborers and storekeepers, I was the first to attend higher education and so had been spared both factory work and commerce. Yet neither my baccalauréat nor my B.A. in liberal arts had waived that inescapable fatality of the working-class—the legacy of poverty—embodied by both the pregnant girl and the alcoholic. My ass had caught up with me, and the thing growing inside me I saw as the stigma of social failure. I wasn’t the least bit apprehensive about getting an abortion. It seemed a highly feasible undertaking, admittedly not an easy one, but one that did not require undue courage. A minor ordeal. All I needed to do was follow in the footsteps of the myriad women who had preceded me
paragraph2: Growing up in a working-class family where manual labor and small-scale trading defined our daily existence, I became determined to chart a different course through education. As the first in my family to attend university, I thought I had successfully distanced myself from the cycle of hardship that marked my upbringing. Yet here I am, confronting an unwanted pregnancy that threatens to drag me back into the very circumstances I fought so hard to escape. When I look at the pregnant teenager at the bus stop or the woman drinking alone at the corner store, I see reflections of the social struggles I thought I'd left behind. Their stories could easily become mine, but I refuse to let this pregnancy derail everything I've worked for. I approach the decision to abort with a clear-headed practicality, knowing countless women before me have walked this path and emerged intact, ready to reclaim their chosen trajectories.

paragraph1: Our language did not join the old man at the Café of the Fountain. She sat alone in her corner. They did not speak.In the time of the universal “yes,” the piazza was quiet. You could hear the songbirds, the larks, whose numbers had not yet been decimated by weekend shooting parties. In the center of the piazza there is a small fountain—the fountain, obviously, from which the café takes its name—and back in the old days the silence allowed you to listen to the water, and soothe your aching heart. The old man was younger then, and his heart ached often, thanks to the repeated rejection of its sincerely offered emotions by young women with hair of different colors.Even in those days when the word “no” was forbidden, those women were able to inform him that his feelings for them were not requited.
paragraph2: In the tranquil piazza, where songbirds' melodies mingle with the gentle murmur of the small fountain, the old man's familiar presence at the Café of the Fountain remains unaccompanied by "our language," who sits solitary in a distant corner. The peaceful setting, untouched by the usual bustle of daily life, serves as a canvas for memories of bygone days. As the old man settles into his usual spot, his mind drifts to his youth, recalling the sharp sting of unrequited love and the countless times his passionate declarations fell on indifferent ears. Even in an era when social conventions pushed people toward mutual agreement and acceptance, he found himself repeatedly facing rejection from the young women who captured his heart. The contrast between that emotionally turbulent past and the acquiescent present hangs in the air like the fountain's mist, creating a bittersweet symphony of remembrance in the quiet square.

paragraph1: In October 1963, in the city of Rouen, I waited for my period for over a week. It was a warm, sunny month. I felt heavy and stuffy in my winter coat, especially in the department stores where I had taken to browsing and buying stockings, waiting for college to resume. When I got back to my room in the girls’ dorm in the Rue d’Herbouville, I would still hope to see a stain appear on my panties. I began writing in my diary every evening—the word NOTHING in big, underlined capital letters. I would wake up in the middle of the night and instinctively know that "nothing" had happened. The year before, around the same time, I had started work on a novel; now this seemed faraway, something that was not to be pursued. One afternoon I went to see Il Posto, an Italian film in black and white. It was the slow, sad story of a young man working as an office clerk—his very first job. The cinema was almost empty. As I watched the frail figure of the boy in his cheap raincoat, the humiliations he suffered during his pathetic existence, somehow I knew the bleeding would not come back. One evening I was talked into going to the theater by some of the girls who had gotten a spare ticket. They were putting on Huis Clos by Jean-Paul Sartre and I had never been to see a contemporary production. The theater was packed. I stared at the brightly lit stage at the back, obsessed with the fact that I no longer had my period. All I can remember about the play is the character called Estelle, a blonde girl in a blue dress, and the Boy dressed as a manservant, with red, lidless eyes. In my diary I wrote"Fantastic. If only I didn’t have this REALITY inside me.
paragraph2: Every October morning in 1963, I found myself wandering through Rouen's department stores, uncomfortably warm in my winter coat, killing time until college classes would begin again. The ritual of checking for my period had become an obsession, each night ending with the same stark entry in my diary: "NOTHING." The waiting consumed me, transforming ordinary days into a blur of anxiety and hope. I tried to distract myself with a novel I'd started the previous year, but the words seemed hollow now, unable to capture my attention as they once had. One afternoon, seeking escape, I watched an Italian film called *Il Posto*, but instead of providing relief, it only crystallized the terrifying possibility that my period might never return. Despite my growing unease, I joined other girls for a showing of Sartre's *Huis Clos*, though my mind remained fixated on my absent period throughout the performance. The play's character Estelle and a peculiar boy with red eyes left an impression, yet even these theatrical elements seemed to merge with my personal crisis. In my diary that night, alongside notes about the performance, I couldn't help but reflect on how my current reality had become as stark and confining as the play's setting. The streets of Rouen, the familiar corridors of the dormitory, and even my own room had become spaces of anxious contemplation, each day marking another moment of uncertainty in this unwanted waiting game.
