paragraph1: I watch helplessly as the discord between Muneeza and Father grows more intense with each passing day, their voices echoing through our home like thunderclaps in an endless storm. My middle sister, barely eleven, has already developed a fierceness that mirrors Father's volatile nature, making their confrontations increasingly dangerous. The day she hurled those kitchen scissors at me, leaving a jagged cut on my thigh, I realized I could no longer play mediator in their battles. The scar serves as a constant reminder of why I now retreat to my room when I hear their arguments begin, though the walls do little to muffle their shouting. Sometimes, I catch glimpses of myself in the mirror and search for signs of Father's temperament in my own features, desperately hoping I haven't inherited his quick-burning anger. My dreams of obtaining British citizenship have become an obsession, representing not just a document but an escape route from this suffocating atmosphere. I tell myself that once I'm far away, I can shed any trace of Father's influence like an old skin, starting fresh in a place where raised voices and flying scissors are not the language of family. Yet, even as I make these plans, a nagging doubt persists - can I truly outrun the parts of him that may already be woven into the fabric of who I am? For now, I remain caught between love and fear, watching my sister follow a path I desperately want to avoid.
paragraph2: My middle sister Muneeza, now eleven, was entering her delinquent phase a little early. She was the true inheritor of my father’s black rage, and when she lost control it was terrible to behold. That summer she seemed to pick fights with my father on purpose; seemed prepared, at her young age, to test her strength against his. (I intervened in her rows with Abba only once, in the kitchen. She grabbed the kitchen scissors and flung them at me. They cut me on the thigh. After that I kept my distance.) As I witnessed their wars I felt myself coming unstuck from the idea of family itself. I looked at my screaming sister and thought how brilliantly selfdestructive she was, how triumphantly she was ruining her relations with the people she needed most. And I looked at my choleric, face-pulling father and thought about British citizenship. My existing Indian passport permitted me to travel only to a very few countries, which were carefully listed on the second right-hand page. But I might soon have a British passport and then, by hook or by crook, I would get away from him. I would not have this face-pulling in my life. At sixteen, you still think you can escape from your father. You aren’t listening to his voice speaking through your mouth, you don’t see how your gestures already mirror his; you don’t see him in the way you hold your body, in the way you sign your name. You don’t hear his whisper in your blood.

I watch helplessly as the discord between Muneeza and Father grows more intense with each passing day, their voices echoing through our home like thunderclaps in an endless storm. My middle sister, barely eleven, has already developed a fierceness that mirrors Father's volatile nature, making their confrontations increasingly dangerous. The day she hurled those kitchen scissors at me, leaving a jagged cut on my thigh, I realized I could no longer play mediator in their battles. The scar serves as a constant reminder of why I now retreat to my room when I hear their arguments begin, though the walls do little to muffle their shouting. Sometimes, I catch glimpses of myself in the mirror and search for signs of Father's temperament in my own features, desperately hoping I haven't inherited his quick-burning anger. My dreams of obtaining British citizenship have become an obsession, representing not just a document but an escape route from this suffocating atmosphere. I tell myself that once I'm far away, I can shed any trace of Father's influence like an old skin, starting fresh in a place where raised voices and flying scissors are not the language of family. Yet, even as I make these plans, a nagging doubt persists - can I truly outrun the parts of him that may already be woven into the fabric of who I am? For now, I remain caught between love and fear, watching my sister follow a path I desperately want to avoid.

Paragraph 2:
My middle sister Muneeza, now eleven, was entering her delinquent phase a little early. She was the true inheritor of my father’s black rage, and when she lost control it was terrible to behold. That summer she seemed to pick fights with my father on purpose; seemed prepared, at her young age, to test her strength against his. (I intervened in her rows with Abba only once, in the kitchen. She grabbed the kitchen scissors and flung them at me. They cut me on the thigh. After that I kept my distance.) As I witnessed their wars I felt myself coming unstuck from the idea of family itself. I looked at my screaming sister and thought how brilliantly selfdestructive she was, how triumphantly she was ruining her relations with the people she needed most. And I looked at my choleric, face-pulling father and thought about British citizenship. My existing Indian passport permitted me to travel only to a very few countries, which were carefully listed on the second right-hand page. But I might soon have a British passport and then, by hook or by crook, I would get away from him. I would not have this face-pulling in my life. At sixteen, you still think you can escape from your father. You aren’t listening to his voice speaking through your mouth, you don’t see how your gestures already mirror his; you don’t see him in the way you hold your body, in the way you sign your name. You don’t hear his whisper in your blood.

paragraph1: By the time we reach the gates of the hotel all is dark. A pair of identical twins, Rico and Rocco, in their twenties, with oily black curls and skinny white jeans—twin iPhones wedged in their tight pockets—have just finished their act and are packing up their boom box. "We come runner-up "X Factor" Spain,” they say, in answer to our queries. "We are Tunisia for birth but now we are Spain.” We wish them well and good night, and divert our children’s eyes from the obscene bulge of those iPhones, the existence of which we have decided not to reveal to them for many years, or at least until they are twelve. At the elevators, we separate from our friends and their children and ascend to our room, which is the same as their room and everybody’s room, and put the children to bed and sit on the balcony with our laptops and our phones, where we look up his Twitter, as we have every night since January. Here and there, on other balconies, we spot other men and women on other loungers with other devices, engaged in much the same routine. Down below, the Lazy River runs, a neon blue, a crazy blue, a Facebook blue. In it stands a fully clothed man armed with a long mop—he is being held in place by another man, who grips him by the waist, so that the first man may angle his mop and position himself against the strong yet somniferous current and clean whatever scum we have left of ourselves off the sides.
paragraph2: While saying goodnight to Rico and Rocco, the charismatic Tunisian twins who'd just wrapped up their performance and proudly shared their X Factor Spain success story, I found myself strategically positioning myself to block my children's view of their protruding iPhones - a technology we'd agreed to withhold until they turned twelve. The twins' identical features and synchronized movements still lingered in my mind as our families parted ways to our mirror-image hotel rooms for the night. Once the kids had drifted off to sleep, we adults gravitated to our usual evening ritual, gathering on the balcony with our devices glowing in the darkness. Like clockwork, we joined the silent community of other guests, all of us perched on our respective balconies, united in our nightly ritual of checking that particular Twitter feed. Below us, the Lazy River attraction curved through the property, its Facebook-blue illumination casting an ethereal glow across the night landscape. The scene was made even more surreal by the sight of a fully clothed man, assisted by his colleague, determinedly working against the current with a mop, methodically cleaning the river's edges in what seemed like an endless battle against the perpetual flow.

paragraph1: During those two beautiful days of melancholy, his compassion (that curse of emotional telepathy) had taken a holiday. It had slept the sound Sunday sleep of a miner who, after a hard week's work, needs to gather strength for his Monday shift. Instead of the patients he was treating, Tomas saw Tereza. He tried to remind himself. Don't think about her! Don't think about her! He said to himself, I'm sick with compassion. It's good that she's gone and that I'll never see her again, though it's not Tereza I need to be free of—it's that sickness, compassion, which I thought I was immune to until she infected me with it. On Saturday and Sunday, he felt the sweet lightness of being rise up to him out of the depths of the future. On Monday, he was hit by a weight the likes of which he had never known. The tons of steel of the Russian tanks were nothing compared with it. For there is nothing heavier than compassion. Not even one's own pain weighs so heavy as the pain one feels with someone, for someone, a pain intensified by the imagination and prolonged by a hundred echoes.
paragraph2: For two precious days, Tomas found himself released from the crushing weight of compassion that had become his constant companion, experiencing a relief as profound as a miner's deep slumber after an exhausting week in the depths of the earth. His mind, though temporarily unburdened, remained fixated on Tereza, not with longing but with a complex understanding that it wasn't her physical presence he sought to escape, but rather the overwhelming compassion she stirred within him. This brief respite allowed him to taste a fragment of freedom, like a prisoner granted a temporary release from his chains, as he moved through the weekend with unusual lightness in his steps. However, the liberation proved fleeting, and by Monday, he found himself once again crushed beneath a burden of compassion more oppressive than any personal suffering he had ever endured. This emotional weight descended upon him with the same brutal force as the Russian tanks that had once rolled through the streets, serving as a stark reminder that his capacity for empathy, though noble, was also his heaviest cross to bear.

paragraph1: I often find myself thinking back to those days when Q and I were neighbors, sharing the most mundane yet meaningful aspects of our lives. We'd knock on each other's doors, borrowing salt or salad dressing, and these simple exchanges gradually built a comfortable friendship. Our evenings were filled with the soft crackle of vinyl records and the gentle hiss of beer cans opening, creating a soundtrack to our youthful conversations. I particularly remember our double date to Kamakura shore, the salty air and laughter mixing together in what now feels like a distant dream. But life, as it often does, took us in different directions when I moved out during that summer break of my senior year. The thread of our friendship, once so strong, gradually unraveled in the silence that followed. Nearly a decade passed before I saw him again, a chance encounter by the hotel pool in Akasaka. He sat there, transformed by time, exuding a quiet dignity I hadn't known in him before. Next to him was a strikingly beautiful woman, their conversation intimate and absorbing. Though I recognized him instantly, something held me back from calling out his name. Perhaps it was the weight of those intervening years, or maybe the realization that some chapters are better left closed. Instead, I returned to my book, letting the moment pass like a leaf on the surface of the pool, creating ripples that would soon disappear into stillness.
paragraph2: Back then, Q lived in the apartment next door to mine. What with lending salt or borrowing salad dressing, we got to be friends, and soon we were at each other’s places all the time, listening to records, drinking beer. Once, my girlfriend and I drove out to the Kamakura shore with Q and his girlfriend. We were very comfortable together. Then, during the summer break of my senior year, I moved out, and that was that.The next time I saw Q, almost a decade had gone by. I was reading a book by a swanky hotel pool near the Akasaka district. Q was sitting in the deck chair next to mine, and beside him was a beautiful long-legged woman in a bikini.I knew right away that it was Q. He was as handsome as ever, and now, just over thirty, he evinced a certain dignity that he hadn’t had before. Young women walking by gave him a quick once-over.He didn’t notice me sitting next to him. I’m a fairly ordinary-looking guy, and I was wearing sunglasses. I wasn’t sure whether I should talk to him, but in the end I decided not to. He and the woman were deep in conversation, and I hesitated to interrupt them. Besides, there wasn’t a lot that he and I could have talked about. “I lent you salt, remember?” “Hey, that’s right, and I borrowed a bottle of salad dressing.” We would have run out of topics quickly. So I kept my mouth shut and stuck to my book.

paragraph1: Standing here in this endless line at the superstore, I can't help but notice how everyone's eyes are darting between their own carts and the glacially moving queue ahead. The summer heat isn't helping, making the air conditioning feel more like a distant dream than reality. It's fascinating how we've all become amateur mathematicians, silently calculating which line might move faster, though we're all stuck in this shared predicament. I briefly entertain a wild fantasy of initiating a customer rebellion – imagine if we all just started ripping open packages of cookies and chocolate bars, defiantly munching away while waiting. The thought makes me smile, but I know it's just that – a thought. Looking around at the weary faces, I can see we're all too drained, too conditioned to proper behavior to even consider such rebellion. Instead, we stand here, united only in our desire to pay and escape, a temporary community formed by fluorescent lights and checkout beepers. We're all thinking the same thoughts, dreaming the same small rebellions, yet remaining perfectly still in our orderly lines.
paragraph2: Here, on another summer evening, I was stuck in a line so long that it stretched all the way to the cookie shelves, out of sight of the checkout. People did not speak to one another but peered ahead to assess how quickly the line was moving. It was very hot. A question came to me, one I often ask myself, the only one worth askingWhy don’t we revolt? Why not avenge ourselves for the wait imposed on us by the superstore, which reduces its costs by cutting back on staff, and, all together, decide to dig into the cookies and the chocolate bars, treat ourselves to free samples as a way of killing time? We are condemned like rats trapped among shelves upon shelves of food, but more docile than rats, for we do not dare to nibble. To how many people did this thought occur? No way to know. Had I taken the lead, no one would have followed me. We were all too tired, and soon we’d finally be outside, out of the snare, forgetful, almost happy. We are a community of desires, not of action.

paragraph1: What does it mean to turn into a rabbit? It means losing all strength. It means that one is no stronger than the other anymore. On they danced to the strains of the piano and violin. Tereza leaned her head on Tomas's shoulder. Just as she had when they flew together in the airplane through the storm clouds. She was experiencing the same odd happiness and odd sadness as then. The sadness meantwe are at the last station. The happiness meantwe are together. The sadness was form, the happiness content. Happiness filled the space of sadness. They went back to their table. She danced twice more with the collective farm chairman and once with the young man who was so drunk he fell with her on the dance floor. Then they all went upstairs and to their two separate rooms. Tomas turned the key and switched on the ceiling light. Tereza saw two beds pushed together, one of them flanked by a bedside table and lamp. Up out of the lampshade, startled by the overhead light, flew a large nocturnal butterfly that began circling the room. The strains of the piano and violin rose up weakly from below.
paragraph2: The peculiar question of whether one could turn into a rabbit lingered in the air as Tereza and Tomas swayed together on the dance floor, their movements synchronized in perfect harmony. She rested her head on his shoulder, the familiar gesture reminiscent of their shared flight, where the same intimate position had brought them closer. In this moment, Tereza experienced a complex blend of emotions - the warmth of their connection intertwined with a bittersweet awareness of life's transient nature. As the evening progressed, they returned to their table, and Tereza ventured to dance with other partners, resulting in a series of awkward yet amusing encounters that lightened the atmosphere. The night eventually drew to a close, and they made their way to their separate rooms, carrying the evening's memories with them. In Tomas's room, the simple act of switching on the light awakened a large butterfly, which began its graceful circular dance around the space, its wings casting delicate shadows on the walls while the muffled music from the festivities below provided a gentle soundtrack to this unexpected nocturnal performance.

paragraph1: In the spring semester of his second year, for three weeks, Subhash boarded a research vessel with a group of students and professors. As the ship pulled away, the water cleaved a foaming trail that vanished even as it was being formed. The shoreline receded, resting calmly like a thin brown snake upon the water. He saw the earth’s mass shrinking, turning faint.Under the sun’s glare, as the ship picked up speed, he felt the wind’s motion on his face, the wild turbulence of the atmosphere. He watched the life that circled the ship, gannets with creamy heads and black-and-white wings, dolphins that leaped in pairs. Humpback whales spouted mists as they breathed, playfully breaching in the water, sometimes swimming beneath the ship without disturbing it, emerging on the other side.Sailing even slightly east reminded Subhash of how far away he was from his family. He thought of the time it took to cross even a tiny portion of the earth’s surface.
paragraph2: Aboard a research vessel during the spring semester of his second year, Subhash found himself surrounded by students and professors as they ventured into the open waters. The ship carved through the waves, leaving a trail of white foam in its wake as the familiar shoreline gradually disappeared from view. He watched in quiet contemplation as gannets swooped and dove into the water, their precise movements a testament to nature's efficiency. Schools of dolphins occasionally emerged, their sleek bodies breaking the surface in playful arcs, while majestic humpback whales breached in the distance, their massive forms creating spectacular splashes against the horizon. As the vessel pressed forward, Subhash felt the weight of the physical distance separating him from his family, and the vastness of the ocean served as a powerful reminder of the earth's immense scale. The rhythmic motion of the ship and the endless expanse of water made him acutely aware of how time and space intertwined in the journey across such enormous distances.

paragraph1: My relationship with Tony was complex, initially driven by my desire to showcase my speed-reading abilities, which I thought would impress him. I could breeze through pages of text in record time, but Tony's disappointment was palpable when he discovered my superficial grasp of the content. His response was to implement a rigorous study regime, focusing particularly on Churchill's account of the Glorious Revolution. At first, I found his insistence on rereading passages and his detailed questioning incredibly frustrating. I yearned for a different kind of connection with Tony, one that wasn't centered around academic improvement. Yet, as our sessions progressed, something unexpected happened. The historical narrative began to come alive in ways I hadn't experienced before. Each reread revealed new layers of understanding, and I found myself genuinely engaging with England's rich history. My initial resistance gradually transformed into a sense of accomplishment as I mastered the material. Tony's persistence had unlocked a deeper appreciation for thorough reading and comprehension, though I hadn't anticipated this educational journey when I first sought his attention. Looking back, while our relationship wasn't what I initially hoped for, it evolved into something arguably more valuable - a transformative learning experience that changed how I approach both reading and understanding.
paragraph2: I often did my reading alone after lunch while Tony took his nap. Initially, I impressed him with my speed-reading. Two hundred pages in a couple of hours! Then I disappointed him. I couldn’t answer his questions clearly—I wasn’t retaining information. He made me go back through Churchill’s version of the Glorious Revolution, tested me, groaned theatrically—“You bloody sieve!”—made me read again, asked more questions. These oral exams happened during walks in the woods and over glasses of wine after the suppers he cooked. At first I resented his persistence. I wanted us to be lovers, not teacher and pupil. I was annoyed with him as well as with myself when I didn’t know the answers. And then, a few querulous sessions later, I began to feel some pride, and not simply in my improved performance. I started to take note of the story itself. Hadn’t England at the end of the seventeenth century been the freest and most inquisitive society the world had ever known? Hadn’t the English Enlightenment been of more consequence than the French? Wasn’t it right that England should have struggled against the Catholic despotisms on the Continent? And surely we were now the inheritors of that freedom.

paragraph1: And while chutney - the same chutney which, back in 1957, my ayah Mary Pereira had made so perfectly; the grasshopper-green chutney which is forever associated with those days - carried them back into the world of my past, while chutney mellowed them and made them receptive, I spoke to them, gently, persuasively, and by a mixture of condiment and oratory kept myself out of the hands of the pernicious green-medicine men. I said"My son will understand. As much as for any living being, I'm telling my story for him, so that afterwards, when I've lost my struggle against cracks, he will know. Morality, judgment, character ... it all starts with memory ... and I am keeping carbons." Green chutney on chilli-pakoras, disappearing down someone's gullet; grasshopper-green on tepid chapatis, vanishing behind Padma's lips. I see them begin to weaken, and press on. 'I told you the truth,' I say yet again, "Memory's truth, because memory has its own special kind. It selects, eliminates, alters, exaggerates, minimizes, glorifies, and vilifies also; but in the end it creates its own reality, its heterogeneous but usually coherent version of events; and no sane human being ever trusts someone else's version more than his own."
paragraph2: Memory flows through me like Mary Pereira's green chutney, that extraordinary concoction from 1957 which still lingers on my tongue and in my mind's deepest recesses. I find myself wielding these preserved moments like weapons against the green-medicine men, who hover at the edges of my consciousness, threatening to strip away the very essence of who I am. When I share these stories with Padma, I watch her eyes grow wide with wonder, and I know the power of my memories has captured her completely, just as that chutney once captured my childhood senses. But it's not just for her that I unravel these threads of the past; my son must know these truths, must understand the tapestry of events that shaped his father's life. Yet even as I recount these tales, I'm acutely aware of how memory bends and shifts, how it selects certain moments while discarding others, creating its own version of reality that might not perfectly align with what others remember. Perhaps that's the beauty of it all – the way our minds craft these personal truths, these intimate histories that become as real and tangible as Mary's chutney, preserved in the jar of time.

paragraph1: I received her letter yesterday, and something about her words rings hollow, especially when she describes her supposedly idyllic life with the French count. While she writes enthusiastically about happiness and companionship, I can't shake the feeling that there's more beneath the surface, a truth she's either unwilling or unable to confront. Her carefully constructed sentences seem to mask a deeper struggle, one that resonates with my own journey. We are both, in our own ways, searching for something that was lost when our parents left us - perhaps not just their physical presence, but the sense of belonging they took with them. As I read between the lines of her elegant script, I recognize the familiar dance of avoiding hard truths, the same one I've performed countless times. Her pursuit of this life in France feels less like a choice and more like another step in our shared destiny, a path we're both walking in different directions but with the same underlying purpose. The futility of our respective quests hangs heavy in my mind, yet we persist, bound by the hope of finding resolution in places and people that may never truly provide it.
paragraph2: There is something about these sections of her letter - and those last lines in particular - that never quit ring true.Some subtle note that runs throughout the letter - indeed, her very act of writing to me at that moment - feels at odds with her report of days filled with 'happiness and companionship'. Was her life with her French count really what she set off to find that day she stepped out on to the jetty in Shanghai? I somehow doubt it. My feeling is that she is thinking of herself as much as of me when she talks of a sense of mission, and the futility of attempting to evade it. Perhaps there are those who are able to go about their lives unfettered by such concerns. But for those like us, our fate is to face the world as orphans, chasing through long years the shadows of vanished parents. There is nothing for it but to try and see through our missions to the end, as best we can, for until we do so, we will be permitted no calm.

paragraph1: Why in fact should one tell the truth? What obliges us to do it? And why do we consider telling the truth to be a virtue? Imagine that you meet a madman, who claims that he is a fish and that we are all fish. Are you going to argue with him? Are you going to undress in front of him and show him that you don't have fins? Are you going to say to his face what you think?...If you told him the whole truth and nothing but the truth, only what you thought, you would enter into a serious conversation with a madman and you yourself would become mad. And it is the same way with the world that surrounds us. If I obstinately told the truth to its face, it would mean that I was taking it seriously. And to take seriously something so unserious means to lose all one's own seriousness. I have to lie, if I don't want to take madmen seriously and become a madman myself.
paragraph2: Truth-telling, while generally considered virtuous, presents complex moral challenges that warrant careful examination. In contemplating this ethical dilemma, I find myself considering a peculiar scenario involving a madman who steadfastly believes all people are fish. This situation raises profound questions about our obligation to truth and the practical implications of absolute honesty. When confronted with such delusional thinking, attempting to engage in rational discourse might prove not only futile but potentially harmful to one's own psychological well-being. The act of earnestly trying to reason with someone who holds fundamentally irrational beliefs could gradually erode our own grip on reality and compromise our capacity for serious, meaningful discourse. In this light, the occasional lie or omission of truth emerges not as a moral failing, but as a practical necessity for maintaining our own mental equilibrium. By choosing when to engage and when to deflect, we protect ourselves from becoming entangled in endless cycles of absurd argumentation, ultimately preserving our ability to engage meaningfully with reality.

paragraph1: The wife from Yamagata sat motionless before the television for five straight days, her eyes fixed on the endless stream of disaster coverage from Kobe, though she had no known connections to the area. Her body remained rigid, creating an invisible barrier between herself and her husband, Komura, who watched helplessly as she refused food, conversation, or any form of acknowledgment. The television's glow cast shifting shadows across her face, which had become as expressionless as a stone mask, while news anchors detailed the mounting casualties and destruction. Komura's attempts to penetrate this wall of silence proved futile; his words seemed to dissolve into the air between them, never reaching their intended destination. He found himself adapting to a strange new routine, preparing his own meals and moving through their shared space like a ghost, careful not to disturb the eerie tableau his wife had become. The air in their apartment grew heavy with unspoken words and mounting tension, until finally, on the sixth day, the spell broke in an unexpected way. Komura returned home to find the television still humming but his wife gone, leaving behind only the lingering echo of her five-day vigil and the unanswered question of what had drawn her so completely into that distant tragedy.
paragraph2: Five straight days she spent in front of the television, staring at crumbled banks and hospitals, whole blocks of stores in flames, severed rail lines and expressways. She never said a word. Sunk deep in the cushions of the sofa, her mouth clamped shut, she wouldn’t answer when Komura spoke to her. She wouldn’t shake her head or nod. Komura could not be sure that the sound of his voice was even getting through to her.Komura’s wife came from way up north in Yamagata, and, as far as he knew, she had no friends or relatives who could have been hurt in Kobe. Yet she stayed planted in front of the television from morning to night. When he got up, Komura would make his own toast and coffee, and head off to work. When he came home in the evening, he’d fix himself a snack with whatever he found in the refrigerator and eat it by himself. She’d still be glaring at the late news when he dropped off to sleep. In his presence, at least, she ate nothing and drank nothing and never went to the toilet. A stone wall of silence surrounded her. Komura gave up trying to break through.And when he came home from work on Sunday, the sixth day, his wife had disappeared.

paragraph1: I am nothing but a corpse, a body at the bottom of a well. Though I drew my last breath long ago and my heart has stopped beating, no one, apart from that vile murderer, knows what’s happened to me. As for that wretch, he felt my pulse and listened for my breath to be sure I was dead, then kicked me in the midriff, carried me to the edge of the well, raised me up and dropped me below. As I fell, my head, which he’d smashed with a stone, broke apart; my face, my forehead and cheeks, were crushed; my bones shattered, and my mouth filled with blood.For nearly four days I have been missingmy wife and children must be searching for me; my daughter, spent from crying, must be staring fretfully at the courtyard gate. Yes, I know they’re all at the window, hoping for my return.But, are they truly waiting? I can’t even be sure of that. Maybe they’ve gotten used to my absence–how dismal! For here, on the other side, one gets the feeling that one’s former life persists. Before my birth there was infinite time, and after my death, inexhaustible time. I never thought of it beforeI’d been living luminously between two eternities of darkness.
paragraph2: As I lie here at the bottom of this dark well, my shattered skull and mangled face serve as permanent reminders of my violent end. That vile murderer was thorough in his work, meticulously checking my pulse and breath before hurling my lifeless body into this watery grave. Four days have passed since that fateful moment, yet time feels different here in death – simultaneously frozen and flowing endlessly. I can't help but wonder about my family, my beloved wife and daughter, and whether they're frantically searching for me or if they've begun to adapt to the hollow space I've left behind. Are they still sitting by the phone, desperately waiting for news of my whereabouts? Or has the rhythm of daily life already started to normalize my absence? It's a peculiar thing, contemplating how the world continues its relentless march forward while I remain static, decomposing in these murky depths. The thought that time existed long before me and will persist long after brings both comfort and despair. Here, in my waterlogged tomb, I'm caught between two worlds – the vibrant life I once knew and this eternal darkness that now embraces me, leaving me to forever ponder the ripples of my existence and their gradual fading into the vast ocean of time.

paragraph1: After three years of Newnham tennis, my throw would have been reasonably strong. But I wasn’t able to show it off. My arm was at the limit of its backswing when I felt his fingers curl around my wrist and tighten. He had the keys off me in seconds. He wasn’t rough, and I put up no struggle. He pushed around me and got into his car without speaking. He had said enough, and, besides, I had just confirmed the worst of his expectations. He tossed my bag onto the ground, slammed the door, and started the engine. Now that I had my voice back, what did I say? Again, I was pathetic. I didn’t want him to leave. I called stupidly through the car’s canvas top, “Tony, stop pretending that you don’t know the truth.”How ridiculous. Of course he wasn’t pretending. That was precisely his failure. He gunned the engine a couple of times, in case I wanted to say anything else that needed drowning out. Then he pulled forward—slowly at first, concerned perhaps that I would throw myself onto the car or under its wheels. But I just stood there like a tragic fool and watched him go. I saw his brake lights come on as he slowed to join the traffic. Then he was gone, and it was over.Two days later, I attended the interview and was accepted. Tony Canning delivered me to my career, but I never saw him again.
paragraph2: That day on the tennis court with Tony Canning remains etched in my memory, a bitter reminder of my inadequacies and shattered confidence. Though I had always prided myself on my tennis abilities, something entirely different was at play that afternoon - a power dynamic that left me feeling helpless and small. When Tony reached for my keys, I couldn't muster the strength to resist, watching passively as they slipped from my grasp into his waiting hand. The disappointment in his eyes was palpable, cutting through me like a knife, and when he threw my bag to the ground with such dismissive force, I felt my heart sink to the depths of my stomach. The gentle purr of his car's engine seemed to mock me as I stood there, desperately trying to make him understand, to acknowledge the truth that hung heavy between us. But he wouldn't - or couldn't - give me that closure. As his car disappeared into the distance, I was left standing there, feeling every bit the tragic fool I'd become in his eyes. The irony wasn't lost on me that just two days later, I would sit through an interview that would launch my career, but that small victory felt hollow without Tony's presence. He never returned to my life after that day, leaving me with nothing but questions and the lingering taste of regret that accompanies unfinished conversations and unresolved emotions.

paragraph1: I woke up this morning with the weight of a three-decade-old memory pressing heavily on my heart, as vivid as if it happened yesterday - the day my mother left us forever. The hospital corridor seems eternally etched in my mind, my feet carrying me faster than they'd ever moved before, only to find her already gone, her body still warm as I held her one last time in desperate farewell. My siblings and I were shattered, our world irreversibly altered by her absence, yet she had thought of us even in her final days, choosing words for her tombstone that promised she'd always be near in spirit. I remember begging the universe to keep her with us longer, despite watching her body fail and her strength fade with each passing day of her illness. Now, thirty years later, the raw anguish of those early days has mellowed into a different kind of sorrow, intertwined with profound gratitude for the privilege of being her child. The pain of losing her never truly disappears - it simply changes shape, becoming a familiar companion that reminds me of the depth of our connection. Sometimes I catch myself reaching for the phone to share news with her, forgetting momentarily that she's gone, yet feeling her presence in the gentle whispers of memory that continue to guide and comfort me through life's journey.
paragraph2: My mother died thirty years ago today. When I woke this morning I lay in bed thinking about that morning three decades ago, when I ran into her hospital room and found her dead. Too late to say goodbye, I clutched her body to mine and said it anyway. Goodbye, Mom. Goodbye, Mom. Goodbye.I am always with you, is what’s written on the tombstone my family and I laid on the spot of ground in the woods in northern Minnesota where we scattered her ashes. Before she died, she told me that’s what she wanted it to say because she wanted us—my brother, sister and me—to know it was true. Nothing distressed my mother more in her dying than the fact that she was leaving her children motherless. The only thing that gave her comfort was believing that she’d loved us hard enough that we’d feel her with us forever.“But I want you actually with me!” I remember protesting, weeping, begging. As if we could negotiate. As if lung cancer and I could make a deal.Thirty years gone and my mother is always with me. Thirty years gone and I still ache for her every day. Thirty years gone and my sorrow has sweetened into gratitude. How lucky I am to have been her daughter. To still be. To feel her shimmering in my bones with every step.

Your task is to determine which paragraph is overall better in terms of writing quality.

Paragraph 1:
I woke up this morning with the weight of a three-decade-old memory pressing heavily on my heart, as vivid as if it happened yesterday - the day my mother left us forever. The hospital corridor seems eternally etched in my mind, my feet carrying me faster than they'd ever moved before, only to find her already gone, her body still warm as I held her one last time in desperate farewell. My siblings and I were shattered, our world irreversibly altered by her absence, yet she had thought of us even in her final days, choosing words for her tombstone that promised she'd always be near in spirit. I remember begging the universe to keep her with us longer, despite watching her body fail and her strength fade with each passing day of her illness. Now, thirty years later, the raw anguish of those early days has mellowed into a different kind of sorrow, intertwined with profound gratitude for the privilege of being her child. The pain of losing her never truly disappears - it simply changes shape, becoming a familiar companion that reminds me of the depth of our connection. Sometimes I catch myself reaching for the phone to share news with her, forgetting momentarily that she's gone, yet feeling her presence in the gentle whispers of memory that continue to guide and comfort me through life's journey.

The only thing that gave her comfort was believing that she’d loved us hard enough that we’d feel her with us forever.“But I want you actually with me!” I remember protesting, weeping, begging. As if we could negotiate. As if lung cancer and I could make a deal.Thirty years gone and my mother is always with me. Thirty years gone and I still ache for her every day. paragraph1: I suppose I was ripe for political action. India was full of politics. But the independence movement didn't exist in the maharaja's state. It was illegal. And though we knew of the great names and the great doings outside we saw them at a distance. I was now at the university. The plan was that I should get a BA degree and then perhaps get a scholarship from the maharaja to do medicine or engineering. Then I was to marry the daughter of the principal of the maharaja's college. All of that was settled. I let it happen, but felt detached from it. I became idler and idler at the university. I didn't understand the BA course. I didn't understand The Mayor of Casterbridge. I couldn't understand the people or the story and didn't know what period the book was set in. Shakespeare was better, but I didn't know what to make of Shelley and Keats and Wordsworth. When I read those poets I wanted to say, "But this is just a pack of lies. No one feels like that." The professor made us copy down his notes. He dictated them, pages and pages, and what I mainly remember is that, because he was dictating notes and wanted them to be brief, and because he
paragraph2: Living in this corner of India, I find myself strangely removed from the political fervor that grips much of the nation. The independence movement, though forbidden in our maharaja's territory, echoes distantly like a song I can barely hear. My life's course has been meticulously charted - a BA degree, the promise of a scholarship, and an arranged marriage to the college principal's daughter - yet I feel no connection to any of it. The university halls, where I spend my days, seem like a foreign land where I wander aimlessly. I struggle to grasp the significance of Hardy's "The Mayor of Casterbridge," finding its Victorian drama utterly disconnected from my reality. The romantic verses of Shelley, Keats, and Wordsworth float past me like autumn leaves in the wind, their meaning always just beyond my reach. Our professor, with his monotonous dictation of endless notes, has become a symbol of everything that feels artificial in my education. His droning voice fills our classroom as we dutifully transcribe his words, but the knowledge remains superficial, never penetrating deeper than the ink on our pages. Sometimes I wonder if I'm merely playing a part in someone else's story, going through motions that hold no real meaning for me.

paragraph1: As usual, I notice a contrast between the nighttime customers, younger and more ethnically diverse, and those of daytime. Whole segments of the clientele are segregated from one another by the hours during which they do their shopping. Early morning is the time for retired couples, unhurried and well organized, with their own shopping bags and their checkbooks, from which they carefully detach a check at the cash register, remembering to record the amount on the stub.In the mid-afternoon, there are many women on their own—middle-aged, or young, with children—who shop with their own grocery carts made of wipe-clean fabric, a sign that they came on foot or by bus, because they don’t know how to drive or don’t own a car.At 5 P.M., the after-work crowd starts pouring in. The pace grows brisker, more jarring. Schoolchildren with mothers. High-school students. Between 8 and 10 P.M., university students and—more rare at other times of day—women in long dresses and head scarves, always accompanied by a man.
paragraph2: Working at the store gives me a fascinating glimpse into how our customer base changes throughout the day, like clockwork. Early mornings bring in retired couples, who take their time examining products and discussing their choices in detail, often spending up to an hour just to select the perfect produce. As we move into mid-afternoon, I notice a shift to middle-aged and young mothers pushing our easy-to-maneuver carts, many of whom arrive on foot since they don't drive. The atmosphere transforms dramatically at 5 P.M. when the after-work rush begins, filling our aisles with tired office workers while mothers shepherd their children through the store and teenagers browse the snack section. The evening hours, particularly between 8 and 10 P.M., bring yet another change as university students stock up on instant meals and energy drinks, sharing the space with women in elegant long dresses and headscarves who shop alongside their male companions.

The pace grows brisker, more jarring. Schoolchildren with mothers. High-school students. Between 8 and 10 P.M., university students and—more rare at other times of day—women in long dresses and head scarves, always accompanied by a man.

Paragraph 2:

paragraph1: Maybe I’ll try it myself sometime. On sleepless nights, that random, fanciful thought sometimes comes to me. I’ll filch the I.D. or the nametag of a woman I love, focus on it like a laser, pull her name inside me, and possess a part of her, all to myself. What would that feel like?No. That’ll never happen. I’ve never been deft with my hands, and would never be able to steal something that belonged to someone else. Even if that something had no physical form, and stealing it wasn’t against the law.Extreme love, extreme loneliness. Ever since then, whenever I listen to a Bruckner symphony I ponder that Shinagawa Monkey’s personal life. I picture the elderly monkey in that tiny hot-springs town, in an attic in a rundown inn, asleep on a thin futon. And I think of the snacks—the kakipi and the dried squid—that we enjoyed as we drank beer together, propped up against the wall.I haven’t seen the beautiful travel-magazine editor since then, so I have no idea what fate befell her name after that. I hope it didn’t cause her any real hardship. She was blameless, after all. Nothing was her fault. I do feel bad about it, but I still can’t bring myself to tell her about the Shinagawa Monkey.
paragraph2: During those restless nights when sleep eludes me, a strange thought occasionally creeps into my consciousness - the peculiar urge to steal a woman's identity, not in any criminal sense, but in a symbolic way, perhaps by taking her nametag or ID card. I quickly brush this notion aside, knowing full well I lack both the nerve and skill for such endeavors, yet the thought lingers like a persistent shadow. It reminds me of my extraordinary encounter with the Shinagawa Monkey, that enigmatic elderly primate who lived secretly in an attic in that sleepy hot-springs town. We shared an unusual connection, drinking beer and munching on snacks while he revealed his own compulsion for collecting names and identities. The memory of those surreal moments remains vivid - the warm amber glow of the attic light, the monkey's weathered face, and his surprisingly articulate confessions about his peculiar habit. Sometimes I wonder about that travel-magazine editor whose name might have been affected by the monkey's mysterious activities. I should probably reach out to her, check if she's doing alright, but something always holds me back, perhaps the fear of confronting the reality of that bizarre experience or maybe the possibility that she wouldn't believe my story about a name-stealing monkey in an attic.

paragraph1: Finding someone reliable to look after my father's house has become an increasingly difficult challenge, making me nostalgic for a time I never knew, when domestic service was commonplace in society. It's remarkable to think that not too long ago, a substantial portion of the population worked as servants, allowing homeowners the freedom to leave their properties for months at a time without a second thought about their maintenance or security. The complete disappearance of this servant class represents a profound social transformation, though its legacy lingers in subtle ways through our cultural habits and social attitudes. Now, when I drive through towns and villages, I see council estates stretching across the landscape, their uniform designs and practical but uninspiring architecture housing today's working class. These estates, while serving an essential purpose in providing affordable housing, lack the charm and character of older residential areas. Sometimes, I find myself wondering if the number of people residing in these modern council developments roughly equals the proportion who once worked in domestic service, as if society has simply reshuffled the same social dynamics into a different arrangement, though the personal connections between classes have largely dissolved.
paragraph2: But duty is duty, and one of my big worries was finding someone to look after the house for my father. There was a time when a substantial portion of the population was in domestic service. There was no problem then. A certain amount of coming and going, but no lasting problem. When you read books from before the war, you notice, if you have this particular worry on your mind, that people quite easily left their houses and went away visiting for days and weeks. Servants gave them that freedom.Now the servant class has vanished. No one knows what the servants have metamorphosed into. One thing we can be sure of is that we have not lost them, that they are still in varying ways with us, in culture and attitudes of dependence. In every town and large village, we now have ancillary council estates, clusters of subsidized dwellings meant originally for the poor. These clusters are recognizable even from the train. They have a deliberate socialist ugliness, a conscious suppression of those ideas of beauty and humanity that rise naturally from the heart. There can be no absolute match of one age with another, but I wouldn’t be surprised if the percentage of people at one time in domestic service isn’t matched now by the numbers on these council estates.

paragraph1: I find myself caught between two opposing forces within my soul: the tranquil acceptance of life's uncontrollable elements and the burning desire to wage a holy war against injustice. As I navigate through these conflicting emotions, I've come to understand that each person carries their own unique history, their personal version of truth, and their individual approaches to solving life's challenges. Sometimes, I'm unsure what others want to hear from me, whether they seek validation of their own beliefs or challenge my perspective. Perhaps the answer lies in standing firm with our truths, even though this stance might not satisfy everyone's expectations or desires. In moments of doubt, I find solace in the Prophet Muhammad's promise of the Day of Resurrection, when all voices will fall silent, and the weight of these earthly struggles will finally lift from our shoulders. The prospect of this ultimate peace brings me comfort as I grapple with these internal conflicts. If you'll excuse me now, I need some time to reflect on these matters.
paragraph2: We are split people. For myself, half of me wishes to sit quietly with my legs crossed, letting the things that are beyond my control wash over me. But the other half wants to fight the holy war. Jihad! And certainly we could argue this out in the street, but I think, in the end, your past is not my past and your truth is not my truth and your solution — it is not my solution. So I do not know what it is you would like me to say. Truth and firmness is one suggestion, though there are many other people you can ask if that answer does not satisfy. Personally, my hope lies in the last days. The prophet Muhammad — peace be upon Him! — tells us that on the Day of Resurrection everyone will be struck unconscious. Deaf and dumb. No chit-chat. Tongueless. And what a bloody relief that will be. Now, if you will excuse me.

You are given two pararaphs of creative writing for a given writing instruction.
Your task is to determine which paragraph is overall better in terms of writing quality.

Paragraph 1:
I find myself caught between two opposing forces within my soul: the tranquil acceptance of life's uncontrollable elements and the burning desire to wage a holy war against injustice. As I navigate through these conflicting emotions, I've come to understand that each person carries their own unique history, their personal version of truth, and their individual approaches to solving life's challenges. Sometimes, I'm unsure what others want to hear from me, whether they seek validation of their own beliefs or challenge my perspective. Perhaps the answer lies in standing firm with our truths, even though this stance might not satisfy everyone's expectations or desires. In moments of doubt, I find solace in the Prophet Muhammad's promise of the Day of Resurrection, when all voices will fall silent, and the weight of these earthly struggles will finally lift from our shoulders. The prospect of this ultimate peace brings me comfort as I grapple with these internal conflicts. If you'll excuse me now, I need some time to reflect on these matters.

Paragraph 2:
We are split people. For myself, half of me wishes to sit quietly with my legs crossed, letting the things that are beyond my control wash over me. But the other half wants to fight the holy war. Jihad! And certainly we could argue this out in the street, but I think, in the end, your past is not my past and your truth is not my truth and your solution — it is not my solution. So I do not know what it is you would like me to say. Truth and firmness is one suggestion, though there are many other people you can ask if that answer does not satisfy. Personally, my hope lies in the last days. The prophet Muhammad — peace be upon Him! — tells us that on the Day of Resurrection everyone will be struck unconscious. Deaf and dumb. No chit-chat. Tongueless. And what a bloody relief that will be. Now, if you will excuse me.

paragraph1: Verna's calculated pursuit of her fourth husband unfolds with meticulous precision as she weaves an elaborate tale about her name's origins, connecting it to a sensual ballet performance she never witnessed. Her target, a man she believes harbors kinky inclinations, seems to be falling for her carefully crafted persona. During their interaction, she deploys her signature move—a deliberately breathy intake of air—while conversing with Bob, a technique she's perfected over years of seduction. Bob Goreham responds with an endearing shyness that almost makes her falter, especially when recognition dawns upon her. The man before her is none other than the former high school celebrity, the local golden boy who once commanded attention wherever he went. A complex mixture of rage and dark humor bubbles within her as memories of his past glory days surface, yet she maintains her facade with practiced ease, never letting her true emotions betray the carefully constructed image she's presenting. The irony of their current encounter adds an unexpected layer to her seduction strategy, one she hadn't anticipated but finds darkly amusing.
paragraph2: During the preliminary stages of netting her fourth husband, whom she’d flagged as a kink addict, Verna had gone even further. She’d told him she’d been named for "The Rite of Spring," a highly sexual ballet that ended with torture and human sacrifice. He’d laughed, but he’d also wriggleda sure sign of the hook going in.Now she says, "And you’re . . . Bob." It’s taken her years to perfect the small breathy intake, a certified knee-melter. "Yes," Bob says. "Bob Goreham," he adds, with a diffidence he surely intends to be charming. Verna smiles widely to disguise her shock. She finds herself flushing with a combination of rage and an almost reckless mirth. She looks him full in the faceyes, underneath the thinning hair and the wrinkles and the obviously whitened and possibly implanted teeth, it’s the same Bob—the Bob of fifty-odd years before. Mr. Heartthrob, Mr. Senior Football Star, Mr. Astounding Catch, from the rich, Cadillac-driving end of town where the mining-company big shots lived. Mr. Shit, with his looming bully’s posture and his lopsided joker’s smile.

paragraph1: Truth-telling, while generally considered virtuous, presents complex moral challenges that warrant careful examination. In contemplating this ethical dilemma, I find myself considering a peculiar scenario involving a madman who steadfastly believes all people are fish. This situation raises profound questions about our obligation to truth and the practical implications of absolute honesty. When confronted with such delusional thinking, attempting to engage in rational discourse might prove not only futile but potentially harmful to one's own psychological well-being. The act of earnestly trying to reason with someone who holds fundamentally irrational beliefs could gradually erode our own grip on reality and compromise our capacity for serious, meaningful discourse. In this light, the occasional lie or omission of truth emerges not as a moral failing, but as a practical necessity for maintaining our own mental equilibrium. By choosing when to engage and when to deflect, we protect ourselves from becoming entangled in endless cycles of absurd argumentation, ultimately preserving our ability to engage meaningfully with reality.
paragraph2: Why in fact should one tell the truth? What obliges us to do it? And why do we consider telling the truth to be a virtue? Imagine that you meet a madman, who claims that he is a fish and that we are all fish. Are you going to argue with him? Are you going to undress in front of him and show him that you don't have fins? Are you going to say to his face what you think?...If you told him the whole truth and nothing but the truth, only what you thought, you would enter into a serious conversation with a madman and you yourself would become mad. And it is the same way with the world that surrounds us. If I obstinately told the truth to its face, it would mean that I was taking it seriously. And to take seriously something so unserious means to lose all one's own seriousness. I have to lie, if I don't want to take madmen seriously and become a madman myself.
text_input:
You are given two pararaphs of creative writing for a given writing instruction.
Your task is to determine which paragraph is overall better in terms of writing quality.

Paragraph 1:
Truth-telling, while generally considered virtuous, presents complex moral challenges that warrant careful examination. In contemplating this ethical dilemma, I find myself considering a peculiar scenario involving a madman who steadfastly believes all people are fish. This situation raises profound questions about our obligation to truth and the practical implications of absolute honesty. When confronted with such delusional thinking, attempting to engage in rational discourse might prove not only futile but potentially harmful to one's own psychological well-being. The act of earnestly trying to reason with someone who holds fundamentally irrational beliefs could gradually erode our own grip on reality and compromise our capacity for serious, meaningful discourse. In this light, the occasional lie or omission of truth emerges not as a moral failing, but as a practical necessity for maintaining our own mental equilibrium. By choosing when to engage and when to deflect, we protect ourselves from becoming entangled in endless cycles of absurd argumentation, ultimately preserving our ability to engage meaningfully with reality.

Paragraph 2:
Why in fact should one tell the truth? What obliges us to do it? And why do we consider telling the truth to be a virtue? Imagine that you meet a madman, who claims that he is a fish and that we are all fish. Are you going to argue with him? Are you going to undress in front of him and show him that you don't have fins? Are you going to say to his face what you think?...If you told him the whole truth and nothing but the truth, only what you thought, you would enter into a serious conversation with a madman and you yourself would become mad. And it is the same way with the world that surrounds us. If I obstinately told the truth to its face, it would mean that I was taking it seriously. And to take seriously something so unserious means to lose all one's own seriousness. I have to lie, if I don't want to take madmen seriously and become a madman myself.

paragraph1: I lie here on my makeshift bed, staring up at the gymnasium's high ceiling, surrounded by the whispers of its past. The varnished wooden floor beneath me still bears the faded lines of countless games, while abandoned basketball hoops hang like silent sentinels above. The wrap-around balcony, now empty, once held generations of spectators, and I can almost catch the mingled scents of their presence – stale sweat, sweet gum, and perfume lingering in the air. My mind wanders through time, picturing the women who sat there: some in modest felt skirts, others in daring minis, and later in fashionable pants, their hairstyles evolving with each passing decade. When darkness falls, the space transforms in my imagination into a vibrant dance hall, where tissue-paper flowers and cardboard devils once adorned the walls, and a glittering mirror ball scattered light across young couples swaying to layers of music that seem to echo still.
paragraph2: We slept in what had once been the gymnasium. The floor was of varnished wood, with stripes and circles painted on it, for the games that were formerly played there; the hoops for the basketball nets were still in place, though the nets were gone. A balcony ran around the room, for the spectators, and I thought I could smell, faintly like an afterimage, the pungent scent of sweat, shot through with the sweet taint of chewing gum and perfume from the watching girls, felt-skirted as I knew from pictures, later in miniskirts, then pants, then in one earring, spiky green-streaked hair. Dances would have been held there; the music lingered, a palimpsest of un-heard sound, style upon style, an undercurrent of drums, a forlorn wail, garlands made of tissue-paper flowers, cardboard devils, a revolving ball of mirrors, powdering the dancers with a snow of light.

When darkness falls, the space transforms in my imagination into a vibrant dance hall, where tissue-paper flowers and cardboard devils once adorned the walls, and a glittering mirror ball scattered light across young couples swaying to layers of music that seem to echo still.
